'一心一意。但你必须确保自己具有价值，并且必须保持自己的独立性。很少有男人能做到这一点。要么你完全退出服务，变得一无是处，要么你戴上安全带，在你的同僚们的拉扯下赚到很多钱。但一定要看看这些精致的直翅目昆虫！”

Lydgate had after all to give some scrutiny to each drawer, the Vicar laughing at himself, and yet persisting in the exhibition.
毕竟，利德盖特必须仔细检查每个抽屉，牧师嘲笑自己，但仍坚持展览。

‘Apropos of what you said about wearing harness,’ Lydgate began, after they had sat down, ‘I made up my mind some time ago to do with as little of it as-possible. That was why I determined not to try anything in London, for a good many years at least. I didn’t like what I saw when I was studying there—so much empty bigwiggism, and obstructive trickery. In the country, people have less pretension to knowledge, and are less of companions, but for that reason they affect one’s amour-propre less: one makes less bad blood, and can follow one’s own course more quietly.’
“关于你所说的关于佩戴安全带的事情，”他们坐下后，利德盖特开始说道，“我不久前就决定尽可能少戴安全带。这就是为什么我决定不在伦敦尝试任何事情，至少在很多年里。我不喜欢在那里学习时所看到的一切——那么多空洞的自大主义和阻碍性的诡计。在乡下，人们不那么自命不凡，也不那么有朋友，但因此他们对自尊心的影响也较小：一个人不会产生太多的仇恨，可以更安静地走自己的路。

‘Yes—well—you have got a good start; you are in the right profession, the work you feel yourself most fit for. Some people miss that, and repent too late. But you must not be too sure of keeping your independence.’
“是的——嗯——你已经有了一个好的开始；您从事的是正确的职业，您认为自己最适合的工作。有些人错过了这一点，后悔得太晚了。但你不能太确定要保持自己的独立性。”

‘You mean of family ties?’ said Lydgate, conceiving that these might press rather tightly on Mr. Farebrother.
“你是说家庭关系吗？”利德盖特说道，他认为这些可能会对费尔布拉泽先生造成相当大的压力。

‘Not altogether. Of course they make many things more difficult. But a good wife—a good unworldly woman—may really help a man, and keep him more independent. There’s a parishioner of mine— a fine fellow, but who would hardly have pulled through as he has done without his wife. Do you know the Garths? I think they were not Peacock’s patients.’
'不完全是这样。当然，它们使许多事情变得更加困难。但一个好妻子——一个优秀的、不谙世事的女人——可能真的可以帮助一个男人，让他更加独立。我有一个教区居民，他是个好人，但如果没有他的妻子，他很难渡过难关。你知道加斯人吗？我认为他们不是孔雀的病人。

‘No; but there is a Miss Garth at old Featherstone’s, at Lowick.’
'不;但洛威克的老费瑟斯通家有一位加斯小姐。

‘Their daughter: an excellent girl.’
“他们的女儿：一个优秀的女孩。”

‘She is very quiet—I have hardly noticed her.’
“她很安静——我几乎没有注意到她。”

‘She has taken notice of you, though, depend upon it.’
“不过，她已经注意到你了，这就是事实。”

‘I don’t understand,’ said Lydgate; he could hardly say ‘Of course.’
“我不明白，”利德盖特说。他很难说“当然”。

‘Oh, she gauges everybody. I prepared her for confirmation— she is a favorite of mine.’
“哦，她衡量每个人。我为她的确认做好了准备——她是我的最爱。

Mr. Farebrother puffed a few moments in silence, Lydgate not caring to know more about the Garths. At last the Vicar laid down his pipe, stretched out his legs, and turned his bright eyes with a smile towards Lydgate, saying—
费勒布拉泽先生沉默了一会儿，利德盖特并不想了解更多关于加思夫妇的事情。最后，牧师放下烟斗，伸出双腿，用明亮的眼睛微笑着转向利德盖特，说道——

‘But we Middlemarchers are not so tame as you take us to be. We have our intrigues and our parties. I am a party man, for example, and Bulstrode is another. If you vote for me you will offend Bulstrode.’
“但是我们米德尔马彻并不像你想象的那么温顺。我们有我们的阴谋和我们的派对。例如，我是一个党派人士，而布尔斯特罗德则是另一个。如果你投票给我，你就会冒犯布尔斯特罗德。”

‘What is there against Bulstrode?’ said Lydgate, emphatically.
“布尔斯特罗德有什么可反对的？”利德盖特强调道。

‘I did not say there was anything against him except that. If you vote against him you will make him your enemy.’
“除此之外，我并没有说有什么不利于他的事情。如果你投票反对他，你就会让他成为你的敌人。

‘I don’t know that I need mind about that,’ said Lydgate, rather proudly; ‘but he seems to have good ideas about hospitals, and he spends large sums on useful public objects. He might help me a good deal in carrying out my ideas. As to his religious notions— why, as Voltaire said, incantations will destroy a flock of sheep if administered with a certain quantity of arsenic. I look for the man who will bring the arsenic, and don’t mind about his incantations.’
“我不知道我需要关心这个，”利德盖特相当自豪地说。 “但他似乎对医院有很好的想法，而且他在有用的公共物品上花费了大量资金。他可能会帮助我实现我的想法。至于他的宗教观念——为什么正如伏尔泰所说，如果施以一定量的砒霜，咒语就会消灭一群羊。我寻找那个能带来砒霜的人，并且不介意他的咒语。

‘Very good. But then you must not offend your arsenic-man. You will not offend me, you know,’ said Mr. Farebrother, quite unaffectedly. ‘I don’t translate my own convenience into other people’s duties. I am opposed to Bulstrode in many ways. I don’t like the set he belongs to: they are a narrow ignorant set, and do more to make their neighbors uncomfortable than to make them better. Their system is a sort of worldly-spiritual cliqueism: they really look on the rest of mankind as a doomed carcass which is to nourish them for heaven. But,’ he added, smilingly, ‘I don’t say that Bulstrode’s new hospital is a bad thing; and as to his wanting to oust me from the old one—why, if he thinks me a mischievous fellow, he is only returning a compliment. And I am not a model clergyman— only a decent makeshift.’
'非常好。但你千万不能得罪你的砒霜人。你知道，你不会冒犯我的。”费尔布拉泽先生毫不掩饰地说道。 “我不会将自己的便利转化为他人的职责。我在很多方面反对布尔斯特罗德。我不喜欢他所属的群体：他们是一个狭隘无知的群体，他们所做的更多是让邻居感到不舒服，而不是让他们变得更好。他们的体系是一种世俗精神派系：他们实际上将其他人类视为注定要滋养他们进入天堂的尸体。但是，”他微笑着补充道，“我并不是说布尔斯特罗德的新医院是一件坏事;至于他想把我从老家伙那里赶走——为什么，如果他认为我是一个淘气的家伙，他只是在回敬一句恭维而已。我不是模范牧师——只是一个像样的临时工。

Lydgate was not at all sure that the Vicar maligned himself. A model clergyman, like a model doctor, ought to think his own profession the finest in the world, and take all knowledge as mere nourishment to his moral pathology and therapeutics. He only said, ‘What reason does Bulstrode give for superseding you?’
利德盖特完全不确定牧师是否诽谤自己。一个模范牧师，就像一个模范医生一样，应该认为自己的职业是世界上最好的，并把所有的知识都视为他的道德病理学和治疗学的营养品。他只说：“布尔斯特罗德有何理由取代你？”

‘That I don’t teach his opinions—which he calls spiritual religion; and that I have no time to spare. Both statements are true. But then I could make time, and I should be glad of the forty pounds. That is the plain fact of the case. But let us dismiss it. I only wanted to tell you that if you vote for your arsenic-man, you are not to cut me in consequence. I can’t spare you. You are a sort of circumnavigator come to settle among us, and will keep up my belief in the antipodes. Now tell me all about them in Paris.’
“我不教导他的观点——他称之为精神宗教；而且我没有空闲时间。两种说法都是正确的。不过这样我就可以腾出时间了，我应该为这四十英镑而高兴。这就是案件的明显事实。但让我们忽略它。我只是想告诉你，如果你投票给你的砒霜人，你就不会因此而砍掉我。我不能放过你。你就像一位环球航行者来到我们中间定居，并将保持我对相反地的信念。现在告诉我关于他们在巴黎的一切。”

CHAPTER XVIII
第十八章

‘Oh, sir, the loftiest hopes on earth
“哦，先生，地球上最崇高的希望

Draw lots with meaner hopes: heroic breasts,
带着更卑微的希望抽签：英雄的乳房，

Breathing bad air, ran risk of pestilence;
呼吸不良空气，有感染瘟疫的危险；

Or, lacking lime-juice when they cross the Line,
或者，当他们越界时缺少酸橙汁，

May languish with the scurvy.’
可能会因坏血病而衰弱。

Some weeks passed after this conversation before the question of the chaplaincy gathered any practical import for Lydgate, and without telling himself the reason, he deferred the predetermination on which side he should give his vote. It would really have been a matter of total indifference to him—that is to say, he would have taken the more convenient side, and given his vote for the appointment of Tyke without any hesitation—if he had not cared personally for Mr. Farebrother.
这次谈话过去了几个星期，牧师职位问题才对利德盖特产生了任何实际意义，在没有告诉自己原因的情况下，他推迟了他应该投票给哪一边的预先决定。这对他来说确实是完全漠不关心的问题——也就是说，如果他个人不关心费雷布拉泽先生，他会站在更方便的一边，毫不犹豫地投票支持泰克的任命。 。

But his liking for the Vicar of St. Botolph’s grew with growing acquaintanceship. That, entering into Lydgate’s position as a new-comer who had his own professional objects to secure, Mr. Farebrother should have taken pains rather to warn off than to obtain his interest, showed an unusual delicacy and generosity, which Lydgate’s nature was keenly alive to. It went along with other points of conduct in Mr. Fare brother which were exceptionally fine, and made his character resemble those southern landscapes which seem divided between natural grandeur and social slovenliness. Very few men could have been as filial and chivalrous as he was to the mother, aunt, and sister, whose dependence on him had in many ways shaped his life rather uneasily for himself; few men who feel the pressure of small needs are so nobly resolute not to dress up their inevitably self-interested desires in a pretext of better motives. In these matters he was conscious that his life would bear the closest scrutiny; and perhaps the consciousness encouraged a little defiance towards the critical strictness of persons whose celestial intimacies seemed not to improve their domestic manners, and whose lofty aims were not needed to account for their actions. Then, his preaching was ingenious and pithy, like the preaching of the English Church in its robust age, and his sermons were delivered without book. People outside his parish went to hear him; and, since to fill the church was always the most difficult part of a clergyman’s function, here was another ground for a careless sense of superiority. Besides, he was a likable man: sweet-tempered, ready-witted, frank, without grins of suppressed bitterness or other conversational flavors which make half of us an affliction to our friends. Lydgate liked him heartily, and wished for his friendship.
但随着熟识的加深，他对圣博托尔夫牧师的好感也与日俱增。法尔布拉泽先生作为一个新来者，有自己的职业目标要确保，进入利德盖特的位置，应该煞费苦心地警告他，而不是引起他的兴趣，这表现出了一种不同寻常的微妙和慷慨，而利德盖特的本性非常活跃。到。这与法尔兄弟的其他品行相得益彰，使他的性格就像那些南方风景，似乎既有自然的宏伟，又有社会的邋遢。很少有人能像他对母亲、姑姑和妹妹那样孝顺和侠义，他们对他的依赖在很多方面使他的生活变得相当不安。很少有男人在感受到小需求的压力时，会如此高尚地坚决不以更好的动机为借口来粉饰自己不可避免的自利欲望。在这些事情上，他意识到他的生活将受到最严格的审视。也许这种意识鼓励了对那些与天上的亲密关系似乎并不能改善他们的家庭礼仪的人的严格严格性的一点蔑视，并且他们的崇高目标不需要解释他们的行为。然后，他的讲道巧妙而精练，就像英国教会在强盛时期的讲道一样，而且他的讲道是在没有书籍的情况下进行的。教区外的人们都去听他的演讲。而且，由于在教堂里任职始终是牧师职责中最困难的部分，因此这是粗心的优越感的另一个理由。此外，他是一个讨人喜欢的人：脾气温和、机智、坦率，笑容中没有压抑的苦涩或其他使我们一半人对我们的朋友感到痛苦的谈话味道。 利德盖特衷心喜欢他，并希望与他建立友谊。

With this feeling uppermost, he continued to waive the question of the chaplaincy, and to persuade himself that it was not only no proper business of his, but likely enough never to vex him with a demand for his vote. Lydgate, at Mr. Bulstrode’s request, was laying down plans for the internal arrangements of the new hospital, and the two were often in consultation. The banker was always presupposing that he could count in general on Lydgate as a coadjutor, but made no special recurrence to the coming decision between Tyke and Farebrother. When the General Board of the Infirmary had met, however, and Lydgate had notice that the question of the chaplaincy was thrown on a council of the directors and medical men, to meet on the following Friday, he had a vexed sense that he must make up his mind on this trivial Middlemarch business. He could not help hearing within him the distinct declaration that Bulstrode was prime minister, and that the Tyke affair was a question of office or no office; and he could not help an equally pronounced dislike to giving up the prospect of office. For his observation was constantly confirming Mr. Farebrother’s assurance that the banker would not overlook opposition. ‘Confound their petty politics!’ was one of his thoughts for three mornings in the meditative process of shaving, when he had begun to feel that he must really hold a court of conscience on this matter. Certainly there were valid things to be said against the election of Mr. Farebrother: he had too much on his hands already, especially considering how much time he spent on non-clerical occupations. Then again it was a continually repeated shock, disturbing Lydgate’s esteem, that the Vicar should obviously play for the sake of money, liking the play indeed, but evidently liking some end which it served. Mr. Farebrother contended on theory for the desirability of all games, and said that Englishmen’s wit was stagnant for want of them; but Lydgate felt certain that he would have played very much less but for the money. There was a billiard-room at the Green Dragon, which some anxious mothers and wives regarded as the chief temptation in Middlemarch. The Vicar was a first-rate billiard-player, and though he did not frequent the Green Dragon, there were reports that he had sometimes been there in the daytime and had won money. And as to the chaplaincy, he did not pretend that he cared for it, except for the sake of the forty pounds. Lydgate was no Puritan, but he did not care for play, and winning money at it had always seemed a meanness to him; besides, he had an ideal of life which made this subservience of conduct to the gaining of small sums thoroughly hateful to him. Hitherto in his own life his wants had been supplied without any trouble to himself, and his first impulse was always to be liberal with half-crowns as matters of no importance to a gentleman; it had never occurred to him to devise a plan for getting half-crowns. He had always known in a general way that he was not rich, but he had never felt poor, and he had no power of imagining the part which the want of money plays in determining the actions of men. Money had never been a motive to him. Hence he was not ready to frame excuses for this deliberate pursuit of small gains. It was altogether repulsive to him, and he never entered into any calculation of the ratio between the Vicar’s income and his more or less necessary expenditure. It was possible that he would not have made such a calculation in his own case.
带着这种感觉，他继续放弃牧师职位的问题，并说服自己，这不仅不适合他，而且很可能永远不会因为要求他投票而烦恼他。利德盖特应布尔斯特罗德先生的要求，为新医院的内部安排制定计划，两人经常进行协商。这位银行家总是预设他总体上可以指望利德盖特作为副官，但并没有特别提及泰克和费雷布拉瑟之间即将做出的决定。然而，当医务室总委员会开会时，利德盖特注意到牧师职位的问题被抛给了一个由董事和医务人员组成的委员会，将于下周五举行会议，他有一种烦恼的感觉，他必须做出决定。他在米德尔马契的这件琐事上打起了主意。他不禁在心里清楚地听到布尔斯特罗德是首相，而泰克事件是一个任职或不任职的问题；他同样明显地不愿意放弃公职的前景。因为他的观察不断证实了费勒布拉泽先生的保证，即银行家不会忽视反对意见。 “打乱他们的小政治！”这是他在剃须的冥想过程中三个早晨的想法之一，当时他开始觉得他必须在这件事上真正进行良心法庭。当然，反对费雷布拉泽先生当选的说法是有道理的：他手上已经有太多事情要做，特别是考虑到他在非文书工作上花费了多少时间。 然而，这又是一次不断重复的震惊，扰乱了利德盖特的自尊，牧师显然应该为了钱而玩，确实喜欢这个游戏，但显然喜欢它所服务的某个目的。法尔布拉泽先生从理论上论证了所有游戏的可取性，并说英国人的智慧因缺乏游戏而停滞不前。但利德盖特确信，如果不是为了钱，他的比赛次数会少得多。绿龙酒店有一个台球室，一些焦虑的母亲和妻子认为这是米德尔马契的主要诱惑。牧师是一位一流的台球手，虽然他不经常光顾绿龙，但有报道称他有时白天也会去那儿并赢过钱。至于牧师的职位，他并没有假装自己很关心，除了四十英镑的缘故。利德盖特不是清教徒，但他不喜欢赌博，而且在他看来，通过赌博赢钱一直是一种卑鄙行为。此外，他的生活理想使他对这种为了获取小额金钱而屈从的行为感到十分厌恶。到目前为止，在他自己的生活中，他的需要已经得到了满足，对他自己来说没有任何麻烦，他的第一冲动总是慷慨地给予半克朗，因为这对绅士来说并不重要。他从来没有想过要制定一个获得半克朗的计划。他一直大体上知道自己并不富有，但他从未感到贫穷，而且他无法想象金钱的匮乏在决定人们的行为方面所扮演的角色。金钱从来都不是他的动机。因此，他不准备为这种刻意追求小利的行为找借口。 这对他来说是完全令人厌恶的，他从来没有计算过牧师的收入和他或多或少的必要支出之间的比率。以他自己的情况，恐怕不会做出这样的算计。

And now, when the question of voting had come, this repulsive fact told more strongly against Mr. Farebrother than it had done before. One would know much better what to do if men’s characters were more consistent, and especially if one’s friends were invariably fit for any function they desired to undertake! Lydgate was convinced that if there had been no valid objection to Mr. Farebrother, he would have voted for him, whatever Bulstrode might have felt on the subject: he did not intend to be a vassal of Bulstrode’s. On the other hand, there was Tyke, a man entirely given to his clerical office, who was simply curate at a chapel of ease in St. Peter’s parish, and had time for extra duty. Nobody had anything to say against Mr. Tyke, except that they could not bear him, and suspected him of cant. Really, from his point of view, Bulstrode was thoroughly justified.
现在，当投票问题到来时，这个令人厌恶的事实比以前更加强烈地反对费尔布拉泽先生。如果男人的性格更加一致，特别是如果一个人的朋友总是适合他们想要承担的任何职责，那么人们就会更好地知道该怎么做！利德盖特确信，如果没有对费勒布拉泽先生提出有效的反对意见，他就会投票给他，无论布尔斯特罗德在这个问题上有什么感受：他无意成为布尔斯特罗德的附庸。另一方面，泰克是一个完全专注于文书工作的人，他只是在圣彼得教区的一个舒适的教堂里担任牧师，并且有时间做额外的工作。没有人对泰克先生有什么意见，只是他们无法忍受他，并怀疑他不诚实。确实，从布尔斯特罗德的角度来看，他是完全有道理的。

But whichever way Lydgate began to incline, there was something to make him wince; and being a proud man, he was a little exasperated at being obliged to wince. He did not like frustrating his own best purposes by getting on bad terms with Bulstrode; he did not like voting against Farebrother, and helping to deprive him of function and salary; and the question occurred whether the additional forty pounds might not leave the Vicar free from that ignoble care about winning at cards. Moreover, Lydgate did not like the consciousness that in voting for Tyke he should be voting on the side obviously convenient for himself. But would the end really be his own convenience? Other people would say so, and would allege that he was currying favor with Bulstrode for the sake of making himself important and getting on in the world. What then? He for his own part knew that if his personal prospects simply had been concerned, he would not have cared a rotten nut for the banker’s friendship or enmity. What he really cared for was a medium for his work, a vehicle for his ideas; and after all, was he not bound to prefer the object of getting a good hospital, where he could demonstrate the specific distinctions of fever and test therapeutic results, before anything else connected with this chaplaincy? For the first time Lydgate was feeling the hampering threadlike pressure of small social conditions, and their frustrating complexity. At the end of his inward debate, when he set out for the hospital, his hope was really in the chance that discussion might somehow give a new aspect to the question, and make the scale dip so as to exclude the necessity for voting. I think he trusted a little also to the energy which is begotten by circumstances—some feeling rushing warmly and making resolve easy, while debate in cool blood had only made it more difficult. However it was, he did not distinctly say to himself on which side he would vote; and all the while he was inwardly resenting the subjection which had been forced upon him. It would have seemed beforehand like a ridiculous piece of bad logic that he, with his unmixed resolutions of independence and his select purposes, would find himself at the very outset in the grasp of petty alternatives, each of which was repugnant to him. In his student’s chambers, he had prearranged his social action quite differently.
但无论利德盖特开始倾向于哪一边，总有一些东西让他皱起眉头。作为一个骄傲的人，他对被迫皱眉感到有点恼火。他不喜欢因为与布尔斯特罗德关系不睦而破坏自己的最佳目的。他不喜欢投票反对费雷布拉泽，并帮助剥夺他的职务和薪水；问题是，额外的四十英镑是否不会让牧师摆脱对打牌获胜的不光彩的关心。此外，利德盖特不喜欢这样的意识：在投票给泰克时，他应该投票给明显对自己有利的一方。但结局真的会是他自己的方便吗？其他人会这么说，并声称他是为了让自己变得重要并在世界上取得进步而讨好布尔斯特罗德。然后怎样呢？他自己也知道，如果只是关心他的个人前景，他根本不会关心银行家的友谊或敌意。他真正关心的是他的工作的媒介，他的想法的载体；毕竟，他不是一定会更喜欢去一家好的医院，在那里他可以展示发烧的具体区别并测试治疗结果，然后再做与牧师相关的任何事情吗？利德盖特第一次感受到了社会小环境带来的丝丝般的阻碍，以及它们令人沮丧的复杂性。在他内心的辩论结束后，当他动身去医院时，他真的希望讨论能够以某种方式给这个问题带来新的方面，并使规模下降，从而排除投票的必要性。 我认为他也有点相信环境所产生的能量——有些人感觉热情奔放，让决心变得容易，而冷静的辩论只会让事情变得更加困难。不管怎样，他并没有明确告诉自己他会投票支持哪一边；他内心一直对强加给他的服从感到怨恨。事先看来，这是一个可笑的、糟糕的逻辑：他怀着纯粹的独立决心和选定的目的，却发现自己一开始就陷入了微不足道的选择之中，而每一个选择都令他感到厌恶。在他的学生宿舍里，他预先安排的社交活动完全不同。

Lydgate was late in setting out, but Dr. Sprague, the two other surgeons, and several of the directors had arrived early; Mr. Bulstrode, treasurer and chairman, being among those who were still absent. The conversation seemed to imply that the issue was problematical, and that a majority for Tyke was not so certain as had been generally supposed. The two physicians, for a wonder, turned out to be unanimous, or rather, though of different minds, they concurred in action. Dr. Sprague, the rugged and weighty, was, as every one had foreseen, an adherent of Mr. Farebrother. The Doctor was more than suspected of having no religion, but somehow Middlemarch tolerated this deficiency in him as if he had been a Lord Chancellor; indeed it is probable that his professional weight was the more believed in, the world-old association of cleverness with the evil principle being still potent in the minds even of lady-patients who had the strictest ideas of frilling and sentiment. It was perhaps this negation in the Doctor which made his neighbors call him hard-headed and dry-witted; conditions of texture which were also held favorable to the storing of judgments connected with drugs. At all events, it is certain that if any medical man had come to Middlemarch with the reputation of having very definite religious views, of being given to prayer, and of otherwise showing an active piety, there would have been a general presumption against his medical skill.
利德盖特出发晚了，但斯普拉格医生、另外两名外科医生和几位主任早到了。财务主管兼董事长布尔斯特罗德先生也是仍然缺席的人之一。这次谈话似乎暗示这个问题是有问题的，而且泰克的多数票并不像人们普遍认为的那么确定。令人惊奇的是，这两位医生竟然意见一致，或者更确切地说，尽管想法不同，但他们的行动却一致。斯普拉格博士性格粗犷、举重若轻，正如大家所预见的那样，他是费雷布拉泽先生的追随者。博士被怀疑没有宗教信仰，但不知怎的，米德尔马奇容忍了他的这种缺陷，就好像他是一位大法官一样；事实上，他的职业分量很可能更受人相信，聪明与邪恶原则的世界古老联系仍然有效，甚至在那些对虚饰和多愁善感有着最严格观念的女病人的头脑中也是如此。也许正是医生的这种否定态度，让他的邻居们称他为顽固分子和愚昧无知的人。质地条件也有利于储存与药物有关的判断。无论如何，可以肯定的是，如果有任何一位医生来到米德尔马奇，并以拥有非常明确的宗教观点、热衷于祈祷以及在其他方面表现出积极的虔诚而闻名，人们就会普遍认为他的医学水平不高。技能。

On this ground it was (professionally speaking) fortunate for Dr. Minchin that his religious sympathies were of a general kind, and such as gave a distant medical sanction to all serious sentiment, whether of Church or Dissent, rather than any adhesion to particular tenets. If Mr. Bulstrode insisted, as he was apt to do, on the Lutheran doctrine of justification, as that by which a Church must stand or fall, Dr. Minchin in return was quite sure that man was not a mere machine or a fortuitous conjunction of atoms; if Mrs. Wimple insisted on a particular providence in relation to her stomach complaint, Dr. Minchin for his part liked to keep the mental windows open and objected to fixed limits; if the Unitarian brewer jested about the Athanasian Creed, Dr. Minchin quoted Pope’s ‘Essay on Man.’ He objected to the rather free style of anecdote in which Dr. Sprague indulged, preferring well-sanctioned quotations, and liking refinement of all kinds: it was generally known that he had some kinship to a bishop, and sometimes spent his holidays at ‘the palace.’
从这个角度来看，（从专业角度来说）明钦博士是幸运的，因为他的宗教同情心是普遍的，并且对所有严肃的情感，无论是教会的还是异见的，都给予了遥远的医学制裁，而不是对特定教义的任何坚持。如果布尔斯特罗德先生坚持路德宗的称义教义（他很容易这样做），认为这是教会生存或衰落的依据，那么作为回报，明钦博士非常确信人不仅仅是一台机器或一个偶然的结合体。原子；如果温普尔夫人坚持对她的胃病有某种特定的天意，明钦医生则喜欢保持精神之窗敞开，并反对固定的限制。如果这位一神论酿酒师取笑亚他那修信条，明钦博士就会引用蒲柏的《人论》。他反对斯普拉格博士所沉迷的相当自由的轶事风格，更喜欢经过严格认可的引文，并喜欢各种精炼：众所周知，他与一位主教有某种亲属关系，有时会在“宫殿”度过假期。

Dr. Minchin was soft-handed, pale-complexioned, and of rounded outline, not to be distinguished from a mild clergyman in appearance: whereas Dr. Sprague was superfluously tall; his trousers got creased at the knees, and showed an excess of boot at a time when straps seemed necessary to any dignity of bearing; you heard him go in and out, and up and down, as if he had come to see after the roofing. In short, he had weight, and might be expected to grapple with a disease and throw it; while Dr. Minchin might be better able to detect it lurking and to circumvent it. They enjoyed about equally the mysterious privilege of medical reputation, and concealed with much etiquette their contempt for each other’s skill. Regarding themselves as Middlemarch institutions, they were ready to combine against all innovators, and against non-professionals given to interference. On this ground they were both in their hearts equally averse to Mr. Bulstrode, though Dr. Minchin had never been in open hostility with him, and never differed from him without elaborate explanation to Mrs. Bulstrode, who had found that Dr. Minchin alone understood her constitution. A layman who pried into the professional conduct of medical men, and was always obtruding his reforms,— though he was less directly embarrassing to the two physicians than to the surgeon-apothecaries who attended paupers by contract, was nevertheless offensive to the professional nostril as such; and Dr. Minchin shared fully in the new pique against Bulstrode, excited by his apparent determination to patronize Lydgate. The long-established practitioners, Mr. Wrench and Mr. Toller; were just now standing apart and having a friendly colloquy, in which they agreed that Lydgate was a jackanapes, just made to serve Bulstrode’s purpose. To non-medical friends they had already concurred in praising the other young practitioner, who had come into the town on Mr. Peacock’s retirement without further recommendation than his own merits and such argument for solid professional acquirement as might be gathered from his having apparently wasted no time on other branches of knowledge. It was clear that Lydgate, by not dispensing drugs, intended to cast imputations on his equals, and also to obscure the limit between his own rank as a general practitioner and that of the physicians, who, in the interest of the profession, felt bound to maintain its various grades,— especially against a man who had not been to either of the English universities and enjoyed the absence of anatomical and bedside study there, but came with a libellous pretension to experience in Edinburgh and Paris, where observation might be abundant indeed, but hardly sound.
明钦博士手脚柔软，肤色苍白，轮廓圆润，从外表上看与一位温和的牧师没有什么区别；而斯普拉格博士则过分高大；他的个子高得过分。他的裤子在膝盖处有褶皱，在当时似乎需要系带才能保持尊严的时候，靴子显得多余。你听见他进进出出，上下上下，仿佛他是来检查屋顶的。简而言之，他有体重，可能会被期望与疾病作斗争并扔掉它；而明钦博士也许能够更好地发现它的潜伏并规避它。他们同样享有医学声誉的神秘特权，并以礼节掩盖了对彼此技术的蔑视。他们将自己视为米德尔马契机构，准备联合起来反对所有创新者和容易干涉的非专业人士。基于这一点，他们内心都同样厌恶布尔斯特罗德先生，尽管明钦医生从未公开敌视他，并且在没有向布尔斯特罗德夫人详细解释的情况下也从未与他有过不同意见，布尔斯特罗德夫人发现明钦医生独自一人了解她的体质。一个外行窥探医生的职业行为，总是妨碍他的改革，尽管他让两位医生直接感到尴尬，而不是让那些按合同为穷人看病的外科医生兼药剂师感到尴尬，但他还是冒犯了专业人士的鼻孔，因为这样的;明钦博士完全赞同布尔斯特罗德对布尔斯特罗德的新的愤怒，他对他明显决心赞助利德盖特感到兴奋。资深从业者，扳手先生和托勒先生；他们刚刚站在一起进行了一次友好的交谈，他们一致认为利德盖特是一只杰克纳猿，只是为了服务布尔斯特罗德的目的而生的。 对于非医学界的朋友来说，他们已经一致赞扬了另一位年轻的从业者，他是在皮科克先生退休后来到这个小镇的，除了他自己的优点之外，没有进一步的推荐，也没有从他明显浪费的时间中收集到扎实的专业知识的论据。没有时间学习其他知识分支。很明显，利德盖特不配药的目的是要对他的同辈人进行指责，并模糊他自己作为全科医生和医生之间的界限，而医生为了职业的利益，感到受到约束为了维持其不同的成绩，特别是针对一个没有去过任何一所英国大学并且享受那里没有解剖学和临床研究的人，但带着诽谤性的借口来到爱丁堡和巴黎，那里的观察可能很丰富确实如此，但很难听起来。

Thus it happened that on this occasion Bulstrode became identified with Lydgate, and Lydgate with Tyke; and owing to this variety of interchangeable names for the chaplaincy question, diverse minds were enabled to form the same judgment concerning it.
因此，这次布尔斯特罗德与利德盖特融为一体，而利德盖特又与泰克融为一体。由于牧师问题有多种可互换的名称，不同的人能够对此形成相同的判断。

Dr. Sprague said at once bluntly. to the group assembled when he entered, ‘I go for Farebrother. A salary, with all my heart. But why take it from the Vicar? He has none too much—has to insure his life, besides keeping house, and doing a vicar’s charities. Put forty pounds in his pocket and you’ll do no harm. He’s a good fellow, is Farebrother, with as little of the parson about him as will serve to carry orders.’
斯普拉格博士立刻直言不讳地说。当他进来时，他对聚集的人群说：“我选择费雷布拉泽。”薪水，全心全意。但为什么要从牧师那里拿它呢？他没有太多的东西——除了持家和做牧师的慈善事业之外，他还必须保证自己的生命。把四十英镑放进他的口袋里，你不会造成任何伤害。费雷布拉泽是个好人，他身上没有牧师的影子，只是负责执行命令。

‘Ho, ho! Doctor,’ said old Mr. Powderell, a retired iron-monger of some standing—his interjection being something between a laugh and a Parliamentary disapproval; ‘we must let you have your say. But what we have to consider is not anybody’s income—it’s the souls of the poor sick people’—here Mr. Powderell’s voice and face had a sincere pathos in them. ‘He is a real Gospel preacher, is Mr. Tyke. I should vote against my conscience if I voted against Mr. Tyke— I should indeed.’
‘嗬，嗬！波德德尔老先生说道，他是一位颇有名气的退休铁商。他的感叹语气介于笑声和议会的反对之间。 ‘我们必须让你有发言权。但我们要考虑的不是任何人的收入，而是那些可怜的病人的灵魂。在这里，波德尔先生的声音和表情都流露出真诚的悲怆。 “泰克先生是一位真正的福音传教士。如果我投票反对泰克先生，我就应该违背我的良心投票——我确实应该这样做。

‘Mr. Tyke’s opponents have not asked any one to vote against his conscience, I believe,’ said Mr. Hackbutt, a rich tanner of fluent speech, whose glittering spectacles and erect hair were turned with some severity towards innocent Mr. Powderell. ‘But in my judgment it behoves us, as Directors, to consider whether we will regard it as our whole business to carry out propositions emanating from a single quarter. Will any member of the committee aver that he would have entertained the idea of displacing the gentleman who has always discharged the function of chaplain here, if it had not been suggested to him by parties whose disposition it is to regard every institution of this town as a machinery for carrying out their own views? I tax no man’s motives: let them lie between himself and a higher Power; but I do say, that there are influences at work here which are incompatible with genuine independence, and that a crawling servility is usually dictated by circumstances which gentlemen so conducting themselves could not afford either morally or financially to avow. I myself am a layman, but I have given no inconsiderable attention to the divisions in the Church and—‘
'先生。我相信，泰克的对手并没有要求任何人违背他的良心投票。”哈克布特先生说。哈克布特是一位皮肤黝黑、言语流畅的人，他闪闪发光的眼镜和直立的头发带着某种严厉的态度转向无辜的波德尔先生。 “但根据我的判断，作为董事，我们应该考虑是否将执行单个季度的提议视为我们的全部业务。委员会的任何成员是否会声称，如果不是那些倾向于将这个镇的每个机构视为一个执行自己观点的机器？我不追究任何人的动机：让它们介于他自己和更高的权力之间；但我确实要说，这里存在着与真正的独立不相容的影响，而这种卑鄙的奴性通常是由这样的绅士们在道德上或经济上都无法承认的环境所决定的。我本人是一个外行，但我对教会中的分歧并没有给予过分的关注，而且——”

‘Oh, damn the divisions!’ burst in Mr. Frank Hawley, lawyer and town-clerk, who rarely presented himself at the board, but now looked in hurriedly, whip in hand. ‘We have nothing to do with them here. Farebrother has been doing the work—what there was—without pay, and if pay is to be given, it should be given to him. I call it a confounded job to take the thing away from Farebrother.’
“哦，该死的分歧！”律师兼镇书记员弗兰克·霍利先生突然插话道。他很少出现在董事会上，但现在手里拿着鞭子，匆忙地看着。 ‘我们在这里与他们没有任何关系。费雷布拉泽一直在做这项工作——以前的工作——没有报酬，如果要给报酬，就应该给他。我称从费雷布拉泽手中夺走这东西是一项令人困惑的工作。

‘I think it would be as well for gentlemen not to give their remarks a personal bearing,’ said Mr. Plymdale. ‘I shall vote for the appointment of Mr. Tyke, but I should not have known, if Mr. Hackbutt hadn’t hinted it, that I was a Servile Crawler.’
“我认为先生们最好不要将自己的言论带有个人色彩，”普林代尔先生说。 “我将投票支持泰克先生的任命，但如果哈克布特先生没有暗示，我不应该知道我是一名奴仆爬行者。”

‘I disclaim any personalities. I expressly said, if I may be allowed to repeat, or even to conclude what I was about to say—‘
“我否认任何个人身份。我明确表示，如果允许我重复，甚至总结我要说的话——”

‘Ah, here’s Minchin!’ said Mr. Frank Hawley; at which everybody turned away from Mr. Hackbutt, leaving him to feel the uselessness of superior gifts in Middlemarch. ‘Come, Doctor, I must have you on the right side, eh?’
“啊，明钦来了！”弗兰克·霍利先生说道。所有人都对哈克巴特先生敬而远之，让他感到在米德尔马契再优秀的天赋也毫无用处。 “来吧，医生，我必须让你站在右边，嗯？”

‘I hope so,’ said Dr. Minchin, nodding and shaking hands here and there; ‘at whatever cost to my feelings.’
“我希望如此，”明钦医生一边点头，一边握手。 “不惜牺牲我的感情。”

‘If there’s any feeling here, it should be feeling for the man who is turned out, I think,’ said Mr. Frank Hawley.
“我想，如果这里有任何感情的话，那应该是对那个被赶出来的人的感情，”弗兰克·霍利先生说。

‘I confess I have feelings on the other side also. I have a divided esteem,’ said Dr. Minchin, rubbing his hands. ‘I consider Mr. Tyke an exemplary man—none more so—and I believe him to be proposed from unimpeachable motives. I, for my part, wish that I could give him my vote. But I am constrained to take a view of the case which gives the preponderance to Mr. Farebrother’s claims. He is an amiable man, an able preacher, and has been longer among us.’
“我承认我对另一方也有感情。 “我的尊重是有分歧的，”明钦博士揉着双手说道。 “我认为泰克先生是一位模范人物——仅此而已——而且我相信他的提议是出于无可指责的动机。就我而言，我希望能给他投票。但我不得不对这个案件采取以费雷布拉泽先生的主张为主的观点。他是一位和蔼可亲的人，一位能干的传教士，并且在我们中间生活的时间更长。

Old Mr. Powderell looked on, sad and silent. Mr. Plymdale settled his cravat, uneasily.
老波德尔先生在一旁看着，悲伤而沉默。普利姆代尔先生不安地系好领带。

‘You don’t set up Farebrother as a pattern of what a clergyman ought to be, I hope,’ said Mr. Larcher, the eminent carrier, who had just come in. ‘I have no ill-will towards him, but I think we owe something to the public, not to speak of anything higher, in these appointments. In my opinion Farebrother is too lax for a clergyman. I don’t wish to bring up particulars against him; but he will make a little attendance here go as far as he can.’
“我希望，你没有把费雷布拉泽视为牧师应有的典范，”刚刚进来的著名携带者拉彻先生说。“我对他没有恶意，但我我认为，在这些任命中，我们欠公众一些东西，更不用说任何更高的东西了。在我看来，费雷布拉泽对于一名牧师来说太宽松了。我不想提出针对他的细节；但他会尽可能地让这里的人少一些。”

‘And a devilish deal better than too much,’ said Mr. Hawley, whose bad language was notorious in that part of the county. ‘Sick people can’t bear so much praying and preaching. And that methodistical sort of religion is bad for the spirits— bad for the inside, eh?’ he added, turning quickly round to the four medical men who were assembled.
“一笔恶魔般的交易总比太多要好，”霍利先生说，他的脏话在该县的那个地区是出了名的。 “病人无法忍受这么多的祈祷和讲道。这种有条不紊的宗教对精神有害——对内心有害，是吗？”他补充道，迅速转向聚集在一起的四位医生。

But any answer was dispensed with by the entrance of three gentlemen, with whom there were greetings more or less cordial. These were the Reverend Edward Thesiger, Rector of St. Peter’s, Mr. Bulstrode, and our friend Mr. Brooke of Tipton, who had lately allowed himself to be put on the board of directors in his turn, but had never before attended, his attendance now being due to Mr. Bulstrode’s exertions. Lydgate was the only person still expected.
但三位绅士的到来让一切都不再需要回答，他们或多或少地受到了亲切的问候。他们是圣彼得教堂的教区长爱德华·塞西格牧师、布尔斯特罗德先生和我们的朋友蒂普顿的布鲁克先生，他最近允许自己轮流进入董事会，但以前从未参加过他的董事会。由于布尔斯特罗德先生的努力，现在的出席率很高。利德盖特是唯一还在等待的人。

Every one now sat down, Mr. Bulstrode presiding, pale and self-restrained as usual. Mr. Thesiger, a moderate evangelical, wished for the appointment of his friend Mr. Tyke, a zealous able man, who, officiating at a chapel of ease, had not a cure of souls too extensive to leave him ample time for the new duty. It was desirable that chaplaincies of this kind should be entered on with a fervent intention: they were peculiar opportunities for spiritual influence; and while it was good that a salary should be allotted, there was the more need for scrupulous watching lest the office should be perverted into a mere question of salary. Mr. Thesiger’s manner had so much quiet propriety that objectors could only simmer in silence.
现在每个人都坐下来，由布尔斯特罗德先生主持，他的脸色苍白，像往常一样克制。塞西格先生是一位温和的福音派人士，他希望任命他的朋友泰克先生为人，泰克先生是一位热心能干的人，负责主持一个安逸的教堂，他没有太多的灵魂治愈方法，无法给他留下足够的时间来履行新的职责。从事这种牧师工作应该怀着热切的意愿，这是可取的：它们是产生精神影响力的特殊机会；虽然工资的分配固然好，但更需要小心谨慎，以免办公室被歪曲成纯粹的工资问题。塞西格先生的举止非常得体，以至于反对者只能默默地忍耐。

Mr. Brooke believed that everybody meant well in the matter. He had not himself attended to the affairs of the Infirmary, though he had a strong interest in whatever was for the benefit of Middlemarch, and was most happy to meet the gentlemen present on any public question— ‘any public question, you know,’ Mr. Brooke repeated, with his nod of perfect understanding. ‘I am a good deal occupied as a magistrate, and in the collection of documentary evidence, but I regard my time as being at the disposal of the public—and, in short, my friends have convinced me that a chaplain with a salary—a salary, you know— is a very good thing, and I am happy to be able to come here and vote for the appointment of Mr. Tyke, who, I understand, is an unexceptionable man, apostolic and eloquent and everything of that kind— and I am the last man to withhold my vote—under the circumstances, you know.’
布鲁克先生相信大家在这件事上都是出于好意。他本人并没有参与医务室的事务，尽管他对任何有利于米德尔马奇的事情都抱有浓厚的兴趣，并且非常高兴能在任何公共问题上会见在场的先生们——“任何公共问题，你知道，”布鲁克先生重复了一遍，点头表示完全理解。 “作为一名地方法官，我忙于收集文件证据，但我认为我的时间是供公众支配的——简而言之，我的朋友们让我相信，一个拿着薪水的牧师——薪水，你知道的——是一件非常好的事情，我很高兴能够来到这里投票支持泰克先生的任命，据我所知，他是一个无可挑剔的人，具有使徒性，雄辩，诸如此类。 ——在这种情况下，我是最后一个不投票的人，你知道的。

‘It seems to me that you have been crammed with one side of the question, Mr. Brooke,’ said Mr. Frank Hawley, who was afraid of nobody, and was a Tory suspicious of electioneering intentions. ‘You don’t seem to know that one of the worthiest men we have has been doing duty as chaplain here for years without pay, and that Mr. Tyke is proposed to supersede him.’
“布鲁克先生，在我看来，你只关注了问题的一面，”弗兰克·霍利先生说。他谁也不害怕，而且是一名对竞选意图持怀疑态度的保守党人。 “你似乎不知道我们最有价值的人之一多年来一直在这里无薪担任牧师，而泰克先生被提议取代他。”

‘Excuse me, Mr. Hawley,’ said Mr. Bulstrode. ‘Mr. Brooke has been fully informed of Mr. Farebrother’s character and position.’
“对不起，霍利先生，”布尔斯特罗德先生说。 '先生。布鲁克已完全了解费尔布拉泽先生的性格和立场。

‘By his enemies,’ flashed out Mr. Hawley.
“是他的敌人干的。”霍利先生突然脱口而出。

‘I trust there is no personal hostility concerned here,’ said Mr. Thesiger.
“我相信这里不存在个人敌意，”塞西格先生说。

‘I’ll swear there is, though,’ retorted Mr. Hawley.
“不过，我发誓确实有，”霍利先生反驳道。

‘Gentlemen,’ said Mr. Bulstrode, in a subdued tone, ‘the merits of the question may be very briefly stated, and if any one present doubts that every gentleman who is about to give his vote has not been fully informed, I can now recapitulate the considerations that should weigh on either side.’
“先生们，”布尔斯特罗德先生用柔和的语气说道，“这个问题的优点可以非常简短地陈述，如果在场的任何人怀疑每一位即将投票的先生都没有得到充分的通知，我可以现在概括一下双方应该考虑的因素。

‘I don’t see the good of that,’ said Mr. Hawley. ‘I suppose we all know whom we mean to vote for. Any man who wants to do justice does not wait till the last minute to hear both sides of the question. I have no time to lose, and I propose that the matter be put to the vote at once.’
“我看不出这样做有什么好处，”霍利先生说。 “我想我们都知道我们要投票给谁。任何想要伸张正义的人都不会等到最后一刻才听取问题双方的意见。我不能再浪费时间了，我建议立即将此事付诸表决。”

A brief but still hot discussion followed before each person wrote ‘Tyke’ or ‘Farebrother’ on a piece of paper and slipped it into a glass tumbler; and in the mean time Mr. Bulstrode saw Lydgate enter.
随后进行了简短但仍然激烈的讨论，然后每个人在一张纸上写下“Tyke”或“Farebrother”并将其放入玻璃杯中；与此同时，布尔斯特罗德先生看到利德盖特进来了。

‘I perceive that the votes are equally divided at present,’ said Mr. Bulstrode, in a clear biting voice. Then, looking up at Lydgate—
“我认为目前选票是平等的，”布尔斯特罗德先生用尖锐的声音说道。然后，抬头看着利德盖特——

‘There is a casting-vote still to be given. It is yours, Mr. Lydgate: will you be good enough to write?’
“还有一个决定性的投票需要进行。这是你的，利德盖特先生：你会写字吗？

‘The thing is settled now,’ said Mr. Wrench, rising. ‘We all know how Mr. Lydgate will vote.’
“现在事情已经解决了，”扳手先生站起来说道。 “我们都知道利德盖特先生将如何投票。”

‘You seem to speak with some peculiar meaning, sir,’ said Lydgate, rather defiantly, and keeping his pencil suspended.
“您说话的意思似乎有些奇怪，先生。”利德盖特悬着铅笔，相当挑衅地说。

‘I merely mean that you are expected to vote with Mr. Bulstrode. Do you regard that meaning as offensive?’
“我只是说你应该投票支持布尔斯特罗德先生。你认为这个意思具有冒犯性吗？

‘It may be offensive to others. But I shall not desist from voting with him on that account.’ Lydgate immediately wrote down ‘Tyke.’
‘这可能会冒犯别人。但我不会因此停止投票支持他。”利德盖特立即写下了“泰克”。

So the Rev. Walter Tyke became chaplain to the Infirmary, and Lydgate continued to work with Mr. Bulstrode. He was really uncertain whether Tyke were not the more suitable candidate, and yet his consciousness told him that if he had been quite free from indirect bias he should have voted for Mr. Farebrother. The affair of the chaplaincy remained a sore point in his memory as a case in which this petty medium of Middlemarch had been too strong for him. How could a man be satisfied with a decision between such alternatives and under such circumstances? No more than he can be satisfied with his hat, which he has chosen from among such shapes as the resources of the age offer him, wearing it at best with a resignation which is chiefly supported by comparison.
因此，沃尔特·泰克牧师成为了医务室的牧师，利德盖特继续与布尔斯特罗德先生一起工作。他确实不确定泰克是否不是更合适的候选人，但他的意识告诉他，如果他完全没有间接偏见，他应该投票给费雷布拉泽先生。牧师的事情仍然是他记忆中的一个痛处，因为米德尔马契的这个小媒介对他来说太强大了。在这样的情况下，一个人怎么会对在这样的选择之间做出的决定感到满意呢？就像他对自己的帽子感到不满意一样，帽子是他从时代资源提供给他的形状中选择的，顶多是带着一种顺从的态度戴上它，这主要是通过比较来支持的。

But Mr. Farebrother met him with the same friendliness as before. The character of the publican and sinner is not always practically incompatible with that of the modern Pharisee, for the majority of us scarcely see more distinctly the faultiness of our own conduct than the faultiness of our own arguments, or the dulness of our own jokes. But the Vicar of St. Botolph’s had certainly escaped the slightest tincture of the Pharisee, and by dint of admitting to himself that he was too much as other men were, he had become remarkably unlike them in this—that he could excuse other; for thinking slightly of him, and could judge impartially of their conduct even when it told against him.
但费雷布拉泽先生见到他时还是一如既往的友善。税吏和罪人的性格实际上并不总是与现代法利赛人的性格不相容，因为我们大多数人几乎没有比我们自己的论点的错误或我们自己的笑话的愚蠢更清楚地看到我们自己行为的错误。但圣博托尔夫教堂的牧师显然没有沾染上丝毫的法利赛人的色彩，并且由于他承认自己与其他人一样，他在这一点上变得与他们截然不同——他可以原谅别人；因为他对他的看法不高，并且能够公正地判断他们的行为，即使这些行为对他不利。

‘The world has been to strong for ME, I know,’ he said one day to Lydgate. ‘But then I am not a mighty man—I shall never be a man of renown. The choice of Hercules is a pretty fable; but Prodicus makes it easy work for the hero, as if the first resolves were enough. Another story says that he came to hold the distaff, and at last wore the Nessus shirt. I suppose one good resolve might keep a man right if everybody else’s resolve helped him.’
“我知道，这个世界对我来说太强大了，”有一天他对利德盖特说道。 ‘但是我不是一个强大的人——我永远不会成为一个有名的人。赫拉克勒斯的选择是一个美丽的寓言。但普罗迪克斯让英雄的工作变得很容易，就好像最初的决心就足够了。另一个故事说他来握住棍子，最后穿上了涅索斯衬衫。我想，如果其他人的决心都对一个人有帮助，那么一个好的决心就可能使一个人保持正确。

The Vicar’s talk was not always inspiriting: he had escaped being a Pharisee, but he had not escaped that low estimate of possibilities which we rather hastily arrive at as an inference from our own failure. Lydgate thought that there was a pitiable infirmity of will in Mr. Farebrother.
牧师的谈话并不总是鼓舞人心：他逃脱了法利赛人的束缚，但他并没有逃脱对可能性的低估计，而这种估计是我们从自己的失败中仓促得出的推论。利德盖特认为费勒布拉泽先生的意志力很薄弱，令人可怜。

CHAPTER XIX
第十九章

‘L’ altra vedete ch’ha fatto alla guancia
Della sua palma, sospirando, letto.’
Della sua palma, sospirando, letto。’

—Purgatorio, vii.
——炼狱，七。

When George the Fourth was still reigning over the privacies of Windsor, when the Duke of Wellington was Prime Minister, and Mr. Vincy was mayor of the old corporation in Middlemarch, Mrs. Casaubon, born Dorothea Brooke, had taken her wedding journey to Rome. In those days the world in general was more ignorant of good and evil by forty years than it is at present. Travellers did not often carry full information on Christian art either in their heads or their pockets; and even the most brilliant English critic of the day mistook the flower-flushed tomb of the ascended Virgin for an ornamental vase due to the painter’s fancy. Romanticism, which has helped to fill some dull blanks with love and knowledge, had not yet penetrated the times with its leaven and entered into everybody’s food; it was fermenting still as a distinguishable vigorous enthusiasm in certain long-haired German artists at Rome, and the youth of other nations who worked or idled near them were sometimes caught in the spreading movement.
当乔治四世还在统治温莎的隐私时，威灵顿公爵担任首相，文西先生担任米德尔马契旧公司的市长时，卡苏邦夫人（原名多萝西娅·布鲁克）已经踏上了前往罗马的婚礼之旅。 。那时的世界，总体上比现在不知善恶多了四十年。旅行者的头脑或口袋中并不经常携带有关基督教艺术的完整信息。由于画家的奇思妙想，就连当时最杰出的英国评论家也将升天圣母的鲜花盛开的坟墓误认为是一个装饰花瓶。浪漫主义曾用爱和知识帮助填补了一些沉闷的空白，但它还没有以其酵母渗透到时代并进入每个人的食物中。在罗马的某些长发德国艺术家中，这种明显的强烈热情仍在发酵，而在他们附近工作或闲逛的其他国家的年轻人有时也被卷入这场蔓延的运动中。

One fine morning a young man whose hair was not immoderately long, but abundant and curly, and who was otherwise English in his equipment, had just turned his back on the Belvedere Torso in the Vatican and was looking out on the magnificent view of the mountains from the adjoining round vestibule. He was sufficiently absorbed not to notice the approach of a dark-eyed, animated German who came up to him and placing a hand on his shoulder, said with a strong accent, ‘Come here, quick! else she will have changed her pose.’
一个晴朗的早晨，一位年轻人的头发不是过分长，而是浓密而卷曲，他的装备是英国式的，他刚刚背对着梵蒂冈的观景台，眺望着壮丽的山景。从毗邻的圆形前厅。他全神贯注，没有注意到一个黑眼睛、生气勃勃的德国人走近，他走到他面前，把手搭在他的肩膀上，用浓重的口音说道：“快过来，快！”否则她就会改变姿势。

Quickness was ready at the call, and the two figures passed lightly along by the Meleager, towards the hall where the reclining Ariadne, then called the Cleopatra, lies in the marble voluptuousness of her beauty, the drapery folding around her with a petal-like ease and tenderness. They were just in time to see another figure standing against a pedestal near the reclining marble: a breathing blooming girl, whose form, not shamed by the Ariadne, was clad in Quakerish gray drapery; her long cloak, fastened at the neck, was thrown backward from her arms, and one beautiful ungloved hand pillowed her cheek, pushing somewhat backward the white beaver bonnet which made a sort of halo to her face around the simply braided dark-brown hair. She was not looking at the sculpture, probably not thinking of it: her large eyes were fixed dreamily on a streak of sunlight which fell across the floor. But she became conscious of the two strangers who suddenly paused as if to contemplate the Cleopatra, and, without looking at them, immediately turned away to join a maid-servant and courier who were loitering along the hall at a little distance off.
很快，两人就准备好了，两个人轻轻地经过梅勒阿格，朝大厅走去，阿里阿德涅，当时被称为克利奥帕特拉，躺在那里，躺在她美丽的大理石上，帷幔像花瓣一样折叠在她身上。轻松和温柔。他们正好看到另一个人影站在斜倚大理石附近的一个基座上：一个呼吸着盛开的女孩，她的身材没有被阿里阿德涅羞辱，穿着贵格会的灰色帷幔；她系在脖子上的长斗篷从怀里向后抛开，一只未戴手套的漂亮手枕在她的脸颊上，把白色的海狸帽往后推了一下，帽子在她简单编成辫子的深棕色头发周围形成了一种光环。她没有在看雕塑，可能也没有在想它：她的大眼睛出神地盯着落在地板上的一缕阳光。但她意识到这两个陌生人突然停下来，仿佛在凝视克利奥帕特拉，没有看他们，立即转过身去，加入了在不远处的大厅里徘徊的女仆和信使。

‘What do you think of that for a fine bit of antithesis?’ said the German, searching in his friend’s face for responding admiration, but going on volubly without waiting for any other answer. ‘There lies antique beauty, not corpse-like even in death, but arrested in the complete contentment of its sensuous perfection: and here stands beauty in its breathing life, with the consciousness of Christian centuries in its bosom. But she should be dressed as a nun; I think she looks almost what you call a Quaker; I would dress her as a nun in my picture. However, she is married; I saw her wedding-ring on that wonderful left hand, otherwise I should have thought the sallow Geistlicher was her father. I saw him parting from her a good while ago, and just now I found her in that magnificent pose. Only think! he is perhaps rich, and would like to have her portrait taken. Ah! it is no use looking after her— there she goes! Let us follow her home!’
“你觉得这样的对立怎么样？”德国人说道，在他朋友的脸上寻找着钦佩的回应，但没有等待任何其他答案，他就滔滔不绝地继续说道。 “那里有古老的美，即使在死亡时也不像尸体，而是在其感性完美的完全满足中被捕：这里存在着呼吸生命的美，怀抱基督教世纪的意识。但她应该穿得像个修女；我认为她看起来几乎就是你们所谓的贵格会教徒；我会把她打扮成我照片中的修女。然而，她已经结婚了；我看到她那漂亮的左手上戴着结婚戒指，否则我真该以为蜡黄的盖斯特利彻是她的父亲。刚才我就看见他和她分开了，现在才发现她摆出那华丽的姿势。只想到！他也许很有钱，想为她拍张肖像。啊!照顾她是没有用的——她走了！我们跟着她回家吧！

‘No, no,’ said his companion, with a little frown.
“不，不，”他的同伴皱着眉头说道。

‘You are singular, Ladislaw. You look struck together. Do you know her?’
“你很独特，拉迪斯瓦夫。你们看起来很合拍。你认识她吗？'

‘I know that she is married to my cousin,’ said Will Ladislaw, sauntering down the hall with a preoccupied air, while his German friend kept at his side and watched him eagerly.
“我知道她嫁给了我的表弟，”威尔·拉迪斯瓦夫说道，他神情专注地在大厅里闲逛，而他的德国朋友则站在他身边，热切地看着他。

‘What! the Geistlicher? He looks more like an uncle—a more useful sort of relation.’
'什么！盖斯特利彻？他看起来更像是一位叔叔——一种更有用的关系。

‘He is not my uncle. I tell you he is my second cousin,’ said Ladislaw, with some irritation.
‘他不是我叔叔。 “我告诉你，他是我的远房表弟。”拉迪斯瓦夫有些恼怒地说。

‘Schon, schon. Don’t be snappish. You are not angry with me for thinking Mrs. Second-Cousin the most perfect young Madonna I ever saw?’
‘舍恩，舍恩。别急躁。你不会因为我认为二表姐夫人是我见过的最完美的年轻麦当娜而生气吧？

‘Angry? nonsense. I have only seen her once before, for a couple of minutes, when my cousin introduced her to me, just before I left England. They were not married then. I didn’t know they were coming to Rome.’
'生气的？废话。我以前只见过她一次，就几分钟，是在我离开英国之前，我表弟把她介绍给我的。那时他们还没有结婚。我不知道他们要来罗马。”

‘But you will go to see them now—you will find out what they have for an address—since you know the name. Shall we go to the post? And you could speak about the portrait.’
“但是你现在就去见他们——你会知道他们的地址——因为你知道名字。我们去邮局吧？你可以谈论这幅肖像。

‘Confound you, Naumann! I don’t know what I shall do. I am not so brazen as you.’
“让你感到困惑，瑙曼！我不知道我该怎么办。我不像你那么厚颜无耻。

‘Bah! that is because you are dilettantish and amateurish. If you were an artist, you would think of Mistress Second-Cousin as antique form animated by Christian sentiment—a sort of Christian Antigone— sensuous force controlled by spiritual passion.’
'呸！那是因为你很业余，很业余。如果你是一名艺术家，你会认为二表姐夫人是一种受基督教情感驱动的古老形式——一种基督教的安提戈涅——受精神激情控制的感性力量。

‘Yes, and that your painting her was the chief outcome of her existence—the divinity passing into higher completeness and all but exhausted in the act of covering your bit of canvas. I am amateurish if you like: I do NOT think that all the universe is straining towards the obscure significance of your pictures.’
“是的，你为她画的画是她存在的主要成果——神性进入了更高的完整性，在覆盖你那块画布的过程中几乎耗尽了神性。”如果你愿意的话，我是业余的：我不认为整个宇宙都在努力追求你的照片的晦涩意义。

‘But it is, my dear!—so far as it is straining through me, Adolf Naumann: that stands firm,’ said the good-natured painter, putting a hand on Ladislaw’s shoulder, and not in the least disturbed by the unaccountable touch of ill-humor in his tone. ‘See now! My existence presupposes the existence of the whole universe— does it NOT? and my function is to paint—and as a painter I have a conception which is altogether genialisch, of your great-aunt or second grandmother as a subject for a picture; therefore, the universe is straining towards that picture through that particular hook or claw which it puts forth in the shape of me— not true?’
“但它就是这样，亲爱的！——就它在我身上的张力而言，阿道夫·瑙曼：它是坚定的，”这位和善的画家说道，将一只手放在拉迪斯瓦夫的肩膀上，丝毫没有因为这种莫名其妙的触摸而感到不安。他的语气里充满了不幽默。 ‘现在看吧！我的存在以整个宇宙的存在为前提——不是吗？我的职责是绘画——作为一名画家，我有一种完全亲切的观念，即把你的曾祖母或第二祖母作为绘画的主题；因此，宇宙正通过它以我的形状伸出的那个特殊的钩子或爪子向那幅图画倾斜——这不是真的吗？

‘But how if another claw in the shape of me is straining to thwart it?— the case is a little less simple then.’
“但是，如果另一只像我一样的爪子正在竭力阻止它怎么办？——那么情况就不那么简单了。”

‘Not at all: the result of the struggle is the same thing— picture or no picture—logically.’
“一点也不：从逻辑上讲，斗争的结果是一样的——有图画或没有图画。”

Will could not resist this imperturbable temper, and the cloud in his face broke into sunshiny laughter.
威尔无法抗拒这种沉着的脾气，脸上的云彩爆发出阳光灿烂的笑声。

‘Come now, my friend—you will help?’ said Naumann, in a hopeful tone.
“来吧，我的朋友——你会帮忙吗？”瑙曼用充满希望的语气说道。

‘No; nonsense, Naumann! English ladies are not at everybody’s service as models. And you want to express too much with your painting. You would only have made a better or worse portrait with a background which every connoisseur would give a different reason for or against. And what is a portrait of a woman? Your painting and Plastik are poor stuff after all. They perturb and dull conceptions instead of raising them. Language is a finer medium.’
'不;胡说，瑙曼！英国女士作为模特并不能为所有人服务。而且你想用你的画来表达太多。你只会拍出更好或更差的肖像，而每个鉴赏家都会给出不同的理由支持或反对的背景。什么是女性肖像？你的画和Plastik毕竟是烂东西。它们非但没有提升概念，反而扰乱了概念并使其变得迟钝。语言是一种更好的媒介。”

‘Yes, for those who can’t paint,’ said Naumann. ‘There you have perfect right. I did not recommend you to paint, my friend.’
“是的，对于那些不会画画的人来说，”瑙曼说。 ‘你有完全的权利。我不建议你画画，我的朋友。

The amiable artist carried his sting, but Ladislaw did not choose to appear stung. He went on as if he had not heard.
这位和蔼可亲的艺术家带着毒刺，但拉迪斯瓦夫并没有选择表现出被毒刺的样子。他继续说下去，就像没有听到一样。

‘Language gives a fuller image, which is all the better for beings vague. After all, the true seeing is within; and painting stares at you with an insistent imperfection. I feel that especially about representations of women. As if a woman were a mere colored superficies! You must wait for movement and tone. There is a difference in their very breathing: they change from moment to moment.—This woman whom you have just seen, for example: how would you paint her voice, pray? But her voice is much diviner than anything you have seen of her.’
“语言提供了更完整的形象，这对于模糊的存在来说是更好的。毕竟，真正的看见是在内心；而绘画则以一种持续的不完美凝视着你。我尤其对女性的代表有这样的感觉。仿佛女人只是一种有色的肤浅之物！你必须等待动作和语气。他们的呼吸是有区别的：他们每时每刻都在变化。——例如，你刚才看到的这个女人：你会如何画她的声音，祈祷？但她的声音比你见过的任何她的声音都要神圣得多。”

‘I see, I see. You are jealous. No man must presume to think that he can paint your ideal. This is serious, my friend! Your great-aunt! ‘Der Neffe als Onkel’ in a tragic sense—ungeheuer!’
‘我明白了，我明白了。你吃醋。任何人都不能自以为能够描绘出你的理想。这很严重，我的朋友！你的曾祖母！悲剧意义上的“Der Neffe als Onkel”——ungeheuer！

‘You and I shall quarrel, Naumann, if you call that lady my aunt again.’
“瑙曼，如果你再称那位女士为我阿姨，你和我就会吵架。”

‘How is she to be called then?’
“那她该怎么称呼呢？”

‘Mrs. Casaubon.’
'太太。卡苏邦。’

‘Good. Suppose I get acquainted with her in spite of you, and find that she very much wishes to be painted?’
'好的。假设我不顾你的关心认识了她，发现她非常希望被画呢？

‘Yes, suppose!’ said Will Ladislaw, in a contemptuous undertone, intended to dismiss the subject. He was conscious of being irritated by ridiculously small causes, which were half of his own creation. Why was he making any fuss about Mrs. Casaubon? And yet he felt as if something had happened to him with regard to her. There are characters which are continually creating collisions and nodes for themselves in dramas which nobody is prepared to act with them. Their susceptibilities will clash against objects that remain innocently quiet.
“是的，假设吧！”威尔·拉迪斯瓦夫用轻蔑的语气说道，打算回避这个话题。他意识到自己会因为一些小得可笑的原因而感到恼火，而这些原因有一半是他自己造成的。他为什么要对卡苏朋夫人大惊小怪呢？但他却觉得她身上好像发生了什么事。有些角色在戏剧中不断为自己制造冲突和节点，但没人准备与之合作。他们的敏感性会与保持天真的安静的物体发生冲突。

CHAPTER XX.
第二十章。

‘A child forsaken, waking suddenly,
“一个被遗弃的孩子突然醒来，

Whose gaze afeard on all things round doth rove,
他的目光敬畏着周围的一切，

And seeth only that it cannot see
只看到它看不到的东西

The meeting eyes of love.’
充满爱意的眼神。

Two hours later, Dorothea was seated in an inner room or boudoir of a handsome apartment in the Via Sistina.
两个小时后，多萝西娅坐在西斯蒂纳大街一套漂亮公寓的内室或闺房里。

I am sorry to add that she was sobbing bitterly, with such abandonment to this relief of an oppressed heart as a woman habitually controlled by pride on her own account and thoughtfulness for others will sometimes allow herself when she feels securely alone. And Mr. Casaubon was certain to remain away for some time at the Vatican.
我很遗憾地补充说，她哭得很伤心，因为一个习惯于为自己的骄傲和对他人的体贴所控制的女人，当她感到安全地孤独时，有时会允许自己释放一颗受压迫的心。卡苏邦先生肯定会离开梵蒂冈一段时间。

Yet Dorothea had no distinctly shapen grievance that she could state even to herself; and in the midst of her confused thought and passion, the mental act that was struggling forth into clearness was a self-accusing cry that her feeling of desolation was the fault of her own spiritual poverty. She had married the man of her choice, and with the advantage over most girls that she had contemplated her marriage chiefly as the beginning of new duties: from the very first she had thought of Mr. Casaubon as having a mind so much above her own, that he must often be claimed by studies which she could not entirely share; moreover, after the brief narrow experience of her girlhood she was beholding Rome, the city of visible history, where the past of a whole hemisphere seems moving in funeral procession with strange ancestral images and trophies gathered from afar.
然而，多萝西娅甚至对自己也没有明显的不满。在她混乱的思绪和激情中，挣扎着变得清晰的精神行为是一种自责的呼喊，她的荒凉感是她自己精神贫困的错。她嫁给了她选择的男人，与大多数女孩相比，她的优势在于，她把婚姻主要视为新责任的开始：从一开始，她就认为卡苏邦先生的思想远远高于她自己的思想。 ，他必须经常被她无法完全分享的研究所声称；此外，在经历了短暂而狭窄的少女时代之后，她看到了罗马，一座可见历史的城市，整个半球的过去似乎在送葬队伍中移动，奇怪的祖先图像和从远处收集的战利品。

But this stupendous fragmentariness heightened the dreamlike strangeness of her bridal life. Dorothea had now been five weeks in Rome, and in the kindly mornings when autumn and winter seemed to go hand in hand like a happy aged couple one of whom would presently survive in chiller loneliness, she had driven about at first with Mr. Casaubon, but of late chiefly with Tantripp and their experienced courier. She had been led through the best galleries, had been taken to the chief points of view, had been shown the grandest ruins and the most glorious churches, and she had ended by oftenest choosing to drive out to the Campagna where she could feel alone with the earth and sky, away-from the oppressive masquerade of ages, in which her own life too seemed to become a masque with enigmatical costumes.
但这种巨大的碎片加剧了她新娘生活的梦幻般的陌生感。多萝西娅现在已经在罗马呆了五个星期了，在那些和蔼可亲的早晨，秋天和冬天似乎齐头并进，就像一对幸福的老年夫妇，其中一人很快就会在寒冷的孤独中生存，她一开始是和卡苏邦先生一起开车去的，但最近主要是与坦特里普和他们经验丰富的信使一起。她被带过最好的画廊，被带到了主要的景点，被带去参观最宏伟的废墟和最辉煌的教堂，最后她最常选择开车去坎帕尼亚，在那里她可以感到孤独。大地和天空，远离岁月压抑的假面舞会，她自己的生活似乎也成了一场穿着神秘服装的假面舞会。

To those who have looked at Rome with the quickening power of a knowledge which breathes a growing soul into all historic shapes, and traces out the suppressed transitions which unite all contrasts, Rome may still be the spiritual centre and interpreter of the world. But let them conceive one more historical contrast: the gigantic broken revelations of that Imperial and Papal city thrust abruptly on the notions of a girl who had been brought up in English and Swiss Puritanism, fed on meagre Protestant histories and on art chiefly of the hand-screen sort; a girl whose ardent nature turned all her small allowance of knowledge into principles, fusing her actions into their mould, and whose quick emotions gave the most abstract things the quality of a pleasure or a pain; a girl who had lately become a wife, and from the enthusiastic acceptance of untried duty found herself plunged in tumultuous preoccupation with her personal lot. The weight of unintelligible Rome might lie easily on bright nymphs to whom it formed a background for the brilliant picnic of Anglo-foreign society; but Dorothea had no such defence against deep impressions. Ruins and basilicas, palaces and colossi, set in the midst of a sordid present, where all that was living and warm-blooded seemed sunk in the deep degeneracy of a superstition divorced from reverence; the dimmer but yet eager Titanic life gazing and struggling on walls and ceilings; the long vistas of white forms whose marble eyes seemed to hold the monotonous light of an alien world: all this vast wreck of ambitious ideals, sensuous and spiritual, mixed confusedly with the signs of breathing forgetfulness and degradation, at first jarred her as with an electric shock, and then urged themselves on her with that ache belonging to a glut of confused ideas which check the flow of emotion. Forms both pale and glowing took possession of her young sense, and fixed themselves in her memory even when she was not thinking of them, preparing strange associations which remained through her after-years. Our moods are apt to bring with them images which succeed each other like the magic-lantern pictures of a doze; and in certain states of dull forlornness Dorothea all her life continued to see the vastness of St. Peter’s, the huge bronze canopy, the excited intention in the attitudes and garments of the prophets and evangelists in the mosaics above, and the red drapery which was being hung for Christmas spreading itself everywhere like a disease of the retina.
对于那些以知识的加速力量看待罗马的人来说，罗马可能仍然是世界的精神中心和解释者，这种知识将不断成长的灵魂注入到所有历史形态中，并追踪出将所有对比统一起来的压抑的转变。但让他们再设想一个历史对比：这座帝国和教皇城市的巨大破碎的启示突然冲击了一个在英国和瑞士清教主义中长大、以贫乏的新教历史和主要是手工艺术为食的女孩的观念。 -屏幕排序；一个女孩，她热情的天性将她所有的一点点知识转化为原则，将她的行动融入到他们的模型中，她的快速情感给最抽象的事物带来了快乐或痛苦的品质；一个刚刚成为妻子的女孩，由于热情地接受了未经尝试的责任，发现自己陷入了对自己个人命运的混乱关注之中。难以理解的罗马的重担可能很容易压在聪明的仙女身上，对她们来说，它构成了英外社会辉煌野餐的背景。但多萝西娅对深刻的印象却没有这样的防御能力。 废墟和长方形教堂，宫殿和巨像，坐落在肮脏的现在之中，那里所有的生命和热血似乎都陷入了与崇敬相分离的迷信的深深堕落之中；泰坦尼克号的生活虽然昏暗但又热切，凝视着墙壁和天花板，挣扎着；白色的长长的远景，大理石的眼睛似乎闪烁着来自外星世界的单调光芒：所有这些雄心勃勃的理想的巨大残骸，感性的和精神的，与呼吸健忘和堕落的迹象混淆地混合在一起，起初让她感到震惊，就像与一个电击，然后用一种属于大量混乱的想法抑制情感流动的疼痛催促自己。苍白和发光的形状占据了她年轻的感觉，即使在她没有想到它们的时候，它们也固定在她的记忆中，准备着奇怪的联想，这些联想在她的晚年中一直存在。我们的心情很容易带来一些连续出现的画面，就像打瞌睡时的幻灯图一样。在某些沉闷而孤独的状态下，多萝西娅一生不断地看到圣彼得大教堂的广阔，巨大的青铜华盖，上面马赛克中先知和福音传道者的态度和服装中的兴奋意图，以及红色的帷幔。圣诞节挂起来像视网膜疾病一样蔓延到各处。

Not that this inward amazement of Dorothea’s was anything very exceptional: many souls in their young nudity are tumbled out among incongruities and left to ‘find their feet’ among them, while their elders go about their business. Nor can I suppose that when Mrs. Casaubon is discovered in a fit of weeping six weeks after her wedding, the situation will be regarded as tragic. Some discouragement, some faintness of heart at the new real future which replaces the imaginary, is not unusual, and we do not expect people to be deeply moved by what is not unusual. That element of tragedy which lies in the very fact of frequency, has not yet wrought itself into the coarse emotion of mankind; and perhaps our frames could hardly bear much of it. If we had a keen vision and feeling of all ordinary human life, it would be like hearing the grass grow and the squirrel’s heart beat, and we should die of that roar which lies on the other side of silence. As it is, the quickest of us walk about well wadded with stupidity.
多萝西娅内心的惊讶并不是什么特别的事：许多年轻的灵魂在不协调的环境中被摔倒，在其中“找到自己的立足点”，而他们的长辈却忙着自己的事情。我也不能认为，当卡苏邦夫人在结婚六周后被发现哭泣时，情况将被视为悲剧。对于取代想象的新的现实未来，有些沮丧、有些胆怯并不罕见，我们也不指望人们会被不寻常的事情深深感动。悲剧的因素就在于频率这一事实，它还没有融入人类粗俗的情感中。也许我们的体格几乎无法承受其中的大部分。如果我们对一切普通人的生活有敏锐的洞察力和感受，就会像听到草的生长和松鼠的心跳一样，我们应该死于寂静另一边的那声咆哮。事实上，我们中走得最快的人都充满了愚蠢。

However, Dorothea was crying, and if she had been required to state the cause, she could only have done so in some such general words as I have already used: to have been driven to be more particular would have been like trying to give a history of the lights and shadows, for that new real future which was replacing the imaginary drew its material from the endless minutiae by which her view of Mr. Casaubon and her wifely relation, now that she was married to him, was gradually changing with the secret motion of a watch-hand from what it had been in her maiden dream. It was too early yet for her fully to recognize or at least admit the change, still more for her to have readjusted that devotedness which was so necessary a part of her mental life that she was almost sure sooner or later to recover it. Permanent rebellion, the disorder of a life without some loving reverent resolve, was not possible to her; but she was now in an interval when the very force of her nature heightened its confusion. In this way, the early months of marriage often are times of critical tumult—whether that of a shrimp-pool or of deeper waters—which afterwards subsides into cheerful peace.
然而，多萝西娅在哭，如果要求她说出原因，她只能用我已经用过的一些笼统的话来这样做：被迫变得更加具体就像试图给出一个光与影的历史，因为那个正在取代想象的新的真实未来从无尽的细节中汲取素材，通过这些细节，她对卡苏邦先生和她的妻子关系的看法，现在她嫁给了他，正在逐渐改变。手表指针的秘密动作，就像她少女梦中那样。对她来说，完全认识到或至少承认这种变化还为时过早，更重要的是，她已经重新调整了那种奉献精神，这种奉献精神是她精神生活的必要组成部分，她几乎肯定迟早会恢复这种奉献精神。永久的叛逆，没有某种爱的虔诚决心的生活的混乱，对她来说是不可能的。但她现在正处于一个间隙，她本性的力量加剧了她的混乱。就这样，婚姻的最初几个月往往是一段关键的骚乱时期——无论是虾池里的骚乱还是更深的水域里的骚乱——随后就会平息到愉快的平静中。

But was not Mr. Casaubon just as learned as before? Had his forms of expression changed, or his sentiments become less laudable? Oh waywardness of womanhood! did his chronology fail him, or his ability to state not only a theory but the names of those who held it; or his provision for giving the heads of any subject on demand? And was not Rome the place in all the world to give free play to such accomplishments? Besides, had not Dorothea’s enthusiasm especially dwelt on the prospect of relieving the weight and perhaps the sadness with which great tasks lie on him who has to achieve them?— And that such weight pressed on Mr. Casaubon was only plainer than before.
但卡苏邦先生不还是像以前一样博学吗？他的表达方式是否发生了变化，或者他的情感变得不那么值得称赞了？噢，女人的任性！是他的年代顺序失败了，还是他不仅没有能力陈述一种理论，而且还没有能力陈述持有该理论的人的名字？或者他根据需要提供任何主题的主题的规定？罗马不正是世界上可以自由发挥这些成就的地方吗？此外，多萝西娅的热情不是特别集中在减轻重担的前景上，也许是减轻那些必须完成这些任务的人所承受的悲伤吗？——而卡苏邦先生所承受的这种负担只是比以前更明显了。

All these are crushing questions; but whatever else remained the same, the light had changed, and you cannot find the pearly dawn at noonday. The fact is unalterable, that a fellow-mortal with whose nature you are acquainted solely through the brief entrances and exits of a few imaginative weeks called courtship, may, when seen in the continuity of married companionship, be disclosed as something better or worse than what you have preconceived, but will certainly not appear altogether the same. And it would be astonishing to find how soon the change is felt if we had no kindred changes to compare with it. To share lodgings with a brilliant dinner-companion, or to see your favorite politician in the Ministry, may bring about changes quite as rapid: in these cases too we begin by knowing little and believing much, and we sometimes end by inverting the quantities.
所有这些都是令人心碎的问题；但无论其他什么都保持不变，光线已经改变了，你找不到正午的珍珠般的黎明。事实是不可改变的，一个凡人的本性，你仅仅通过几个富有想象力的几周（称为求爱）的短暂进出而熟悉，当你从婚姻伴侣的连续性中观察时，可能会被揭露为比你更好或更坏的东西。你先入为主的想法，但肯定不会表现得完全一样。如果我们没有类似的变化与之比较，那么我们会惊讶地发现这种变化很快就会被感受到。与一位才华横溢的共进晚餐的同伴合住，或者去见见你最喜欢的部里政治家，可能会带来同样迅速的变化：在这些情况下，我们也是从知之甚少而相信很多，有时以颠倒数量而结束。

Still, such comparisons might mislead, for no man was more incapable of flashy make-believe than Mr. Casaubon: he was as genuine a character as any ruminant animal, and he had not actively assisted in creating any illusions about himself. How was it that in the weeks since her marriage, Dorothea had not distinctly observed but felt with a stifling depression, that the large vistas and wide fresh air which she had dreamed of finding in her husband’s mind were replaced by anterooms and winding passages which seemed to lead nowhither? I suppose it was that in courtship everything is regarded as provisional and preliminary, and the smallest sample of virtue or accomplishment is taken to guarantee delightful stores which the broad leisure of marriage will reveal. But the door-sill of marriage once crossed, expectation is concentrated on the present. Having once embarked on your marital voyage, it is impossible not to be aware that you make no way and that the sea is not within sight—that, in fact, you are exploring an enclosed basin.
尽管如此，这样的比较可能会产生误导，因为没有人比卡苏邦先生更不会做出浮华的虚构：他和任何反刍动物一样真实，而且他没有积极协助制造任何关于自己的幻想。结婚后的几个星期里，多萝西娅并没有清楚地观察到，但她却感到一种令人窒息的沮丧，她在丈夫心中梦想找到的广阔的景色和广阔的新鲜空气已经被前厅和蜿蜒的通道所取代，这些房间似乎无处可去？我想，在求爱过程中，一切都被视为临时的和初步的，最微小的美德或成就的样本都被用来保证婚姻的广泛闲暇所揭示的令人愉快的储备。但一旦跨过婚姻的门槛，期望就集中在当下。一旦踏上婚姻的航程，你不可能不知道自己没有前进的道路，也看不见大海——事实上，你正在探索一个封闭的盆地。

In their conversation before marriage, Mr. Casaubon had often dwelt on some explanation or questionable detail of which Dorothea did not see the bearing; but such imperfect coherence seemed due to the brokenness of their intercourse, and, supported by her faith in their future, she had listened with fervid patience to a recitation of possible arguments to be brought against Mr. Casaubon’s entirely new view of the Philistine god Dagon and other fish-deities, thinking that hereafter she should see this subject which touched him so nearly from the same high ground whence doubtless it had become so important to him. Again, the matter-of-course statement and tone of dismissal with which he treated what to her were the most stirring thoughts, was easily accounted for as belonging to the sense of haste and preoccupation in which she herself shared during their engagement. But now, since they had been in Rome, with all the depths of her emotion roused to tumultuous activity, and with life made a new problem by new elements, she had been becoming more and more aware, with a certain terror, that her mind was continually sliding into inward fits of anger and repulsion, or else into forlorn weariness. How far the judicious Hooker or any other hero of erudition would have been the same at Mr. Casaubon’s time of life, she had no means of knowing, so that he could not have the advantage of comparison; but her husband’s way of commenting on the strangely impressive objects around them had begun to affect her with a sort of mental shiver: he had perhaps the best intention of acquitting himself worthily, but only of acquitting himself. What was fresh to her mind was worn out to his; and such capacity of thought and feeling as had ever been stimulated in him by the general life of mankind had long shrunk to a sort of dried preparation, a lifeless embalmment of knowledge.
在他们婚前的谈话中，卡苏邦先生经常详述一些解释或有问题的细节，而多萝西娅却看不出其中的意义。但这种不完美的连贯性似乎是由于他们交往的中断造成的，而且，在她对他们未来的信心的支持下，她以热情的耐心聆听了对卡苏朋先生对非利士神达衮的全新观点的可能论证的背诵。和其他鱼神，认为今后她应该从同一高地看到这个几乎触动他的主题，毫无疑问，它对他来说变得如此重要。再一次，他对待她最激动人心的想法的理所当然的陈述和不屑一顾的语气，很容易被解释为属于她自己在订婚期间所共有的匆忙和全神贯注的感觉。但现在，自从他们来到了罗马，她内心深处的情感都被激起了激烈的活动，随着生活因新的因素而产生了新的问题，她越来越意识到，带着某种恐惧，她的思想不断地陷入内心的愤怒和厌恶，或者陷入绝望的疲倦。明智的胡克或任何其他博学的英雄在卡苏邦先生的一生中会在多大程度上相同，她无从得知，因此他无法获得比较的优势；但她丈夫对周围令人印象深刻的奇怪物体的评论方式已经开始让她产生一种精神上的颤抖：他也许最想表现出自己的价值，但只是表现出自己的表现。 她心目中新鲜的事物对他来说却已陈旧不堪。他的思想和感情的能力，曾经在人类的普遍生活中激发出来的，早已萎缩成一种干涸的准备，一种死气沉沉的知识防腐剂。

When he said, ‘Does this interest you, Dorothea? Shall we stay a little longer? I am ready to stay if you wish it,’—it seemed to her as if going or staying were alike dreary. Or, ‘Should you like to go to the Farnesina, Dorothea? It contains celebrated frescos designed or painted by Raphael, which most persons think it worth while to visit.’
当他说：‘多萝西娅，你对这个感兴趣吗？我们要再呆一会儿吗？如果你愿意的话，我已经准备好留下来了。”——在她看来，走或留都一样沉闷。或者，‘多萝西娅，你想去法尔内西纳吗？它包含拉斐尔设计或绘制的著名壁画，大多数人认为值得一游。

‘But do you care about them?’ was always Dorothea’s question.
“但是你关心他们吗？”这始终是多萝西娅的问题。

‘They are, I believe, highly esteemed. Some of them represent the fable of Cupid and Psyche, which is probably the romantic invention of a literary period, and cannot, I think, be reckoned as a genuine mythical product. But if you like these wall-paintings we can easily drive thither; and you ill then, I think, have seen the chief works of Raphael, any of which it were a pity to omit in a visit to Rome. He is the painter who has been held to combine the most complete grace of form with sublimity of expression. Such at least I have gathered to be the opinion of conoscenti.’
“我相信，他们非常受人尊敬。其中一些代表了丘比特和普赛克的寓言，这可能是文学时期的浪漫发明，我认为不能被视为真正的神话产物。但如果您喜欢这些壁画，我们可以轻松开车前往；我想，你一定已经看过拉斐尔的主要作品了，在访问罗马时错过其中任何一部作品都是一种遗憾。他是一位被认为将最完整的形式优雅与表现力的崇高结合起来的画家。至少我认为这是 conoscenti 的观点。

This kind of answer given in a measured official tone, as of a clergyman reading according to the rubric, did not help to justify the glories of the Eternal City, or to give her the hope that if she knew more about them the world would be joyously illuminated for her. There is hardly any contact more depressing to a young ardent creature than that of a mind in which years full of knowledge seem to have issued in a blank absence of interest or sympathy.
这种以一种有节制的官方语气给出的答案，就像一位牧师根据标题朗读的语气，无助于证明永恒之城的荣耀是正当的，也无助于给她带来希望，即如果她对它们了解得更多，世界就会变得更好。为她欢乐地照亮。对于一个热心的年轻人来说，没有什么接触比他的思想更令人沮丧的了，在他的思想中，多年的知识丰富似乎已经失去了兴趣或同情心。

On other subjects indeed Mr. Casaubon showed a tenacity of occupation and an eagerness which are usually regarded as the effect of enthusiasm, and Dorothea was anxious to follow this spontaneous direction of his thoughts, instead of being made to feel that she dragged him away from it. But she was gradually ceasing to expect with her former delightful confidence that she should see any wide opening where she followed him. Poor Mr. Casaubon himself was lost among small closets and winding stairs, and in an agitated dimness about the Cabeiri, or in an exposure of other mythologists’ ill-considered parallels, easily lost sight of any purpose which had prompted him to these labors. With his taper stuck before him he forgot the absence of windows, and in bitter manuscript remarks on other men’s notions about the solar deities, he had become indifferent to the sunlight.
在其他问题上，卡苏邦先生确实表现出了一种坚韧的专注力和一种热切的渴望，这通常被认为是热情的结果，多萝西娅急于追随他的这种自发的思想方向，而不是让他觉得她把他拖离了。它。但她逐渐不再像以前那样充满信心，认为她会在跟随他时看到任何广阔的机会。可怜的卡苏邦先生本人迷失在小壁橱和蜿蜒的楼梯中，沉浸在对卡贝里的焦躁昏暗中，或者暴露在其他神话学家考虑不周的相似之处中，很容易忘记促使他从事这些工作的任何目的。他面前插着蜡烛，他忘记了没有窗户，在手稿中对其他人关于太阳神观念的尖酸刻薄的评论中，他对阳光变得漠不关心。

These characteristics, fixed and unchangeable as bone in Mr. Casaubon, might have remained longer unfelt by Dorothea if she had been encouraged to pour forth her girlish and womanly feeling—if he would have held her hands between his and listened with the delight of tenderness and understanding to all the little histories which made up her experience, and would have given her the same sort of intimacy in return, so that the past life of each could be included in their mutual knowledge and affection—or if she could have fed her affection with those childlike caresses which are the bent of every sweet woman, who has begun by showering kisses on the hard pate of her bald doll, creating a happy soul within that woodenness from the wealth of her own love. That was Dorothea’s bent. With all her yearning to know what was afar from her and to be widely benignant, she had ardor enough for what was near, to have kissed Mr. Casaubon’s coat-sleeve, or to have caressed his shoe-latchet, if he would have made any other sign of acceptance than pronouncing her, with his unfailing propriety, to be of a most affectionate and truly feminine nature, indicating at the same time by politely reaching a chair for her that he regarded these manifestations as rather crude and startling. Having made his clerical toilet with due care in the morning, he was prepared only for those amenities of life which were suited to the well-adjusted stiff cravat of the period, and to a mind weighted with unpublished matter.
这些特征在卡苏朋先生身上像骨头一样固定不变，如果鼓励多萝西娅倾诉她的少女感和女人味——如果他能把她的双手放在他的中间，带着温柔的喜悦倾听她的声音，她可能会更长时间地感觉不到。和理解构成她经历的所有小历史，并且会给她同样的亲密感作为回报，这样每个人的过去的生活都可以包含在他们相互的知识和感情中——或者如果她可以喂养她的话孩子般的爱抚是每个可爱女人的爱好，她们从在她的秃头娃娃的硬头上亲吻开始，在她自己丰富的爱的木讷中创造一个快乐的灵魂。这就是多萝西娅的倾向。尽管她渴望了解远处的事物，并表现出广泛的仁慈，但她对近处的事物却有足够的热情，亲吻卡苏邦先生的衣袖，或者抚摸他的鞋带，如果他愿意的话除了用他一贯的礼节宣布她具有最深情和真正的女性气质之外，还有其他任何接受的迹象，同时礼貌地为她找到椅子，表明他认为这些表现相当粗鲁和令人震惊。早上，他小心翼翼地洗完办公室的厕所后，只准备了那些适合那个时期精心调整的僵硬领带和充满未发表内容的头脑的生活便利设施。

And by a sad contradiction Dorothea’s ideas and resolves seemed like melting ice floating and lost in the warm flood of which they had been but another form. She was humiliated to find herself a mere victim of feeling, as if she could know nothing except through that medium: all her strength was scattered in fits of agitation, of struggle, of despondency, and then again in visions of more complete renunciation, transforming all hard conditions into duty. Poor Dorothea! she was certainly troublesome—to herself chiefly; but this morning for the first time she had been troublesome to Mr. Casaubon.
令人悲伤的是，多萝西娅的想法和决心似乎就像融化的冰块漂浮在温暖的洪水中，而它们只是另一种形式。她感到羞辱地发现自己只是感情的受害者，仿佛除了通过这种媒介她什么都不知道：她所有的力量都分散在一阵阵的激动、挣扎、沮丧中，然后又分散在更彻底的放弃、转变的幻象中。一切艰苦条件都投入到岗位中。可怜的多萝西娅！她确实很麻烦——主要是对她自己来说。但今天早上，她第一次给卡苏邦先生带来麻烦。

She had begun, while they were taking coffee, with a determination to shake off what she inwardly called her selfishness, and turned a face all cheerful attention to her husband when he said, ‘My dear Dorothea, we must now think of all that is yet left undone, as a preliminary to our departure. I would fain have returned home earlier that we might have been at Lowick for the Christmas; but my inquiries here have been protracted beyond their anticipated period. I trust, however, that the time here has not been passed unpleasantly to you. Among the sights of Europe, that of Rome has ever been held one of the most striking and in some respects edifying. I well remember that I considered it an epoch in my life when I visited it for the first time; after the fall of Napoleon, an event which opened the Continent to travellers. Indeed I think it is one among several cities to which an extreme hyperbole has been applied— ‘See Rome and die:’ but in your case I would propose an emendation and say, See Rome as a bride, and live henceforth as a happy wife.’
当他们喝咖啡的时候，她就开始下定决心，要摆脱她内心所说的自私，当她丈夫说：“我亲爱的多萝西娅，我们现在必须考虑到这一切时，她满脸高兴地注视着他。”但尚未完成，作为我们离开的准备。我真想早点回家，这样我们就可以在洛威克过圣诞节了。但我在这里的询问已经超出了他们的预期期限。不过，我相信您在这里度过的时光并没有不愉快。在欧洲的景点中，罗马一直被认为是最引人注目、在某些方面最有启发性的景点之一。我清楚地记得，当我第一次参观它时，我认为这是我生命中的一个纪元；拿破仑垮台后，这一事件向旅行者开放了欧洲大陆。事实上，我认为它是几个被极端夸张的城市之一——“见罗马而死”：但就你的情况而言，我会提出一项修正，说：“把罗马视为新娘，从此作为幸福的妻子生活” .'

Mr. Casaubon pronounced this little speech with the most conscientious intention, blinking a little and swaying his head up and down, and concluding with a smile. He had not found marriage a rapturous state, but he had no idea of being anything else than an irreproachable husband, who would make a charming young woman as happy as she deserved to be.
卡苏邦先生以最认真的意图宣读了这段简短的演讲，他眨了眨眼睛，上下摇头，最后微笑着结束了讲话。他并不认为婚姻是一种令人欣喜若狂的状态，但他除了成为一个无可指责的丈夫之外，别无其他想法，他会让一个迷人的年轻女子得到她应得的幸福。

‘I hope you are thoroughly satisfied with our stay—I mean, with the result so far as your studies are concerned,’ said Dorothea, trying to keep her mind fixed on what most affected her husband.
“我希望你对我们的住宿感到非常满意——我的意思是，就你的学习而言，结果很满意，”多萝西娅说，试图把注意力集中在对她丈夫影响最大的事情上。

‘Yes,’ said Mr. Casaubon, with that peculiar pitch of voice which makes the word half a negative. ‘I have been led farther than I had foreseen, and various subjects for annotation have presented themselves which, though I have no direct need of them, I could not pretermit. The task, notwithstanding the assistance of my amanuensis, has been a somewhat laborious one, but your society has happily prevented me from that too continuous prosecution of thought beyond the hours of study which has been the snare of my solitary life.’
“是的，”卡苏邦先生说，他的语调很奇特，使这个词带有半否定的意味。 “我被引导得比我预想的更远，各种需要注释的主题已经出现，尽管我没有直接需要它们，但我不能预先规定。尽管有我的抄写员的帮助，这项任务还是有点费力，但你们的社会很高兴地阻止了我在学习之外持续不断地追寻思想，这一直是我孤独生活的陷阱。

‘I am very glad that my presence has made any difference to you,’ said Dorothea, who had a vivid memory of evenings in which she had supposed that Mr. Casaubon’s mind had gone too deep during the day to be able to get to the surface again. I fear there was a little temper in her reply. ‘I hope when we get to Lowick, I shall be more useful to you, and be able to enter a little more into what interests you.’
“我很高兴我的存在给你带来了任何改变，”多萝西娅说，她对那些夜晚有着清晰的记忆，在那些夜晚，她认为卡苏邦先生白天的思绪太深了，无法理解事情的真相。再次浮出水面。我担心她的回答里有一点脾气。 “我希望当我们到达洛威克时，我会对你更有用，并且能够更多地了解你感兴趣的事情。”

‘Doubtless, my dear,’ said Mr. Casaubon, with a slight bow. ‘The notes I have here made will want sifting, and you can, if you please, extract them under my direction.’
“毫无疑问，亲爱的，”卡苏邦先生微微鞠了一躬说道。 “我在这里做的笔记需要筛选，如果你愿意的话，你可以在我的指导下提取它们。”

‘And all your notes,’ said Dorothea, whose heart had already burned within her on this subject, so that now she could not help speaking with her tongue. ‘All those rows of volumes—will you not now do what you used to speak of?—will you not make up your mind what part of them you will use, and begin to write the book which will make your vast knowledge useful to the world? I will write to your dictation, or I will copy and extract what you tell me: I can be of no other use.’ Dorothea, in a most unaccountable, darkly feminine manner, ended with a slight sob and eyes full of tears.
“还有你所有的笔记，”多萝西娅说，她的心已经在这个问题上燃烧起来，所以现在她忍不住用舌头说话。 “所有这些成排的书卷——你现在不会做你以前所说的吗？——你不会决定使用其中的哪一部分，并开始写这本书，这将使你的渊博知识对人们有用吗？”世界？我会按照你的口述写信，或者我会复制并摘录你告诉我的内容：我没有其他用处。”多萝西娅以一种最不负责任、阴暗女性的方式，以轻微的抽泣和眼里充满泪水结束。

The excessive feeling manifested would alone have been highly disturbing to Mr. Casaubon, but there were other reasons why Dorothea’s words were among the most cutting and irritating to him that she could have been impelled to use. She was as blind to his inward troubles as he to hers: she had not yet learned those hidden conflicts in her husband which claim our pity. She had not yet listened patiently to his heartbeats, but only felt that her own was beating violently. In Mr. Casaubon’s ear, Dorothea’s voice gave loud emphatic iteration to those muffled suggestions of consciousness which it was possible to explain as mere fancy, the illusion of exaggerated sensitiveness: always when such suggestions are unmistakably repeated from without, they are resisted as cruel and unjust. We are angered even by the full acceptance of our humiliating confessions—how much more by hearing in hard distinct syllables from the lips of a near observer, those confused murmurs which we try to call morbid, and strive against as if they were the oncoming of numbness! And this cruel outward accuser was there in the shape of a wife—nay, of a young bride, who, instead of observing his abundant pen-scratches and amplitude of paper with the uncritical awe of an elegant-minded canary-bird, seemed to present herself as a spy watching everything with a malign power of inference. Here, towards this particular point of the compass, Mr. Casaubon had a sensitiveness to match Dorothea’s, and an equal quickness to imagine more than the fact. He had formerly observed with approbation her capacity for worshipping the right object; he now foresaw with sudden terror that this capacity might be replaced by presumption, this worship by the most exasperating of all criticism,—that which sees vaguely a great many fine ends, and has not the least notion what it costs to reach them.
仅表现出过度的感情就会让卡苏邦先生感到非常不安，但还有其他原因可以解释为什么多萝西娅的话对他来说是最尖锐和最恼人的，她不得不使用这些话。她对他内心的烦恼视而不见，就像他对她内心的烦恼视而不见一样：她还没有了解到她丈夫身上隐藏的那些需要我们怜悯的冲突。她还没有耐心听他的心跳，只感觉自己的心跳得剧烈。在卡苏邦先生的耳边，多萝西娅的声音大声强调了那些含糊不清的意识暗示，这些暗示可以被解释为纯粹的幻想，是夸大敏感的幻觉：当这些暗示毫无疑问地从外部重复出现时，它们总是被视为残酷和残酷的。不公正。甚至当我们完全接受我们羞辱性的供词时，我们也会感到愤怒——更何况是当我们听到附近观察者的嘴唇发出生硬而清晰的音节时，那些我们试图称之为病态的混乱的低语，并努力抵制它们，就好像它们是即将来临的一样。麻木！而这个残酷的外在控诉者是以妻子的形式出现的——不，是一位年轻的新娘，她没有像一只优雅的金丝雀那样不加批判地敬畏地观察他丰富的钢笔划痕和大片纸张，而是似乎将自己呈现为一名间谍，以恶意的推理能力观察着一切。在这里，卡苏邦先生对罗盘的这一特定点有着与多萝西娅相媲美的敏感度，并且同样能快速地想象出比事实更多的东西。 他以前曾赞赏地观察过她崇拜正确对象的能力。他现在突然恐惧地预见到，这种能力可能会被自以为是所取代，这种崇拜可能会被所有批评中最令人恼火的批评所取代——这种批评隐约看到了许多美好的目标，却丝毫不知道实现这些目标需要付出什么代价。

For the first time since Dorothea had known him, Mr. Casaubon’s face had a quick angry flush upon it.
自从多萝西娅认识他以来，卡苏邦先生的脸上第一次出现了愤怒的红晕。

‘My love,’ he said, with irritation reined in by propriety, ‘you may rely upon me for knowing the times and the seasons, adapted to the different stages of a work which is not to be measured by the facile conjectures of ignorant onlookers. It had been easy for me to gain a temporary effect by a mirage of baseless opinion; but it is ever the trial of the scrupulous explorer to be saluted with the impatient scorn of chatterers who attempt only the smallest achievements, being indeed equipped for no other. And it were well if all such could be admonished to discriminate judgments of which the true subject-matter lies entirely beyond their reach, from those of which the elements may be compassed by a narrow and superficial survey.’
“我的爱人，”他说，带着礼节所抑制的愤怒，“你可以相信我了解时间和季节，适应一部作品的不同阶段，这不能用无知的旁观者轻率的猜测来衡量。对我来说，毫无根据的幻想很容易获得暂时的效果。但是，对一丝不苟的探险家来说，受到那些喋喋不休的人的不耐烦的蔑视始终是一种考验，他们只尝试最小的成就，实际上没有准备好做其他事情。如果所有这些人都能够受到警告，不要做出歧视性的判断，而真正的主题完全超出了他们的能力范围，而其中的要素可以通过狭隘和肤浅的调查来涵盖，那就太好了。
