文西夫人相信罗莎蒙德能够管理好她的爸爸，这是有根据的。除了他的晚餐和他的巡游之外，文西先生虽然气势汹汹，却很少有自己的行事方式，就好像他是一名首相一样：环境的力量对他来说很容易承受不了，因为这对大多数快乐来说都是如此-热爱花色的男人；被称为“罗莎蒙德”的环境尤其具有强大的力量，因为它具有温和的持久性，正如我们所知，这种温和的持久性使白色柔软的生命物质能够在与岩石相对的情况下前进。爸爸不是一块石头：除了有时被称为习惯的交替冲动的固定性之外，他没有其他固定性，这完全不利于他在女儿订婚时采取唯一决定性的行为方针，即彻底调查利德盖特的情况，宣布自己无力提供金钱，并禁止迅速结婚或订婚时间太长。这在声明中看起来非常简单和容易；但是，在寒冷的早晨形成的令人不快的决心与早霜一样有很多条件，而且很少能在白天变暖的影响下持续下去。文西先生倾向于间接但强调地表达意见，但在这种情况下却受到了很大的限制：利德盖特是一个骄傲的人，对他进行暗示显然是不安全的，把他的帽子扔到地板上是不可能的。文西先生对他有点敬畏，有点自负地想娶罗莎蒙德，有点不愿意提出金钱问题，而他自己的地位并不有利，有点害怕在与男人对话时被打败。他比他受过更好的教育，更有教养，而且有点害怕做他女儿不喜欢的事情。先生部分 文西更喜欢扮演慷慨的主人，没有人批评他。当天早些时候，有事阻碍任何关于不利决定的正式沟通；后来有晚餐，有酒，有惠斯特，总体满意。与此同时，每一个小时都留下了一点点存款，并逐渐形成了不采取行动的最终原因，即行动太晚了。这位公认的情人晚上的大部分时间都在洛威克门度过，做爱完全不依赖于岳父的预付款，也不依赖于职业的预期收入，在文西先生的眼皮子底下进行得很顺利。年轻时的做爱——那张薄纱网！甚至它所依附的点——其微妙的交织所摆动的东西——也几乎无法被察觉：指尖的瞬间触摸，蓝色和黑色球体发出的光线的相遇，未完成的短语，脸颊和嘴唇的最轻微的变化，最轻微的颤抖。网络本身是由自发的信念和无法定义的快乐、一种生活对另一种生活的渴望、完整的愿景、无限期的信任组成的。利德盖特开始以惊人的速度从他的内心开始编织这张网，尽管他的经历应该以劳尔的戏剧结束——尽管还有医学和生物学；人们观察到，检查浸软的肌肉或盘子里的眼睛（比如圣卢西亚的眼睛），以及其他科学探究事件，与天生的迟钝或对最低级散文的强烈沉迷相比，与诗意的爱情更不相容。至于罗莎蒙德，她正沉浸在睡莲对自己更加充实的生命不断扩大的惊叹中，她也在共同的网上勤奋地旋转。 所有这一切都发生在客厅角落里，钢琴所在的地方，虽然光线很微妙，但除了费尔布拉泽先生之外，许多观察者都可以看到它的光线，就像彩虹一样。在没有正式宣布的情况下，文西小姐和利德盖特先生订婚的确定性在米德尔马契已成为普遍现象。

Aunt Bulstrode was again stirred to anxiety; but this time she addressed herself to her brother, going to the warehouse expressly to avoid Mrs. Vincy’s volatility. His replies were not satisfactory.
布尔斯特罗德姨妈再次感到焦虑。但这一次，她向哥哥求助，特意去了仓库，以避免文西夫人的情绪波动。他的答复并不令人满意。

‘Walter, you never mean to tell me that you have allowed all this to go on without inquiry into Mr. Lydgate’s prospects?’ said Mrs. Bulstrode, opening her eyes with wider gravity at her brother, who was in his peevish warehouse humor. ‘Think of this girl brought up in luxury—in too worldly a way, I am sorry to say— what will she do on a small income?’
“沃尔特，你难道不想告诉我，你在没有调查利德盖特先生的前景的情况下就让这一切继续下去吗？”布尔斯特罗德夫人说，睁大了眼睛，更加严肃地看着她的哥哥，她的哥哥正处于他暴躁的仓库幽默中。 “想想这个在奢侈环境中长大的女孩——我很遗憾地说，以一种过于世俗的方式长大——她靠着微薄的收入会做什么？”

‘Oh, confound it, Harriet I what can I do when men come into the town without any asking of mine? Did you shut your house up against Lydgate? Bulstrode has pushed him forward more than anybody. I never made any fuss about the young fellow. You should go and talk to your husband about it, not me.’
“哦，真奇怪，哈丽特，如果有人未经我的同意就闯进城里，我该怎么办？你有没有对利德盖特关闭你的房子？布尔斯特罗德比任何人都更能推动他前进。我从来没有对这个年轻人大惊小怪。你应该去和你丈夫谈谈这件事，而不是我。”

‘Well, really, Walter, how can Mr. Bulstrode be to blame? I am sure he did not wish for the engagement.’
“嗯，真的，沃尔特，布尔斯特罗德先生怎么能受到责备呢？我确信他不希望订婚。

‘Oh, if Bulstrode had not taken him by the hand, I should never have invited him.’
“哦，如果布尔斯特罗德没有握住他的手，我就不会邀请他。”

‘But you called him in to attend on Fred, and I am sure that was a mercy,’ said Mrs. Bulstrode, losing her clew in the intricacies of the subject.
“但是你叫他来照顾弗雷德，我确信这是一种仁慈，”布尔斯特罗德夫人说道，她对这个错综复杂的话题失去了理智。

‘I don’t know about mercy,’ said Mr. Vincy, testily. ‘I know I am worried more than I like with my family. I was a good brother to you, Harriet, before you married Bulstrode, and I must say he doesn’t always show that friendly spirit towards your family that might have been expected of him.’ Mr. Vincy was very little like a Jesuit, but no accomplished Jesuit could have turned a question more adroitly. Harriet had to defend her husband instead of blaming her brother, and the conversation ended at a point as far from the beginning as some recent sparring between the brothers-in-law at a vestry meeting.
“我不懂怜悯，”文西先生暴躁地说。 “我知道我对家人的担心超过了我对家人的期望。哈里特，在你嫁给布尔斯特罗德之前，我是你的好兄弟，我必须说，他并不总是对你的家人表现出人们对他所期望的友好精神。”文西先生一点也不像耶稣会士，但没有一位有成就的耶稣会士能够更巧妙地解决这个问题。哈丽特必须捍卫她的丈夫，而不是责怪她的兄弟，谈话结束时，距离开始的时间还很远，就像最近姐夫在教区会议上发生的一些争吵一样。

Mrs. Bulstrode did not repeat her brother’s complaints to her husband, but in the evening she spoke to him of Lydgate and Rosamond. He did not share her warm interest, however; and only spoke with resignation of the risks attendant on the beginning of medical practice and the desirability of prudence.
布尔斯特罗德夫人没有向丈夫重复她哥哥的抱怨，但晚上她向他谈到了利德盖特和罗莎蒙德。然而，他并不像她那样感兴趣。并且只是无奈地谈到了医疗实践开始时所伴随的风险和谨慎的必要性。

‘I am sure we are bound to pray for that thoughtless girl— brought up as she has been,’ said Mrs. Bulstrode, wishing to rouse her husband’s feelings.
“我相信我们一定要为那个没有思想的女孩祈祷——她从小就这样长大，”布尔斯特罗德夫人说，希望唤起她丈夫的感情。

‘Truly, my dear,’ said Mr. Bulstrode, assentingly. ‘Those who are not of this world can do little else to arrest the errors of the obstinately worldly. That is what we must accustom ourselves to recognize with regard to your brother’s family. I could have wished that Mr. Lydgate had not entered into such a union; but my relations with him are limited to that use of his gifts for God’s purposes which is taught us by the divine government under each dispensation.’
“确实如此，亲爱的，”布尔斯特罗德先生赞同地说。 ‘那些不属于这个世界的人无法采取任何其他措施来制止顽固的世俗之人的错误。对于你兄弟的家人，我们必须习惯于认识到这一点。我真希望利德盖特先生没有加入这样的联盟。但我与他的关系仅限于将他的恩赐用于上帝的目的，这是神圣政府在每个时代教导我们的。

Mrs. Bulstrode said no more, attributing some dissatisfaction which she felt to her own want of spirituality. She believed that her husband was one of those men whose memoirs should be written when they died.
布尔斯特罗德夫人没有再说什么，她把自己的不满归咎于自己缺乏灵性。她相信她的丈夫是那些死后应该写回忆录的人之一。

As to Lydgate himself, having been accepted, he was prepared to accept all the consequences which he believed himself to foresee with perfect clearness. Of course he must be married in a year— perhaps even in half a year. This was not what he had intended; but other schemes would not be hindered: they would simply adjust themselves anew. Marriage, of course, must be prepared for in the usual way. A house must be taken instead of the rooms he at present occupied; and Lydgate, having heard Rosamond speak with admiration of old Mrs. Bretton’s house (situated in Lowick Gate), took notice when it fell vacant after the old lady’s death, and immediately entered into treaty for it.
至于利德盖特本人，既然被接受了，他就准备好接受他相信自己能够清楚地预见到的所有后果。当然，他必须在一年内——甚至半年内——结婚。这不是他的本意。但其他计划不会受到阻碍：它们只会重新调整自己。当然，婚姻必须以通常的方式准备。必须征用一所房子，而不是他现在所住的房间；利德盖特听到罗莎蒙德对布雷顿老太太的房子（位于洛威克门）充满钦佩之情后，注意到老太太死后房子空置了，并立即为此签订了条约。

He did this in an episodic way, very much as he gave orders to his tailor for every requisite of perfect dress, without any notion of being extravagant. On the contrary, he would have despised any ostentation of expense; his profession had familiarized him with all grades of poverty, and he cared much for those who suffered hardships. He would have behaved perfectly at a table where the sauce was served in a jug with the handle off, and he would have remembered nothing about a grand dinner except that a man was there who talked well. But it had never occurred to him that he should live in any other than what he would have called an ordinary way, with green glasses for hock, and excellent waiting at table. In warming himself at French social theories he had brought away no smell of scorching. We may handle even extreme opinions with impunity while our furniture, our dinner-giving, and preference for armorial bearings in our own ease, link us indissolubly with the established order. And Lydgate’s tendency was not towards extreme opinions: he would have liked no barefooted doctrines, being particular about his boots: he was no radical in relation to anything but medical reform and the prosecution of discovery. In the rest of practical life he walked by hereditary habit; half from that personal pride and unreflecting egoism which I have already called commonness, and half from that naivete which belonged to preoccupation with favorite ideas.
他以一种间歇性的方式做到这一点，就像他向裁缝下达完美服装的每一个必需品一样，没有任何奢侈的想法。相反，他会鄙视任何炫耀的花费。他的职业使他熟悉了各种贫困程度，他非常关心那些遭受苦难的人。在餐桌上，他会表现得很完美，酱汁装在一个没有把手的壶里，他对一顿盛大的晚餐一无所知，除了那里有一个能说会道的人。但他从来没有想过，他应该过一种不同于他所谓的普通方式的生活，戴着绿色眼镜，在餐桌上做出色的服务员。在法国社会理论的熏陶下，他并没有带走任何焦灼的味道。我们甚至可以不受惩罚地处理极端的意见，而我们的家具、我们的晚餐以及我们对徽章轴承的偏好，将我们与既定秩序牢不可破地联系在一起。利德盖特的倾向并不是极端的观点：他不喜欢赤脚的学说，对他的靴子很挑剔：除了医疗改革和发现的起诉之外，他对任何事情都不激进。在余下的实际生活中，他一直遵循着遗传的习惯。一半来自于我已经称之为“普遍性”的个人骄傲和不加反思的利己主义，一半来自于对自己喜欢的想法的全神贯注的天真。

Any inward debate Lydgate had as to the consequences of this engagement which had stolen upon him, turned on the paucity of time rather than of money. Certainly, being in love and being expected continually by some one who always turned out to be prettier than memory could represent her to be, did interfere with the diligent use of spare hours which might serve some ‘plodding fellow of a German’ to make the great, imminent discovery. This was really an argument for not deferring the marriage too long, as he implied to Mr. Farebrother, one day that the Vicar came to his room with some pond-products which he wanted to examine under a better microscope than his own, and, finding Lydgate’s tableful of apparatus and specimens in confusion, said sarcastically—
利德盖特对于这次偷偷发生的订婚的后果的任何内心争论都集中在时间的缺乏而不是金钱的缺乏上。当然，恋爱中并不断被某个总是比记忆中所代表的更漂亮的人所期待，确实干扰了对业余时间的勤奋利用，而这可能有助于某些“德国人的辛勤工作”，以取得成功。伟大的、迫在眉睫的发现。这实际上是一个不要将婚姻推迟太久的理由，正如他向费雷布拉泽先生暗示的那样，有一天，牧师带着一些池塘产品来到他的房间，他想在比他自己的显微镜更好的显微镜下检查这些产品，并且，发现利德盖特桌上的仪器和标本混乱不堪，讽刺地说——

‘Eros has degenerated; he began by introducing order and harmony, and now he brings back chaos.’
‘爱欲已经退化；他一开始引入了秩序与和谐，现在又带回了混乱。”

‘Yes, at some stages,’ said Lydgate, lifting his brows and smiling, while he began to arrange his microscope. ‘But a better order will begin after.’
“是的，在某些阶段，”利德盖特扬起眉毛微笑着说道，同时开始布置他的显微镜。 “但更好的秩序将会在之后开始。”

‘Soon?’ said the Vicar.
“很快？”牧师说。

‘I hope so, really. This unsettled state of affairs uses up the time, and when one has notions in science, every moment is an opportunity. I feel sure that marriage must be the best thing for a man who wants to work steadily. He has everything at home then—no teasing with personal speculations—he can get calmness and freedom.’
“我希望如此，真的。这种不稳定的状态消耗了时间，当一个人有科学观念时，每时每刻都是一个机会。我相信，对于一个想要稳定工作的男人来说，婚姻一定是最好的事情。那时他就拥有了家里的一切——没有个人猜测的戏弄——他可以获得平静和自由。”

‘You are an enviable dog,’ said the Vicar, ‘to have such a prospect— Rosamond, calmness and freedom, all to your share. Here am I with nothing but my pipe and pond-animalcules. Now, are you ready?’
“你是一只令人羡慕的狗，”牧师说，“拥有这样的前景——罗莎蒙德，平静和自由，这一切都是你的。我现在什么都没有，除了我的烟斗和池塘里的小动物。现在，你准备好了吗？

Lydgate did not mention to the Vicar another reason he had for wishing to shorten the period of courtship. It was rather irritating to him, even with the wine of love in his veins, to be obliged to mingle so often with the family party at the Vincys’, and to enter so much into Middlemarch gossip, protracted good cheer, whist-playing, and general futility. He had to be deferential when Mr. Vincy decided questions with trenchant ignorance, especially as to those liquors which were the best inward pickle, preserving you from the effects of bad air. Mrs. Vincy’s openness and simplicity were quite unstreaked with suspicion as to the subtle offence she might give to the taste of her intended son-in-law; and altogether Lydgate had to confess to himself that he was descending a little in relation to Rosamond’s family. But that exquisite creature herself suffered in the same sort of way:— it was at least one delightful thought that in marrying her, he could give her a much-needed transplantation.
利德盖特没有向牧师提及他希望缩短求爱期的另一个原因。尽管他的血管里流淌着爱的美酒，但不得不如此频繁地参加文西家的家庭聚会，并如此频繁地参与米德尔马契的八卦，长时间的欢乐，打惠斯特，这对他来说是相当恼人的，和普遍的徒劳。当文西先生极其无知地决定问题时，他必须表现得恭敬，特别是那些酒，它们是最好的内心泡菜，可以保护你免受不良空气的影响。文西夫人的坦率和单纯，丝毫没有让人怀疑她可能会对她未来女婿的品味产生微妙的冒犯。总的来说，利德盖特不得不承认，他与罗莎蒙德一家的关系有些下降。但这个精致的生物本身也遭受着同样的痛苦：——至少有一个令人愉快的想法：在娶了她之后，他可以给她进行急需的移植手术。

‘Dear!’ he said to her one evening, in his gentlest tone, as he sat down by her and looked closely at her face—
“亲爱的！”一天晚上，他坐在她身边，仔细地看着她的脸，用最温柔的语气对她说道——

But I must first say that he had found her alone in the drawing-room, where the great old-fashioned window, almost as large as the side of the room, was opened to the summer scents of the garden at the back of the house. Her father and mother were gone to a party, and the rest were all out with the butterflies.
但我必须首先说，他发现她独自一人在客厅里，那扇老式的大窗户几乎和房间的一侧一样大，敞开着，房子后面花园里夏天的香味扑面而来。 。她的父亲和母亲去参加一个聚会，其余的人都和蝴蝶一起出去了。

‘Dear! your eyelids are red.’
'亲爱的！你的眼皮是红的。”

‘Are they?’ said Rosamond. ‘I wonder why.’ It was not in her nature to pour forth wishes or grievances. They only came forth gracefully on solicitation.
“是吗？”罗莎蒙德说。 “我不知道为什么。”倾诉愿望或委屈不是她的本性。他们只是在恳求下才优雅地出现。

‘As if you could hide it from me!’? said Lydgate, laying his hand tenderly on both of hers. ‘Don’t I see a tiny drop on one of the lashes? Things trouble you, and you don’t tell me. That is unloving.’
“好像你能瞒着我一样！”？利德盖特温柔地把手放在她的双手上说道。 “我没看到其中一根睫毛上有一滴小滴吗？有事情困扰你，你却不告诉我。那是没有爱心的。

‘Why should I tell you what you cannot alter? They are every-day things:—perhaps they have been a little worse lately.’
‘我为什么要告诉你你无法改变的事情？它们是日常生活中的事情：——也许最近情况更糟了。

‘Family annoyances. Don’t fear speaking. I guess them.’
‘家庭烦恼。不要害怕说话。我猜是他们。

‘Papa has been more irritable lately. Fred makes him angry, and this morning there was a fresh quarrel because Fred threatens to throw his whole education away, and do something quite beneath him. And besides—‘
“爸爸最近脾气比较暴躁。弗雷德让他很生气，今天早上又发生了一场新的争吵，因为弗雷德威胁要放弃他所受的全部教育，并做一些对他来说很不光彩的事情。除此之外——”

Rosamond hesitated, and her cheeks were gathering a slight flush. Lydgate had never seen her in trouble since the morning of their engagement, and he had never felt so passionately towards her as at this moment. He kissed the hesitating lips gently, as if to encourage them.
罗莎蒙德犹豫了，她的脸颊微微泛红。自从他们订婚的那天早上起，利德盖特就从来没有见过她遇到麻烦，他也从来没有像这一刻这样对她感到如此热情。他轻轻地吻了一下犹豫的嘴唇，像是在鼓励它们。

‘I feel that papa is not quite pleased about our engagement,’ Rosamond continued, almost in a whisper; ‘and he said last night that he should certainly speak to you and say it must be given up.’
“我觉得爸爸对我们订婚不太高兴，”罗莎蒙德继续说道，声音几乎是低声的。 “他昨晚说他一定要跟你谈谈，说必须放弃。”

‘Will you give it up?’ said Lydgate, with quick energy—almost angrily.
“你愿意放弃吗？”利德盖特语气急促，几乎是愤怒地说道。

‘I never give up anything that I choose to do,’ said Rosamond, recovering her calmness at the touching of this chord.
“我永远不会放弃我选择做的任何事情，”罗莎蒙德说道，在这和弦的触动下恢复了平静。

‘God bless you!’ said Lydgate, kissing her again. This constancy of purpose in the right place was adorable. He went on:—
“上帝保佑你！”利德盖特说道，再次亲吻了她。这种在正确的地方坚定不移的目标是可爱的。他接着说：-

‘It is too late now for your father to say that our engagement must be given up. You are of age, and I claim you as mine. If anything is done to make you unhappy,—that is a reason for hastening our marriage.’
“现在你父亲说必须放弃我们的婚约已经太晚了。你已经成年了，我承认你是我的。如果做了什么让你不高兴的事，那就是我们加速结婚的理由。”

An unmistakable delight shone forth from the blue eyes that met his, and the radiance seemed to light up all his future with mild sunshine. Ideal happiness (of the kind known in the Arabian Nights, in which you are invited to step from the labor and discord of the street into a paradise where everything is given to you and nothing claimed) seemed to be an affair of a few weeks’ waiting, more or less.
与他对视的蓝眼睛里闪烁着明显的喜悦，那光芒似乎用温和的阳光照亮了他的整个未来。理想的幸福（《一千零一夜》中的那种幸福，邀请你从街头的劳作和不和谐中走出来，进入天堂，那里一切都给了你，没有任何索取）似乎是几周内的事情。等待，或多或少。

‘Why should we defer it?’ he said, with ardent insistence. ‘I have taken the house now: everything else can soon be got ready— can it not? You will not mind about new clothes. Those can be bought afterwards.’
“我们为什么要推迟呢？”他热切地坚持说。 “我现在已经买下了房子：其他一切很快就能准备好——不是吗？”你不会介意新衣服。这些可以事后购买。

‘What original notions you clever men have!’ said Rosamond, dimpling with more thorough laughter than usual at this humorous incongruity. ‘This is the first time I ever heard of wedding-clothes being bought after marriage.’
“你们这些聪明人的想法多么新颖啊！”罗莎蒙德说，由于这种幽默的不协调，她笑得比平常更彻底。 “我还是第一次听说结婚后要买婚纱。”

‘But you don’t mean to say you would insist on my waiting months for the sake of clothes?’ said Lydgate, half thinking that Rosamond was tormenting him prettily, and half fearing that she really shrank from speedy marriage. ‘Remember, we are looking forward to a better sort of happiness even than this—being continually together, independent of others, and ordering our lives as we will. Come, dear, tell me how soon you can be altogether mine.’
“但你的意思不是说，为了衣服，你会坚持让我等上几个月吗？”利德盖特说道，他一半认为罗莎蒙德在巧妙地折磨他，一半担心她真的不愿尽快结婚。 “记住，我们期待着比这更好的幸福——持续在一起，独立于他人，按照我们的意愿安排我们的生活。来吧，亲爱的，告诉我多久你才能完全属于我。

There was a serious pleading in Lydgate’s tone, as if he felt that she would be injuring him by any fantastic delays. Rosamond became serious too, and slightly meditative; in fact, she was going through many intricacies of lace-edging and hosiery and petticoat-tucking, in order to give an answer that would at least be approximative.
利德盖特的语气里带着严肃的恳求，仿佛他觉得她的任何奇妙的拖延都会伤害他。罗莎蒙德也变得严肃起来，略带沉思。事实上，她正在经历许多复杂的蕾丝边、袜子和衬裙的褶皱，以便给出至少是近似的答案。

‘Six weeks would be ample—say so, Rosamond,’ insisted Lydgate, releasing her hands to put his arm gently round her.
“六个星期就足够了——说吧，罗莎蒙德，”利德盖特坚持说，松开了她的手，用手臂轻轻地搂着她。

One little hand immediately went to pat her hair, while she gave her neck a meditative turn, and then said seriously—
一只小手立即伸手拍了拍她的头发，她则扭动脖子，认真说道——

‘There would be the house-linen and the furniture to be prepared. Still, mamma could see to those while we were away.’
“还有需要准备的家用亚麻布和家具。不过，当我们不在的时候，妈妈可以照看这些。”

‘Yes, to be sure. We must be away a week or so.’
是的，当然。我们必须离开一周左右。

‘Oh, more than that!’ said Rosamond, earnestly. She was thinking of her evening dresses for the visit to Sir Godwin Lydgate’s, which she had long been secretly hoping for as a delightful employment of at least one quarter of the honeymoon, even if she deferred her introduction to the uncle who was a doctor of divinity (also a pleasing though sober kind of rank, when sustained by blood). She looked at her lover with some wondering remonstrance as she spoke, and he readily understood that she might wish to lengthen the sweet time of double solitude.
“哦，不仅如此！”罗莎蒙德认真地说。她正在考虑为拜访戈德温·利德盖特爵士而穿的晚礼服，她长期以来一直暗自希望能在蜜月中度过至少四分之一的愉快时光，即使她推迟了向戈德温·利德盖特爵士的医生叔叔的介绍。神性（当由血统维持时，也是一种令人愉快但清醒的等级）。说话时，她带着某种好奇的抗议看着她的爱人，他很容易理解她可能希望延长双重孤独的甜蜜时光。

‘Whatever you wish, my darling, when the day is fixed. But let us take a decided course, and put an end to any discomfort you may be suffering. Six weeks!—I am sure they would be ample.’
“无论你想要什么，亲爱的，当日子确定的时候。但让我们采取坚定的行动，结束你可能遭受的任何不适。六个星期！——我相信足够了。”

‘I could certainly hasten the work,’ said Rosamond. ‘Will you, then, mention it to papa?—I think it would be better to write to him.’ She blushed and looked at him as the garden flowers look at us when we walk forth happily among them in the transcendent evening light: is there not a soul beyond utterance, half nymph, half child, in those delicate petals which glow and breathe about the centres of deep color?
“我当然可以加快工作速度，”罗莎蒙德说。 “那么，你能向爸爸提起这件事吗？——我想最好写信给他。”她脸红了，看着他，就像当我们在超然的夜光下快乐地在花园里的花朵中行走时，花园里的花朵看着我们一样：在那些在深色中心周围发光和呼吸的精致花瓣中，难道没有一个无法言喻的灵魂，一半是仙女，一半是孩子吗？

He touched her ear and a little bit of neck under it with his lips, and they sat quite still for many minutes which flowed by them like a small gurgling brook with the kisses of the sun upon it. Rosamond thought that no one could be more in love than she was; and Lydgate thought that after all his wild mistakes and absurd credulity, he had found perfect womanhood—felt as If already breathed upon by exquisite wedded affection such as would be bestowed by an accomplished creature who venerated his high musings and momentous labors and would never interfere with them; who would create order in the home and accounts with still magic, yet keep her fingers ready to touch the lute and transform life into romance at any moment; who was instructed to the true womanly limit and not a hair’s- breadth beyond—docile, therefore, and ready to carry out behests which came from that limit. It was plainer now than ever that his notion of remaining much longer a bachelor had been a mistake: marriage would not be an obstruction but a furtherance. And happening the next day to accompany a patient to Brassing, he saw a dinner-service there which struck him as so exactly the right thing that he bought it at once. It saved time to do these things just when you thought of them, and Lydgate hated ugly crockery. The dinner-service in question was expensive, but that might be in the nature of dinner-services. Furnishing was necessarily expensive; but then it had to be done only once.
他用嘴唇碰触她的耳朵和耳朵下面的一小部分脖子，他们一动不动地坐了好几分钟，它们像一条潺潺的小溪流过，上面有阳光的亲吻。罗莎蒙德认为没有人比她更爱她了。利德盖特认为，在经历了所有疯狂的错误和荒谬的轻信之后，他已经找到了完美的女性气质——感觉好像已经被精致的婚姻感情所呼吸，就像一个有成就的人所赐予的，他崇敬他的崇高沉思和重大劳动，永远不会干涉跟他们;她会用魔法创造秩序和账目，同时随时准备好弹奏琵琶，将生活变成浪漫；她被教导要达到真正的女性极限，不能超出一丝一毫——因此，她很温顺，并准备好执行来自该极限的命令。现在比以往任何时候都更加清楚的是，他继续保持单身状态的想法是错误的：婚姻不会成为障碍，而是促进。第二天，他陪一位病人去布拉辛，在那里看到了一套餐具，这让他觉得非常合适，所以他立即买了它。当你想到这些事情时就做这些事情可以节省时间，而且利德盖特讨厌丑陋的陶器。所讨论的晚餐服务很昂贵，但这可能是晚餐服务的本质。家具必然很昂贵；但这样就只能进行一次。

‘It must be lovely,’ said Mrs. Vincy, when Lydgate mentioned his purchase with some descriptive touches. ‘Just what Rosy ought to have. I trust in heaven it won’t be broken!’
当利德盖特用一些描述性的方式提到他买的东西时，文西夫人说：“它一定很可爱。” ‘这正是罗西应该拥有的。我相信天堂不会被打破！”

‘One must hire servants who will not break things,’ said Lydgate. (Certainly, this was reasoning with an imperfect vision of sequences. But at that period there was no sort of reasoning which was not more or less sanctioned by men of science.)
“必须雇用不会破坏东西的仆人，”利德盖特说。 （当然，这是用不完美的序列视觉进行的推理。但在那个时期，没有一种推理不或多或少地受到科学家的认可。）

Of course it was unnecessary to defer the mention of anything to mamma, who did not readily take views that were not cheerful, and being a happy wife herself, had hardly any feeling but pride in her daughter’s marriage. But Rosamond had good reasons for suggesting to Lydgate that papa should be appealed to in writing. She prepared for the arrival of the letter by walking with her papa to the warehouse the next morning, and telling him on the way that Mr. Lydgate wished to be married soon.
当然，没有必要向妈妈提任何事情，她不会轻易接受不愉快的观点，而且她自己也是一个幸福的妻子，对女儿的婚姻除了自豪之外几乎没有任何感觉。但罗莎蒙德有充分的理由向利德盖特建议应该以书面形式向爸爸提出上诉。第二天早上，她和爸爸一起走到仓库，为这封信的到来做好了准备，并在路上告诉他利德盖特先生希望尽快结婚。

‘Nonsense, my dear!’ said Mr. Vincy. ‘What has he got to marry on? You’d much better give up the engagement. I’ve told you so pretty plainly before this. What have you had such an education for, if you are to go and marry a poor man? It’s a cruel thing for a father to see.’
“胡说，亲爱的！”文西先生说。 ‘他凭什么结婚？你最好放弃订婚。我之前已经很清楚地告诉过你了。如果你要嫁给一个穷人，你受过这样的教育是为了什么？对于一个父亲来说，看到这样的事情是一件残酷的事情。”

‘Mr. Lydgate is not poor, papa. He bought Mr. Peacock’s practice, which, they say, is worth eight or nine hundred a-year.’
'先生。利德盖特并不穷，爸爸。他买下了皮科克先生的诊所，据说每年值八九百美元。

‘Stuff and nonsense! What’s buying a practice? He might as well buy next year’s swallows. It’ll all slip through his fingers.’
'东西，废话！什么叫买练习？他不妨买明年的燕子。这一切都会从他的指缝中溜走。

‘On the contrary, papa, he will increase the practice. See how he has been called in by the Chettams and Casaubons.’
‘相反，爸爸，他会增加练习。看看他是如何被切塔姆家族和卡苏邦家族召来的。

‘I hope he knows I shan’t give anything—with this disappointment about Fred, and Parliament going to be dissolved, and machine-breaking everywhere, and an election coming on—‘
“我希望他知道我不会给予任何东西——对弗雷德的失望，议会将被解散，到处都有机器损坏，选举即将到来——”

‘Dear papa! what can that have to do with my marriage?’
‘亲爱的爸爸！这和我的婚姻有什么关系？

‘A pretty deal to do with it! We may all be ruined for what I know— the country’s in that state! Some say it’s the end of the world, and be hanged if I don’t think it looks like it! Anyhow, it’s not a time for me to be drawing money out of my business, and I should wish Lydgate to know that.’
‘这件事可真够干的！据我所知，我们可能都会被毁掉——这个国家就处于这种状态！有人说这是世界末日，如果我不这么认为，我就会被绞死！不管怎样，现在不是我从我的生意中赚钱的时候，我希望利德盖特知道这一点。

‘I am sure he expects nothing, papa. And he has such very high connections: he is sure to rise in one way or another. He is engaged in making scientific discoveries.’
“我确信他什么也没期待，爸爸。而且他拥有非常高的人脉关系：他肯定会以某种方式晋升。他致力于科学发现。

Mr. Vincy was silent.
文西先生沉默了。

‘I cannot give up my only prospect of happiness, papa Mr. Lydgate is a gentleman. I could never love any one who was not a perfect gentleman. You would not like me to go into a consumption, as Arabella Hawley did. And you know that I never change my mind.’
“我不能放弃我唯一的幸福希望，爸爸利德盖特先生是一位绅士。我永远不会爱任何一个不是完美绅士的人。你不会希望我像阿拉贝拉·霍利那样陷入肺病。你知道我永远不会改变主意。

Again papa was silent.
爸爸又沉默了。

‘Promise me, papa, that you will consent to what we wish. We shall never give each other up; and you know that you have always objected to long courtships and late marriages.’
“爸爸，请答应我，你会同意我们的愿望。我们永远不会放弃彼此；而且你知道你一直反对长时间的求爱和晚婚。

There was a little more urgency of this kind, till Mr. Vincy said, ‘Well, well, child, he must write to me first before I car answer him,’— and Rosamond was certain that she had gained her point.
这种情况有点紧迫，直到文西先生说：“好吧，好吧，孩子，在我回复他之前，他必须先写信给我，”——罗莎蒙德确信她已经明白了自己的意思。

Mr. Vincy’s answer consisted chiefly in a demand that Lydgate should insure his life—a demand immediately conceded. This was a delightfully reassuring idea supposing that Lydgate died, but in the mean time not a self-supporting idea. However, it seemed to make everything comfortable about Rosamond’s marriage; and the necessary purchases went on with much spirit. Not without prudential considerations, however. A bride (who is going to visit at a baronet’s) must have a few first-rate pocket-handkerchiefs; but beyond the absolutely necessary half-dozen, Rosamond contented herself without the very highest style of embroidery and Valenciennes. Lydgate also, finding that his sum of eight hundred pounds had been considerably reduced since he had come to Middlemarch, restrained his inclination for some plate of an old pattern which was shown to him when he went into Kibble’s establishment at Brassing to buy forks and spoons. He was too proud to act as if he presupposed that Mr. Vincy would advance money to provide furniture-; and though, since it would not be necessary to pay for everything at once, some bills would be left standing over, he did not waste time in conjecturing how much his father-in-law would give in the form of dowry, to make payment easy. He was not going to do anything extravagant, but the requisite things must be bought, and it would be bad economy to buy them of a poor quality. All these matters were by the bye. Lydgate foresaw that science and his profession were the objects he should alone pursue enthusiastically; but he could not imagine himself pursuing them in such a home as Wrench had—the doors all open, the oil-cloth worn, the children in soiled pinafores, and lunch lingering in the form of bones, black-handled knives, and willow-pattern. But Wrench had a wretched lymphatic wife who made a mummy of herself indoors in a large shawl; and he must have altogether begun with an ill-chosen domestic apparatus.
文西先生的回答主要是要求利德盖特为他的生命投保——这一要求立即得到了承认。假设利德盖特死了，这是一个令人愉快、令人安心的想法，但同时并不是一个自给自足的想法。然而，罗莎蒙德的婚姻似乎让一切都变得舒适起来。必要的采购继续进行。然而，并非没有审慎的考虑。新娘（要去拜访准男爵）必须有几条一流的手帕；但除了绝对必要的六种之外，罗莎蒙德对没有最高风格的刺绣和瓦朗谢讷感到满意。利德盖特还发现，自从他来到米德尔马奇以来，他的八百英镑已经大大减少，因此他克制了自己对一些老式盘子的兴趣，当他去布拉辛的基布尔商店购买叉子和勺子时，有人向他展示了这些盘子。 。他太骄傲了，不会表现得好像他预先假设文西先生会预付钱来提供家具一样——；虽然，由于没有必要一次性支付所有费用，所以会留下一些账单，但他并没有浪费时间去猜测他的岳父会以嫁妆的形式支付多少，以支付费用。简单的。他不会做任何奢侈的事情，但必需的东西必须买，买质量差的东西就不经济了。所有这些事情都由再见了。利德盖特预见到科学和他的职业是他应该独自热情追求的目标。但他无法想象自己会在扳手那样的家里追​​捕他们——门全开，油布破旧，孩子们穿着肮脏的围裙，午餐以骨头、黑柄刀子和柳树的形式徘徊——图案。 但扳手有一个可怜的淋巴妻子，她在室内用一条大披肩把自己变成了木乃伊；他肯定是从一个选择不当的家庭机构开始的。

Rosamond, however, was on her side much occupied with conjectures, though her quick imitative perception warned her against betraying them too crudely.
然而，罗莎蒙德站在她这一边，充满了猜测，尽管她的快速模仿感知警告她不要太粗鲁地背叛他们。

‘I shall like so much to know your family,’ she said one day, when the wedding journey was being discussed. ‘We might perhaps take a direction that would allow us to see them as we returned. Which of your uncles do you like best?’
“我非常想认识你的家人，”有一天，当她正在讨论婚礼之旅时，她说道。 “我们也许会选择一个可以让我们在返回时看到他们的方向。你最喜欢你的叔叔中的哪一个？

‘Oh,—my uncle Godwin, I think. He is a good-natured old fellow.’
“哦，我想是我的戈德温叔叔。他是一个心地善良的老家伙。

‘You were constantly at his house at Quallingham, when you were a boy, were you not? I should so like to see the old spot and everything you were used to. Does he know you are going to be married?’
“当你还是个孩子的时候，你经常去他位于奎林厄姆的家里，不是吗？我很想看看那个老地方和你习惯的一切。他知道你要结婚吗？

‘No,’ said Lydgate, carelessly, turning in his chair and rubbing his hair up.
“不，”利德盖特漫不经心地说，在椅子上转过身，揉着头发。

‘Do send him word of it, you naughty undutiful nephew. He will perhaps ask you to take me to Quallingham; and then you could show me about the grounds, and I could imagine you there when you were a boy. Remember, you see me in my home, just as it has been since I was a child. It is not fair that I should be so ignorant of yours. But perhaps you would be a little ashamed of me. I forgot that.’
‘你这顽皮不孝的侄子，一定要把这件事告诉他。他也许会请你带我去奎林厄姆；然后你可以带我参观场地，我可以想象你小时候在那里。请记住，你在我家里看到我，就像我小时候一样。我对你的事如此无知，这是不公平的。但也许你会为我感到有点羞耻。我忘记了。

Lydgate smiled at her tenderly, and really accepted the suggestion that the proud pleasure of showing so charming a bride was worth some trouble. And now he came to think of it, he would like to see the old spots with Rosamond.
利德盖特温柔地对她微笑，并真正接受了这样的建议：展示如此迷人的新娘所带来的自豪感值得一些麻烦。现在他想起来了，他想和罗莎蒙德一起去看看那些老地方。

‘I will write to him, then. But my cousins are bores.’
“那我就写信给他。但我的堂兄弟们都很无聊。

It seemed magnificent to Rosamond to be able to speak so slightingly of a baronet’s family, and she felt much contentment in the prospect of being able to estimate them contemptuously on her own account.
对罗莎蒙德来说，能够如此轻蔑地谈论一个从男爵的家庭似乎是一件了不起的事，而且她对能够以自己的名义轻蔑地评价他们感到非常满足。

But mamma was near spoiling all, a day or two later, by saying—
但一两天后，妈妈几乎毁了一切，她说——

‘I hope your uncle Sir Godwin will not look down on Rosy, Mr. Lydgate. I should think he would do something handsome. A thousand or two can be nothing to a baronet.’
“我希望你的叔叔戈德温爵士不会看不起罗西，利德盖特先生。我应该认为他会做一些帅气的事情。对于从男爵来说，一千两个根本不算什么。

‘Mamma!’ said Rosamond, blushing deeply; and Lydgate pitied her so much that he remained silent and went to the other end of the room to examine a print curiously, as if he had been absent-minded. Mamma had a little filial lecture afterwards, and was docile as usual. But Rosamond reflected that if any of those high-bred cousins who were bores, should be induced to visit Middlemarch, they would see many things in her own family which might shock them. Hence it seemed desirable that Lydgate should by-and-by get some first-rate position elsewhere than in Middlemarch; and this could hardly be difficult in the case of a man who had a titled uncle and could make discoveries. Lydgate, you perceive, had talked fervidly to Rosamond of his hopes as to the highest uses of his life, and had found it delightful to be listened to by a creature who would bring him the sweet furtherance of satisfying affection—beauty—repose—such help as our thoughts get from the summer sky and the flower-fringed meadows.
“妈妈！”罗莎蒙德说，脸涨得通红。利德盖特非常同情她，所以他保持沉默，走到房间的另一端好奇地检查印刷品，就好像他心不在焉一样。妈妈听了一番孝顺的教训后，又像往常一样温顺了。但罗莎蒙德想，如果那些令人厌烦的高教养表亲中的任何一个被引诱去拜访米德尔马契，他们会在她自己的家族中看到许多可能令他们震惊的事情。因此，利德盖特似乎应该在米德尔马契以外的其他地方获得一些一流的职位。对于一个有头衔的叔叔并且能够做出发现的人来说，这并不困难。你知道，利德盖特曾热情地向罗莎蒙德讲述他对人生最高目标的希望，并且发现被一个能给他带来满足的情感、美丽、安宁等甜美的帮助的人倾听是一件令人愉快的事。当我们的思绪来自夏日的天空和鲜花盛开的草地时，我们会得到帮助。

Lydgate relied much on the psychological difference between what for the sake of variety I will call goose and gander: especially on the innate submissiveness of the goose as beautifully corresponding to the strength of the gander.
利德盖特在很大程度上依赖于我称之为鹅和公鹅之间的心理差异：特别是鹅与生俱来的顺从，与公鹅的力量完美对应。

CHAPTER XXXVII
第三十七章

‘Thrice happy she that is so well assured
“她非常高兴，因为她如此放心

Unto herself and settled so in heart
对她自己，心里如此安定

That neither will for better be allured
两者都不会更好地被诱惑

Ne fears to worse with any chance to start,
只要有机会开始，我就担心会变得更糟，

But like a steddy ship doth strongly part
但就像一艘坚固的船一样强烈分开

The raging waves and keeps her course aright;
汹涌的海浪，让她保持正确的航向；

Ne aught for tempest doth from it depart,
暴风雨也不会离开它，

Ne aught for fairer weather’s false delight.
没有什么比晴朗的天气虚假的快乐更重要的了。

Such self-assurance need not fear the spight
有这样的自信就不用害怕别人的目光

Of grudging foes; ne favour seek of friends;
不怀好意的敌人；朋友的恩惠；

But in the stay of her own stedfast might
但在她自己坚定的力量下

Neither to one herself nor other bends.
既不向自己也不向其他人弯曲。

Most happy she that most assured doth rest,
最幸福的是她最放心地休息，

But he most happy who such one loves best.’
但这样的人最爱的人，他才是最幸福的。”

—SPENSER.
——斯宾塞。

The doubt hinted by Mr. Vincy whether it were only the general election or the end of the world that was coming on, now that George the Fourth was dead, Parliament dissolved, Wellington and Peel generally depreciated and the new King apologetic, was a feeble type of the uncertainties in provincial opinion at that time. With the glow-worm lights of country places, how could men see which were their own thoughts in the confusion of a Tory Ministry passing Liberal measures, of Tory nobles and electors being anxious to return Liberals rather than friends of the recreant Ministers, and of outcries for remedies which seemed to have a mysteriously remote bearing on private interest, and were made suspicious by the advocacy of disagreeable neighbors? Buyers of the Middlemarch newspapers found themselves in an anomalous position: during the agitation on the Catholic Question many had given up the ‘Pioneer’—which had a motto from Charles James Fox and was in the van of progress— because it had taken Peel’s side about the Papists, and had thus blotted its Liberalism with a toleration of Jesuitry and Baal; but they were illsatisfied with the ‘Trumpet,’ which—since its blasts against Rome, and in the general flaccidity of the public mind (nobody knowing who would support whom)—had become feeble in its blowing.
既然乔治四世死了，议会解散，惠灵顿和皮尔普遍贬值，新国王道歉，文西先生所暗示的怀疑是只是大选还是世界末日即将到来，这是一个无力的说法。当时省内意见的不确定性。在乡村地方的萤火虫灯光下，在保守党内阁通过自由党措施的混乱中，在保守党贵族和选民急于回归自由党而不是胆怯的部长们的朋友的情况下，人们怎么能看出哪些是他们自己的想法呢？对似乎与私人利益有着神秘而遥远的关系的补救措施的强烈呼声，并且因令人不快的邻居的倡导而受到怀疑？ 《米德尔马契》报纸的购买者发现自己处于一种反常的境地：在天主教问题引发的骚动中，许多人放弃了《先锋报》——它有查尔斯·詹姆斯·福克斯的座右铭，是进步的先锋——因为它站在了皮尔一边。关于天主教徒，并因此用对耶稣会和巴力的宽容来抹去其自由主义；但他们对“号角”并不满意，自从它向罗马发起猛烈攻击以来，由于公众思想普遍软弱（没有人知道谁会支持谁），它的吹奏已经变得无力。

It was a time, according to a noticeable article in the ‘Pioneer,’ when the crying needs of the country might well counteract a reluctance to public action on the part of men whose minds had from long experience acquired breadth as well as concentration, decision of judgment as well as tolerance, dispassionateness as well as energy— in fact, all those qualities which in the melancholy experience of mankind have been the least disposed to share lodgings.
《先锋报》上一篇引人注目的文章指出，在这个时代，国家迫切的需要很可能会抵消一些人不愿采取公共行动的态度，这些人的思想从长期的经验中获得了广度和集中度、决策力。判断力和宽容，冷静和精力——事实上，所有这些品质在人类的忧郁经历中都是最不愿意共享住宿的。

Mr. Hackbutt, whose fluent speech was at that time floating more widely than usual, and leaving much uncertainty as to its ultimate channel, was heard to say in Mr. Hawley’s office that the article in question ‘emanated’ from Brooke of Tipton, and that Brooke had secretly bought the ‘Pioneer’ some months ago.
哈克布特先生的流利演讲当时比平时传播得更广，并且其最终渠道留下了很多不确定性，有人在霍利先生的办公室里说，相关文章“出自”蒂普顿的布鲁克，并且布鲁克几个月前秘密购买了“先锋”号。

‘That means mischief, eh?’ said Mr. Hawley. ‘He’s got the freak of being a popular man now, after dangling about like a stray tortoise. So much the worse for him. I’ve had my eye on him for some time. He shall be prettily pumped upon. He’s a damned bad landlord. What business has an old county man to come currying favor with a low set of dark-blue freemen? As to his paper, I only hope he may do the writing himself. It would be worth our paying for.’
“这意味着恶作剧，是吗？”霍利先生说。 “在像迷途的乌龟一样晃来晃去之后，他现在成了一个受欢迎的人。”对他来说更糟糕。我关注他有一段时间了。他将会被漂亮地吸引。他真是个坏房东。一个老县人有什么资格来巴结一群低矮的深蓝色自由民呢？至于他的论文，我只希望他能自己写。这值得我们付出代价。

‘I understand he has got a very brilliant young fellow to edit it, who can write the highest style of leading article, quite equal to anything in the London papers. And he means to take very high ground on Reform.’
“我知道他有一个非常聪明的年轻人来编辑它，他可以写出最高风格的头条文章，与伦敦报纸上的任何文章相当。他打算在改革方面占据很高的地位。

‘Let Brooke reform his rent-roll. He’s a cursed old screw, and the buildings all over his estate are going to rack. I sup pose this young fellow is some loose fish from London.’
“让布鲁克改革他的租金登记。他是个该死的老螺丝钉，他庄园里的所有建筑物都会倒塌。我想这个年轻人是来自伦敦的一些散养的鱼。

‘His name is Ladislaw. He is said to be of foreign extraction.’
“他的名字叫拉迪斯瓦夫。据说他有外国人血统。

‘I know the sort,’ said Mr. Hawley; ‘some emissary. He’ll begin with flourishing about the Rights of Man and end with murdering a wench. That’s the style.’
“我知道那种人，”霍利先生说。 ‘某个使者。他将以大肆宣传人权开始，以谋杀一名少女结束。这就是风格。

‘You must concede that there are abuses, Hawley,’ said Mr. Hackbutt, foreseeing some political disagreement with his family lawyer. ‘I myself should never favor immoderate views—in fact I take my stand with Huskisson—but I cannot blind myself to the consideration that the non-representation of large towns—‘
“你必须承认存在虐待行为，霍利，”哈克布特先生说道，他预见到他与家庭律师之间会存在一些政治分歧。 “我本人永远不应该赞成不节制的观点——事实上，我支持赫斯基森——但我不能忽视大城市的不代表性——”

‘Large towns be damned!’ said Mr. Hawley, impatient of exposition. ‘I know a little too much about Middlemarch elections. Let ‘em quash every pocket borough to-morrow, and bring in every mushroom town in the kingdom—they’ll only increase the expense of getting into Parliament. I go upon facts.’
“去死吧，大城市！”霍利先生不耐烦地说道。 “我对米德尔马契选举了解得太多了。让他们明天就镇压每一个袖珍行政区，并占领王国里的每一个蘑菇小镇——他们只会增加进入议会的费用。我以事实为依据。

Mr. Hawley’s disgust at the notion of the ‘Pioneer’ being edited by an emissary, and of Brooke becoming actively political— as if a tortoise of desultory pursuits should protrude its small head ambitiously and become rampant—was hardly equal to the annoyance felt by some members of Mr. Brooke’s own family. The result had oozed forth gradually, like the discovery that your neighbor has set up an unpleasant kind of manufacture which will be permanently under your nostrils without legal remedy. The ‘Pioneer’ had been secretly bought even before Will Ladislaw’s arrival, the expected opportunity having offered itself in the readiness of the proprietor to part with a valuable property which did not pay; and in the interval since Mr. Brooke had written his invitation, those germinal ideas of making his mind tell upon the world at large which had been present in him from his younger years, but had hitherto lain in some obstruction, had been sprouting under cover.
霍利先生对《先锋报》由特使编辑以及布鲁克变得积极政治化的厌恶——就好像一只杂乱无章的乌龟应该雄心勃勃地伸出它的小脑袋并变得猖獗——与布鲁克先生自己的一些家庭成员。结果逐渐浮出水面，就像发现你的邻居已经建立了一种令人不快的工厂，它将永远在你的鼻孔下，没有法律补救措施。甚至在威尔·拉迪斯瓦夫到来之前，“先锋号”就已经被秘密购买了，业主准备放弃一笔尚未支付的有价值的财产，这就是预期的机会。在布鲁克先生写下邀请函之后的这段时间里，那些让他的心灵讲述整个世界的萌芽想法，从他年轻的时候就已经存在于他的心中，但迄今为止一直处于某种障碍之中，一直在掩盖下萌芽。 。

The development was much furthered by a delight in his guest which proved greater even than he had anticipated. For it seemed that Will was not only at home in all those artistic and literary subjects which Mr. Brooke had gone into at one time, but that he was strikingly ready at seizing the points of the political situation, and dealing with them in that large spirit which, aided by adequate memory, lends itself to quotation and general effectiveness of treatment.
他的客人的喜悦之情进一步推动了这一发展，事实证明这种喜悦甚至超出了他的预期。因为看起来威尔不仅对布鲁克先生曾经涉足的所有艺术和文学科目都很熟悉，而且他非常善于抓住政治局势的要点，并在大范围内处理它们。这种精神，在足够的记忆的帮助下，有助于引用和治疗的总体效果。

‘He seems to me a kind of Shelley, you know,’ Mr. Brooke took an opportunity of saying, for the gratification of Mr. Casaubon. ‘I don’t mean as to anything objectionable—laxities or atheism, or anything of that kind, you know—Ladislaw’s sentiments in every way I am sure are good—indeed, we were talking a great deal together last night. But he has the same sort of enthusiasm for liberty, freedom, emancipation—a fine thing under guidance— under guidance, you know. I think I shall be able to put him on the right tack; and I am the more pleased because he is a relation of yours, Casaubon.’
“你知道，在我看来，他有点像雪莱，”布鲁克先生趁机说道，为了让卡苏邦先生满意。 “我并不是指任何令人反感的事情——松懈或无神论，或任何类似的事情，你知道——我确信拉迪斯拉夫的观点在各方面都是好的——事实上，我们昨晚在一起谈论了很多事情。但他对自由、自由、解放有着同样的热情——在指导下是一件好事——在指导下，你知道。我想我应该能够让他走上正确的道路；我更高兴的是，因为他是你的亲戚，卡苏朋。

If the right tack implied anything more precise than the rest of Mr. Brooke’s speech, Mr. Casaubon silently hoped that it referred to some occupation at a great distance from Lowick. He had disliked Will while he helped him, but he had begun to dislike him still more now that Will had declined his help. That is the way with us when we have any uneasy jealousy in our disposition: if our talents are chiefly of the burrowing kind, our honey-sipping cousin (whom we have grave reasons for objecting to) is likely to have a secret contempt for us, and any one who admires him passes an oblique criticism on ourselves. Having the scruples of rectitude in our souls, we are above the meanness of injuring him— rather we meet all his claims on us by active benefits; and the drawing of cheeks for him, being a superiority which he must recognize, gives our bitterness a milder infusion. Now Mr. Casaubon had been deprived of that superiority (as anything more than a remembrance) in a sudden, capricious manner. His antipathy to Will did not spring from the common jealousy of a winter-worn husband: it was something deeper, bred by his lifelong claims and discontents; but Dorothea, now that she was present—Dorothea, as a young wife who herself had shown an offensive capability of criticism, necessarily gave concentration to the uneasiness which had before been vague.
如果正确的方针意味着比布鲁克先生演讲的其余部分更精确的话，卡苏邦先生默默地希望它指的是距洛伊克很远的某个职业。当威尔帮助他时，他不喜欢他，但现在威尔拒绝了他的帮助，他开始更加不喜欢他。当我们的性格中存在令人不安的嫉妒时，我们就会遇到这种情况：如果我们的才能主要是挖掘型的，那么我们的爱喝蜂蜜的表弟（我们有充分的理由反对他）很可能会暗自蔑视我们，任何钦佩他的人都会对我们自己进行间接的批评。我们灵魂中怀有正直的顾虑，因此不会卑鄙地伤害他——相反，我们会通过积极的利益来满足他对我们的所有要求；为他画下脸颊，这是他必须承认的一种优越感，使我们的痛苦更加温和。现在，卡苏邦先生的这种优越感被突然、反复无常地剥夺了（不仅仅是一种纪念）。他对威尔的反感并非源于对一个饱经严冬的丈夫普遍的嫉妒：这是一种更深层次的东西，是由他一生的主张和不满所孕育的；但是多萝西娅，既然她在场——多萝西娅，作为一个年轻的妻子，她自己也表现出了一种进攻性的批评能力，必然把注意力集中在以前模糊的不安上。

Will Ladislaw on his side felt that his dislike was flourishing at the expense of his gratitude, and spent much inward discourse in justifying the dislike. Casaubon hated him—he knew that very well; on his first entrance he could discern a bitterness in the mouth and a venom in the glance which would almost justify declaring war in spite of past benefits. He was much obliged to Casaubon in the past, but really the act of marrying this wife was a set-off against the obligation It was a question whether gratitude which refers to what is done for one’s self ought not to give way to indignation at what is done against another. And Casaubon had done a wrong to Dorothea in marrying her. A man was bound to know himself better than that, and if he chose to grow gray crunching bones in a cavern, he had no business to be luring a girl into his companionship. ‘It is the most horrible of virgin-sacrifices,’ said Will; and he painted to himself what were Dorothea’s inward sorrows as if he had been writing a choric wail. But he would never lose sight of her: he would watch over her—if he gave up everything else in life he would watch over her, and she should know that she had one slave in the world, Will had—to use Sir Thomas Browne’s phrase— a ‘passionate prodigality’ of statement both to himself and others. The simple truth was that nothing then invited him so strongly as the presence of Dorothea.
威尔·拉迪斯瓦夫则认为，他的厌恶情绪正在以牺牲他的感激之情为代价，因此他花了很多内心的话语来证明这种厌恶情绪的合理性。卡苏朋恨他——他很清楚这一点。当他第一次进来时，他就能感觉到嘴里的苦涩和眼神中的毒液，这几乎证明宣战是合理的，尽管过去有过好处。过去他对卡苏朋非常感激，但实际上娶这个妻子的行为是对义务的抵消。问题是，对自己所做的事情的感激是否不应该让位于对自己所做的事情的愤慨。是针对另一个人完成的。卡苏朋娶了多萝西娅，这对她来说是一种错误。一个男人一定比这更了解自己，如果他选择在洞穴里长出灰色的嘎吱嘎吱的骨头，他就没有理由引诱一个女孩加入他的陪伴。 “这是最可怕的处女牺牲，”威尔说。他向自己描绘了多萝西娅内心的悲伤，仿佛他在写一首合唱的哀号。但他永远不会失去她：他会照顾她——如果他放弃生活中的一切，他会照顾她，她应该知道她在世界上只有一个奴隶，威尔必须——使用托马斯·布朗爵士的奴隶短语——对自己和他人的“热情挥霍”。简单的事实是，没有什么比多萝西娅的出现更能吸引他了。

Invitations of the formal kind had been wanting, however, for Will had never been asked to go to Lowick. Mr. Brooke, indeed, confident of doing everything agreeable which Casaubon, poor fellow, was too much absorbed to think of, had arranged to bring Ladislaw to Lowick several times (not neglecting meanwhile to introduce him elsewhere on every opportunity as ‘a young relative of Casaubon’s’). And though Will had not seen Dorothea alone, their interviews had been enough to restore her former sense of young companionship with one who was cleverer than herself, yet seemed ready to be swayed by her. Poor Dorothea before her marriage had never found much room in other minds for what she cared most to say; and she had not, as we know, enjoyed her husband’s superior instruction so much as she had expected. If she spoke with any keenness of interest to Mr. Casaubon, he heard her with an air of patience as if she had given a quotation from the Delectus familiar to him from his tender years, and sometimes mentioned curtly what ancient sects or personages had held similar ideas, as if there were too much of that sort in stock already; at other times he would inform her that she was mistaken, and reassert what her remark had questioned.
然而，我们一直缺乏正式的邀请，因为威尔从未被邀请去洛威克。确实，布鲁克先生对卡索邦这个可怜的家伙全神贯注而无暇顾及的一切事情充满信心，多次安排将拉迪斯瓦夫带到洛威克（同时也不忘记利用每一个机会把他介绍到其他地方，作为“一个年轻的亲戚”）卡苏邦的”）。尽管威尔没有单独见过多萝西娅，但他们的会面足以让她恢复年轻时与一个比自己聪明但似乎准备被她左右的人的友谊。可怜的多萝西娅在结婚前从未在别人的心中找到足够的空间来表达她最想说的话；据我们所知，她并没有像她预想的那样享受丈夫的卓越指导。如果她对卡苏朋先生怀有浓厚的兴趣，他就会带着耐心地听她说话，仿佛她引用了他幼年时熟悉的《德莱克图斯》中的一段话，有时还简短地提到古代教派或人物所持有的观点。类似的想法，好像库存已经太多了；有时他会告诉她她错了，并重申她的言论所质疑的内容。

But Will Ladislaw always seemed to see more in what she said than she herself saw. Dorothea had little vanity, but she had the ardent woman’s need to rule beneficently by making the joy of another soul. Hence the mere chance of seeing Will occasionally was like a lunette opened in the wall of her prison, giving her a glimpse of the sunny air; and this pleasure began to nullify her original alarm at what her husband might think about the introduction of Will as her uncle’s guest. On this subject Mr. Casaubon had remained dumb.
但威尔·拉迪斯瓦夫从她所说的话中看到的似乎总是比她自己看到的更多。多萝西娅没有什么虚荣心，但她有一个热心女人的需要，即通过为另一个灵魂带来欢乐来进行仁慈的统治。因此，偶尔见到威尔的机会就像在她监狱的墙上开了一个半月形，让她瞥见阳光明媚的空气；这种快乐开始消除了她最初对丈夫介绍威尔作为她叔叔的客人可能有何看法的担忧。在这个问题上，卡苏邦先生一直保持沉默。

But Will wanted to talk with Dorothea alone, and was impatient of slow circumstance. However slight the terrestrial intercourse between Dante and Beatrice or Petrarch and Laura, time changes the proportion of things, and in later days it is preferable to have fewer sonnets and more conversation. Necessity excused stratagem, but stratagem was limited by the dread of offending Dorothea. He found out at last that he wanted to take a particular sketch at Lowick; and one morning when Mr. Brooke had to drive along the Lowick road on his way to the county town, Will asked to be set down with his sketch-book and camp-stool at Lowick, and without announcing himself at the Manor settled himself to sketch in a position where he must see Dorothea if she came out to walk— and he knew that she usually walked an hour in the morning.
但威尔想单独和多萝西娅谈谈，并且对缓慢的情况感到不耐烦。无论但丁和比阿特丽斯或彼特拉克和劳拉之间的尘世交往多么轻微，时间改变了事物的比例，在以后的日子里，最好少写十四行诗，多说话。出于必要，可以采取计谋，但由于害怕冒犯多萝西娅，计谋受到了限制。他最后发现他想在洛威克画一幅特别的素描。一天早上，当布鲁克先生不得不沿着洛威克路开车前往县城时，威尔要求在洛威克放下他的素描本和露营凳，并没有宣布自己在庄园里。素描的位置是，如果多萝西娅出来散步，他一定能看到她——而且他知道她通常早上散步一个小时。

But the stratagem was defeated by the weather. Clouds gathered with treacherous quickness, the rain came down, and Will was obliged to take shelter in the house. He intended, on the strength of relationship, to go into the drawing-room and wait there without being announced; and seeing his old acquaintance the butler in the hall, he said, ‘Don’t mention that I am here, Pratt; I will wait till luncheon; I know Mr. Casaubon does not like to be disturbed when he is in the library.’
但这个计谋因天气而落空。云层迅速聚集，雨倾盆而下，威尔不得不躲进屋里。凭借关系，他打算不经通知就进入客厅等候。当他看到大厅里的老熟人管家时，他说道：“普拉特，别提我在这里；我会等到午餐；我知道卡苏邦先生在图书馆时不喜欢被打扰。

‘Master is out, sir; there’s only Mrs. Casaubon in the library. I’d better tell her you’re here, sir,’ said Pratt, a red-cheeked man given to lively converse with Tantripp, and often agreeing with her that it must be dull for Madam.
“主人出去了，先生；图书馆里只有卡索邦夫人。我最好告诉她你在这里，先生。”普拉特说道，他是一个红脸颊的男人，习惯于与坦特里普进行热烈的交谈，并且经常同意她的观点，这对夫人来说一定很无聊。

‘Oh, very well; this confounded rain has hindered me from sketching,’ said Will, feeling so happy that he affected indifference with delightful ease.
'哦，很好;这场混乱的雨妨碍了我画画。”威尔说，他感到非常高兴，轻松地装出一副漠不关心的样子。

In another minute he was in the library, and Dorothea was meeting him with her sweet unconstrained smile.
又过了一分钟，他就到了图书馆，多萝西娅带着甜美、不受约束的微笑迎接他。

‘Mr. Casaubon has gone to the Archdeacon’s,’ she said, at once. ‘I don’t know whether he will be at home again long before dinner. He was uncertain how long he should be. Did you want to say anything particular to him?’
'先生。卡索邦已经去了副主教家了。”她立刻说道。 “我不知道他是否会在晚饭前很久再次回到家。他不确定自己应该待多久。你有什么特别想对他说的吗？

‘No; I came to sketch, but the rain drove me in. Else I would not have disturbed you yet. I supposed that Mr. Casaubon was here, and I know he dislikes interruption at this hour.’
'不;我是来写生的，但是雨把我赶了进去，不然我也不会打扰你了。我猜想卡苏邦先生在这里，而且我知道他不喜欢这个时候被打扰。

‘I am indebted to the rain, then. I am so glad to see you.’ Dorothea uttered these common words with the simple sincerity of an unhappy child, visited at school.
“那么，我就欠下雨了。”我很高兴见到你。”多萝西娅以一个在学校拜访的不快乐的孩子的朴素真诚说出了这些常见的话。

‘I really came for the chance of seeing you alone,’ said Will, mysteriously forced to be just as simple as she was. He could not stay to ask himself, why not? ‘I wanted to talk about things, as we did in Rome. It always makes a difference when other people are present.’
“我来真的是为了有机会单独见到你，”威尔说，神秘地被迫像她一样简单。他无法留下来问自己，为什么不呢？ “我想谈论一些事情，就像我们在罗马所做的那样。当其他人在场时，事情总是会有所不同。

‘Yes,’ said Dorothea, in her clear full tone of assent. ‘Sit down.’ She seated herself on a dark ottoman with the brown books behind her, looking in her plain dress of some thin woollen-white material, without a single ornament on her besides her wedding-ring, as if she were under a vow to be different from all other women; and Will sat down opposite her at two yards’ distance, the light falling on his bright curls and delicate but rather petulant profile, with its defiant curves of lip and chin. Each looked at the other as if they had been two flowers which had opened then and there. Dorothea for the moment forgot her husband’s mysterious irritation against Will: it seemed fresh water at her thirsty lips to speak without fear to the one person whom she had found receptive; for in looking backward through sadness she exaggerated a past solace.
“是的，”多萝西娅用她清晰、饱满的同意语气说道。 “坐下。”她坐在一张深色的脚凳上，棕色的书在她身后，她穿着一件薄薄的羊毛白色布料制成的朴素连衣裙，除了结婚戒指外，身上没有任何装饰，仿佛她穿着一身薄纱。发誓要与其他女人不同；威尔在她对面坐下，距离她两码远，光线落在他明亮的卷发和精致但相当任性的侧面上，嘴唇和下巴的曲线充满挑衅。他们彼此看着对方，仿佛他们是两朵花，就在此时此地绽放。多萝西娅一时忘记了她丈夫对威尔的神秘恼怒：她干渴的嘴唇上仿佛有淡水，毫无畏惧地与她发现的那个愿意接受的人说话；她感到很高兴。因为在悲伤中回顾过去时，她夸大了过去的安慰。

‘I have often thought that I should like to talk to you again,’ she said, immediately. ‘It seems strange to me how many things I said to you.’
“我经常想我应该再次和你谈谈，”她立即说道。 “我对你说了这么多话，我觉得很奇怪。”

‘I remember them all,’ said Will, with the unspeakable content in his soul of feeling that he was in the presence of a creature worthy to be perfectly loved. I think his own feelings at that moment were perfect, for we mortals have our divine moments, when love is satisfied in the completeness the beloved object.
“我都记得，”威尔说，他的灵魂深处感到难以言表的满足，因为他感觉自己面对的是一个值得被完全爱的生物。我认为他自己在那一刻的感受是完美的，因为我们凡人都有神圣的时刻，当爱在心爱的对象的完整性中得到满足。

‘I have tried to learn a great deal since we were in Rome,’ said Dorothea. ‘I can read Latin a little, and I am beginning to understand just a little Greek. I can help Mr. Casaubon better now. I can find out references for him and save his eyes in many ways. But it is very difficult to be learned; it seems as if people were worn out on the way to great thoughts, and can never enjoy them because they are too tired.’
“自从我们来到罗马以来，我一直努力学习很多东西，”多萝西娅说。 “我能读一点拉丁语，而且我开始懂一点希腊语。我现在可以更好地帮助卡苏邦先生了。我可以通过多种方式为他找到参考资料，挽救他的眼睛。但学起来却非常困难；似乎人们在通往伟大思想的路上已经疲惫不堪，而且永远无法享受它们，因为他们太累了。

‘If a man has a capacity for great thoughts, he is likely to overtake them before he is decrepit,’ said Will, with irrepressible quickness. But through certain sensibilities Dorothea was as quick as he, and seeing her face change, he added, immediately, ‘But it is quite true that the best minds have been sometimes overstrained in working out their ideas.’
“如果一个人有能力产生伟大的思想，他很可能会在衰老之前超越这些思想，”威尔以难以抑制的敏捷说道。但在某些方面，多萝西娅的反应速度和他一样快，看到她的脸色发生变化，他立即补充道，“但确实，最优秀的头脑有时在思考自己的想法时会过度紧张。”

‘You correct me,’ said Dorothea. ‘I expressed myself ill. I should have said that those who have great thoughts get too much worn in working them out. I used to feel about that, even when I was a little girl; and it always seemed to me that the use I should like to make of my life would be to help some one who did great works, so that his burthen might be lighter.’
“你纠正我了，”多萝西娅说。 “我表达了自己的不适。我应该说，那些有伟大想法的人在实现这些想法时会感到疲惫不堪。即使当我还是个小女孩的时候，我也曾有过这样的感觉。在我看来，我应该利用自己的生命来帮助那些做出了伟大贡献的人，这样他的负担就会减轻一些。

Dorothea was led on to this bit of autobiography without any sense of making a revelation. But she had never before said anything to Will which threw so strong a light on her marriage. He did not shrug his shoulders; and for want of that muscular outlet he thought the more irritably of beautiful lips kissing holy skulls and other emptinesses ecclesiastically enshrined. Also he had to take care that his speech should not betray that thought.
多萝西娅在没有任何揭露真相的情况下就读了这段自传。但她以前从未对威尔说过任何让她的婚姻受到如此强烈影响的话语。他没有耸肩，而是耸了耸肩。由于缺乏肌肉的出口，他认为美丽的嘴唇亲吻神圣的头骨和教会所供奉的其他空虚会更加烦躁。他还必须注意他的讲话不应该泄露这个想法。

‘But you may easily carry the help too far,’ he said, ‘and get over-wrought yourself. Are you not too much shut up? You already look paler. It would be better for Mr. Casaubon to have a secretary; he could easily get a man who would do half his work for him. It would save him more effectually, and you need only help him in lighter ways.’
“但你可能很容易把帮助做得太过分，”他说，“让自己过度劳累。”你是不是太闭嘴了？你看起来已经更苍白了。卡苏邦先生最好有一名秘书；他很容易找到一个能为他做一半工作的人。这样会更有效地救他，你只需要用更轻松的方式帮助他。

‘How can you think of that?’ said Dorothea, in a tone of earnest remonstrance. ‘I should have no happiness if I did not help him in his work. What could I do? There is no good to be done in Lowick. The only thing I desire is to help him more. And he objects to a secretary: please not to mention that again.’
“你怎么能想到这个？”多萝西娅用恳切的抗议语气说道。 “如果我不帮助他工作，我就不会有幸福。”我能做什么？在洛威克没有什么好事可做。我唯一的愿望就是能​​够帮助他更多。他还反对秘书：请不要再提这件事了。

‘Certainly not, now I know your feeling. But I have heard both Mr. Brooke and Sir James Chettam express the same wish.’
“当然不是，现在我知道你的感受了。但我听到布鲁克先生和詹姆斯·切塔姆爵士都表达了同样的愿望。

‘Yes?’ said Dorothea, ‘but they don’t understand—they want me to be a great deal on horseback, and have the garden altered and new conservatories, to fill up my days. I thought you could understand that one’s mind has other wants,’ she added, rather impatiently— ‘besides, Mr. Casaubon cannot bear to hear of a secretary.’
“是吗？”多萝西娅说，“但他们不明白——他们希望我经常骑在马背上，并改造花园和新的温室，以充实我的生活。我以为你能理解一个人的心里有其他的愿望，”她相当不耐烦地补充道，“而且，卡苏邦先生无法忍受听到秘书的事。”

‘My mistake is excusable,’ said Will. ‘In old days I used to hear Mr. Casaubon speak as if he looked forward to having a secretary. Indeed he held out the prospect of that office to me. But I turned out to be—not good enough for it.’
“我的错误是可以原谅的，”威尔说。 “以前我经常听到卡苏邦先生说话，好像他期待有一位秘书。事实上，他向我展示了担任该职位的前景。但事实证明我还不够好。

Dorothea was trying to extract out of this an excuse for her husband’s evident repulsion, as she said, with a playful smile, ‘You were not a steady worker enough.’
多萝西娅试图从中找出丈夫明显反感的借口，她俏皮地微笑着说：“你还不够稳定。”

‘No,’ said Will, shaking his head backward somewhat after the manner of a-spirited horse. And then, the old irritable demon prompting him to give another good pinch at the moth-wings of poor Mr. Casaubon’s glory, he went on, ‘And I have seen since that Mr. Casaubon does not like any one to overlook his work. and know thoroughly what he is doing. He is too doubtful—too uncertain of himself. I may not be good for much, but he dislikes me because I disagree with him.’
“不，”威尔说，像没有精神的马一样向后摇了摇头。然后，那个烦躁的老恶魔促使他再狠狠地掐一下可怜的卡苏邦先生的荣耀的飞蛾翅膀，他继续说道，“从那以后我就发现卡苏邦先生不喜欢任何人忽视他的工作。”并彻底了解他在做什么。他太怀疑了——对自己太不确定了。我可能没什么用处，但他不喜欢我，因为我不同意他的观点。

Will was not without his intentions to be always generous, but our tongues are little triggers which have usually been pulled before general intentions can be brought to bear. And it was too intolerable that Casaubon’s dislike of him should not be fairly accounted for to Dorothea. Yet when he had spoken he was rather uneasy as to the effect on her.
威尔并非没有意图总是慷慨大方，但我们的舌头就像小扳机，通常在总体意图得以实现之前就被拉动了。令人难以忍受的是，卡苏朋对他的厌恶不应该公平地告诉多萝西娅。然而，当他说话时，他对这对她的影响感到相当不安。

But Dorothea was strangely quiet—not immediately indignant, as she had been on a like occasion in Rome. And the cause lay deep. She was no longer struggling against the perception of facts, but adjusting herself to their clearest perception; and now when she looked steadily at her husband’s failure, still more at his possible consciousness of failure, she seemed to be looking along the one tract where duty became tenderness. Will’s want of reticence might have been met with more severity, if he had not already been recommended to her mercy by her husband’s dislike, which must seem hard to her till she saw better reason for it.
但多萝西娅出奇地安静——并没有像在罗马的类似场合那样立即感到愤怒。原因很深。她不再与事实的认知作斗争，而是调整自己以适应他们最清晰的认知；现在，当她坚定地注视着丈夫的失败，尤其是他可能意识到的失败时，她似乎正在沿着一条责任变成温柔的道路寻找。威尔的沉默寡言可能会受到更严厉的对待，如果他没有因为她丈夫的厌恶而被推荐给她仁慈的话，这对她来说一定很难接受，直到她找到更好的理由。

She did not answer at once, but after looking down ruminatingly she said, with some earnestness, ‘Mr. Casaubon must have overcome his dislike of you so far as his actions were concerned: and that is admirable.’
她没有立刻回答，低头沉思之后，有些认真地说道：“先生。”就卡苏朋的行为而言，他一定已经克服了对你的厌恶：这是令人钦佩的。

‘Yes; he has shown a sense of justice in family matters. It was an abominable thing that my grandmother should have been disinherited because she made what they called a mesalliance, though there was nothing to be said against her husband except that he was a Polish refugee who gave lessons for his bread.’
'是的;他在家庭事务上表现出了正义感。这是一件令人憎恶的事情，我的祖母应该被剥夺继承权，因为她做了他们所谓的“Mesalliance”，尽管没有什么可以反对她的丈夫，除了他是一个波兰难民，为他的面包而上课。

‘I wish I knew all about her!’ said Dorothea. ‘I wonder how she bore the change from wealth to poverty: I wonder whether she was happy with her husband! Do you know much about them?’
“我希望我了解她的一切！”多萝西娅说。 “我不知道她是如何承受从富裕到贫穷的转变：我不知道她和她的丈夫是否幸福！”你对他们了解很多吗？

‘No; only that my grandfather was a patriot—a bright fellow— could speak many languages—musical—got his bread by teaching all sorts of things. They both died rather early. And I never knew much of my father, beyond what my mother told me; but he inherited the musical talents. I remember his slow walk and his long thin hands; and one day remains with me when he was lying ill, and I was very hungry, and had only a little bit of bread.’
'不;只是我的祖父是一位爱国者——一个聪明的小伙子——会说多种语言——音乐——通过教授各种各样的东西来谋生。他们俩都死得很早。除了母亲告诉我的以外，我对父亲的了解并不多。但他继承了音乐天赋。我记得他缓慢的步伐和他细长的双手；有一天，他病了，我很饿，只吃了一点面包。

‘Ah, what a different life from mine!’ said Dorothea, with keen interest, clasping her hands on her lap. ‘I have always had too much of everything. But tell me how it was— Mr. Casaubon could not have known about you then.’
“啊，这与我的生活多么不同啊！”多萝西娅饶有兴趣地说，双手紧握在腿上。 “我总是对一切都吃得太多。但告诉我那是怎么回事——卡苏邦先生当时不可能知道你的事。”

‘No; but my father had made himself known to Mr. Casaubon, and that was my last hungry day. My father died soon after, and my mother and I were well taken care of. Mr. Casaubon always expressly recognized it as his duty to take care of us because of the harsh injustice which had been shown to his mother’s sister. But now I am telling you what is not new to you.’
'不;但我父亲已经向卡苏邦先生表明了自己的身份，那是我饥饿的最后一天。不久父亲就去世了，我和母亲得到了很好的照顾。卡苏邦先生总是明确地承认照顾我们是他的责任，因为他母亲的妹妹受到了严重的不公正对待。但现在我告诉你的事情对你来说并不新鲜。

In his inmost soul Will was conscious of wishing to tell Dorothea what was rather new even in his own construction of things— namely, that Mr. Casaubon had never done more than pay a debt towards him. Will was much too good a fellow to be easy under the sense of being ungrateful. And when gratitude has become a matter of reasoning there are many ways of escaping from its bonds.
在他的内心深处，威尔意识到他希望告诉多萝西娅什么是相当新的，甚至在他自己的构建中也是如此——也就是说，卡苏邦先生从来没有做过比他还债更多的事情。威尔是一个太好的人了，他不会因为忘恩负义而心存侥幸。当感恩成为一种推理问题时，就有很多方法可以摆脱它的束缚。

‘No,’ answered Dorothea; ‘Mr. Casaubon has always avoided dwelling on his own honorable actions.’ She did not feel that her husband’s conduct was depreciated; but this notion of what justice had required in his relations with Will Ladislaw took strong hold on her mind. After a moment’s pause, she added, ‘He had never told me that he supported your mother. Is she still living?’
“不，”多萝西娅回答道。 '先生。卡苏邦一直避免沉溺于自己的光荣行为。”她并不觉得她丈夫的行为受到贬低；相反，她认为丈夫的行为受到了贬低。但是，在他与威尔·拉迪斯瓦夫的关系中，正义所要求的这一观念牢牢地扎根在她的脑海里。停顿了一会儿，她补充道：“他从来没有告诉过我他支持你的母亲。”她还活着吗？

‘No; she died by an accident—a fall—four years ago. It is curious that my mother, too, ran away from her family, but not for the sake of her husband. She never would tell me anything about her family, except that she forsook them to get her own living—went on the stage, in fact. She was a dark-eyed creature, with crisp ringlets, and never seemed to be getting old. You see I come of rebellious blood on both sides,’ Will ended, smiling brightly at Dorothea, while she was still looking with serious intentness before her, like a child seeing a drama for the first time.
'不;四年前，她因一次意外坠落而去世。奇怪的是，我的母亲也逃离了家人，但并不是为了她的丈夫。她从来不会告诉我任何关于她家庭的事情，除了她为了谋生而抛弃了他们——事实上，她是为了自己的生活而走上舞台的。她是一个黑眼睛的生物，留着清爽的卷发，似乎永远不会变老。你看，我两边都有叛逆的血统。”威尔最后对多萝西娅灿烂地微笑着，而她仍然专注地看着前方，就像一个第一次看戏剧的孩子一样。

But her face, too, broke into a smile as she said, ‘That is your apology, I suppose, for having yourself been rather rebellious; I mean, to Mr. Casaubon’s wishes. You must remember that you have not done what he thought best for you. And if he dislikes you— you were speaking of dislike a little while ago—but I should rather say, if he has shown any painful feelings towards you, you must consider how sensitive he has become from the wearing effect of study. Perhaps,’ she continued, getting into a pleading tone, ‘my uncle has not told you how serious Mr. Casaubon’s illness was. It would be very petty of us who are well and can bear things, to think much of small offences from those who carry a weight of trial.’
但她的脸上也绽开了笑容，说道：“我想，这就是你为自己的叛逆而道歉的原因；”我的意思是，按照卡苏邦先生的意愿。你必须记住，你没有做他认为最适合你的事情。而如果他不喜欢你——你刚才说的是不喜欢——但我更应该说，如果他对你表现出任何痛苦的感觉，你必须考虑到他因学习的磨损而变得多么敏感。也许，”她用恳求的语气继续说道，“我叔叔没有告诉你卡苏邦先生的病有多严重。对于我们这些身体健康、能承受一切的人来说，如果对那些承受着审判重担的人的小小冒犯太过重视，那就太小气了。

‘You teach me better,’ said Will. ‘I will never grumble on that subject again.’ There was a gentleness in his tone which came from the unutterable contentment of perceiving—what Dorothea was hardly conscious of—that she was travelling into the remoteness of pure pity and loyalty towards her husband. Will was ready to adore her pity and loyalty, if she would associate himself with her in manifesting them. ‘I have really sometimes been a perverse fellow,’ he went on, ‘but I will never again, if I can help it, do or say what you would disapprove.’
“你教得更好，”威尔说。 “我再也不会在这个问题上发牢骚了。”他的语气里有一种温柔，这是因为她感到难以言喻的满足——多萝西娅几乎没有意识到——她正在走向对丈夫的纯粹怜悯和忠诚。威尔准备好崇拜她的怜悯和忠诚，如果她愿意与她一起表现出来的话。 “我有时确实是个乖僻的人，”他继续说道，“但如果可以的话，我再也不会做或说你不赞成的事情了。”

‘That is very good of you,’ said Dorothea, with another open smile. ‘I shall have a little kingdom then, where I shall give laws. But you will soon go away, out of my rule, I imagine. You will soon be tired of staying at the Grange.’
“你真是太好了，”多萝西娅说道，脸上又露出了灿烂的笑容。 “那么我将拥有一个小王国，我将在那里制定法律。但我想你很快就会离开我的统治。你很快就会厌倦呆在农庄的。

‘That is a point I wanted to mention to you—one of the reasons why I wished to speak to you alone. Mr. Brooke proposes that I should stay in this neighborhood. He has bought one of the Middlemarch newspapers, and he wishes me to conduct that, and also to help him in other ways.’
“这就是我想向你提及的一点——这也是我想单独与你交谈的原因之一。布鲁克先生建议我留在这个街区。他买了一份《米德尔马契》报纸，他希望我能帮他办这件事，并在其他方面帮助他。”

‘Would not that be a sacrifice of higher prospects for you?’ said Dorothea.
“这对你来说不是牺牲了更高的前景吗？”多萝西娅说。

‘Perhaps; but I have always been blamed for thinking of prospects, and not settling to anything. And here is something offered to me. If you would not like me to accept it, I will give it up. Otherwise I would rather stay in this part of the country than go away. I belong to nobody anywhere else.’
'也许;但我总是被指责只考虑前景，不满足任何事情。这是提供给我的东西。如果你不愿意我接受，我就放弃。否则我宁愿留在这个国家的这个地区也不愿离开。我不属于任何其他地方。

‘I should like you to stay very much,’ said Dorothea, at once, as simply and readily as she had spoken at Rome. There was not the shadow of a reason in her mind at the moment why she should not say so.
“我非常希望你留下来，”多萝西娅立即说道，就像她在罗马时所说的那样简单而轻松。此刻，她的脑海里根本就没有任何不应该这么说的理由。

‘Then I WILL stay,’ said Ladislaw, shaking his head backward, rising and going towards the window, as if to see whether the rain had ceased.
“那我就留下来，”拉迪斯瓦夫说着，向后摇了摇头，站起身来，朝窗户走去，仿佛想看看雨是否已经停了。

But the next moment, Dorothea, according to a habit which was getting continually stronger, began to reflect that her husband felt differently from herself, and she colored deeply under the double embarrassment of having expressed what might be in opposition to her husband’s feeling, and of having to suggest this opposition to Will. If is face was not turned towards her, and this made it easier to say—
但下一刻，多萝西娅按照一种越来越强烈的习惯，开始反思她丈夫的感受与自己不同，她因表达了可能与丈夫的感受相反的言论而感到深深的羞愧。不得不向威尔提出反对意见。如果他的脸没有转向她，这样就更容易说——

‘But my opinion is of little consequence on such a subject. I think you should be guided by Mr. Casaubon. I spoke without thinking of anything else than my own feeling, which has nothing to do with the real question. But it now occurs to me— perhaps Mr. Casaubon might see that the proposal was not wise. Can you not wait now and mention it to him?’
“但我的观点对这样的话题影响不大。我认为你应该接受卡苏邦先生的指导。我说话时没有考虑任何其他事情，只考虑自己的感受，这与真正的问题无关。但现在我想到——也许卡苏邦先生可能会认为这个提议并不明智。你现在不能等一下向他提起吗？

‘I can’t wait to-day,’ said Will, inwardly seared by the possibility that Mr. Casaubon would enter. ‘The rain is quite over now. I told Mr. Brooke not to call for me: I would rather walk the five miles. I shall strike across Halsell Common, and see the gleams on the wet grass. I like that.’
“我今天已经等不及了，”威尔说，卡苏邦先生可能会进来，他内心感到焦灼。 ‘雨现在已经停了。我告诉布鲁克先生不要叫我：我宁愿步行五英里。我将穿越哈塞尔公地，看到湿草地上的微光。我喜欢。'

He approached her to shake hands quite hurriedly, longing but not daring to say, ‘Don’t mention the subject to Mr. Casaubon.’ No, he dared not, could not say it. To ask her to be less simple and direct would be like breathing on the crystal that you want to see the light through. And there was always the other great dread— of himself becoming dimmed and forever ray-shorn in her eyes.
他急忙走到她跟前握手，渴望却又不敢说：“别向卡苏朋先生提这个话题。”不，他不敢，也说不出来。要求她不那么简单和直接就像在水晶上呼吸一样，你想透过水晶看到光。而且总是有另一种巨大的恐惧——他自己在她的眼中变得黯淡无光，永远被光线撕裂。

‘I wish you could have stayed,’ said Dorothea, with a touch of mournfulness, as she rose and put out her hand. She also had her thought which she did not like to express:—Will certainly ought to lose no time in consulting Mr. Casaubon’s wishes, but for her to urge this might seem an undue dictation.
“我希望你能留下来，”多萝西娅站起来伸出手，语气里带着一丝悲伤。她也有她不愿意表达的想法：——威尔当然应该不失时机地征求卡苏邦先生的意愿，但对她来说，这么要求似乎是一种不适当的命令。

So they only said ‘Good-by,’ and Will quitted the house, striking across the fields so as not to run any risk of encountering Mr. Casaubon’s carriage, which, however, did not appear at the gate until four o’clock. That was an unpropitious hour for coming home: it was too early to gain the moral support under ennui of dressing his person for dinner, and too late to undress his mind of the day’s frivolous ceremony and affairs, so as to be prepared for a good plunge into the serious business of study. On such occasions he usually threw into an easy-chair in the library, and allowed Dorothea to read the London papers to him, closing his eyes the while. To-day, however, he declined that relief, observing that he had already had too many public details urged upon him; but he spoke more cheerfully than usual, when Dorothea asked about his fatigue, and added with that air of formal effort which never forsook him even when he spoke without his waistcoat and cravat—
于是他们只说了一声“再见”，威尔就离开了家，穿过田野，以免遇到卡苏邦先生的马车，然而，卡苏邦先生的马车直到四点钟才出现在门口。这对于回家来说是一个不吉利的时刻：在为晚餐穿好衣服的倦怠中获得道义上的支持还为时过早，而要让他摆脱当天琐碎的仪式和事务的束缚，为美好的一天做好准备，又太晚了。投入到严肃的学习中。在这种情况下，他通常会在图书馆的一张安乐椅上坐下，让多萝西娅给他读伦敦报纸，同时闭上眼睛。然而今天，他拒绝了这种宽慰，因为他发现自己已经收到了太多公开细节。但当多萝西娅询问他的疲劳情况时，他的语气比平时更加​​愉快，并补充道，他的态度正式而努力，即使在他不穿背心和领带说话时，这种态度也从未放弃过——

‘I have had the gratification of meeting my former acquaintance, Dr. Spanning, to-day, and of being praised by one who is himself a worthy recipient of praise. He spoke very handsomely of my late tractate on the Egyptian Mysteries,—using, in fact, terms which it would not become me to repeat.’ In uttering the last clause, Mr. Casaubon leaned over the elbow of his chair, and swayed his head up and down, apparently as a muscular outlet instead of that recapitulation which would not have been becoming.
“今天，我很高兴见到了我以前的熟人斯潘宁博士，并受到了一位值得赞扬的人的赞扬。他非常漂亮地谈到了我最近关于埃及之谜的论文，事实上，使用了我不适合重复的术语。头部上下移动，显然是作为肌肉的出口，而不是那种本来不合适的重演。

‘I am very glad you have had that pleasure,’ said Dorothea, delighted to see her husband less weary than usual at this hour. ‘Before you came I had been regretting that you happened to be out to-day.’
“我很高兴你有这样的乐趣，”多萝西娅说道，她很高兴看到她的丈夫此时比平时没有那么疲倦。 “在你来之前，我一直很遗憾你今天正好出去了。”

‘Why so, my dear?’ said Mr. Casaubon, throwing himself backward again.
“为什么会这样，亲爱的？”卡苏邦先生说着，又向后仰了仰。

‘Because Mr. Ladislaw has been here; and he has mentioned a proposal of my uncle’s which I should like to know your opinion of.’ Her husband she felt was really concerned in this question. Even with her ignorance of the world she had a vague impression that the position offered to Will was out of keeping with his family connections, and certainly Mr. Casaubon had a claim to be consulted. He did not speak, but merely bowed.
‘因为拉迪斯瓦夫先生来过这里；他提到了我叔叔的一项提议，我想知道你的看法。”她觉得她的丈夫非常关心这个问题。尽管她对世界一无所知，但她还是有一种模糊的印象，认为提供给威尔的职位与他的家庭关系不相符，而且卡苏邦先生当然有权要求征求意见。他没有说话，只是鞠了一躬。

‘Dear uncle, you know, has many projects. It appears that he has bought one of the Middlemarch newspapers, and he has asked Mr. Ladislaw to stay in this neighborhood and conduct the paper for him, besides helping him in other ways.’
‘亲爱的叔叔，你知道，他有很多项目。看来他买了一份《米德尔马契》报纸，除了以其他方式帮助他之外，他还要求拉迪斯瓦夫先生留在这个街区，为他管理这份报纸。

Dorothea looked at her husband while she spoke, but he had at first blinked and finally closed his eyes, as if to save them; while his lips became more tense. ‘What is your opinion?’ she added, rather timidly, after a slight pause.
多萝西娅一边说话，一边看着她的丈夫，但他先是眨了眨眼，最后闭上了眼睛，仿佛要拯救他们。同时他的嘴唇也变得更加紧张。 “你的意见是什么？”稍稍停顿后，她相当胆怯地补充道。

‘Did Mr. Ladislaw come on purpose to ask my opinion?’ said Mr. Casaubon, opening his eyes narrowly with a knife-edged look at Dorothea. She was really uncomfortable on the point he inquired about, but she only became a little more serious, and her eyes did not swerve.
“拉迪斯瓦夫先生是故意来征求我的意见的吗？”卡苏邦先生说，他眯起眼睛，用刀锋般的眼神看着多萝西娅。被他问到的那点，她确实很不舒服，但只是严肃了一些，目光却没有移开。

‘No,’ she answered immediately, ‘he did not say that he came to ask your opinion. But when he mentioned the proposal, he of course expected me to tell you of it.’
“不，”她立即回答，“他并没有说他是来征求你的意见的。”但当他提到这个提议时，他当然希望我告诉你。”

Mr. Casaubon was silent.
卡苏邦先生沉默了。

‘I feared that you might feel some objection. But certainly a young man with so much talent might be very useful to my uncle— might help him to do good in a better way. And Mr. Ladislaw wishes to have some fixed occupation. He has been blamed, he says, for not seeking something of that kind, and he would like to stay in this neighborhood because no one cares for him elsewhere.’
“我担心你可能会反对。但毫无疑问，一个如此有才华的年轻人可能对我叔叔非常有用——可能会帮助他更好地做好事。拉迪斯瓦夫先生希望有一些固定的职业。他说，他因为没有寻求类似的东西而受到指责，他想留在这个社区，因为其他地方没有人关心他。

Dorothea felt that this was a consideration to soften her husband. However, he did not speak, and she presently recurred to Dr. Spanning and the Archdeacon’s breakfast. But there was no longer sunshine on these subjects.
多萝西娅觉得这是软化丈夫的考虑。然而，他没有说话，她很快又想起了斯潘宁博士和副主教的早餐。但这些话题不再有阳光。

The next morning, without Dorothea’s knowledge, Mr. Casaubon despatched the following letter, beginning ‘Dear Mr. Ladislaw’ (he had always before addressed him as ‘Will’):—
第二天早上，在多萝西娅不知情的情况下，卡苏邦先生寄出了以下信，开头是“亲爱的拉迪斯瓦夫先生”（他以前一直称呼他为“威尔”）：

‘Mrs. Casaubon informs me that a proposal has been made to you, and (according to an inference by no means stretched) has on your part been in some degree entertained, which involves your residence in this neighborhood in a capacity which I am justified in saying touches my own position in such a way as renders it not only natural and warrantable IN me when that effect is viewed under the influence of legitimate feeling, but incumbent on me when the same effect is considered in the light of my responsibilities, to state at once that your acceptance of the proposal above indicated would be highly offensive to me. That I have some claim to the exercise of a veto here, would not, I believe, be denied by any reasonable person cognizant of the relations between us: relations which, though thrown into the past by your recent procedure, are not thereby annulled in their character of determining antecedents. I will not here make reflections on any person’s judgment. It is enough for me to point out to yourself that there are certain social fitnesses and proprieties which should hinder a somewhat near relative of mine from becoming any wise conspicuous in this vicinity in a status not only much beneath my own, but associated at best with the sciolism of literary or political adventurers. At any rate, the contrary issue must exclude you from further reception at my house.
'太太。卡索邦告诉我，有人向你提出了一项建议，并且（根据绝非夸大的推论）你已经在某种程度上接受了，这涉及你在这个社区的居住，我有理由说接触我自己的立场，使得它不仅在我看来是在合法情感的影响下自然且有保证的，而且是在根据我的责任考虑相同效果时我有责任立即声明你接受上述建议将令我感到非常反感。我相信，我在这里有权行使否决权，任何了解我们之间关系的理性人士都不会否认这一点：这种关系虽然被你们最近的程序抛到了过去，但并没有因此而被废除。他们决定前因的特征。我不会在这里对任何人的判断进行反思。我只要向自己指出，某些社会适应性和礼节应该会阻碍我的一位近亲在这附近成为任何引人注目的智者，其地位不仅远低于我自己，而且最多只能与我相关。文学或政治冒险家的社会主义。无论如何，相反的问题必须排除你在我家进一步接待。

Yours faithfully,
此致，

‘EDWARD CASAUBON.’
“爱德华·卡索邦。”

Meanwhile Dorothea’s mind was innocently at work towards the further embitterment of her husband; dwelling, with a sympathy that grew to agitation, on what Will had told her about his parents and grandparents. Any private hours in her day were usually spent in her blue-green boudoir, and she had come to be very fond of its pallid quaintness. Nothing had been outwardly altered there; but while the summer had gradually advanced over the western fields beyond the avenue of elms, the bare room had gathered within it those memories of an inward life which fill the air as with a cloud of good or had angels, the invisible yet active forms of our spiritual triumphs or our spiritual falls. She had been so used to struggle for and to find resolve in looking along the avenue towards the arch of western light that the vision itself had gained a communicating power. Even the pale stag seemed to have reminding glances and to mean mutely, ‘Yes, we know.’ And the group of delicately touched miniatures had made an audience as of beings no longer disturbed about their own earthly lot, but still humanly interested. Especially the mysterious ‘Aunt Julia’ about whom Dorothea had never found it easy to question her husband.
与此同时，多萝西娅的心思天真地在使她丈夫更加痛苦。怀着一种逐渐变得激动的同情，回想起威尔告诉她的有关他父母和祖父母的事情。她一天中的任何私人时间通常都是在她蓝绿色的闺房里度过的，她非常喜欢它苍白的古朴。那里的表面没有任何改变；但是，当夏天逐渐降临到榆树大道之外的西边田野时，空荡荡的房间里却聚集了一些关于内心生活的记忆，这些记忆充满在空气中，就像一朵善良的云彩或天使一样，是看不见的但活跃的形式。我们精神上的胜利或精神上的堕落。她已经习惯了沿着大道向西边的光拱门望去，为之奋斗并找到决心，以至于视觉本身已经获得了沟通的力量。就连苍白的雄鹿似乎也有提醒的目光，无声地表示：“是的，我们知道。”而这组精致的微缩模型让观众不再为自己的尘世命运而烦恼，但仍然对人类感兴趣。尤其是神秘的“朱莉娅姨妈”，多萝西娅从来不觉得向她的丈夫提出质疑是件容易的事。

And now, since her conversation with Will, many fresh images had gathered round that Aunt Julia who was Will’s grandmother; the presence of that delicate miniature, so like a living face that she knew, helping to concentrate her feelings. What a wrong, to cut off the girl from the family protection and inheritance only because she had chosen a man who was poor! Dorothea, early troubling her elders with questions about the facts around her, had wrought herself into some independent clearness as to the historical, political reasons why eldest sons had superior rights, and why land should be entailed: those reasons, impressing her with a certain awe, might be weightier than she knew, but here was a question of ties which left them uninfringed. Here was a daughter whose child— even according to the ordinary aping of aristocratic institutions by people who are no more aristocratic than retired grocers, and who have no more land to ‘keep together’ than a lawn and a paddock— would have a prior claim. Was inheritance a question of liking or of responsibility? All the energy of Dorothea’s nature went on the side of responsibility—the fulfilment of claims founded on our own deeds, such as marriage and parentage.
现在，自从她和威尔谈话以来，许多新鲜的景象都聚集在威尔的祖母朱莉娅阿姨周围。那个精致的微型模型的存在，就像她认识的一张活生生的脸，有助于集中她的感情。仅仅因为她选择了一个贫穷的男人，就剥夺了她的家庭保护和继承权，这是多么错误的事情啊！多萝西娅很早就对周围的事实提出了一些问题，让长辈们感到困扰，她对长子拥有优越权利以及土地为何应继承的历史和政治原因有一定的独立清晰性：这些原因给她留下了一定的印象。敬畏，可能比她想象的更重要，但这是一个使他们不受侵犯的纽带问题。这是一个女儿，她的孩子——即使按照那些并不比退休杂货商更贵族的人对贵族机构的普通模仿，而且他们没有比草坪和围场更多的土地来“维持”在一起——也会有优先权。继承是喜好问题还是责任问题？多萝西娅天性中的所有能量都集中在责任方面——履行基于我们自己行为的要求，例如婚姻和父母身份。

It was true, she said to herself, that Mr. Casaubon had a debt to the Ladislaws—that he had to pay back what the Ladislaws had been wronged of. And now she began to think of her husband’s will, which had been made at the time of their marriage, leaving the bulk of his property to her, with proviso in case of her having children. That ought to be altered; and no time ought to be lost. This very question which had just arisen about Will Ladislaw’s occupation, was the occasion for placing things on a new, right footing. Her husband, she felt sure, according to all his previous conduct, would be ready to take the just view, if she proposed it—she, in whose interest an unfair concentration of the property had been urged. His sense of right had surmounted and would continue to surmount anything that might be called antipathy. She suspected that her uncle’s scheme was disapproved by Mr. Casaubon, and this made it seem all the more opportune that a fresh understanding should be begun, so that instead of Will’s starting penniless and accepting the first function that offered itself, he should find himself in possession of a rightful income which should be paid by her husband during his life, and, by an immediate alteration of the will, should be secured at his death. The vision of all this as what ought to be done seemed to Dorothea like a sudden letting in of daylight, waking her from her previous stupidity and incurious self-absorbed ignorance about her husband’s relation to others. Will Ladislaw had refused Mr. Casaubon’s future aid on a ground that no longer appeared right to her; and Mr. Casaubon had never himself seen fully what was the claim upon him. ‘But he will!’ said Dorothea. ‘The great strength of his character lies here. And what are we doing with our money? We make no use of half of our income. My own money buys me nothing but an uneasy conscience.’
她对自己说，卡苏邦先生确实欠拉迪斯瓦夫一家人情，他必须偿还拉迪斯瓦夫一家所受的冤屈。现在她开始想到她丈夫在结婚时立下的遗嘱，将他的大部分财产留给她，但前提是她生孩子。这一点应该改变；不应该浪费时间。刚刚出现的关于威尔·拉迪斯瓦夫职业的这个问题，正是让事情重新站稳脚跟的契机。她确信，根据她丈夫以前的所有行为，如果她提出的话，他会准备采取公正的观点——为了她的利益，有人敦促她不公平地集中财产。他的正义感已经超越并将继续超越任何可能被称为反感的东西。她怀疑她叔叔的计划遭到了卡苏邦先生的反对，这使得开始一种新的理解似乎更加合适，这样威尔就不会一文不名地开始接受自己提供的第一个职能，而是应该发现自己拥有应由其丈夫生前支付的合法收入，并且通过立即改变遗嘱，应在他去世时得到保障。对多萝西娅来说，所有这一切都是应该做的事情，就像突然的阳光照进来一样，把她从以前的愚蠢和对丈夫与他人关系的冷漠自私的无知中唤醒。威尔·拉迪斯瓦夫拒绝了卡苏邦先生未来的援助，理由在她看来不再合适。卡苏邦先生自己从来没有完全了解过他的要求是什么。 “但他会的！”多萝西娅说。 ‘他性格的伟大力量就在这里。我们用我们的钱做什么？ 我们一半的收入都没有使用。我自己的钱除了给我带来不安的良心之外什么也买不到。’

There was a peculiar fascination for Dorothea in this division of property intended for herself, and always regarded by her as excessive. She was blind, you see, to many things obvious to others— likely to tread in the wrong places, as Celia had warned her; yet her blindness to whatever did not lie in her own pure purpose carried her safely by the side of precipices where vision would have been perilous with fear.
多萝西娅对这种为她自己分配财产有一种特殊的迷恋，她总是认为这种分配太过分了。你看，她对许多对其他人来说显而易见的事情视而不见——可能会踏入错误的地方，正如西莉亚警告她的那样；然而，她对一切不属于她纯粹目的的事物的盲目性使她安全地走到了悬崖边，在那里，视力会因为恐惧而变得危险。

The thoughts which had gathered vividness in the solitude of her boudoir occupied her incessantly through the day on which Mr. Casaubon had sent his letter to Will. Everything seemed hindrance to her till she could find an opportunity of opening her heart to her husband. To his preoccupied mind all subjects were to be approached gently, and she had never since his illness lost from her consciousness the dread of agitating him. Bat when young ardor is set brooding over the conception of a prompt deed, the deed itself seems to start forth with independent life, mastering ideal obstacles. The day passed in a sombre fashion, not unusual, though Mr. Casaubon was perhaps unusually silent; but there were hours of the night which might be counted on as opportunities of conversation; for Dorothea, when aware of her husband’s sleeplessness, had established a habit of rising, lighting a candle, and reading him to sleep again.
