‘But that is what the country wants,’-said Will. ‘Else there would be no meaning in political unions or any other movement that knows what it’s about. It wants to have a House of Commons which is not weighted with nominees of the landed class, but with representatives of the other interests. And as to contending for a reform short of that, it is like asking for a bit of an avalanche which has already begun to thunder.’
“但这就是国家想要的，”威尔说。 “否则政治联盟或任何其他知道其含义的运动就没有任何意义。它希望下议院的权重不在于地主阶级的提名，而在于其他利益集团的代表。至于争取不到这一点的改革，这就像是要求一场已经开始轰鸣的雪崩。

‘That is fine, Ladislaw: that is the way to put it. Write that down, now. We must begin to get documents about the feeling of the country, as well as the machine-breaking and general distress.’
“很好，拉迪斯瓦夫：就是这样说的。现在把它写下来。我们必须开始获取有关这个国家的感受以及机器故障和普遍困境的文件。

‘As to documents,’ said Will, ‘a two-inch card will hold plenty. A few rows of figures are enough to deduce misery from, and a few more will show the rate at which the political determination of the people is growing.’
“至于文件，”威尔说，“一张两英寸的卡片就足够了。”几行数字就足以推断出苦难，再多几行数字就能显示出人民政治决心的增长速度。”

‘Good: draw that out a little more at length, Ladislaw. That is an idea, now: write it out in the ‘Pioneer.’ Put the figures and deduce the misery, you know; and put the other figures and deduce— and so on. You have a way of putting things. Burke, now:—when I think of Burke, I can’t help wishing somebody had a pocket-borough to give you, Ladislaw. You’d never get elected, you know. And we shall always want talent in the House: reform as we will, we shall always want talent. That avalanche and the thunder, now, was really a little like Burke. I want that sort of thing—not ideas, you know, but a way of putting them.’
“好：拉迪斯瓦，再详细一点。”现在，这是一个想法：把它写在《先锋报》上。你知道，放上数字并推断出痛苦；然后输入其他数字并进行推断——等等。你有办法放置东西。伯克，现在：——当我想到伯克时，我情不自禁地希望有人能给你一个小型行政区，拉迪斯瓦夫。你知道，你永远不会当选。我们将永远需要众议院的人才：无论我们如何改革，我们都将永远需要人才。那个雪崩和雷霆，现在看来，真的有点像伯克。我想要那种东西——不是想法，你知道，而是一种表达它们的方式。

‘Pocket-boroughs would be a fine thing,’ said Ladislaw, ‘if they were always in the right pocket, and there were always a Burke at hand.’
“袖珍行政区将是一件好事，”拉迪斯瓦夫说，“如果它们总是在正确的口袋里，并且总是有一个伯克在手边。”

Will was not displeased with that complimentary comparison, even from Mr. Brooke; for it is a little too trying to human flesh to be conscious of expressing one’s self better than others and never to have it noticed, and in the general dearth of admiration for the right thing, even a chance bray of applause falling exactly in time is rather fortifying. Will felt that his literary refinements were usually beyond the limits of Middlemarch perception; nevertheless, he was beginning thoroughly to like the work of which when he began he had said to himself rather languidly, ‘Why not?’—and he studied the political situation with as ardent an interest as he had ever given to poetic metres or mediaevalism. It is undeniable that but for the desire to be where Dorothea was, and perhaps the want of knowing what else to do, Will would not at this time have been meditating on the needs of the English people or criticising English statesmanship: he would probably have been rambling in Italy sketching plans for several dramas, trying prose and finding it too jejune, trying verse and finding it too artificial, beginning to copy ‘bits’ from old pictures, leaving off because they were ‘no good,’ and observing that, after all, self-culture was the principal point; while in politics he would have been sympathizing warmly with liberty and progress in general. Our sense of duty must often wait for some work which shall take the place of dilettanteism and make us feel that the quality of our action is not a matter of indifference.
威尔对这种恭维的比较并没有感到不满，即使是布鲁克先生的比较。因为对于人类来说，意识到自己比别人更好地表达自己却又不被注意到，这有点太费劲了，而且在普遍缺乏对正确事物的钦佩的情况下，即使是偶然的一声掌声恰好及时落下，也是如此。比较强化。威尔觉得他的文学修养通常超出了米德尔马奇的感知范围。然而，他开始彻底喜欢这部作品，当他开始创作时，他相当懒洋洋地对自己说：“为什么不呢？”——他以对诗律或中世纪主义的热情来研究政治局势。 。不可否认的是，如果不是因为渴望去多萝西娅所在的地方，也许是想知道还能做什么，威尔此时就不会思考英国人民的需求或批评英国的政治家风范：他可能会在意大利闲逛，为几部戏剧草拟计划，尝试散文，发现它太空洞，尝试诗歌，发现它太做作，开始复制旧照片中的“片段”，因为它们“不好”而放弃，并观察到，毕竟，自我修养才是重点。而在政治上，他会热烈地支持自由和进步。我们的责任感往往必须等待某种工作来取代业余爱好，并使我们感到我们的行动质量并非无关紧要。

Ladislaw had now accepted his bit of work, though it was not that indeterminate loftiest thing which he had once dreamed of as alone worthy of continuous effort. His nature warmed easily in the presence of subjects which were visibly mixed with life and action, and the easily stirred rebellion in him helped the glow of public spirit. In spite of Mr. Casaubon and the banishment from Lowick, he was rather happy; getting a great deal of fresh knowledge in a vivid way and for practical purposes, and making the ‘Pioneer’ celebrated as far as Brassing (never mind the smallness of the area; the writing was not worse than much that reaches the four corners of the earth).
拉迪斯瓦夫现在已经接受了他的一份工作，尽管这并不是他曾经梦想过的那种不确定的、值得持续努力的最崇高的事情。他的天性在明显与生活和行动混合在一起的主题面前很容易变得温暖，他内心容易激起的叛逆有助于激发公共精神。尽管有卡苏邦先生和被逐出洛威克，他还是相当高兴。以生动、实用的方式获得大量新鲜知识，使“先锋”的名声远至黄铜（别说面积小了；写得并不比写到书的四个角差）地球）。

Mr. Brooke was occasionally irritating; but Will’s impatience was relieved by the division of his time between visits to the Grange and retreats to his Middlemarch lodgings, which gave variety to his life.
布鲁克先生有时很烦人。但威尔的不耐烦情绪因他将时间分为参观农庄和撤退到米德尔马契的住处而缓解，这使他的生活变得丰富多彩。

‘Shift the pegs a little,’ he said to himself, ‘and Mr. Brooke might be in the Cabinet, while I was Under-Secretary. That is the common order of things: the little waves make the large ones and are of the same pattern. I am better here than in the sort of life Mr. Casaubon would have trained me for, where the doing would be all laid down by a precedent too rigid for me to react upon. I don’t care for prestige or high pay.’
“稍微移动一下钉子，”他对自己说，“布鲁克先生可能会进入内阁，而我是副国务卿。”这是事物的共同规律：小波浪形成大波浪，并且具有相同的模式。我在这里比卡苏邦先生训练我的那种生活要好，在那里，所有的行为都由一个过于严格的先例所规定，我无法做出反应。我不关心声望或高薪。

As Lydgate had said of him, he was a sort of gypsy, rather enjoying the sense of belonging to no class; he had a feeling of romance in his position, and a pleasant consciousness of creating a little surprise wherever he went. That sort of enjoyment had been disturbed when he had felt some new distance between himself and Dorothea in their accidental meeting at Lydgate’s, and his irritation had gone out towards Mr. Casaubon, who had declared beforehand that Will would lose caste. ‘I never had any caste,’ he would have said, if that prophecy had been uttered to him, and the quick blood would have come and gone like breath in his transparent skin. But it is one thing to like defiance, and another thing to like its consequences.
正如利德盖特所说，他是一个吉普赛人，很享受不属于任何阶级的感觉；他在自己的位置上有一种浪漫的感觉，并且有一种愉快的意识，无论走到哪里都会制造一点惊喜。当他和多萝西娅在利德盖特的偶然相遇中感到自己和多萝西娅之间出现了一些新的距离时，这种享受就被扰乱了，他的愤怒转向了卡苏邦先生，因为他事先宣布威尔将失去种姓。如果这个预言是对他说的，他会说：“我从来没有任何种姓。”而快速的血液就会像呼吸一样在他透明的皮肤上来来去去。但喜欢反抗是一回事，喜欢它的后果又是另一回事。

Meanwhile, the town opinion about the new editor of the ‘Pioneer’ was tending to confirm Mr. Casaubon’s view. Will’s relationship in that distinguished quarter did not, like Lydgate’s high connections, serve as an advantageous introduction: if it was rumored that young Ladislaw was Mr. Casaubon’s nephew or cousin, it was also rumored that ‘Mr. Casaubon would have nothing to do with him.’
与此同时，镇上对《先锋》新任编辑的评价也逐渐证实了卡苏邦先生的观点。威尔在那个显赫地区的关系并不像利德盖特的高层关系那样成为有利的介绍：如果有传言说年轻的拉迪斯瓦夫是卡苏邦先生的侄子或表弟，那么也有传言说“威尔先生”是卡苏邦先生的侄子或表弟。卡苏邦不会和他有任何关系。

‘Brooke has taken him up,’ said Mr. Hawley, ‘because that is what no man in his senses could have expected. Casaubon has devilish good reasons, you may be sure, for turning the cold shoulder on a young fellow whose bringing-up he paid for. Just like Brooke— one of those fellows who would praise a cat to sell a horse.’
“布鲁克已经接受了他，”霍利先生说，“因为这是任何一个有理智的人都无法预料到的。”你可以肯定，卡苏邦有充分的理由冷落一个他花钱养大的年轻人。就像布鲁克一样——那些称赞猫卖马的人。

And some oddities of Will’s, more or less poetical, appeared to support Mr. Keck, the editor of the ‘Trumpet,’ in asserting that Ladislaw, if the truth were known, was not only a Polish emissary but crack-brained, which accounted for the preternatural quickness and glibness of his speech when he got on to a platform—as he did whenever he had an opportunity, speaking with a facility which cast reflections on solid Englishmen generally. It was disgusting to Keck to see a strip of a fellow, with light curls round his head, get up and speechify by the hour against institutions ‘which had existed when he was in his cradle.’ And in a leading article of the ‘Trumpet,’ Keck characterized Ladislaw’s speech at a Reform meeting as ‘the violence of an energumen—a miserable effort to shroud in the brilliancy of fireworks the daring of irresponsible statements and the poverty of a knowledge which was of the cheapest and most recent description.’
威尔的一些奇怪之处，或多或少有些诗意，似乎支持凯克先生，《喇叭》的编辑，他断言拉迪斯瓦夫，如果真相为人所知，不仅是一名波兰使者，而且是个疯子，这说明了拉迪斯瓦夫的观点。因为当他登上讲台时，他的演讲异常敏捷和圆滑——只要有机会，他就会这么做，说话的流畅程度让一般的英国人都感到很踏实。凯克看到一个头上戴着浅色卷发的人站起来发表演讲，反对“在他的摇篮里就已经存在的机构”，这让凯克感到恶心。凯克将拉迪斯瓦夫在一次改革会议上的演讲描述为“一种能量的暴力——一种悲惨的努力，试图用烟花的灿烂来掩盖不负责任的言论的大胆和最廉价、最新描述的知识的贫乏。”

‘That was a rattling article yesterday, Keck,’ said Dr. Sprague, with sarcastic intentions. ‘But what is an energumen?’
“昨天那篇文章令人震惊，凯克，”斯普拉格博士带着讽刺的意思说道。 “但是什么是能量呢？”

‘Oh, a term that came up in the French Revolution,’ said Keck.
“哦，法国大革命中出现的一个术语，”凯克说。

This dangerous aspect of Ladislaw was strangely contrasted with other habits which became matter of remark. He had a fondness, half artistic, half affectionate, for little children—the smaller they were on tolerably active legs, and the funnier their clothing, the better Will liked to surprise and please them. We know that in Rome he was given to ramble about among the poor people, and the taste did not quit him in Middlemarch.
拉迪斯瓦夫的这一危险方面与其他引起人们关注的习惯形成了奇怪的对比。他对小孩子有一种半艺术半深情的喜爱——他们的腿越小，腿还算活跃，衣服越有趣，威尔就越喜欢给他们带来惊喜和取悦。我们知道，在罗马，他喜欢在穷人中闲逛，而在米德尔马契，他也没有放弃这种品味。

He had somehow picked up a troop of droll children, little hatless boys with their galligaskins much worn and scant shirting to hang out, little girls who tossed their hair out of their eyes to look at him, and guardian brothers at the mature age of seven. This troop he had led out on gypsy excursions to Halsell Wood at nutting-time, and since the cold weather had set in he had taken them on a clear day to gather sticks for a bonfire in the hollow of a hillside, where he drew out a small feast of gingerbread for them, and improvised a Punch-and-Judy drama with some private home-made puppets. Here was one oddity. Another was, that in houses where he got friendly, he was given to stretch himself at full length on the rug while he talked, and was apt to be discovered in this attitude by occasional callers for whom such an irregularity was likely to confirm the notions of his dangerously mixed blood and general laxity.
他不知何故捡到了一群滑稽的孩子，没有帽子的小男孩，他们的马皮已经破旧，衬衫很少，可以闲逛，小女孩把头发从眼睛里甩出来看着他，还有七岁成熟的监护人兄弟。 。他在坚果时间带领这支部队去哈塞尔伍德进行吉普赛远足，自从寒冷的天气来临之后，他就在晴朗的日子里带着他们去山坡的洼地里收集树枝生火，然后他就在那里拉出来。为他们准备了一小顿姜饼大餐，并用一些私人自制的木偶即兴表演了《潘趣与朱迪》戏剧。这里有一个奇怪的地方。另一个原因是，在他变得友好的房子里，他在说话时会在地毯上伸直身体，并且很容易被偶尔来访的人发现这种态度，对他们来说，这种不规则行为可能会证实这种想法。他危险的混血和普遍的松懈。

But Will’s articles and speeches naturally recommended him in families which the new strictness of party division had marked off on the side of Reform. He was invited to Mr. Bulstrode’s; but here he could not lie down on the rug, and Mrs. Bulstrode felt that his mode of talking about Catholic countries, as if there were any truce with Antichrist, illustrated the usual tendency to unsoundness in intellectual men.
但威尔的文章和演讲自然而然地在家庭中推荐了他，因为新的党派分裂的严格性已经使他站在了改革派一边。他被邀请去布尔斯特罗德先生家。但在这里他不能躺在地毯上，布尔斯特罗德夫人觉得他谈论天主教国家的方式，就好像与反基督者有休战一样，说明了知识分子通常的不健全倾向。

At Mr. Farebrother’s, however, whom the irony of events had brought on the same side with Bulstrode in the national movement, Will became a favorite with the ladies; especially with little Miss Noble, whom it was one of his oddities to escort when he met her in the street with her little basket, giving her his arm in the eyes of the town, and insisting on going with her to pay some call where she distributed her small filchings from her own share of sweet things.
然而，在费勒布拉泽先生家里，讽刺的是，发生的事件让他在民族运动中与布尔斯特罗德站在了同一边，威尔成了女士们的最爱。尤其是对待小诺布尔小姐，当他提着小篮子在街上遇见她时，他护送她是他的怪事之一，他在全镇人的注视下伸出手臂，坚持要和她一起去拜访她所在的地方。把她从自己那份甜食中偷来的小东西分发出去。

But the house where he visited oftenest and lay most on the rug was Lydgate’s. The two men were not at all alike, but they agreed none the worse. Lydgate was abrupt but not irritable, taking little notice of megrims in healthy people; and Ladislaw did not usually throw away his susceptibilities on those who took no notice of them. With Rosamond, on the other hand, he pouted and was wayward—nay, often uncomplimentary, much to her inward surprise; nevertheless he was gradually becoming necessary to her entertainment by his companionship in her music, his varied talk, and his freedom from the grave preoccupation which, with all her husband’s tenderness and indulgence, often made his manners unsatisfactory to her, and confirmed her dislike of the medical profession.
但他最常去的房子和躺在地毯上最多的房子是利德盖特的房子。这两个人一点也不相似，但他们的意见却丝毫不差。利德盖特很突然，但并不急躁，很少注意到健康人的megrims。拉迪斯瓦夫通常不会把自己的易感性抛给那些不注意的人。另一方面，与罗莎蒙德在一起时，他撅起嘴，任性——不，经常不恭维，这让她内心大吃一惊。然而，他逐渐成为她娱乐的必需品，他陪伴着她的音乐，他的多变的谈话，以及他摆脱了严肃的专注，而她丈夫的温柔和纵容，常常使他的举止令她不满意，并证实了她对他的厌恶。医学界。

Lydgate, inclined to be sarcastic on the superstitious faith of the people in the efficacy of ‘the bill,’ while nobody cared about the low state of pathology, sometimes assailed Will with troublesome questions. One evening in March, Rosamond in her cherry-colored dress with swansdown trimming about the throat sat at the tea-table; Lydgate, lately come in tired from his outdoor work, was seated sideways on an easy-chair by the fire with one leg over the elbow, his brow looking a little troubled as his eyes rambled over the columns of the ‘Pioneer,’ while Rosamond, having noticed that he was perturbed, avoided looking at him, and inwardly thanked heaven that she herself had not a moody disposition. Will Ladislaw was stretched on the rug contemplating the curtain-pole abstractedly, and humming very low the notes of ‘When first I saw thy face;’ while the house spaniel, also stretched out with small choice of room, looked from between his paws at the usurper of the rug with silent but strong objection.
利德盖特倾向于讽刺人们对“法案”功效的迷信，而没有人关心病态的低级状态，有时他会用一些棘手的问题攻击威尔。三月的一个晚上，罗莎蒙德穿着樱桃色连衣裙，领口饰有天鹅绒，坐在茶几旁。利德盖特刚刚从户外工作中累了回来，他侧身坐在火边的一张安乐椅上，一条腿搭在肘部，他的眉毛看起来有点困扰，眼睛在“先锋”的柱子上闲逛，而罗莎蒙德见他心烦意乱，避开看他，心里谢天谢地，自己没有喜怒无常的性格。威尔·拉迪斯瓦躺在地毯上，心不在焉地凝视着窗帘杆，低声哼着“当我第一次看到你的脸时”的曲调；而那只西班牙猎犬，也伸着懒腰，没有多少空间，从爪子之间看着篡夺地毯的人默默但强烈地反对。

Rosamond bringing Lydgate his cup of tea, he threw down the paper, and said to Will, who had started up and gone to the table—
罗莎蒙德给利德盖特端来一杯茶，他扔下报纸，对已经站起来走向桌边的威尔说——

‘It’s no use your puffing Brooke as a reforming landlord, Ladislaw: they only pick the more holes in his coat in the ‘Trumpet.’’
“拉迪斯洛，你那气喘吁吁的布鲁克作为一个改革的房东是没有用的：他们只会在‘喇叭’中挑出他外套上更多的洞。”

‘No matter; those who read the ‘Pioneer’ don’t read the ‘Trumpet,’’ said Will, swallowing his tea and walking about. ‘Do you suppose the public reads with a view to its own conversion? We should have a witches’ brewing with a vengeance then—‘Mingle, mingle, mingle, mingle, You that mingle may’—and nobody would know which side he was going to take.’
'不管;读《先锋》的人不会读《号角》。”威尔一边说着，一边喝完茶，四处走动。 “你认为公众阅读是为了改变自己的信仰吗？那么我们就应该酝酿一场复仇的女巫之战——“混在一起，混在一起，混在一起，混在一起，你可能会混在一起”——没有人知道他会站在哪一​​边。

‘Farebrother says, he doesn’t believe Brooke would get elected if the opportunity came: the very men who profess to be for him would bring another member out of the bag at the right moment.’
“费厄布拉泽说，他不相信如果机会到来，布鲁克会当选：那些自称支持他的人会在适当的时候泄露另一名成员的秘密。”

‘There’s no harm in trying. It’s good to have resident members.’
‘尝试一下总没有坏处。有常驻会员是件好事。”

‘Why?’ said Lydgate, who was much given to use that inconvenient word in a curt tone.
“为什么？”利德盖特问道，他很习惯用简短的语气使用这个不方便的词。

‘They represent the local stupidity better,’ said Will, laughing, and shaking his curls; ‘and they are kept on their best behavior in the neighborhood. Brooke is not a bad fellow, but he has done some good things on his estate that he never would have done but for this Parliamentary bite.’
“它们更能代表当地的愚蠢，”威尔笑着说道，摇晃着他的卷发。 “他们在社区里一直保持着最好的行为。”布鲁克不是一个坏人，但他在自己的庄园里做了一些好事，如果不是议会的这次行动，他永远不会做这些事。

‘He’s not fitted to be a public man,’ said Lydgate, with contemptuous decision. ‘He would disappoint everybody who counted on him: I can see that at the Hospital. Only, there Bulstrode holds the reins and drives him.’
“他不适合当一名公众人物，”利德盖特轻蔑地说道。 “他会让所有指望他的人失望：我可以在医院看到这一点。只是，布尔斯特罗德掌握着缰绳并驱动着他。

‘That depends on how you fix your standard of public men,’ said Will. ‘He’s good enough for the occasion: when the people have made up their mind as they are making it up now, they don’t want a man— they only want a vote.’
“这取决于你如何确定公职人员的标准，”威尔说。 “他足够适合这个场合：当人们像现在这样做出决定时，他们不需要一个人——他们只想要一张选票。”

‘That is the way with you political writers, Ladislaw—crying up a measure as if it were a universal cure, and crying up men who are a part of the very disease that wants curing.’
“拉迪斯瓦夫，你们这些政治作家就是这样——高喊一项措施，就好像它是一种万能药一样，而那些属于需要治愈的疾病的一部分的人又哭了。”

‘Why not? Men may help to cure themselves off the face of the land without knowing it,’ said Will, who could find reasons impromptu, when he had not thought of a question beforehand.
'为什么不？人们可能会在不知情的情况下帮助自己从这片土地上治愈自己，”威尔说，当他事先没有想到问题时，他可以即兴找到理由。

‘That is no excuse for encouraging the superstitious exaggeration of hopes about this particular measure, helping the cry to swallow it whole and to send up voting popinjays who are good for nothing but to carry it. You go against rottenness, and there is nothing more thoroughly rotten than making people believe that society can be cured by a political hocus-pocus.’
“这并不是鼓励迷信地夸大对这一特定措施的希望的借口，而是帮助呼声将其完全吞没，并派出除了执行该措施之外一无是处的选民投票。”你反对腐败，没有什么比让人们相信政治骗局可以治愈社会更彻底的腐败了。

‘That’s very fine, my dear fellow. But your cure must begin somewhere, and put it that a thousand things which debase a population can never be reformed without this particular reform to begin with. Look what Stanley said the other day—that the House had been tinkering long enough at small questions of bribery, inquiring whether this or that voter has had a guinea when everybody knows that the seats have been sold wholesale. Wait for wisdom and conscience in public agents—fiddlestick! The only conscience we can trust to is the massive sense of wrong in a class, and the best wisdom that will work is the wisdom of balancing claims. That’s my text— which side is injured? I support the man who supports their claims; not the virtuous upholder of the wrong.’
‘那很好，我亲爱的朋友。但你的治疗必须从某个地方开始，并且说，如果没有这一特定的改革，一千种贬低人口的事情就永远无法改革。看看斯坦利前几天所说的话——众议院已经在贿赂的小问题上摆弄了足够长的时间，在每个人都知道席位已被批发出售的情况下询问这个或那个选民是否有几内亚。等待公共代理人的智慧和良心——胡闹！我们唯一可以信赖的良知是阶级中存在的巨大错误感，而最有效的智慧是平衡主张的智慧。这就是我的文字——哪一侧受伤了？我支持支持他们主张的人；不是错误的道德支持者。”

‘That general talk about a particular case is mere question begging, Ladislaw. When I say, I go in for the dose that cures, it doesn’t follow that I go in for opium in a given case of gout.’
“拉迪斯瓦夫，对特定案件的一般性讨论只是在回避问题。当我说，我服用能治愈的剂量时，并不意味着我在特定的痛风病例中服用鸦片。

‘I am not begging the question we are upon—whether we are to try for nothing till we find immaculate men to work with. Should you go on that plan? If there were one man who would carry you a medical reform and another who would oppose it, should you inquire which had the better motives or even the better brains?’
“我并不是在回避我们面临的问题——我们是否应该无所事事，直到找到完美的人一起工作。你应该继续那个计划吗？如果一个人支持你推行医改，另一个人反对你，你是否应该问问谁的动机更好，甚至脑子更好？

‘Oh, of course,’ said Lydgate, seeing himself checkmated by a move which he had often used himself, ‘if one did not work with such men as are at hand, things must come to a dead-lock. Suppose the worst opinion in the town about Bulstrode were a true one, that would not make it less true that he has the sense and the resolution to do what I think ought to be done in the matters I know and care most about; but that is the only ground on which I go with him,’ Lydgate added rather proudly, bearing in mind Mr. Farebrother’s remarks. ‘He is nothing to me otherwise; I would not cry him up on any personal ground—I would keep clear of that.’
“哦，当然，”利德盖特说，他看到自己被自己经常使用的一招所围堵，“如果不与手头的人一起工作，事情就会陷入僵局。假设镇上关于布尔斯特罗德的最坏的看法是真实的，这并不会削弱他有理智和决心在我知道和最关心的事情上做我认为应该做的事情的真实性； “但这是我支持他的唯一理由，”利德盖特相当自豪地补充道，同时牢记费勒布拉泽先生的言论。 “除此之外，他对我来说什么都不是；我不会因为任何个人原因而让他哭——我会避开这一点。

‘Do you mean that I cry up Brooke on any personal ground?’ said Will Ladislaw, nettled, and turning sharp round. For the first time he felt offended with Lydgate; not the less so, perhaps, because he would have declined any close inquiry into the growth of his relation to Mr. Brooke.
“你的意思是我会因为个人原因而对布鲁克大喊大叫？”威尔·拉迪斯瓦夫生气地说，猛地转过身来。他第一次对利德盖特感到被冒犯了。或许，情况并非如此，因为他拒绝对他与布鲁克先生关系的发展进行任何仔细的调查。

‘Not at all,’ said Lydgate, ‘I was simply explaining my own action. I meant that a man may work for a special end with others whose motives and general course are equivocal, if he is quite sure of his personal independence, and that he is not working for his private interest—either place or money.’
“一点也不，”利德盖特说，“我只是在解释我自己的行为。我的意思是，如果一个人非常确定自己的个人独立性，并且他不是为了自己的私人利益（无论是地位还是金钱）而工作，那么他可以与其他动机和总体方针模棱两可的人一起为特殊目的而工作。

‘Then, why don’t you extend your liberality to others?’ said Will, still nettled. ‘My personal independence is as important to me as yours is to you. You have no more reason to imagine that I have personal expectations from Brooke, than I have to imagine that you have personal expectations from Bulstrode. Motives are points of honor, I suppose— nobody can prove them. But as to money and place in the world.’ Will ended, tossing back his head, ‘I think it is pretty clear that I am not determined by considerations of that sort.’
“那么，你为什么不向其他人伸出你的慷慨之手呢？”威尔仍然生气地说。 “我的个人独立对我来说和你的个人独立对你一样重要。你没有理由想象我对布鲁克有个人期望，就像我没有理由想象你对布尔斯特罗德有个人期望一样。我认为，动机是荣誉的体现——没有人能证明它们。但至于金钱和在世界上的地位。”威尔摇摇头，最后说道，“我想很明显，我不是由这类考虑决定的。”

‘You quite mistake me, Ladislaw,’ said Lydgate, surprised. He had been preoccupied with his own vindication, and had been blind to what Ladislaw might infer on his own account. ‘I beg your pardon for unintentionally annoying you. In fact, I should rather attribute to you a romantic disregard of your own worldly interests. On the political question, I referred simply to intellectual bias.’
“你完全误会我了，拉迪斯瓦夫，”利德盖特惊讶地说。他一直全神贯注于自己的辩护，而对拉迪斯瓦夫可能从他自己的角度推断出的东西视而不见。 ‘请原谅我无意中打扰了你。事实上，我更应该将其归因于你对自己世俗利益的浪漫漠视。在政治问题上，我简单地提到了知识偏见。

‘How very unpleasant you both are this evening!’ said Rosamond. ‘I cannot conceive why money should have been referred to. Polities and Medicine are sufficiently disagreeable to quarrel upon. You can both of you go on quarrelling with all the world and with each other on those two topics.’
“今晚你们俩真是太不愉快了！”罗莎蒙德说。 “我无法想象为什么要提及金钱。政治和医学是非常不愉快的，值得争论。你们俩可以继续在这两个话题上与全世界以及彼此争吵。

Rosamond looked mildly neutral as she said this, rising to ring the bell, and then crossing to her work-table.
罗莎蒙德说这句话时，表情显得温和中立，她起身按响了门铃，然后走到她的工作台前。

‘Poor Rosy!’ said Lydgate, putting out his hand to her as she was passing him. ‘Disputation is not amusing to cherubs. Have some music. Ask Ladislaw to sing with you.’
“可怜的罗西！”当她经过利德盖特身边时，他向她伸出了手。 ‘对于小天使来说，争论并不有趣。听点音乐。请拉迪斯瓦夫和你一起唱歌。

When Will was gone Rosamond said to her husband, ‘What put you out of temper this evening, Tertius?’
威尔走后，罗莎蒙德对她丈夫说：“特蒂斯，今晚是什么让你发脾气？”

‘Me? It was Ladislaw who was out of temper. He is like a bit of tinder.’
'我？发脾气的是拉迪斯瓦夫。他就像一个火种。

‘But I mean, before that. Something had vexed you before you came in, you looked cross. And that made you begin to dispute with Mr. Ladislaw. You hurt me very much when you look so, Tertius.’
“但我的意思是，在那之前。你进来之前有什么事让你烦恼，你看起来很生气。这让你开始与拉迪斯瓦先生发生争执。当你看起来如此时，我非常受伤，特蒂斯。

‘Do I? Then I am a brute,’ said Lydgate, caressing her penitently.
‘是吗？那我就是个畜生了。”利德盖特一边说道，一边悔恨地抚摸着她。

‘What vexed you?’
“什么让你烦恼？”

‘Oh, outdoor things—business.’ It was really a letter insisting on the payment of a bill for furniture. But Rosamond was expecting to have a baby, and Lydgate wished to save her from any perturbation.
“哦，户外活动——生意。”这实际上是一封坚持支付家具账单的信。但罗莎蒙德即将生孩子，利德盖特希望让她免受任何干扰。

CHAPTER XLVII
第四十七章

Was never true love loved in vain,
真爱从来都不是徒劳的，

For truest love is highest gain.
因为最真挚的爱就是最高的收获。

No art can make it: it must spring
没有艺术可以做到：它必须春天

Where elements are fostering.
元素正在孕育的地方。

So in heaven’s spot and hour
所以在天堂的地点和时间

Springs the little native flower,
春天的小土花，

Downward root and upward eye,
根向下，眼向上，

Shapen by the earth and sky.
由大地和天空塑造。

It happened to be on a Saturday evening that Will Ladislaw had that little discussion with Lydgate. Its effect when he went to his own rooms was to make him sit up half the night, thinking over again, under a new irritation, all that he had before thought of his having settled in Middlemarch and harnessed himself with Mr. Brooke. Hesitations before he had taken the step had since turned into susceptibility to every hint that he would have been wiser not to take it; and hence came his heat towards Lydgate—a heat which still kept him restless. Was he not making a fool of himself?— and at a time when he was more than ever conscious of being something better than a fool? And for what end?
碰巧在一个周六的晚上，威尔·拉迪斯瓦夫与利德盖特进行了一次小小的讨论。当他回到自己的房间时，它的效果是让他坐了半夜，在新的刺激下再次思考他之前在米德尔马契定居并与布鲁克先生一起束缚自己的一切。他在迈出这一步之前的犹豫，后来变成了对每一个暗示的敏感：如果他不迈出这一步，他会更明智。因此，他对利德盖特产生了热情——这种热情仍然让他坐立不安。他不是在愚弄自己吗？——而且在他比以往任何时候都更加意识到自己比傻瓜更好的时候？又是为了什么目的呢？

Well, for no definite end. True, he had dreamy visions of possibilities: there is no human being who having both passions and thoughts does not think in consequence of his passions—does not find images rising in his mind which soothe the passion with hope or sting it with dread. But this, which happens to us all, happens to some with a wide difference; and Will was not one of those whose wit ‘keeps the roadway:’ he had his bypaths where there were little joys of his own choosing, such as gentlemen cantering on the highroad might have thought rather idiotic. The way in which he made a sort of happiness for himself out of his feeling for Dorothea was an example of this. It may seem strange, but it is the fact, that the ordinary vulgar vision of which Mr. Casaubon suspected him—namely, that Dorothea might become a widow, and that the interest he had established in her mind might turn into acceptance of him as a husband— had no tempting, arresting power over him; he did not live in the scenery of such an event, and follow it out, as we all do with that imagined ‘otherwise’ which is our practical heaven. It was not only that he was unwilling to entertain thoughts which could be accused of baseness, and was already uneasy in the sense that he had to justify himself from the charge of ingratitude— the latent consciousness of many other barriers between himself and Dorothea besides the existence of her husband, had helped to turn away his imagination from speculating on what might befall Mr. Casaubon. And there were yet other reasons. Will, we know, could not bear the thought of any flaw appearing in his crystal: he was at once exasperated and delighted by the calm freedom with which Dorothea looked at him and spoke to him, and there was something so exquisite in thinking of her just as she was, that he could not long for a change which must somehow change her. Do we not shun the street version of a fine melody?—or shrink from the news that the rarity—some bit of chiselling or engraving perhaps— which we have dwelt on even with exultation in the trouble it has cost us to snatch glimpses of it, is really not an uncommon thing, and may be obtained as an every-day possession? Our good depends on the quality and breadth of our emotion; and to Will, a creature who cared little for what are called the solid things of life and greatly for its subtler influences, to have within him such a feeling as he had towards Dorothea, was like the inheritance of a fortune. What others might have called the futility of his passion, made an additional delight for his imagination: he was conscious of a generous movement, and of verifying in his own experience that higher love-poetry which had charmed his fancy. Dorothea, he said to himself, was forever enthroned in his soul: no other woman could sit higher than her footstool; and if he could have written out in immortal syllables the effect she wrought within him, he might have boasted after the example of old Drayton, that,—
好吧，没有明确的结局。诚然，他对各种可能性抱有梦幻般的幻想：凡是既有激情又有思想的人，都会根据自己的激情进行思考——他的脑海中会浮现出一些画面，这些画面可以用希望抚平激情，也可以用恐惧刺痛激情。但这种情况发生在我们所有人身上，也发生在一些差异很大的人身上。威尔并不是那些用智慧“保持道路”的人之一：他有自己的小路，那里没有他自己选择的乐趣，就像在大路上慢跑的绅士们可能会认为相当愚蠢的那样。他从对多萝西娅的感情中为自己创造了某种幸福就是一个例子。这可能看起来很奇怪，但事实就是卡苏邦先生怀疑他的普通庸俗愿景——即多萝西娅可能会成为寡妇，而他在她心目中建立的兴趣可能会转变为接受他为寡妇。丈夫——对他没有诱惑力、拘束力；他并没有生活在这样一个事件的场景中，并遵循它，就像我们所有人对想象的“否则”，即我们实际的天堂所做的那样。这不仅是因为他不愿意考虑那些可能被指责为卑鄙的想法，而且他已经感到不安，因为他必须为自己的忘恩负义的指控辩护——他和多萝西娅之间潜在的意识除了她丈夫的存在，帮助他转移了对卡苏邦先生可能遭遇的事情的想象。还有其他原因。 我们知道，威尔无法忍受他的水晶中出现任何缺陷：多萝西娅看着他并与他说话时的平静自由，让他立即感到愤怒和高兴，想到她有一种如此美妙的感觉。正如她一样，他不能渴望某种改变，而这种改变必须以某种方式改变她。难道我们不会回避一首优美旋律的街头版本吗？——或者对这种稀有性——也许是一些凿刻或雕刻——的消息感到畏惧，尽管我们为瞥见它而付出的代价而欣喜若狂，但我们一直在关注它。 ，真的不是什么稀奇的东西，可以作为日常拥有品获得吗？我们的善行取决于我们情感的质量和广度；对于威尔这样一个不太关心生活中所谓的实体事物而非常关心其微妙影响的人来说，拥有像对多萝西娅那样的感情，就像继承了一笔财富。其他人可能认为他的激情是徒劳的，却为他的想象力增添了额外的乐趣：他意识到一种慷慨的举动，并在他自己的经验中证实了令他着迷的更高层次的爱情诗。 他对自己说，多萝西娅永远在他的灵魂中占据着王位：没有其他女人可以坐得比她的脚凳还高；她的脚凳比她的脚凳高。如果他能用不朽的音节写出她对他产生的影响，他可能会效仿老德雷顿的例子，夸耀说：

‘Queens hereafter might be glad to live
“今后的女王们可能会很高兴生活

Upon the alms of her superfluous praise.’
靠的是她多余的赞美的施舍。

But this result was questionable. And what else could he do for Dorothea? What was his devotion worth to her? It was impossible to tell. He would not go out of her reach. He saw no creature among her friends to whom he could believe that she spoke with the same simple confidence as to him. She had once said that she would like him to stay; and stay he would, whatever fire-breathing dragons might hiss around her.
但这个结果值得商榷。他还能为多萝西娅做些什么呢？他对她的付出又有什么价值呢？这很难说。他不会离开她的范围。在她的朋友中，他看不到任何人可以相信她对他说话时的语气和对他一样简单而自信。她曾经说过，她希望他留下来；但现在她已经答应了。无论喷火龙在她周围发出怎样的嘶嘶声，他都会留下来。

This had always been the conclusion of Will’s hesitations. But he was not without contradictoriness and rebellion even towards his own resolve. He had often got irritated, as he was on this particular night, by some outside demonstration that his public exertions with Mr. Brooke as a chief could not seem as heroic as he would like them to be, and this was always associated with the other ground of irritation—that notwithstanding his sacrifice of dignity for Dorothea’s sake, he could hardly ever see her. Whereupon, not being able to contradict these unpleasant facts, he contradicted his own strongest bias and said, ‘I am a fool.’
这一直是威尔犹豫不决的结论。但他对自己的决心也并非没有矛盾和反叛。就像在这个特别的夜晚一样，他经常因为一些外界的表现而感到恼火，这些表现表明他与布鲁克先生作为酋长的公开努力似乎并不像他希望的那样英勇，而这总是与其他人联系在一起。令人恼火的原因是——尽管他为了多萝西娅牺牲了尊严，但他却几乎看不到她。于是，由于无法反驳这些令人不快的事实，他反驳了自己最强烈的偏见，并说：“我是个傻瓜。”

Nevertheless, since the inward debate necessarily turned on Dorothea, he ended, as he had done before, only by getting a livelier sense of what her presence would be to him; and suddenly reflecting that the morrow would be Sunday, he determined to go to Lowick Church and see her. He slept upon that idea, but when he was dressing in the rational morning light, Objection said—
尽管如此，由于内心的争论必然会转向多萝西娅，所以他就像以前所做的那样，只是更加生动地意识到她的存在对他来说意味着什么；然后他就结束了。突然想到明天就是周日，他决定去洛伊克教堂看看她。他抱着这个想法入睡，但当他在理性的晨光中穿衣时，反对说——

‘That will be a virtual defiance of Mr. Casaubon’s prohibition to visit Lowick, and Dorothea will be displeased.’
“这实际上是对卡苏邦先生访问洛威克禁令的蔑视，多萝西娅会很不高兴。”

‘Nonsense!’ argued Inclination, ‘it would be too monstrous for him to hinder me from going out to a pretty country church on a spring morning. And Dorothea will be glad.’
“胡说！”倾向争辩道，“如果他阻止我在春天的早晨去一座美丽的乡村教堂，那就太可怕了。多萝西娅会很高兴的。

‘It will be clear to Mr. Casaubon that you have come either to annoy him or to see Dorothea.’
“卡苏邦先生很清楚，你来这里要么是为了惹恼他，要么是为了见多萝西娅。”

‘It is not true that I go to annoy him, and why should I not go to see Dorothea? Is he to have everything to himself and be always comfortable? Let him smart a little, as other people are obliged to do. I have always liked the quaintness of the church and congregation; besides, I know the Tuckers: I shall go into their pew.’
“我并不是去惹恼他，我为什么不去见多萝西娅呢？”他是否应该拥有一切并始终感到舒适？让他聪明一点，就像其他人有义务做的那样。我一直很喜欢教堂和会众的古色古香。此外，我认识塔克一家：我会坐在他们的座位上。

Having silenced Objection by force of unreason, Will walked to Lowick as if he had been on the way to Paradise, crossing Halsell Common and skirting the wood, where the sunlight fell broadly under the budding boughs, bringing out the beauties of moss and lichen, and fresh green growths piercing the brown. Everything seemed to know that it was Sunday, and to approve of his going to Lowick Church. Will easily felt happy when nothing crossed his humor, and by this time the thought of vexing Mr. Casaubon had become rather amusing to him, making his face break into its merry smile, pleasant to see as the breaking of sunshine on the water—though the occasion was not exemplary. But most of us are apt to settle within ourselves that the man who blocks our way is odious, and not to mind causing him a little of the disgust which his personality excites in ourselves. Will went along with a small book under his arm and a hand in each side-pocket, never reading, but chanting a little, as he made scenes of what would happen in church and coming out. He was experimenting in tunes to suit some words of his own, sometimes trying a ready-made melody, sometimes improvising. The words were not exactly a hymn, but they certainly fitted his Sunday experience:—
威尔用非理性的力量压制了反对意见，然后朝洛威克走去，仿佛他正走在通往天堂的路上，穿过哈塞尔公地，绕过树林，阳光大范围地落在发芽的树枝下，衬托出苔藓和地衣的美丽，新鲜的绿色植物刺穿棕色。一切似乎都知道今天是星期天，都同意他去洛威克教堂。当没有任何事情违背他的幽默感时，威尔很容易感到高兴，而此时，让卡苏邦先生烦恼的想法对他来说变得相当有趣，让他的脸绽放出快乐的微笑，令人愉快地看到阳光照在水面上——尽管这次事件并不具有典范性。但我们大多数人都倾向于认为挡住我们道路的人是可憎的，并且不介意让他的个性在我们心中激起一点厌恶。威尔腋下夹着一本小书，一只手插在侧袋里，他从不读书，只是唱了一点歌，同时描绘了教堂里和出来时会发生的事情。他不断尝试曲调来适应自己的一些歌词，有时尝试现成的旋律，有时即兴发挥。这些话并不完全是一首赞美诗，但它们确实适合他周日的经历：——

‘O me, O me, what frugal cheer
‘哦我，哦我，多么节俭的欢呼啊

My love doth feed upon!
我的爱不断汲取！

A touch, a ray, that is not here,
一次触摸，一道光线，但不在这里，

A shadow that is gone:
消失的影子：

‘A dream of breath that might be near,
“呼吸的梦想可能就在眼前，

An inly-echoed tone,
内心回响的声音，

The thought that one may think me dear,
一想到有人会认为我是亲爱的，

The place where one was known,
一个人认识的地方，

‘The tremor of a banished fear,
‘被驱散的恐惧所带来的颤抖，

An ill that was not done—
未曾做过的恶事——

O me, O me, what frugal cheer
哦我，哦我，多么节俭的欢乐啊

My love doth feed upon!’
我的爱不断汲取！

Sometimes, when he took off his hat, shaking his head backward, and showing his delicate throat as he sang, he looked like an incarnation of the spring whose spirit filled the air—a bright creature, abundant in uncertain promises.
有时，当他摘下帽子，向后​​摇头，露出纤细的喉咙唱歌时，他看起来就像春天的化身，充满了空气——一个明亮的生物，充满了不确定的承诺。

The bells were still ringing when he got to Lowick, and he went into the curate’s pew before any one else arrived there. But he was still left alone in it when the congregation had assembled. The curate’s pew was opposite the rector’s at the entrance of the small chancel, and Will had time to fear that Dorothea might not come while he looked round at the group of rural faces which made the congregation from year to year within the white-washed walls and dark old pews, hardly with more change than we see in the boughs of a tree which breaks here and there with age, but yet has young shoots. Mr. Rigg’s frog-face was something alien and unaccountable, but notwithstanding this shock to the order of things, there were still the Waules and the rural stock of the Powderells in their pews side by side; brother Samuel’s cheek had the same purple round as ever, and the three generations of decent cottagers came as of old with a sense of duty to their betters generally— the smaller children regarding Mr. Casaubon, who wore the black gown and mounted to the highest box, as probably the chief of all betters, and the one most awful if offended. Even in 1831 Lowick was at peace, not more agitated by Reform than by the solemn tenor of the Sunday sermon. The congregation had been used to seeing Will at church in former days, and no one took much note of him except the choir, who expected him to make a figure in the singing.
当他到达洛威克时，钟声还在响，他在其他人到达之前就坐进了牧师的座位。但当会众聚集时，他仍然独自一人在里面。牧师的长椅在小圣坛入口处的教区长的对面，威尔有时间担心多萝西娅可能不会来，同时他环顾四周，看到一群乡村面孔，年复一年地在粉刷成白色的墙壁里聚集了会众。黑色的老长凳，几乎没有比我们在一棵树的树枝上看到的变化更多的东西，这些树枝随着年龄的增长到处断裂，但仍然有嫩芽。里格先生的青蛙脸显得有些陌生和不可理喻，但尽管对事物的秩序造成了如此冲击，沃勒斯家族和乡村的波德德尔家族仍然并排坐在他们的长凳上；弟弟塞缪尔的脸颊还是一如既往的紫色圆润，三代正派的农夫一如往常地对长辈抱有一种责任感——较小的孩子们就是卡苏邦先生，他穿着黑色长袍，登上了最高的台阶。盒子，可能是所有更好的东西中的佼佼者，如果被冒犯的话，也是最可怕的。即使在 1831 年，洛威克仍然很平静，宗教改革并不比周日布道的庄严基调更让他激动。以前，会众们已经习惯在教堂里见到威尔，除了唱诗班之外，没有人太注意他，他们希望他能在歌声中崭露头角。

Dorothea did at last appear on this quaint background, walking up the short aisle in her white beaver bonnet and gray cloak—the same she had worn in the Vatican. Her face being, from her entrance, towards the chancel, even her shortsighted eyes soon discerned Will, but there was no outward show of her feeling except a slight paleness and a grave bow as she passed him. To his own surprise Will felt suddenly uncomfortable, and dared not look at her after they had bowed to each other. Two minutes later, when Mr. Casaubon came out of the vestry, and, entering the pew, seated himself in face of Dorothea, Will felt his paralysis more complete. He could look nowhere except at the choir in the little gallery over the vestry-door: Dorothea was perhaps pained, and he had made a wretched blunder. It was no longer amusing to vex Mr. Casaubon, who had the advantage probably of watching him and seeing that he dared not turn his head. Why had he not imagined this beforehand?— but he could not expect that he should sit in that square pew alone, unrelieved by any Tuckers, who had apparently departed from Lowick altogether, for a new clergyman was in the desk. Still he called himself stupid now for not foreseeing that it would be impossible for him to look towards Dorothea—nay, that she might feel his coming an impertinence. There was no delivering himself from his cage, however; and Will found his places and looked at his book as if he had been a school-mistress, feeling that the morning service had never been so immeasurably long before, that he was utterly ridiculous, out of temper, and miserable. This was what a man got by worshipping the sight of a woman! The clerk observed with surprise that Mr. Ladislaw did not join in the tune of Hanover, and reflected that he might have a cold.
多萝西娅终于出现在这个古色古香的背景中，戴着白色海狸软帽，穿着灰色斗篷——她在梵蒂冈穿的同样的衣服——走在短过道上。她的脸从入口处朝向圣坛，就连她那双近视的眼睛也很快就认出了威尔，但她没有任何外在表现出她的感觉，只是当她经过他身边时，脸色有些苍白，深深地鞠了一躬。令他自己惊讶的是，威尔突然感到不舒服，在他们互相鞠躬后不敢看她。两分钟后，当卡苏邦先生从礼拜室出来，进入长凳，在多萝西娅面前坐下时，威尔感觉自己的瘫痪更加彻底了。除了法室门上方小走廊里的唱诗班外，他什么也看不见：多萝西娅也许很痛苦，而他犯了一个可悲的错误。惹恼卡苏邦先生已经不再是一件有趣的事了，他的优势可能是看着他，发现他不敢回头。为什么他事先没有想到这一点？——但他不能指望他会独自坐在那张方形长椅上，没有任何塔克家族的人来安慰，塔克家族显然已经完全离开了洛伊克，因为桌子上坐着一位新牧师。但他现在仍称自己愚蠢，因为没有预见到他不可能看向多萝西娅——不，她可能会觉得他的到来是一种无礼。然而，他却无法从笼子里挣脱出来。威尔找到了自己的位置，看着自己的书，就好像他是一位女校长一样，感觉早上的礼拜从来没有这么漫长过，他完全可笑，脾气暴躁，而且痛苦不堪。这就是男人崇拜女人的结果！店员惊讶地发现拉迪斯瓦夫先生没有加入汉诺威的曲调，并认为他可能感冒了。

Mr. Casaubon did not preach that morning, and there was no change in Will’s situation until the blessing had been pronounced and every one rose. It was the fashion at Lowick for ‘the betters’ to go out first. With a sudden determination to break the spell that was upon him, Will looked straight at Mr. Casaubon. But that gentleman’s eyes were on the button of the pew-door, which he opened, allowing Dorothea to pass, and following her immediately without raising his eyelids. Will’s glance had caught Dorothea’s as she turned out of the pew, and again she bowed, but this time with a look of agitation, as if she were repressing tears. Will walked out after them, but they went on towards the little gate leading out of the churchyard into the shrubbery, never looking round.
那天早上卡苏邦先生没有讲道，直到祝福声宣布完毕、每个人都起身之后，威尔的情况才发生了变化。在洛威克，“优秀者”先出去是一种时尚。威尔突然下定决心要打破身上的魔咒，他直视着卡苏邦先生。但那位绅士的目光落在了座位门的按钮上，他打开了门，让多萝西娅通过，然后连眼皮都没抬起就立即跟了上去。当多萝西娅走出长凳时，威尔的目光与她对视了一眼，她再次鞠了个躬，但这次的表情很激动，仿佛在强忍泪水。威尔跟在他们后面走了出去，但他们继续朝那扇从小墓地通向灌木丛的小门走去，没有回头看一眼。

It was impossible for him to follow them, and he could only walk back sadly at mid-day along the same road which he had trodden hopefully in the morning. The lights were all changed for him both without and within.
他不可能跟上他们，只能在中午悲伤地沿着早上满怀希望走过的那条路走回去。无论是外表还是内在，灯光都变了。

CHAPTER XLVIII
第四十八章

Surely the golden hours are turning gray
黄金时段肯定正在变成灰色

And dance no more, and vainly strive to run:
不再跳舞，徒劳地努力奔跑：

I see their white locks streaming in the wind—
我看到她们的白发在风中飘扬——

Each face is haggard as it looks at me,
每一张脸都憔悴地看着我，

Slow turning in the constant clasping round
在不断的紧握轮中缓慢转动

Storm-driven.
风暴驱动。

Dorothea’s distress when she was leaving the church came chiefly from the perception that Mr. Casaubon was determined not to speak to his cousin, and that Will’s presence at church had served to mark more strongly the alienation between them. Will’s coming seemed to her quite excusable, nay, she thought it an amiable movement in him towards a reconciliation which she herself had been constantly wishing for. He had probably imagined, as she had, that if Mr. Casaubon and he could meet easily, they would shake hands and friendly intercourse might return. But now Dorothea felt quite robbed of that hope. Will was banished further than ever, for Mr. Casaubon must have been newly embittered by this thrusting upon him of a presence which he refused to recognize.
当多萝西娅离开教堂时，她的痛苦主要来自于卡苏邦先生决心不和他的表弟说话，而威尔出现在教堂更强烈地标志着他们之间的疏远。在她看来，威尔的到来是情有可原的，不，她认为这是他为了实现她自己一直渴望的和解而做出的和蔼可亲的举动。他可能和她一样，也想象过，如果卡苏邦先生和他能轻松见面，他们就会握手，友好的交往可能会恢复。但现在多萝西娅觉得这个希望完全被剥夺了。威尔比以往任何时候都更加被放逐，因为卡苏邦先生肯定因为这个他拒绝承认的存在强加在他身上而感到痛苦。

He had not been very well that morning, suffering from some difficulty in breathing, and had not preached in consequence; she was not surprised, therefore, that he was nearly silent at luncheon, still less that he made no allusion to Will Ladislaw. For her own part she felt that she could never again introduce that subject. They usually spent apart the hours between luncheon and dinner on a Sunday; Mr. Casaubon in the library dozing chiefly, and Dorothea in her boudoir, where she was wont to occupy herself with some of her favorite books. There was a little heap of them on the table in the bow-window—of various sorts, from Herodotus, which she was learning to read with Mr. Casaubon, to her old companion Pascal, and Keble’s ‘Christian Year.’ But to-day opened one after another, and could read none of them. Everything seemed dreary: the portents before the birth of Cyrus— Jewish antiquities—oh dear!—devout epigrams—the sacred chime of favorite hymns—all alike were as flat as tunes beaten on wood: even the spring flowers and the grass had a dull shiver in them under the afternoon clouds that hid the sun fitfully; even the sustaining thoughts which had become habits seemed to have in them the weariness of long future days in which she would still live with them for her sole companions. It was another or rather a fuller sort of companionship that poor Dorothea was hungering for, and the hunger had grown from the perpetual effort demanded by her married life. She was always trying to be what her husband wished, and never able to repose on his delight in what she was. The thing that she liked, that she spontaneously cared to have, seemed to be always excluded from her life; for if it was only granted and not shared by her husband it might as well have been denied. About Will Ladislaw there had been a difference between them from the first, and it had ended, since Mr. Casaubon had so severely repulsed Dorothea’s strong feeling about his claims on the family property, by her being convinced that she was in the right and her husband in the wrong, but that she was helpless. This afternoon the helplessness was more wretchedly benumbing than ever: she longed for objects who could be dear to her, and to whom she could be dear. She longed for work which would be directly beneficent like the sunshine and the rain, and now it appeared that she was to live more and more in a virtual tomb, where there was the apparatus of a ghastly labor producing what would never see the light. Today she had stood at the door of the tomb and seen Will Ladislaw receding into the distant world of warm activity and fellowship— turning his face towards her as he went.
那天早上他身体不太好，呼吸有些困难，因此没有讲道。因此，对于他在午餐时几乎保持沉默，更不用说他没有提及威尔·拉迪斯瓦夫，她并不感到惊讶。就她自己而言，她觉得自己再也不能介绍这个话题了。他们通常在周日的午餐和晚餐之间分开度过。卡苏邦先生主要在图书馆里打瞌睡，多萝西娅则在她的闺房里，她习惯于在那里阅读一些她最喜欢的书。弓窗的桌子上有一小堆书——各种各样，从希罗多德的书（她正在和卡苏朋先生一起学读）到她的老朋友帕斯卡的书，还有基布尔的《基督教年》。日子一天又一天地打开，却读不完。一切都显得沉闷：居鲁士出生前的预兆——犹太古物——天哪！——虔诚的警句——人们喜爱的赞美诗的神圣钟声——全都像在木头上敲打的曲子一样平淡：连春天的花儿和小草都黯淡无光。在午后时断时续地遮住太阳的云层下，他们在颤抖；甚至那些已经成为习惯的持续的想法似乎也带着对未来漫长日子的厌倦，在未来的日子里，她仍然会和他们一起生活，成为她唯一的同伴。这是可怜的多萝西娅所渴望的另一种陪伴，或者更确切地说是一种更全面的陪伴，而这种渴望是由于她婚姻生活所要求的不断努力而增长的。她总是努力成为丈夫所希望的那样，却始终无法满足他对她的喜悦。她喜欢的东西，她自发地想要拥有的东西，似乎总是被排除在她的生活之外；因为如果只是授予了她的丈夫而不分享的话，那还不如被拒绝。 关于威尔·拉迪斯瓦夫，他们之间从一开始就存在着分歧，而且这种分歧已经结束了，因为卡苏邦先生强烈反对多萝西娅对他对家族财产的主张的强烈感觉，因为她确信自己是对的，而且她也认为自己是对的。丈夫的错，只是她的无奈。今天下午，这种无助感比以往任何时候都更加令人痛苦和麻木：她渴望那些对她来说是珍贵的东西，对她来说也是珍贵的。她渴望从事像阳光和雨水一样直接有益的工作，而现在看来，她越来越生活在一个虚拟的坟墓里，那里有可怕的劳动设备，生产着永远见不到光的东西。今天，她站在坟墓门口，看到威尔·拉迪斯瓦夫退入遥远的、充满热情的活动和友谊的世界——走的时候把脸转向她。

Books were of no use. Thinking was of no use. It was Sunday, and she could not have the carriage to go to Celia, who had lately had a baby. There was no refuge now from spiritual emptiness and discontent, and Dorothea had to bear her bad mood, as she would have borne a headache.
书本没有任何用处。思考是没有用的。那天是星期天，她没有马车去见刚刚生完孩子的西莉亚。现在，精神上的空虚和不满已经无处可逃，多萝西娅不得不忍受自己的坏心情，因为她会头痛。

After dinner, at the hour when she usually began to read aloud, Mr. Casaubon proposed that they should go into the library, where, he said, he had ordered a fire and lights. He seemed to have revived, and to be thinking intently.
晚饭后，也就是她通常开始大声朗读的时间，卡苏邦先生提议他们应该去图书馆，他说，他已经下令在图书馆生火和照明。他似乎又苏醒了，并且开始专心思考。

In the library Dorothea observed that he had newly arranged a row of his note-books on a table, and now he took up and put into her hand a well-known volume, which was a table of contents to all the others.
在图书馆里，多萝西娅注意到他在桌子上新摆了一排笔记本，现在他拿起一本熟悉的书，放在她手里，这对其他所有人来说都是一个目录。

‘You will oblige me, my dear,’ he said, seating himself, ‘if instead of other reading this evening, you will go through this aloud, pencil in hand, and at each point where I say ‘mark,’ will make a cross with your pencil. This is the first step in a sifting process which I have long had in view, and as we go on I shall be able to indicate to you certain principles of selection whereby you will, I trust, have an intelligent participation in my purpose.’
“亲爱的，你会帮我的忙，”他一边坐下一边说道，“如果你今天晚上不用读其他书，而是用手中的铅笔大声读一遍这篇文章，并在我说‘记号’的每一点上做一个记号。”用你的铅笔划十字。这是我长期以来一直考虑的筛选过程的第一步，随着我们的继续，我将能够向您表明某些选择原则，我相信您将明智地参与我的目的。

This proposal was only one more sign added to many since his memorable interview with Lydgate, that Mr. Casaubon’s original reluctance to let Dorothea work with him had given place to the contrary disposition, namely, to demand much interest and labor from her.
自从他与利德盖特进行令人难忘的采访以来，这一提议只是又一个迹象，表明卡苏邦先生最初不愿意让多萝西娅与他一起工作，现在已被相反的性格所取代，即要求她付出更多的兴趣和劳动。

After she had read and marked for two hours, he said, ‘We will take the volume up-stairs—and the pencil, if you please— and in case of reading in the night, we can pursue this task. It is not wearisome to you, I trust, Dorothea?’
在她读完并标记了两个小时后，他说：“我们会把这本书带到楼上——如果你愿意的话，还有铅笔——如果晚上读书，我们可以继续这项任务。”我相信，这对你来说并不令人厌烦，多萝西娅？

‘I prefer always reading what you like best to hear,’ said Dorothea, who told the simple truth; for what she dreaded was to exert herself in reading or anything else which left him as joyless as ever.
“我更喜欢读你最喜欢听的内容，”多萝西娅说道，她说出了简单的事实。因为她害怕的是用力读书或做其他让他一如既往不快乐的事情。

It was a proof of the force with which certain characteristics in Dorothea impressed those around her, that her husband, with all his jealousy and suspicion, had gathered implicit trust in the integrity of her promises, and her power of devoting herself to her idea of the right and best. Of late he had begun to feel that these qualities were a peculiar possession for himself, and he wanted to engross them.
这证明了多萝西娅的某些特质给她周围的人留下了深刻的印象，她的丈夫尽管充满嫉妒和怀疑，却对她的承诺的完整性和她全身心投入到自己的想法中的力量产生了绝对的信任。正确和最好的。最近，他开始觉得这些品质对自己来说是一种特殊的拥有，他想要全神贯注于它们。

The reading in the night did come. Dorothea in her young weariness had slept soon and fast: she was awakened by a sense of light, which seemed to her at first like a sudden vision of sunset after she had climbed a steep hill: she opened her eyes and saw her husband wrapped in his warm gown seating himself in the arm-chair near the fire-place where the embers were still glowing. He had lit two candles, expecting that Dorothea would awake, but not liking to rouse her by more direct means.
夜读确实来了。多萝西娅在她年轻的疲倦中很快就睡着了：她被一种光的感觉唤醒，这对她来说起初似乎是她爬上陡峭的山坡后突然看到的日落：她睁开眼睛，看到她的丈夫裹着他穿着温暖的长袍，坐在壁炉旁的扶手椅上，壁炉里的余烬仍然在燃烧。他点燃了两根蜡烛，期待多萝西娅会醒来，但不想用更直接的方式唤醒她。

‘Are you ill, Edward?’ she said, rising immediately.
“你病了吗，爱德华？”她立即站了起来。

‘I felt some uneasiness in a reclining posture. I will sit here for a time.’ She threw wood on the fire, wrapped herself up, and said, ‘You would like me to read to you?’
“我在躺着的姿势中感到有些不安。我会在这里坐一会儿。”她把木头扔到火上，把自己裹起来，说：“你想让我念书给你听吗？

‘You would oblige me greatly by doing so, Dorothea,’ said Mr. Casaubon, with a shade more meekness than usual in his polite manner. ‘I am wakeful: my mind is remarkably lucid.’
“多萝西娅，你这样做真是太感激我了，”卡苏邦先生说道，他的礼貌态度比平时更加​​温和。 “我醒了：我的头脑非常清醒。”

‘I fear that the excitement may be too great for you,’ said Dorothea, remembering Lydgate’s cautions.
“我担心这种兴奋对你来说可能太大了，”多萝西娅说道，想起了利德盖特的警告。

‘No, I am not conscious of undue excitement. Thought is easy.’ Dorothea dared not insist, and she read for an hour or more on the same plan as she had done in the evening, but getting over the pages with more quickness. Mr. Casaubon’s mind was more alert, and he seemed to anticipate what was coming after a very slight verbal indication, saying, ‘That will do—mark that’—or ‘Pass on to the next head—I omit the second excursus on Crete.’ Dorothea was amazed to think of the bird-like speed with which his mind was surveying the ground where it had been creeping for years. At last he said—
“不，我没有意识到过度的兴奋。思考很容易。”多萝西娅不敢坚持，她按照晚上的计划读了一个多小时，但翻得更快了。卡苏邦先生的头脑更加警觉，他似乎预见到了在一个非常轻微的口头指示后会发生什么，他说，“那就行了——记下这一点”——或者“转到下一个标题——我省略了关于克里特岛的第二个附注多萝西娅惊讶地想到，他的思绪以鸟类般的速度审视着多年来一直在爬行的地面。最后他说——

‘Close the book now, my dear. We will resume our work to-morrow. I have deferred it too long, and would gladly see it completed. But you observe that the principle on which my selection is made, is to give adequate, and not disproportionate illustration to each of the theses enumerated in my introduction, as at present sketched. You have perceived that distinctly, Dorothea?’
“现在合上书吧，亲爱的。我们明天将恢复工作。我已经推迟了太久，很高兴看到它完成。但你注意到，我的选择的原则是对我引言中列举的每一个论点（如目前所概述的）给出充分的、而不是不成比例的说明。你已经清楚地意识到这一点了吗，多萝西娅？

‘Yes,’ said Dorothea, rather tremulously. She felt sick at heart.
“是的，”多萝西娅相当颤抖地说。她心里一阵难受。

‘And now I think that I can take some repose,’ said Mr. Casaubon. He laid down again and begged her to put out the lights. When she had lain down too, and there was a darkness only broken by a dull glow on the hearth, he said—
“现在我想我可以休息一下了，”卡苏邦先生说。他又躺了下来，恳求她把灯关掉。当她也躺下时，只有炉边的昏暗光芒打破了黑暗，他说——

‘Before I sleep, I have a request to make, Dorothea.’
“在我睡觉之前，我有一个请求，多萝西娅。”

‘What is it?’ said Dorothea, with dread in her mind.
“这是什么？”多萝西娅心中充满恐惧问道。

‘It is that you will let me know, deliberately, whether, in case of my death, you will carry out my wishes: whether you will avoid doing what I should deprecate, and apply yourself to do what I should desire.’
“你会故意让我知道，如果我死了，你是否会实现我的愿望：你是否会避免做我应该反对的事情，而致力于做我应该做的事情。”

Dorothea was not taken by surprise: many incidents had been leading her to the conjecture of some intention on her husband’s part which might make a new yoke for her. She did not answer immediately.
多萝西娅并不感到惊讶：许多事件让她猜测她丈夫可能有某种意图，这可能会给她带来新的枷锁。她没有立即回答。

‘You refuse?’ said Mr. Casaubon, with more edge in his tone.
“你拒绝？”卡苏邦先生说道，语气更加尖锐了。

‘No, I do not yet refuse,’ said Dorothea, in a clear voice, the need of freedom asserting itself within her; ‘but it is too solemn— I think it is not right—to make a promise when I am ignorant what it will bind me to. Whatever affection prompted I would do without promising.’
“不，我还没有拒绝。”多萝西娅用清晰的声音说道，她内心渴望自由。 “但是，当我不知道承诺将如何约束我时，做出承诺就太庄严了——我认为这是不对的。”无论感情激发什么，我都会去做，但不会做出任何承诺。

‘But you would use your own judgment: I ask you to obey mine; you refuse.’
“但你会用你自己的判断：我要求你服从我的；你拒绝。

‘No, dear, no!’ said Dorothea, beseechingly, crushed by opposing fears. ‘But may I wait and reflect a little while? I desire with my whole soul to do what will comfort you; but I cannot give any pledge suddenly— still less a pledge to do I know not what.’
“不，亲爱的，不！”多萝西娅恳求地说，被相反的恐惧压垮了。 “但是我可以等一下并思考一下吗？”我全心全意地渴望做一些能让你感到安慰的事情；但我不能突然做出任何承诺——更不用说承诺做我不知道的事情了。

‘You cannot then confide in the nature of my wishes?’
“那么你就不能相信我的愿望吗？”

‘Grant me till to-morrow,’ said Dorothea, beseechingly.
“请允许我等到明天，”多萝西娅恳求地说。

‘Till to-morrow then,’ said Mr. Casaubon.
“那就到明天吧，”卡苏邦先生说。

Soon she could hear that he was sleeping, but there was no more sleep for her. While she constrained herself to lie still lest she should disturb him, her mind was carrying on a conflict in which imagination ranged its forces first on one side and then on the other. She had no presentiment that the power which her husband wished to establish over her future action had relation to anything else than his work. But it was clear enough to her that he would expect her to devote herself to sifting those mixed heaps of material, which were to be the doubtful illustration of principles still more doubtful. The poor child had become altogether unbelieving as to the trustworthiness of that Key which had made the ambition and the labor of her husband’s life. It was not wonderful that, in spite of her small instruction, her judgment in this matter was truer than his: for she looked with unbiassed comparison and healthy sense at probabilities on which he had risked all his egoism. And now she pictured to herself the days, and months, and years which she must spend in sorting what might be called shattered mummies, and fragments of a tradition which was itself a mosaic wrought from crushed ruins—sorting them as food for a theory which was already withered in the birth like an elfin child. Doubtless a vigorous error vigorously pursued has kept the embryos of truth a-breathing: the quest of gold being at the same time a questioning of substances, the body of chemistry is prepared for its soul, and Lavoisier is born. But Mr. Casaubon’s theory of the elements which made the seed of all tradition was not likely to bruise itself unawares against discoveries: it floated among flexible conjectures no more solid than those etymologies which seemed strong because of likeness in sound until it was shown that likeness in sound made them impossible: it was a method of interpretation which was not tested by the necessity of forming anything which had sharper collisions than an elaborate notion of Gog and Magog: it was as free from interruption as a plan for threading the stars together. And Dorothea had so often had to check her weariness and impatience over this questionable riddle-guessing, as it revealed itself to her instead of the fellowship in high knowledge which was to make life worthier! She could understand well enough now why her husband had come to cling to her, as possibly the only hope left that his labors would ever take a shape in which they could be given to the world. At first it had seemed that he wished to keep even her aloof from any close knowledge of what he was doing; but gradually the terrible stringency of human need—the prospect of a too speedy death—
很快她就听到他睡着了，但她却再也睡不着了。虽然她强迫自己静静地躺着，以免打扰他，但她的思想却在进行着一场冲突，想象力首先将其力量集中在一侧，然后又转移到另一侧。她没有预感到她丈夫希望对她未来的行动建立的权力与他的工作以外的任何其他事情有关。但她很清楚，他希望她全身心地筛选那些混杂的材料，这些材料是对更值得怀疑的原则的可疑说明。这个可怜的孩子已经完全不相信这把钥匙的可靠性，这把钥匙成就了她丈夫一生的抱负和努力。这并不奇怪，尽管她的指导很少，但她在这件事上的判断比他的更真实：因为她以公正的比较和健康的感觉来看待他冒着所有利己主义的风险的可能性。现在，她向自己描绘了她必须花费多少天、月、年来整理那些可能被称为破碎的木乃伊的东西，以及传统的碎片，而传统的碎片本身就是由破碎的废墟制成的马赛克——将它们分类为一种理论的素材，该理论就像一个小精灵一样，在出生时就已经枯萎了。毫无疑问，一个大力追求的错误使真理的胚胎得以呼吸：对黄金的追求同时也是对物质的质疑，化学的躯体为它的灵魂做好了准备，拉瓦锡诞生了。但先生。 卡苏朋的关于构成所有传统种子的要素的理论不可能在不知不觉中受到发现的打击：它漂浮在灵活的猜想中，并不比那些因声音相似而显得强大的词源更坚固，直到有人证明声音相似使得它们是不可能的：这是一种解释方法，没有经过形成任何比歌革和玛各的复杂概念具有更尖锐碰撞的必要性的考验：它就像将星星串在一起的计划一样不受干扰。多萝西娅经常不得不抑制自己对这种可疑的猜谜语的厌倦和不耐烦，因为它向她展示了自己，而不是让生活更有价值的高深知识的友谊！她现在很清楚为什么她的丈夫会依附于她，这可能是他的劳动成果能够呈现给世界的唯一希望。 起初，他似乎甚至想让她远离他所做的事情。但渐渐地，人类的需求变得可怕而紧迫——死亡太快的前景——

And here Dorothea’s pity turned from her own future to her husband’s past—nay, to his present hard struggle with a lot which had grown out of that past: the lonely labor, the ambition breathing hardly under the pressure of self-distrust; the goal receding, and the heavier limbs; and now at last the sword visibly trembling above him! And had she not wished to marry him that she might help him in his life’s labor?—But she had thought the work was to be something greater, which she could serve in devoutly for its own sake. Was it right, even to soothe his grief—would it be possible, even if she promised—to work as in a treadmill fruitlessly?
在这里，多萝西娅的怜悯从她自己的未来转向了她丈夫的过去——不，是转向他现在与许多源自过去的事物的艰苦斗争：孤独的劳动，在自我不信任的压力下几乎喘不过气来的野心；目标越来越远，四肢越来越沉重；现在，剑终于在他上方明显颤抖了！难道她不想嫁给他，以便在他一生的工作中帮助他吗？——但她认为这项工作是更伟大的事情，她可以为了它本身而虔诚地服务。即使是为了抚慰他的悲伤——即使她答应了——像在跑步机上一样徒劳无功地工作，这是正确的吗？

And yet, could she deny him? Could she say, ‘I refuse to content this pining hunger?’ It would be refusing to do for him dead, what she was almost sure to do for him living. If he lived as Lydgate had said he might, for fifteen years or more, her life would certainly be spent in helping him and obeying him.
然而，她能拒绝他吗？她能说：“我拒绝满足这令人窒息的饥饿吗？”那就等于拒绝为死去的他做她几乎肯定会为他活着做的事情。如果他像利德盖特所说的那样生活十五年或更长时间，她的一生肯定会花在帮助他和服从他上。

Still, there was a deep difference between that devotion to the living and that indefinite promise of devotion to the dead. While he lived, he could claim nothing that she would not still be free to remonstrate against, and even to refuse. But— the thought passed through her mind more than once, though she could not believe in it—might he not mean to demand something more from her than she had been able to imagine, since he wanted her pledge to carry out his wishes without telling her exactly what they were? No; his heart was bound up in his work only: that was the end for which his failing life was to be eked out by hers.
尽管如此，对生者的奉献和对死者的无限期奉献之间仍然存在着深刻的区别。当他活着的时候，他所提出的任何要求，她仍然可以自由地抗议，甚至拒绝。但是——这个想法不止一次地在她脑海中闪过，尽管她无法相信——他是否有意向她提出超出她想象的要求，因为他希望她保证在不告诉的情况下实现他的愿望。她到底是什么人？不;他的心只专注于他的工作：这就是他失败的生活将由她的生活来弥补的最终目的。

And now, if she were to say, ‘No! if you die, I will put no finger to your work’—it seemed as if she would be crushing that bruised heart.
现在，如果她说：‘不！如果你死了，我不会对你的工作置之不理”——似乎她会压碎那颗受伤的心。

For four hours Dorothea lay in this conflict, till she felt ill and bewildered, unable to resolve, praying mutely. Helpless as a child which has sobbed and sought too long, she fell into a late morning sleep, and when she waked Mr. Casaubon was already up. Tantripp told her that he had read prayers, breakfasted, and was in the library.
多萝西娅在这场冲突中躺了四个小时，直到她感到不适和困惑，无法解决，默默地祈祷。她就像一个哭泣和寻求太久的孩子一样无助，在清晨睡得很晚，当她醒来时，卡苏邦先生已经起床了。坦特里普告诉她，他已经读过祈祷文，吃过早餐，现在正在图书馆。

‘I never saw you look so pale, madam,’ said Tantripp, a solid-figured woman who had been with the sisters at Lausanne.
“我从来没有见过你脸色这么苍白，女士，”曾在洛桑与姐妹们在一起的身材魁梧的坦特里普说道。

‘Was I ever high-colored, Tantripp?’ said Dorothea, smiling faintly.
“坦特里普，我的肤色曾经很华丽吗？”多萝西娅微微一笑说道。

‘Well, not to say high-colored, but with a bloom like a Chiny rose. But always smelling those leather books, what can be expected? Do rest a little this morning, madam. Let me say you are ill and not able to go into that close library.’
‘嗯，不是说色彩鲜艳，而是像中国玫瑰一样绽放。但总闻那些皮书的味道，还能指望什么呢？女士，今天早上请休息一下。让我说你病了，无法进入那个封闭的图书馆。

‘Oh no, no! let me make haste,’ said Dorothea. ‘Mr. Casaubon wants me particularly.’
‘哦不，不！让我抓紧时间，”多萝西娅说。 '先生。卡索邦特别想要我。

When she went down she felt sure that she should promise to fulfil his wishes; but that would be later in the day—not yet.
当她下去时，她确信她应该答应满足他的愿望；但那是在当天晚些时候——还不是时候。

As Dorothea entered the library, Mr. Casaubon turned round from the table where he had been placing some books, and said—
当多萝西娅走进图书馆时，卡苏邦先生从他放着一些书的桌子旁转过身来，说道——

‘I was waiting for your appearance, my dear. I had hoped to set to work at once this morning, but I find myself under some indisposition, probably from too much excitement yesterday. I am going now to take a turn in the shrubbery, since the air is milder.’
“我一直在等待你的出现，亲爱的。我原本希望今天早上就可以开始工作，但我发现自己有些不舒服，可能是因为昨天太兴奋了。我现在要去灌木丛转转，因为空气更温和了。

‘I am glad to hear that,’ said Dorothea. ‘Your mind, I feared, was too active last night.’
“我很高兴听到这个消息，”多萝西娅说。 “我担心你昨晚脑子太活跃了。”

‘I would fain have it set at rest on the point I last spoke of, Dorothea. You can now, I hope, give me an answer.’
“我希望它能停留在我上次谈到的那个点上，多萝西娅。我希望你现在可以给我答案。

‘May I come out to you in the garden presently?’ said Dorothea, winning a little breathing space in that way.
“我可以到花园里去找你吗？”多萝西娅说道，这样就赢得了一点喘息的空间。

‘I shall be in the Yew-tree Walk for the next half-hour,’ said Mr. Casaubon, and then he left her.
“接下来的半个小时我会在紫杉树步道上，”卡苏邦先生说，然后就离开了她。

Dorothea, feeling very weary, rang and asked Tantripp to bring her some wraps. She had been sitting still for a few minutes, but not in any renewal of the former conflict: she simply felt that she was going to say ‘Yes’ to her own doom: she was too weak, too full of dread at the thought of inflicting a keen-edged blow on her husband, to do anything but submit completely. She sat still and let Tantripp put on her bonnet and shawl, a passivity which was unusual with her, for she liked to wait on herself.
多萝西娅感到非常疲倦，打电话让坦特里普给她拿一些包裹。她一动不动地坐了几分钟，但并没有重蹈之前的冲突的覆辙：她只是觉得自己要对自己的厄运说“是”：她太虚弱了，一想到这个，她就充满了恐惧。对她的丈夫造成了尖锐的打击，除了完全屈服之外，她什么也做不了。她一动不动地坐着，让坦特里普戴上帽子和披肩，这种被动态度对她来说很不寻常，因为她喜欢伺候自己。

‘God bless you, madam!’ said Tantripp, with an irrepressible movement of love towards the beautiful, gentle creature for whom she felt unable to do anything more, now that she had finished tying the bonnet.
“上帝保佑您，女士！”坦特里普说，她已经把帽子系好了，对这个美丽、温柔的生物充满了无法抑制的爱意。

This was too much for Dorothea’s highly-strung feeling, and she burst into tears, sobbing against Tantripp’s arm. But soon she checked herself, dried her eyes, and went out at the glass door into the shrubbery.
这让多萝西娅高度紧张的感觉难以承受，她放声大哭，靠在坦特里普的手臂上抽泣。但很快她就​​检查了自己，擦干眼睛，从玻璃门出去，走进了灌木丛。

‘I wish every book in that library was built into a caticom for your master,’ said Tantripp to Pratt, the butler, finding him in the breakfast-room. She had been at Rome, and visited the antiquities, as we know; and she always declined to call Mr. Casaubon anything but ‘your master,’ when speaking to the other servants.
“我希望图书馆里的每一本书都能成为你主人的一部猫科喜剧，”坦特里普在早餐室里找到了管家普拉特，对他说道。据我们所知，她曾去过罗马，参观过古物。在与其他仆人交谈时，她总是拒绝称呼卡苏朋先生，只称呼他为“您的主人”。

Pratt laughed. He liked his master very well, but he liked Tantripp better.
普拉特笑了。他很喜欢他的主人，但他更喜欢坦特里普。

When Dorothea was out on the gravel walks, she lingered among the nearer clumps of trees, hesitating, as she had done once before, though from a different cause. Then she had feared lest her effort at fellowship should be unwelcome; now she dreaded going to the spot where she foresaw that she must bind herself to a fellowship from which she shrank. Neither law nor the world’s opinion compelled her to this—only her husband’s nature and her own compassion, only the ideal and not the real yoke of marriage. She saw clearly enough the whole situation, yet she was fettered: she could not smite the stricken soul that entreated hers. If that were weakness, Dorothea was weak. But the half-hour was passing, and she must not delay longer. When she entered the Yew-tree Walk she could not see her husband; but the walk had bends, and she went, expecting to catch sight of his figure wrapped in a blue cloak, which, with a warm velvet cap, was his outer garment on chill days for the garden. It occurred to her that he might be resting in the summer-house, towards which the path diverged a little. Turning the angle, she could see him seated on the bench, close to a stone table. His arms were resting on the table, and his brow was bowed down on them, the blue cloak being dragged forward and screening his face on each side.
当多萝西娅在碎石路上行走时，她在附近的树林中徘徊，犹豫不决，就像她以前做过的那样，尽管出于不同的原因。然后她担心自己在团契方面的努力会不受欢迎。现在，她害怕去到她预见到必须将自己束缚在一种令她退缩的团契之中的地方。法律和世俗的观点都没有迫使她这样做——只有她丈夫的本性和她自己的同情心，只有婚姻的理想而不是真正的枷锁。她清楚地看到了整个情况，但她却受到了束缚：她无法打击恳求她的受伤的灵魂。如果这就是弱点的话，那么多萝西娅就是软弱的。但半个小时已经过去了，她不能再耽搁了。当她进入紫杉树步道时，她看不到她的丈夫。但这条路有弯道，她走着走着，希望能看到他裹着一件蓝色斗篷的身影，这件斗篷戴着一顶温暖的天鹅绒帽子，是他在寒冷的日子里在花园里穿的外衣。她想到他可能正在避暑别墅里休息，通往避暑别墅的小路有一点岔道。转过角度，看到他坐在长凳上，靠近一张石桌。他的手臂搁在桌子上，眉毛低垂在手臂上，蓝色斗篷被向前拖着，遮住了他脸的两侧。

‘He exhausted himself last night,’ Dorothea said to herself, thinking at first that he was asleep, and that the summer-house was too damp a place to rest in. But then she remembered that of late she had seen him take that attitude when she was reading to him, as if he found it easier than any other; and that he would sometimes speak, as well as listen, with his face down in that way. She went into the summerhouse and said, ‘I am come, Edward; I am ready.’
“他昨晚已经筋疲力尽了，”多萝西娅自言自语道，起初以为他睡着了，避暑别墅太潮湿了，不适合休息。但后来她想起，最近她看到他采取了这种态度。当她给他读书时，他觉得这比其他任何事情都容易；他有时会这样低下头说话和听。她走进凉亭说道：“我来了，爱德华；我已经准备好了。'

He took no notice, and she thought that he must be fast asleep. She laid her hand on his shoulder, and repeated, ‘I am ready!’ Still he was motionless; and with a sudden confused fear, she leaned down to him, took off his velvet cap, and leaned her cheek close to his head, crying in a distressed tone—
他没有理睬，她想他一定是睡熟了。她把手放在他的肩膀上，重复道：“我准备好了！”他仍然一动不动。她突然感到一阵莫名的恐惧，她俯下身子，摘下他的天鹅绒帽子，把脸颊贴在他的头上，用痛苦的语气哭道——

‘Wake, dear, wake! Listen to me. I am come to answer.’ But Dorothea never gave her answer.
‘醒来吧，亲爱的，醒来吧！听我说。我是来回答的。”但多萝西娅始终没有给出答案。

Later in the day, Lydgate was seated by her bedside, and she was talking deliriously, thinking aloud, and recalling what had gone through her mind the night before. She knew him, and called him by his name, but appeared to think it right that she should explain everything to him; and again, and again, begged him to explain everything to her husband.
当天晚些时候，利德盖特坐在她的床边，她神志不清地说话，大声思考，回忆着前一天晚上脑子里发生的事情。她认识他，也叫过他的名字，但似乎认为她应该向他解释一切。一次又一次恳求他向丈夫解释一切。

‘Tell him I shall go to him soon: I am ready to promise. Only, thinking about it was so dreadful—it has made me ill. Not very ill. I shall soon be better. Go and tell him.’
“告诉他我很快就会去找他：我已经准备好答应了。”只是，一想到这件事就太可怕了——它让我生病了。病得不重。我很快就会好起来的。去告诉他吧。

But the silence in her husband’s ear was never more to be broken.
但她丈夫耳边的沉默再也没有被打破。

CHAPTER XLIX
第二十九章

A task too strong for wizard spells
对于巫师咒语来说任务太艰巨

This squire had brought about;
这位乡绅带来了；

‘T is easy dropping stones in wells,
“往井里扔石头很容易，

But who shall get them out?’
但谁能把他们救出来呢？

‘I wish to God we could hinder Dorothea from knowing this,’ said Sir James Chettam, with a little frown on his brow, and an expression of intense disgust about his mouth.
“我希望上帝能阻止多萝西娅知道这一点，”詹姆斯·切塔姆爵士说道，他的眉头微微皱起，嘴里流露出强烈的厌恶之情。

He was standing on the hearth-rug in the library at Lowick Grange, and speaking to Mr. Brooke. It was the day after Mr. Casaubon had been buried, and Dorothea was not yet able to leave her room.
他正站在洛威克农庄图书馆的炉边地毯上，和布鲁克先生说话。那是卡苏邦先生下葬后的第二天，多萝西娅还无法离开她的房间。

‘That would be difficult, you know, Chettam, as she is an executrix, and she likes to go into these things—property, land, that kind of thing. She has her notions, you know,’ said Mr. Brooke, sticking his eye-glasses on nervously, and exploring the edges of a folded paper which he held in his hand; ‘and she would like to act— depend upon it, as an executrix Dorothea would want to act. And she was twenty-one last December, you know. I can hinder nothing.’
“这会很困难，你知道，切塔姆，因为她是执行人，她喜欢涉足这些事情——财产、土地，诸如此类的事情。”你知道，她有她的想法。”布鲁克先生紧张地戴上眼镜，探索着手里拿着的一张折叠纸的边缘。 “她愿意采取行动——取决于它，就像执行人多萝西娅想要采取的行动一样。”你知道，去年十二月她二十一岁。我什么也不能阻止。

Sir James looked at the carpet for a minute in silence, and then lifting his eyes suddenly fixed them on Mr. Brooke, saying, ‘I will tell you what we can do. Until Dorothea is well, all business must be kept from her, and as soon as she is able to be moved she must come to us. Being with Celia and the baby will be the best thing in the world for her, and will pass away the time. And meanwhile you must get rid of Ladislaw: you must send him out of the country.’ Here Sir James’s look of disgust returned in all its intensity.
詹姆斯爵士沉默地看了地毯一分钟，然后突然抬起眼睛盯着布鲁克先生，说道：“我来告诉你我们能做什么。”在多萝西娅康复之前，一切事务都不得与她接触，一旦她能够搬家，她就必须来找我们。与西莉亚和孩子在一起对她来说是世界上最好的事情，并且会消磨时间。与此同时，你必须除掉拉迪斯瓦夫：你必须把他赶出这个国家。”说到这里，詹姆斯爵士的厌恶表情再次变得最强烈。

Mr. Brooke put his hands behind him, walked to the window and straightened his back with a little shake before he replied.
布鲁克先生双手背在身后，走到窗前，微微颤抖地挺直了背脊，才回答道。

‘That is easily said, Chettam, easily said, you know.’
“这很容易说，切塔姆，很容易说，你知道。”

‘My dear sir,’ persisted Sir James, restraining his indignation within respectful forms, ‘it was you who brought him here, and you who keep him here—I mean by the occupation you give him.’
“我亲爱的先生，”詹姆斯爵士继续说道，以恭敬的方式抑制着自己的愤怒，“是您把他带到这里来的，也是您让他留在这里的——我指的是您给他的职业。”

‘Yes, but I can’t dismiss him in an instant without assigning reasons, my dear Chettam. Ladislaw has been invaluable, most satisfactory. I consider that I have done this part of the country a service by bringing him—by bringing him, you know.’ Mr. Brooke ended with a nod, turning round to give it.
“是的，但我不能在没有说明理由的情况下立即解雇他，亲爱的切塔姆。拉迪斯瓦夫是无价的，最令人满意的。我认为我通过带他来为这个国家的这一地区做出了贡献——通过带他来，你知道。”布鲁克先生最后点了点头，转身表示同意。

‘It’s a pity this part of the country didn’t do without him, that’s all I have to say about it. At any rate, as Dorothea’s brother-in-law, I feel warranted in objecting strongly to his being kept here by any action on the part of her friends. You admit, I hope, that I have a right to speak about what concerns the dignity of my wife’s sister?’
“遗憾的是这个国家的这个地区没有他，这就是我要说的。无论如何，作为多萝西娅的妹夫，我觉得有理由强烈反对她朋友们的任何行为将他留在这里。我希望你承认我有权谈论涉及我妻子妹妹尊严的问题？

Sir James was getting warm.
詹姆斯爵士开始暖和起来。

‘Of course, my dear Chettam, of course. But you and I have different ideas—different—‘
“当然，我亲爱的切塔姆，当然。但你和我有不同的想法——不同——”

‘Not about this action of Casaubon’s, I should hope,’ interrupted Sir James. ‘I say that he has most unfairly compromised Dorothea. I say that there never was a meaner, more ungentlemanly action than this—a codicil of this sort to a will which he made at the time of his marriage with the knowledge and reliance of her family— a positive insult to Dorothea!’
“我希望不是关于卡苏朋的这次行动，”詹姆斯爵士打断道。 “我说他对多萝西娅做出了最不公平的妥协。我想说，从来没有比这更卑鄙、更不绅士的行为了——他在结婚时在她家人的知情和信任下制定了这样的遗嘱附录——这是对多萝西娅的公开侮辱！

‘Well, you know, Casaubon was a little twisted about Ladislaw. Ladislaw has told me the reason—dislike of the bent he took, you know— Ladislaw didn’t think much of Casaubon’s notions, Thoth and Dagon— that sort of thing: and I fancy that Casaubon didn’t like the independent position Ladislaw had taken up. I saw the letters between them, you know. Poor Casaubon was a little buried in books— he didn’t know the world.’
“嗯，你知道，卡苏朋对拉迪斯瓦夫有点扭曲。拉迪斯瓦夫告诉了我原因——不喜欢他所采取的倾向，你知道——拉迪斯瓦夫对卡苏朋的观念、透特和大衮没有太多的看法——诸如此类的事情：而且我认为卡苏朋不喜欢拉迪斯瓦夫的独立立场占用。我看到了他们之间的信件，你知道。可怜的卡索邦有点沉浸在书本中——他不了解这个世界。

‘It’s all very well for Ladislaw to put that color on it,’ said Sir James. ‘But I believe Casaubon was only jealous of him on Dorothea’s account, and the world will suppose that she gave him some reason; and that is what makes it so abominable— coupling her name with this young fellow’s.’
“拉迪斯瓦夫把这种颜色涂在上面真是太好了，”詹姆斯爵士说。 “但我相信卡苏朋只是因为多萝西娅的缘故而嫉妒他，全世界都会认为她给了他一些理由；这就是让它如此令人厌恶的原因——把她的名字和这个年轻人的名字联系在一起。

‘My dear Chettam, it won’t lead to anything, you know,’ said Mr. Brooke, seating himself and sticking on his eye- glass again. ‘It’s all of a piece with Casaubon’s oddity. This paper, now, ‘Synoptical Tabulation’ and so on, ‘for the use of Mrs. Casaubon,’ it was locked up in the desk with the will. I suppose he meant Dorothea to publish his researches, eh? and she’ll do it, you know; she has gone into his studies uncommonly.’
“我亲爱的切塔姆，你知道，这不会带来任何结果，”布鲁克先生说着，坐了下来，再次戴上眼镜。 “这与卡索邦的古怪之处息息相关。这张纸，现在是《天气表》等等，“供卡苏邦夫人使用”，它和遗嘱一起锁在桌子上。我想他是想让多萝西娅发表他的研究成果，嗯？你知道，她会做到的；她对他的学习非常不寻常。

‘My dear sir,’ said Sir James, impatiently, ‘that is neither here nor there. The question is, whether you don’t see with me the propriety of sending young Ladislaw away?’
“亲爱的先生，”詹姆斯爵士不耐烦地说，“那既不在这里也不在那里。问题是，你是否不认为把年轻的拉迪斯瓦夫送走是合适的？

‘Well, no, not the urgency of the thing. By-and-by, perhaps, it may come round. As to gossip, you know, sending him away won’t hinder gossip. People say what they like to say, not what they have chapter and verse for,’ said Mr Brooke, becoming acute about the truths that lay on the side of his own wishes. ‘I might get rid of Ladislaw up to a certain point—take away the ‘Pioneer’ from him, and that sort of thing; but I couldn’t send him out of the country if he didn’t choose to go—didn’t choose, you know.’
“嗯，不，事情不紧急。也许，不久之后，它就会出现。至于流言蜚语，你知道，把他送走并不妨碍流言蜚语。人们说他们想说的话，而不是他们有章节和诗句的内容，”布鲁克先生说，他对不利于他自己愿望的事实变得敏锐。 “在某种程度上，我可能会摆脱拉迪斯瓦夫——从他手中夺走‘先锋’，诸如此类的事情；但如果他不选择离开，我就不能把他送出国——没有选择，你知道。”

Mr. Brooke, persisting as quietly as if he were only discussing the nature of last year’s weather, and nodding at the end with his usual amenity, was an exasperating form of obstinacy.
布鲁克先生静静地坚持着，仿佛他只是在讨论去年天气的本质，最后还像往常一样和蔼可亲地点点头，这是一种令人恼火的固执。

‘Good God!’ said Sir James, with as much passion as he ever showed, ‘let us get him a post; let us spend money on him. If he could go in the suite of some Colonial Governor! Grampus might take him— and I could write to Fulke about it.’
“天哪！”詹姆斯爵士带着一如既往的热情说道，“让我们给他一个职位吧！”让我们为他花钱吧。如果他能去某个殖民地总督的套房就好了！鲸八可能会带走他——我可以写信给富尔克告知此事。

‘But Ladislaw won’t be shipped off like a head of cattle, my dear fellow; Ladislaw has his ideas. It’s my opinion that if he were to part from me to-morrow, you’d only hear the more of him in the country. With his talent for speaking and drawing up documents, there are few men who could come up to him as an agitator—an agitator, you know.’
“但是拉迪斯瓦夫不会像一头牛一样被运走，亲爱的朋友；拉迪斯瓦夫有他的想法。我认为，如果他明天离开我，你只会在乡下听到更多关于他的消息。以他的演讲和起草文件的天赋，很少有人能比得上他作为煽动者——你知道的，一个煽动者。

‘Agitator!’ said Sir James, with bitter emphasis, feeling that the syllables of this word properly repeated were a sufficient exposure of its hatefulness.
“煽动者！”詹姆斯爵士尖刻地说道，他觉得这个词的音节被正确地重复就足以暴露出它的可恨性。

‘But be reasonable, Chettam. Dorothea, now. As you say, she had better go to Celia as soon as possible. She can stay under your roof, and in the mean time things may come round quietly. Don’t let us be firing off our guns in a hurry, you know. Standish will keep our counsel, and the news will be old before it’s known. Twenty things may happen to carry off Ladislaw— without my doing anything, you know.’
“但是要讲道理，切塔姆。多萝西娅，现在。正如你所说，她最好尽快去找西莉亚。她可以住在你的屋檐下，同时事情可能会悄然发生。你知道，不要让我们匆忙开枪。斯坦迪什会遵守我们的建议，而消息在得知之前就已经过时了。可能会发生二十件事来夺走拉迪斯瓦夫——你知道，我什么都不做。”

‘Then I am to conclude that you decline to do anything?’
“那么我的结论是你拒绝做任何事情？”

‘Decline, Chettam?—no—I didn’t say decline. But I really don’t see what I could do. Ladislaw is a gentleman.’
“拒绝，切塔姆？——不——我没有说拒绝。但我真的不知道我能做什么。拉迪斯瓦夫是一位绅士。

‘I am glad to hear It!’ said Sir James, his irritation making him forget himself a little. ‘I am sure Casaubon was not.’
“我很高兴听到这个消息！”詹姆斯爵士说，他的恼怒让他有点忘记了自己。 “我确信卡苏邦不是。”

‘Well, it would have been worse if he had made the codicil to hinder her from marrying again at all, you know.’
“嗯，你知道，如果他制定附录来阻止她再次结婚，情况会更糟。”

‘I don’t know that,’ said Sir James. ‘It would have been less indelicate.’
“我不知道，”詹姆斯爵士说。 “这样就不会那么不雅了。”

‘One of poor Casaubon’s freaks! That attack upset his brain a little. It all goes for nothing. She doesn’t WANT to marry Ladislaw.’
‘可怜的卡索邦的怪胎之一！那次攻击让他的大脑有些混乱。这一切都是徒劳的。她不想嫁给拉迪斯瓦夫。

‘But this codicil is framed so as to make everybody believe that she did. I don’t believe anything of the sort about Dorothea,’ said Sir James— then frowningly, ‘but I suspect Ladislaw. I tell you frankly, I suspect Ladislaw.’
“但这份附录的目的是让每个人都相信她做到了。我不相信关于多萝西娅的任何事情，”詹姆斯爵士说道，然后皱起眉头，“但我怀疑拉迪斯洛。我坦白地告诉你，我怀疑拉迪斯瓦夫。

‘I couldn’t take any immediate action on that ground, Chettam. In fact, if it were possible to pack him off—send him to Norfolk Island— that sort of thing—it would look all the worse for Dorothea to those who knew about it. It would seem as if we distrusted her— distrusted her, you know.’
“我无法就此采取任何立即行动，切塔姆。事实上，如果有可能把他打发走——送他去诺福克岛——诸如此类的事情——对于那些知道这件事的人来说，多萝西娅的处境会更糟。看起来我们好像不信任她——不信任她，你知道的。

That Mr. Brooke had hit on an undeniable argument, did not tend to soothe Sir James. He put out his hand to reach his hat, implying that he did not mean to contend further, and said, still with some heat—
布鲁克先生提出了一个无可否认的论点，但这并不能安抚詹姆斯爵士。他伸手摸了摸帽子，示意他没有再争辩的意思，语气中带着几分热情说道——

‘Well, I can only say that I think Dorothea was sacrificed once, because her friends were too careless. I shall do what I can, as her brother, to protect her now.’
‘好吧，我只能说我认为多萝西娅被牺牲了一次，因为她的朋友们太粗心了。作为她的兄弟，我现在将尽我所能来保护她。

‘You can’t do better than get her to Freshitt as soon as possible, Chettam. I approve that plan altogether,’ said Mr. Brooke, well pleased that he had won the argument. It would have been highly inconvenient to him to part with Ladislaw at that time, when a dissolution might happen any day, and electors were to be convinced of the course by which the interests of the country would be best served. Mr. Brooke sincerely believed that this end could be secured by his own return to Parliament: he offered the forces of his mind honestly to the nation.
“切塔姆，你最好尽快把她送到弗雷希特。”我完全同意这个计划。”布鲁克先生说，他很高兴自己赢得了这场争论。那时与拉迪斯瓦夫分手对他来说是非常不方便的，因为解散随时可能发生，选民们必须相信最有利于国家利益的方针。布鲁克先生真诚地相信，他自己重返议会就可以实现这一目标：他诚实地向国家提供了自己的思想力量。

‘This Loller here wol precilen us somewhat.’

‘Nay by my father’s soule! that schal he nat,’

Canterbury Tales.
坎特伯雷寓言（故事。

Dorothea had been safe at Freshitt Hall nearly a week before she had askeVVd any dangerous questions. Every morning now she sat with Celia in the prettiest of up-stairs sitting-rooms, opening into a small conservatory— Celia all in white and lavender like a bunch of mixed violets, watching the remarkable acts of the baby, which were so dubious to her inexperienced mind that all conversation was interrupted by appeals for their interpretation made to the oracular nurse. Dorothea sat by in her widow’s dress, with an expression which rather provoked Celia, as being much too sad; for not only was baby quite well, but really when a husband had been so dull and troublesome while he lived, and besides that had—well, well! Sir James, of course, had told Celia everything, with a strong representation how important it was that Dorothea should not know it sooner than was inevitable.
在多萝西娅问任何危险问题之前，她已经安全地待在弗雷西特庄园近一周了。现在每天早上，她都会和西莉亚一起坐在楼上最漂亮的起居室里，客厅通向一个小温室——西莉亚穿着白色和淡紫色的衣服，就像一束混合紫罗兰，看着婴儿的非凡行为，这些行为对她来说是如此可疑。她的头脑缺乏经验，所有的谈话都被向神谕护士解释的请求打断了。多萝西娅穿着寡妇的衣服坐在旁边，她的表情让西莉亚很恼火，因为她太悲伤了。因为不仅宝贝身体很好，而且当丈夫活着的时候是如此迟钝和麻烦，除此之外，还有——好吧，好吧！当然，詹姆斯爵士已经把一切都告诉了西莉亚，并强烈表示多萝西娅不应该早点知道这件事是多么重要。

But Mr. Brooke had been right in predicting that Dorothea would not long remain passive where action had been assigned to her; she knew the purport of her husband’s will made at the time of their marriage, and her mind, as soon as she was clearly conscious of her position, was silently occupied with what she ought to do as the owner of Lowick Manor with the patronage of the living attached to it.
但布鲁克先生的预测是正确的，多萝西娅不会长期在分配给她的行动中保持被动。她知道她丈夫在结婚时立下的遗嘱的要旨，当她清楚地意识到自己的地位时，她的心思就默默地专注于她作为洛威克庄园的主人在洛威克庄园的赞助下应该做的事情。依附于其的生者。

One morning when her uncle paid his usual visit, though with an unusual alacrity in his manner which he accounted for by saying that it was now pretty certain Parliament would be dissolved forthwith, Dorothea said—
一天早上，当她叔叔像往常一样来访时，尽管他的态度异常敏捷，他说现在可以肯定议会将立即解散，多萝西娅说——

‘Uncle, it is right now that I should consider who is to have the living at Lowick. After Mr. Tucker had been provided for, I never heard my husband say that he had any clergyman in his mind as a successor to himself. I think I ought to have the keys now and go to Lowick to examine all my husband’s papers. There may be something that would throw light on his wishes.’
“叔叔，现在我应该考虑谁在洛威克生活。在塔克先生被供养之后，我从未听我丈夫说过他心中有任何牧师作为他的继承人。我想我现在应该拿到钥匙，去洛威克检查我丈夫的所有文件。也许有什么东西可以阐明他的愿望。

‘No hurry, my dear,’ said Mr. Brooke, quietly. ‘By-and-by, you know, you can go, if you like. But I cast my eyes over things in the desks and drawers—there was nothing—nothing but deep subjects, you know—besides the will. Everything can be done by-and-by. As to the living, I have had an application for interest already— I should say rather good. Mr. Tyke has been strongly recommended to me—I had something to do with getting him an appointment before.
