But it is a pity that young Lydgate should have married one of these Middlemarch girls. Considering he’s a son of somebody, he might have got a woman with good blood in her veins, and not too young, who would have put up with his profession. There’s Clara Harfager, for instance, whose friends don’t know what to do with her; and she has a portion. Then we might have had her among us. However!—it’s no use being wise for other people. Where is Celia? Pray let us go in.’
詹姆斯爵士看了她一眼，后悔自己的计谋。但卡德瓦拉德夫人在任何场合都一样，摊开手掌说道：“老天保佑，亲爱的！”我的意思是，所有关于任何人的坏故事都可能是假的。但遗憾的是，年轻的利德盖特本应该娶其中一位米德尔马契女孩为妻。考虑到他是某人的儿子，他可能有一个血管里流淌着良好血液的女人，而且不太年轻，她会忍受他的职业。例如，克拉拉·哈法格 (Clara Harfager) 的朋友们不知道该拿她怎么办；她也有一份。那么我们可能就会有她在我们中间。然而！——聪明对其他人来说是没有用的。西莉亚在哪里？请让我们进去吧。

‘I am going on immediately to Tipton,’ said Dorothea, rather haughtily. ‘Good-by.’
“我马上就去蒂普顿，”多萝西娅相当傲慢地说。 '有效期。'

Sir James could say nothing as he accompanied her to the carriage. He was altogether discontented with the result of a contrivance which had cost him some secret humiliation beforehand.
詹姆斯爵士陪着她走向马车，什么也没说。他对这个计划的结果非常不满意，因为这个计划让他事先蒙受了一些秘密的羞辱。

Dorothea drove along between the berried hedgerows and the shorn corn-fields, not seeing or hearing anything around. The tears came and rolled down her cheeks, but she did not know it. The world, it seemed, was turning ugly and hateful, and there was no place for her trustfulness. ‘It is not true—it is not true!’ was the voice within her that she listened to; but all the while a remembrance to which there had always clung a vague uneasiness would thrust itself on her attention—the remembrance of that day when she had found Will Ladislaw with Mrs. Lydgate, and had heard his voice accompanied by the piano.
多萝西娅开车穿过长满浆果的树篱和修剪过的玉米地，没有看到或听到周围有任何东西。泪水顺着脸颊流下来，但她自己却浑然不觉。世界似乎变得丑陋而充满仇恨，她的信任已无立足之地。 “这不是真的——这不是真的！”这是她内心的声音。但一直以来，一种一直笼罩在模糊不安之中的记忆会突然出现在她的注意力上——那天她找到了威尔·拉迪斯瓦夫和利德盖特太太，并听到了他在钢琴伴奏下的声音。

‘He said he would never do anything that I disapproved—I wish I could have told him that I disapproved of that,’ said poor Dorothea, inwardly, feeling a strange alternation between anger with Will and the passionate defence of him. ‘They all try to blacken him before me; but I will care for no pain, if he is not to blame. I always believed he was good.’—These were her last thoughts before she felt that the carriage was passing under the archway of the lodge-gate at the Grange, when she hurriedly pressed her handkerchief to her face and began to think of her errands. The coachman begged leave to take out the horses for half an hour as there was something wrong with a shoe; and Dorothea, having the sense that she was going to rest, took off her gloves and bonnet, while she was leaning against a statue in the entrance-hall, and talking to the housekeeper. At last she said—
“他说他永远不会做任何我不赞成的事情——我希望我能告诉他我不赞成这样做，”可怜的多萝西娅内心说道，在对威尔的愤怒和对他的热情辩护之间感到一种奇怪的交替。 “他们都想在我面前抹黑他；但如果不是他的错的话，我不会在乎任何痛苦。我一直相信他是个好人。”——这是她感觉到马车驶过农庄小屋门拱门下之前的最后一个念头，她赶紧用手帕捂住脸，开始思考她的差事。 。车夫请求允许半个小时把马运出去，因为马蹄铁出了问题。多萝西娅感觉到自己要休息了，便脱下手套和帽子，靠在门厅的一尊雕像上，与管家交谈。最后她说——

‘I must stay here a little, Mrs. Kell. I will go into the library and write you some memoranda from my uncle’s letter, if you will open the shutters for me.’
“我必须在这里待一会儿，凯尔夫人。如果你愿意为我打开百叶窗的话，我会去图书馆给你写一些我叔叔信中的备忘录。

‘The shutters are open, madam,’ said Mrs. Kell, following Dorothea, who had walked along as she spoke. ‘Mr. Ladislaw is there, looking for something.’
“百叶窗是开着的，女士，”凯尔太太跟在多萝西娅身后说道，她说话时，多萝西娅也在旁边走着。 '先生。拉迪斯瓦夫在那儿，正在寻找什么东西。”

(Will had come to fetch a portfolio of his own sketches which he had missed in the act of packing his movables, and did not choose to leave behind.)
（威尔来取他自己的草图集，他在收拾动产时遗漏了这些草图，因此没有选择留下。）

Dorothea’s heart seemed to turn over as if it had had a blow, but she was not perceptibly checked: in truth, the sense that Will was there was for the moment all-satisfying to her, like the sight of something precious that one has lost. When she reached the door she said to Mrs. Kell—
多萝西娅的心似乎受到了重击，但她并没有明显地受到抑制：事实上，威尔在那儿的感觉让她此刻感到非常满意，就像看到一个人失去的珍贵的东西一样。当她到达门口时，她对凯尔太太说——

‘Go in first, and tell him that I am here.’
“你先进去吧，告诉他我在这里。”

Will had found his portfolio, and had laid it on the table at the far end of the room, to turn over the sketches and please himself by looking at the memorable piece of art which had a relation to nature too mysterious for Dorothea. He was smiling at it still, and shaking the sketches into order with the thought that he might find a letter from her awaiting him at Middlemarch, when Mrs. Kell close to his elbow said—
威尔找到了他的作品集，把它放在房间另一端的桌子上，翻阅草图，欣赏这件令人难忘的艺术品，这件艺术品与自然的关系对多萝西娅来说太神秘了。他仍然微笑着看着它，并把草图整理好，想着他可能会在米德尔马奇找到她的一封信在等他，这时靠近他肘部的凯尔夫人说——

‘Mrs. Casaubon is coming in, sir.’
'太太。卡索邦要进来了，先生。”

Will turned round quickly, and the next moment Dorothea was entering. As Mrs. Kell closed the door behind her they met: each was looking at the other, and consciousness was overflowed by something that suppressed utterance. It was not confusion that kept them silent, for they both felt that parting was near, and there is no shamefacedness in a sad parting.
威尔迅速转过身，下一刻多萝西娅就进来了。当凯尔夫人关上身后的门时，他们相遇了：每个人都看着对方，意识被某种抑制言语的东西所淹没。让他们沉默的并不是困惑，因为他们都觉得离别已近，而悲伤的离别并不羞耻。

She moved automatically towards her uncle’s chair against the writing-table, and Will, after drawing it out a little for her, went a few paces off and stood opposite to her.
她自然而然地走向写字台上叔叔的椅子，威尔为她拉了一点之后，退了几步，站在她对面。

‘Pray sit down,’ said Dorothea, crossing her hands on her lap; ‘I am very glad you were here.’ Will thought that her face looked just as it did when she first shook hands with him in Rome; for her widow’s cap, fixed in her bonnet, had gone off with it, and he could see that she had lately been shedding tears. But the mixture of anger in her agitation had vanished at the sight of him; she had been used, when they were face to face, always to feel confidence and the happy freedom which comes with mutual understanding, and how could other people’s words hinder that effect on a sudden? Let the music which can take possession of our frame and fill the air with joy for us, sound once more—what does it signify that we heard it found fault with in its absence?
“请坐下，”多萝西娅双手交叉放在腿上说道。 “我很高兴你在这里。”威尔认为她的脸看起来就像她第一次在罗马与他握手时一样。因为她固定在帽子上的寡妇帽也随之脱落了，他看得出来她最近一直在流泪。但一看到他，她激动中的愤怒就消失了。她已经习惯了，当他们面对面的时候，总是能够感受到自信和相互理解带来的快乐自由，别人的言语又怎么会突然阻碍这种效果呢？让那可以占据我们的身体、让空气充满欢乐的音乐再次响起——我们听到它在缺席时挑剔它意味着什么？

‘I have sent a letter to Lowick Manor to-day, asking leave to see you,’ said Will, seating himself opposite to her. ‘I am going away immediately, and I could not go without speaking to you again.’
“我今天给洛威克庄园寄了一封信，请假去见你，”威尔坐在她对面说道。 “我马上就要走了，如果不再次和你说话我就不能离开。”

‘I thought we had parted when you came to Lowick many weeks ago— you thought you were going then,’ said Dorothea, her voice trembling a little.
“几周前你来洛威克时，我以为我们已经分手了——那时你以为你要走了，”多萝西娅说，她的声音有点颤抖。

‘Yes; but I was in ignorance then of things which I know now— things which have altered my feelings about the future. When I saw you before, I was dreaming that I might come back some day. I don’t think I ever shall—now.’ Will paused here.
'是的;但当时我对现在所知道的事情一无所知——这些事情改变了我对未来的感受。当我以前见到你时，我就梦想着有一天我会回来。我想我永远不会——现在。”威尔说到这里停了下来。

‘You wished me to know the reasons?’ said Dorothea, timidly.
“你想让我知道原因吗？”多萝西娅胆怯地说。

‘Yes,’ said Will, impetuously, shaking his head backward, and looking away from her with irritation in his face. ‘Of course I must wish it. I have been grossly insulted in your eyes and in the eyes of others. There has been a mean implication against my character. I wish you to know that under no circumstances would I have lowered myself by— under no circumstances would I have given men the chance of saying that I sought money under the pretext of seeking—something else. There was no need of other safeguard against me—the safeguard of wealth was enough.’
“是的，”威尔急躁地说，向后摇着头，脸上带着恼怒，把目光从她身上移开。 “当然，我一定希望如此。我在你和其他人的眼中受到了严重的侮辱。这对我的性格有一种卑鄙的暗示。我希望你知道，在任何情况下，我都不会降低自己的身份——在任何情况下，我都不会让人们有机会说我以寻求其他东西为借口来寻求金钱。我不需要其他的保障——财富的保障就足够了。

Will rose from his chair with the last word and went—he hardly knew where; but it was to the projecting window nearest him, which had been open as now about the same season a year ago, when he and Dorothea had stood within it and talked together. Her whole heart was going out at this moment in sympathy with Will’s indignation: she only wanted to convince him that she had never done him injustice, and he seemed to have turned away from her as if she too had been part of the unfriendly world.
威尔从椅子上站起来，留下最后一句话，然后就走了——他几乎不知道去哪里；但那是离他最近的一扇突出的窗户，大约一年前的同一季节，窗户一直开着，当时他和多萝西娅站在窗户里一起说话。此时此刻，她全心全意地同情威尔的愤慨：她只想让他相信，她从未对他做过不公正的事，而他似乎已经远离了她，仿佛她也曾是这个不友好世界的一部分。

‘It would be very unkind of you to suppose that I ever attributed any meanness to you,’ she began. Then in her ardent way, wanting to plead with him, she moved from her chair and went in front of him to her old place in the window, saying, ‘Do you suppose that I ever disbelieved in you?’
“如果你认为我曾把任何卑鄙的行为归咎于你，那你就太不友善了，”她开始说道。然后，她热切地想要恳求他，从椅子上站起来，走到他面前原来靠窗的地方，说道：“你认为我曾经不相信过你吗？”

When Will saw her there, he gave a start and moved backward out of the window, without meeting her glance. Dorothea was hurt by this movement following up the previous anger of his tone. She was ready to say that it was as hard on her as on him, and that she was helpless; but those strange particulars of their relation which neither of them could explicitly mention kept her always in dread of saying too much. At this moment she had no belief that Will would in any case have wanted to marry her, and she feared using words which might imply such a belief. She only said earnestly, recurring to his last word—
当威尔看到她在那里时，他吓了一跳，向后退到窗外，没有看她的一眼。继他先前愤怒的语气之后，多萝西娅被这个动作伤害了。她准备说，这对她和对他一样艰难，她很无助；但他们关系中那些奇怪的细节，他们俩都无法明确提及，这让她总是害怕说得太多。此时此刻，她不相信威尔无论如何都会想娶她，而且她害怕使用可能暗示这种信念的词语。她只是认真地说，重复着他的最后一句话——

‘I am sure no safeguard was ever needed against you.’
“我确信你不需要采取任何保护措施。”

Will did not answer. In the stormy fluctuation of his feelings these words of hers seemed to him cruelly neutral, and he looked pale and miserable after his angry outburst. He went to the table and fastened up his portfolio, while Dorothea looked at him from the distance. They were wasting these last moments together in wretched silence. What could he say, since what had got obstinately uppermost in his mind was the passionate love for her which he forbade himself to utter? What could she say, since she might offer him no help— since she was forced to keep the money that ought to have been his?— since to-day he seemed not to respond as he used to do to her thorough trust and liking?
威尔没有回答。在他情绪的剧烈波动中，她的这句话对他来说似乎是残酷的中性，他在愤怒爆发后显得苍白而痛苦。他走到桌边，系好档案袋，多萝西娅则远远地看着他。他们在可悲的沉默中度过了最后的时光。既然他心中最重要的是他禁止自己说出的对她的热烈的爱，他还能说什么？既然她可能无法向他提供任何帮助——既然她被迫保留了本该属于他的钱？——既然今天他似乎没有像以前那样回应她彻底的信任和喜爱？

But Will at last turned away from his portfolio and approached the window again.
但威尔最终还是转身离开了他的公文包，再次走到了窗户边。

‘I must go,’ he said, with that peculiar look of the eyes which sometimes accompanies bitter feeling, as if they had been tired and burned with gazing too close at a light.
“我必须走了，”他说，那双眼睛有时带着一种奇特的神情，有时还带着苦涩的感觉，就好像它们因为太靠近灯光而感到疲倦和灼痛。

‘What shall you do in life?’ said Dorothea, timidly. ‘Have your intentions remained just the same as when we said good-by before?’
“你这一生要做什么？”多萝西娅胆怯地说。 “你的意图还和我们之前告别时一样吗？”

‘Yes,’ said Will, in a tone that seemed to waive the subject as uninteresting. ‘I shall work away at the first thing that offers. I suppose one gets a habit of doing without happiness or hope.’
“是的，”威尔说，语气似乎是因为这个话题无趣而放弃。 “我会努力做第一件事。”我想一个人会养成一种习惯，就是在没有快乐或希望的情况下做事。”

‘Oh, what sad words!’ said Dorothea, with a dangerous tendency to sob. Then trying to smile, she added, ‘We used to agree that we were alike in speaking too strongly.’
“哦，多么悲伤的话语啊！”多萝西娅说，带着危险的抽泣倾向。然后她试图微笑，补充道，“我们过去都一致认为，我们的言论都太过强烈了。”

‘I have not spoken too strongly now,’ said Will, leaning back against the angle of the wall. ‘There are certain things which a man can only go through once in his life; and he must know some time or other that the best is over with him. This experience has happened to me while I am very young—that is all. What I care more for than I can ever care for anything else is absolutely forbidden to me— I don’t mean merely by being out of my reach, but forbidden me, even if it were within my reach, by my own pride and honor— by everything I respect myself for. Of course I shall go on living as a man might do who had seen heaven in a trance.’
“我现在没有说得太强硬，”威尔靠在墙角上说道。 “有些事，人一生只能经历一次；他总有一天会知道最好的时光已经结束了。这种经历是在我很小的时候就发生过的——仅此而已。我所关心的事情比我关心的任何事情都对我来说是绝对禁止的——我的意思不仅仅是超出我的能力范围，而是出于我自己的骄傲和荣誉而禁止我，即使它在我能力范围之内。 ——通过我尊重自己的一切。当然，我会像一个在恍惚中看到天堂的人一样继续生活。

Will paused, imagining that it would be impossible for Dorothea to misunderstand this; indeed he felt that he was contradicting himself and offending against his self-approval in speaking to her so plainly; but still—it could not be fairly called wooing a woman to tell her that he would never woo her. It must be admitted to be a ghostly kind of wooing.
威尔停了下来，想象多萝西娅不可能误解这一点。事实上，他觉得自己如此直白地跟她说话是自相矛盾，冒犯了他的自我肯定。但尽管如此——告诉一个女人他永远不会追求她，这还不能算是追求一个女人。必须承认这是一种幽灵般的求爱。

But Dorothea’s mind was rapidly going over the past with quite another vision than his. The thought that she herself might be what Will most cared for did throb through her an instant, but then came doubt: the memory of the little they had lived through together turned pale and shrank before the memory which suggested how much fuller might have been the intercourse between Will and some one else with whom he had had constant companionship. Everything he had said might refer to that other relation, and whatever had passed between him and herself was thoroughly explained by what she had always regarded as their simple friendship and the cruel obstruction thrust upon it by her husband’s injurious act. Dorothea stood silent, with her eyes cast down dreamily, while images crowded upon her which left the sickening certainty that Will was referring to Mrs. Lydgate. But why sickening? He wanted her to know that here too his conduct should be above suspicion.
但多萝西娅的思绪很快就回到了过去，带着与他完全不同的愿景。她自己可能就是威尔最关心的人，这个念头瞬间在她心头闪过，但随之而来的是怀疑：他们一起经历的那段小日子的记忆在这表明他们曾经经历过的小事的记忆面前变得苍白并萎缩。威尔和其他一个和他一直保持着友谊的人之间的交往。他所说的一切都可能指的是另一种关系，而他和她之间发生的一切都可以通过她一直认为是他们的简单友谊和她丈夫的伤害行为所施加的残酷阻碍来彻底解释。多萝西娅一言不发地站着，目光若有所思地低垂着，脑海中浮现出无数的画面，让威尔确信威尔指的是利德盖特太太，这令人作呕。但为什么令人恶心呢？他想让她知道，在这里他的行为也应该是不容怀疑的。

Will was not surprised at her silence. His mind also was tumultuously busy while he watched her, and he was feeling rather wildly that something must happen to hinder their parting—some miracle, clearly nothing in their own deliberate speech. Yet, after all, had she any love for him?—he could not pretend to himself that he would rather believe her to be without that pain. He could not deny that a secret longing for the assurance that she loved him was at the root of all his words.
威尔对她的沉默并不感到惊讶。当他注视着她的时候，他的思绪也变得混乱起来，他疯狂地感觉到一定会发生什么事情来阻碍他们的分离——某种奇迹，在他们自己故意的谈话中显然没有什么。然而，她到底爱他吗？——他不能假装自己宁愿相信她没有那种痛苦。他无法否认，他所有话语的根源都是出于对她爱他的保证的秘密渴望。

Neither of them knew how long they stood in that way. Dorothea was raising her eyes, and was about to speak, when the door opened and her footman came to say—
两人都不知道自己就这样站了多久。多萝西娅抬起眼睛，正要说话，门开了，她的男仆走过来说——

‘The horses are ready, madam, whenever you like to start.’
“夫人，马匹已经准备好了，您什么时候想出发都可以。”

‘Presently,’ said Dorothea. Then turning to Will, she said, ‘I have some memoranda to write for the housekeeper.’
“现在，”多萝西娅说。然后她转向威尔说：“我有一些备忘录要写给管家。”

‘I must go,’ said Will, when the door had closed again—advancing towards her. ‘The day after to-morrow I shall leave Middlemarch.’
“我必须走了，”当门再次关上时，威尔向她走来，说道。 “后天我就要离开米德尔马奇了。”

‘You have acted in every way rightly,’ said Dorothea, in a low tone, feeling a pressure at her heart which made it difficult to speak.
“你在各方面都做得对。”多萝西娅低声说道，她感到心里有压力，难以言语。

She put out her hand, and Will took it for an instant with. out speaking, for her words had seemed to him cruelly cold and unlike herself. Their eyes met, but there was discontent in his, and in hers there was only sadness. He turned away and took his portfolio under his arm.
她伸出手，威尔立刻握住了她的手。他觉得她的话冷酷无情，不像她自己。他们的目光交汇，但他的眼里有不满，她的眼里只有悲伤。他转过身去，把文件夹夹在腋下。

‘I have never done you injustice. Please remember me,’ said Dorothea, repressing a rising sob.
‘我从来没有冤枉过你。请记住我，”多萝西娅强忍着抽泣说道。

‘Why should you say that?’ said Will, with irritation. ‘As if I were not in danger of forgetting everything else.’
“你为什么要这么说？”威尔恼怒地说。 “好像我没有忘记其他一切的危险。”

He had really a movement of anger against her at that moment, and it impelled him to go away without pause. It was all one flash to Dorothea— his last words—his distant bow to her as he reached the door— the sense that he was no longer there. She sank into the chair, and for a few moments sat like a statue, while images and emotions were hurrying upon her. Joy came first, in spite of the threatening train behind it—joy in the impression that it was really herself whom Will loved and was renouncing, that there was really no other love less permissible, more blameworthy, which honor was hurrying him away from. They were parted all the same, but—Dorothea drew a deep breath and felt her strength return—she could think of him unrestrainedly. At that moment the parting was easy to bear: the first sense of loving and being loved excluded sorrow. It was as if some hard icy pressure had melted, and her consciousness had room to expand: her past was come back to her with larger interpretation. The joy was not the less—perhaps it was the more complete just then— because of the irrevocable parting; for there was no reproach, no contemptuous wonder to imagine in any eye or from any lips. He had acted so as to defy reproach, and make wonder respectful.
他此刻确实对她产生了一种愤怒的情绪，这迫使他毫不犹豫地走开。多萝西娅脑海中突然闪现出这一切——他的最后一句话——他走到门口时远远地向她鞠了一躬——他感觉自己已经不在那儿了。她一屁股坐在椅子上，像一尊雕像一样坐了一会儿，画面和情感在她脑海中急速涌来。喜悦是第一位的，尽管背后有威胁性的火车——喜悦是因为威尔所爱并正在放弃的确实是她自己，确实没有其他爱更不被允许、更应受谴责，而荣誉正在催促他远离。他们还是分开了，但是——多萝西娅深吸了一口气，感觉自己的力量又回来了——她可以无拘无束地想起他。那一刻的离别是容易承受的：第一次爱与被爱的感觉排除了悲伤。仿佛某种坚硬冰冷的压力融化了，她的意识有了扩展的空间：她的过去带着更大的解释回到了她身边。喜悦并没有因为不可挽回的离别而减少——也许是更彻底；因为任何人的眼中或嘴唇上都没有责备，也没有轻蔑的惊奇。他的所作所为是为了无视责备，让奇迹受到尊重。

Any one watching her might have seen that there was a fortifying thought within her. Just as when inventive power is working with glad ease some small claim on the attention is fully met as if it were only a cranny opened to the sunlight, it was easy now for Dorothea to write her memoranda. She spoke her last words to the housekeeper in cheerful tones, and when she seated herself in the carriage her eyes were bright and her cheeks blooming under the dismal bonnet. She threw back the heavy ‘weepers,’ and looked before her, wondering which road Will had taken. It was in her nature to be proud that he was blameless, and through all her feelings there ran this vein—‘I was right to defend him.’
任何人只要看着她，就会发现她的内心深处蕴藏着一股强大的力量。正如当创造力轻松地发挥作用时，对注意力的一些小要求得到了充分满足，就好像它只是向阳光敞开的缝隙一样，现在多萝西娅可以轻松地写她的备忘录。她用欢快的语气向管家说了最后一句话，当她坐上马车时，她的眼睛明亮，阴郁的帽子下脸颊红润。她扔掉沉重的“哭泣者”，看着前方，想知道威尔走了哪条路。她的本性是为他的清白而感到自豪，在她所有的感情中都流露出这样的情绪：“我为他辩护是正确的。”

The coachman was used to drive his grays at a good pane, Mr. Casaubon being unenjoying and impatient in everything away from his desk, and wanting to get to the end of all journeys; and Dorothea was now bowled along quickly. Driving was pleasant, for rain in the night had laid the dust, and the blue sky looked far off, away from the region of the great clouds that sailed in masses. The earth looked like a happy place under the vast heavens, and Dorothea was wishing that she might overtake Will and see him once more.
车夫习惯于在一块好玻璃前驾驶他的灰色衣服，卡苏邦先生对远离他的办公桌的一切都感到不愉快和不耐烦，并且想要完成所有旅程；多萝西娅现在很快就被打滚了。开车很愉快，夜雨扬起尘土，蓝天看起来很遥远，远离了大片云彩的区域。广阔的天空下，大地看起来像一个幸福的地方，多萝西娅希望她能赶上威尔，再次见到他。

After a turn of the road, there he was with the portfolio under his arm; but the next moment she was passing him while he raised his hat, and she felt a pang at being seated there in a sort of exaltation, leaving him behind. She could not look back at him. It was as if a crowd of indifferent objects had thrust them asunder, and forced them along different paths, taking them farther and farther away from each other, and making it useless to look back. She could no more make any sign that would seem to say, ‘Need we part?’ than she could stop the carriage to wait for him. Nay, what a world of reasons crowded upon her against any movement of her thought towards a future that might reverse the decision of this day!
拐过一个路口后，他就到了，腋下夹着公文包。但下一刻，当他举起帽子时，她就从他身边经过了，她感到一种痛苦，因为她怀着一种兴奋的心情坐在那儿，把他抛在了后面。她无法回头看他。仿佛一群无关紧要的物体将他们推开，迫使他们走上不同的道路，让他们彼此之间的距离越来越远，再也没有回头的意义。她无法做出任何似乎是在说“我们需要分手吗？”的手势，就像她无法停下马车等他一样。不，她有太多的理由来反对她对未来的任何想法，因为这可能会扭转今天的决定！

‘I only wish I had known before—I wish he knew—then we could be quite happy in thinking of each other, though we are forever parted. And if I could but have given him the money, and made things easier for him!’—were the longings that came back the most persistently. And yet, so heavily did the world weigh on her in spite of her independent energy, that with this idea of Will as in need of such help and at a disadvantage with the world, there came always the vision of that unfittingness of any closer relation between them which lay in the opinion of every one connected with her. She felt to the full all the imperativeness of the motives which urged Will’s conduct. How could he dream of her defying the barrier that her husband had placed between them?—how could she ever say to herself that she would defy it?
“我只希望我之前就知道——我希望他知道——那么我们就会很高兴地想着彼此，尽管我们永远分开了。如果我能给他钱，让他的生活变得更轻松就好了！’——这是最持久的渴望。然而，尽管她有独立的精力，但这个世界对她的压力如此之大，以至于威尔需要这样的帮助，并且在世界上处于不利地位，总有一种认为任何更密切的关系都不合适的想法。他们之间存在着与她有关的每个人的看法。她充分感受到促使威尔行为的所有动机的迫切性。他怎么能梦见她反抗她丈夫在他们之间设置的障碍呢？——她怎么能对自己说她会反抗它呢？

Will’s certainty as the carriage grew smaller in the distance, had much more bitterness in it. Very slight matters were enough to gall him in his sensitive mood, and the sight of Dorothea driving past him while he felt himself plodding along as a poor devil seeking a position in a world which in his present temper offered him little that he coveted, made his conduct seem a mere matter of necessity, and took away the sustainment of resolve. After all, he had no assurance that she loved him: could any man pretend that he was simply glad in such a case to have the suffering all on his own side?
随着马车距离越来越远，威尔的确定感中也多了更多的苦涩。非常轻微的事情就足以让他敏感的心情感到恼火，当他看到多萝西娅开车从他身边驶过时，他觉得自己像一个可怜的魔鬼一样缓慢地前行，在这个世界上寻找一个位置，而以他目前的脾气，这个世界几乎没有给他带来他所渴望的位置，这让他感到很沮丧。他的行为似乎只是一种必然，并失去了维持决心的动力。毕竟，他不能保证她爱他：在这种情况下，有哪个男人能假装他只是很高兴把所有的痛苦都放在自己一边呢？

That evening Will spent with the Lydgates; the next evening he was gone.
那天晚上，威尔和利德盖特一家一起度过。第二天晚上他就走了。

BOOK VII.
第七册。


TWO TEMPTATIONS.
两个诱惑。


Chapter LXIII
第六十三章

These little things are great to little man.—GOLDSMITH.
这些小事对小个子来说却是伟大的。——金史密斯。

‘Have you seen much of your scientific phoenix, Lydgate, lately?’ said Mr. Toller at one of his Christmas dinner-parties, speaking to Mr. Farebrother on his right hand.
“利德盖特，你最近见过你的科学凤凰吗？”托勒先生在一次圣诞晚宴上对坐在他右手边的费尔布拉泽先生说道。

‘Not much, I am sorry to say,’ answered the Vicar, accustomed to parry Mr. Toller’s banter about his belief in the new medical light. ‘I am out of the way and he is too busy.’
“我很遗憾地说，没什么。”牧师回答道，他习惯于回避托勒先生关于他对新医学光明信仰的玩笑。 “我不碍事，他太忙了。”

‘Is he? I am glad to hear it,’ said Dr. Minchin, with mingled suavity and surprise.
'是他？ “我很高兴听到这个消息。”明钦博士语气中夹杂着温和和惊讶。

‘He gives a great deal of time to the New Hospital,’ said Mr. Farebrother, who had his reasons for continuing the subject: ‘I hear of that from my neighbor, Mrs. Casaubon, who goes there often. She says Lydgate is indefatigable, and is making a fine thing of Bulstrode’s institution. He is preparing a new ward in case of the cholera coming to us.’
“他为新医院投入了大量的时间，”费雷布拉泽先生说，他有理由继续这个话题：“我从我的邻居卡索邦夫人那里听说了这件事，她经常去那里。”她说利德盖特不知疲倦，并且正在使布尔斯特罗德的机构变得很好。他正在准备一个新病房，以防霍乱袭击我们。”

‘And preparing theories of treatment to try on the patients, I suppose,’ said Mr. Toller.
“我想，我们正在准备治疗理论，以便在患者身上进行试验，”托勒先生说。

‘Come, Toller, be candid,’ said Mr. Farebrother. ‘You are too clever not to see the good of a bold fresh mind in medicine, as well as in everything else; and as to cholera, I fancy, none of you are very sure what you ought to do. If a man goes a little too far along a new road, it is usually himself that he harms more than any one else.’
“来吧，托勒，说实话，”费雷布拉泽先生说。 “你太聪明了，不可能看不到在医学以及其他一切领域中大胆新鲜头脑的好处；至于霍乱，我想你们都不太清楚自己应该做什么。如果一个人在一条新道路上走得太远，通常他自己受到的伤害比任何人都大。

‘I am sure you and Wrench ought to be obliged to him,’ said Dr. Minchin, looking towards Toller, ‘for he has sent you the cream of Peacock’s patients.’
“我确信你和扳手应该感谢他，”铭钦医生看着托勒说道，“因为他给你送来了皮科克的病人中的精华。”

‘Lydgate has been living at a great rate for a young beginner,’ said Mr. Harry Toller, the brewer. ‘I suppose his relations in the North back him up.’
“对于一个年轻的初学者来说，利德盖特的生活水平很高，”酿酒师哈里·托勒先生说。 “我想他在北方的关系会支持他。”

‘I hope so,’ said Mr. Chichely, ‘else he ought not to have married that nice girl we were all so fond of. Hang it, one has a grudge against a man who carries off the prettiest girl in the town.’
“我希望如此，”奇切利先生说，“否则他就不应该娶我们都喜欢的那个好女孩。”算了，对一个抢走了城里最漂亮女孩的男人有仇。”

‘Ay, by God! and the best too,’ said Mr. Standish.
‘哎呀，上帝啊！也是最好的，”斯坦迪什先生说。

‘My friend Vincy didn’t half like the marriage, I know that,’ said Mr. Chichely. ‘HE wouldn’t do much. How the relations on the other side may have come down I can’t say.’ There was an emphatic kind of reticence in Mr. Chichely’s manner of speaking.
“我知道，我的朋友文西不太喜欢这桩婚姻，”奇切利先生说。 “他不会做太多事。我不能说对方的关系会如何恶化。”奇切利先生的说话方式中有一种明显的沉默。

‘Oh, I shouldn’t think Lydgate ever looked to practice for a living,’ said Mr. Toller, with a slight touch of sarcasm, and there the subject was dropped.
“噢，我不认为利德盖特会以练习为生。”托勒先生略带讽刺地说，然后话题就被搁置了。

This was not the first time that Mr. Farebrother had heard hints of Lydgate’s expenses being obviously too great to be met by his practice, but he thought it not unlikely that there were resources or expectations which excused the large outlay at the time of Lydgate’s marriage, and which might hinder any bad consequences from the disappointment in his practice. One evening, when he took the pains to go to Middlemarch on purpose to have a chat with Lydgate as of old, he noticed in him an air of excited effort quite unlike his usual easy way of keeping silence or breaking it with abrupt energy whenever he had anything to say. Lydgate talked persistently when they were in his work-room, putting arguments for and against the probability of certain biological views; but he had none of those definite things to say or to show which give the waymarks of a patient uninterrupted pursuit, such as he used himself to insist on, saying that ‘there must be a systole and diastole in all inquiry,’ and that ‘a man’s mind must be continually expanding and shrinking between the whole human horizon and the horizon of an object-glass.’ That evening he seemed to be talking widely for the sake of resisting any personal bearing; and before long they went into the drawing room, where Lydgate, having asked Rosamond to give them music, sank back in his chair in silence, but with a strange light in his eyes. ‘He may have been taking an opiate,’ was a thought that crossed Mr. Farebrother’s mind—‘tic-douloureux perhaps—or medical worries.’
这并不是费雷布拉泽先生第一次听到有人暗示利德盖特的开支明显太大，无法通过他的诊所来满足，但他认为，在利德盖特结婚时，有资源或期望可以原谅这笔巨额开支，这并非不可能。 ，这可能会阻止他的实践中的失望所带来的任何不良后果。一天晚上，当他特意去米德尔马奇，像往常一样与利德盖特聊天时，他注意到他身上有一种兴奋的努力神情，这与他平时保持沉默或突然精力充沛地打破沉默的轻松方式截然不同。有话要说。当他们在利德盖特的工作室里时，他们一直在不停地交谈，对某些生物学观点的可能性提出支持和反对的论据。但他没有明确的事情要说或展示，这些事情给耐心不间断的追求留下了路标，就像他自己过去坚持的那样，他说“在所有的探究中都必须有一个收缩和舒张”，并且“一个人的思想必须在整个人类地平线和物体玻璃的地平线之间不断地扩展和缩小。不久，他们走进客厅，利德盖特请罗莎蒙德给他们演奏音乐后，默默地靠在椅子上，但眼中闪烁着奇怪的光芒。 “他可能服用了阿片类药物，”法尔布拉泽先生的脑海中闪过一个念头——“也许是抽动症——或者是医疗上的担忧。”

It did not occur to him that Lydgate’s marriage was not delightful: he believed, as the rest did, that Rosamond was an amiable, docile creature, though he had always thought her rather uninteresting— a little too much the pattern-card of the finishing-school; and his mother could not forgive Rosamond because she never seemed to see that Henrietta Noble was in the room. ‘However, Lydgate fell in love with her,’ said the Vicar to himself, ‘and she must be to his taste.’
他没有想到利德盖特的婚姻并不令人愉快：他和其他人一样相信罗莎蒙德是一个和蔼可亲、温顺的人，尽管他一直认为她相当无趣——有点太过于结束的模式卡。 -学校;他的母亲无法原谅罗莎蒙德，因为她似乎从来没有看到亨利埃塔·诺布尔在房间里。 “然而，利德盖特爱上了她，”牧师自言自语道，“她一定很合他的口味。”

Mr. Farebrother was aware that Lydgate was a proud man, but having very little corresponding fibre in himself, and perhaps too little care about personal dignity, except the dignity of not being mean or foolish, he could hardly allow enough for the way in which Lydgate shrank, as from a burn, from the utterance of any word about his private affairs. And soon after that conversation at Mr. Toller’s, the Vicar learned something which made him watch the more eagerly for an opportunity of indirectly letting Lydgate know that if he wanted to open himself about any difficulty there was a friendly ear ready.
费勒布拉泽先生知道利德盖特是一个骄傲的人，但他自己却没有相应的素质，也许太不关心个人尊严，除了不卑鄙或愚蠢的尊严之外，他几乎不能允许足够的方式利德盖特就像被烧伤一样，不敢说出任何有关他私人事务的字眼。在托勒先生家的那次谈话之后不久，牧师学到了一些东西，这让他更加渴望有机会间接地让利德盖特知道，如果他想敞开心扉谈论任何困难，那么友好的倾听者已经准备好了。

The opportunity came at Mr. Vincy’s, where, on New Year’s Day, there was a party, to which Mr. Farebrother was irresistibly invited, on the plea that he must not forsake his old friends on the first new year of his being a greater man, and Rector as well as Vicar. And this party was thoroughly friendly: all the ladies of the Farebrother family were present; the Vincy children all dined at the table, and Fred had persuaded his mother that if she did not invite Mary Garth, the Farebrothers would regard it as a slight to themselves, Mary being their particular friend. Mary came, and Fred was in high spirits, though his enjoyment was of a checkered kind— triumph that his mother should see Mary’s importance with the chief personages in the party being much streaked with jealousy when Mr. Farebrother sat down by her. Fred used to be much more easy about his own accomplishments in the days when he had not begun to dread being ‘bowled out by Farebrother,’ and this terror was still before him. Mrs. Vincy, in her fullest matronly bloom, looked at Mary’s little figure, rough wavy hair, and visage quite without lilies and roses, and wondered; trying unsuccessfully to fancy herself caring about Mary’s appearance in wedding clothes, or feeling complacency in grandchildren who would ‘feature’ the Garths. However, the party was a merry one, and Mary was particularly bright; being glad, for Fred’s sake, that his friends were getting kinder to her, and being also quite willing that they should see how much she was valued by others whom they must admit to be judges.
机会来到了文西先生家里，元旦那天，那里举办了一场聚会，法尔布拉泽先生不可抗拒地被邀请参加，请求他在成为一名更伟大的人的第一个新年里一定不能抛弃他的老朋友。人，还有教区长和牧师。这次聚会非常友好：费雷兄弟家族的所有女士都在场；文西家的孩子们都在餐桌上吃饭，弗雷德说服了他的母亲，如果她不邀请玛丽·加思，费尔兄弟会认为这是对他们自己的侮辱，因为玛丽是他们特别的朋友。玛丽来了，弗雷德兴高采烈，尽管他的喜悦是一种参差不齐的胜利——他的母亲应该看到玛丽的重要性，而当费雷布拉泽先生坐在她旁边时，聚会中的主要人物都充满了嫉妒。在弗雷德还没有开始担心“被费雷布拉泽击倒”的日子里，他对自己的成就感到更加轻松，这种恐惧仍然在他面前。文西夫人尽显主妇风范，看着玛丽娇小的身材、粗糙的卷发、毫无百合花和玫瑰色的面容，不禁感到纳闷。试图想象自己关心玛丽穿着婚纱的外表，或者对孙子们将“成为”加斯家族的主角感到自满，但没有成功。不过，聚会很欢乐，玛丽尤其聪明。看在弗雷德的份上，他很高兴他的朋友们对她越来越友善，而且也非常愿意让他们看到她受到那些他们必须承认是评判者的其他人的重视。

Mr. Farebrother noticed that Lydgate seemed bored, and that Mr. Vincy spoke as little as possible to his son-in-law. Rosamond was perfectly graceful and calm, and only a subtle observation such as the Vicar had not been roused to bestow on her would have perceived the total absence of that interest in her husband’s presence which a loving wife is sure to betray, even if etiquette keeps her aloof from him. When Lydgate was taking part in the conversation, she never looked towards him any more than if she had been a sculptured Psyche modelled to look another way: and when, after being called out for an hour or two, he re-entered the room, she seemed unconscious of the fact, which eighteen months before would have had the effect of a numeral before ciphers. In reality, however, she was intensely aware of Lydgate’s voice and movements; and her pretty good-tempered air of unconsciousness was a studied negation by which she satisfied her inward opposition to him without compromise of propriety. When the ladies were in the drawing-room after Lydgate had been called away from the dessert, Mrs. Farebrother, when Rosamond happened to be near her, said—‘You have to give up a great deal of your husband’s society, Mrs. Lydgate.’
费勒布拉泽先生注意到利德盖特似乎很无聊，文西先生也尽量少和他的女婿说话。罗莎蒙德非常优雅和平静，只有像牧师这样的微妙观察没有被唤醒，才会发现她对丈夫的存在完全没有兴趣，而一个可爱的妻子肯定会背叛，即使礼节保持她对他疏远了。当利德盖特参与谈话时，她从来没有看向他，就好像她是一个雕塑般的普赛克，以另一种方式看她：当他被叫出一两个小时后，他重新进入房间，她似乎没有意识到这一事实，十八个月前，这会产生数字与密码的效果。但事实上，她对利德盖特的声音和动作有着强烈的感知；她那种脾气很好、无意识的神情是一种刻意的否定，她用这种否定来满足自己内心对他的反对，但又不失礼节。当利德盖特被叫走离开甜点后，女士们来到客厅时，费雷布拉泽夫人，当罗莎蒙德碰巧在她身边时，说道：“你必须放弃与你丈夫的交往，利德盖特夫人.'

‘Yes, the life of a medical man is very arduous: especially when he is so devoted to his profession as Mr. Lydgate is,’ said Rosamond, who was standing, and moved easily away at the end of this correct little speech.
“是的，医生的生活是非常艰辛的：尤其是当他像利德盖特先生一样全身心投入自己的职业时，”站着的罗莎蒙德说，在这个正确的简短演讲结束后，他轻松地走开了。

‘It is dreadfully dull for her when there is no company,’ said Mrs. Vincy, who was seated at the old lady’s side. ‘I am sure I thought so when Rosamond was ill, and I was staying with her. You know, Mrs. Farebrother, ours is a cheerful house. I am of a cheerful disposition myself, and Mr. Vincy always likes something to be going on. That is what Rosamond has been used to. Very different from a husband out at odd hours, and never knowing when he will come home, and of a close, proud disposition, I think’—indiscreet Mrs. Vincy did lower her tone slightly with this parenthesis. ‘But Rosamond always had an angel of a temper; her brothers used very often not to please her, but she was never the girl to show temper; from a baby she was always as good as good, and with a complexion beyond anything. But my children are all good-tempered, thank God.’
“没有人陪伴，她会感到非常无聊，”坐在老太太身边的文西夫人说。 “我确信当罗莎蒙德生病时我也是这么想的，而我和她住在一起。你知道，费勒兄弟夫人，我们的房子很令人愉快。我自己性格开朗，文西先生总是喜欢有事情发生。这就是罗莎蒙德已经习惯的事情。我认为，这与一个丈夫在奇怪的时间出去，永远不知道什么时候回家，以及一种亲密而骄傲的性格非常不同——不谨慎的文西夫人确实用这句话稍微降低了语气。 “但罗莎蒙德总是有天使般的脾气；她的哥哥们常常不讨好她，但她从来不是一个发脾气的女孩。她从小就一直很优秀，肤色也超凡脱俗。但我的孩子们都很脾气好，感谢上帝。”

This was easily credible to any one looking at Mrs. Vincy as she threw back her broad cap-strings, and smiled towards her three little girls, aged from seven to eleven. But in that smiling glance she was obliged to include Mary Garth, whom the three girls had got into a corner to make her tell them stories. Mary was just finishing the delicious tale of Rumpelstiltskin, which she had well by heart, because Letty was never tired of communicating it to her ignorant elders from a favorite red volume. Louisa, Mrs. Vincy’s darling, now ran to her with wide-eyed serious excitement, crying, ‘Oh mamma, mamma, the little man stamped so hard on the floor he couldn’t get his leg out again!’
这对于任何看着文西夫人的人来说都很容易相信，因为她把宽大的帽带向后一甩，并对她的三个小女儿（年龄从七岁到十一岁）微笑。但在那微笑的一瞥中，她不得不把玛丽·加思也包括在内，三个女孩把她逼到了角落里，让她给她们讲故事。玛丽刚刚读完侏儒怪的精彩故事，她已经牢牢记住了这个故事，因为莱蒂乐此不疲地从一本最喜欢的红书里向她无知的长辈们讲述这个故事。文西夫人的宝贝路易莎现在睁大眼睛，兴奋地跑向她，哭喊着：“哦，妈妈，妈妈，这个小个子在地板上跺得很重，腿再也抽不出来了！”

‘Bless you, my cherub!’ said mamma; ‘you shall tell me all about it to-morrow. Go and listen!’ and then, as her eyes followed Louisa back towards the attractive corner, she thought that if Fred wished her to invite Mary again she would make no objection, the children being so pleased with her.
“祝福你，我的小天使！”妈妈说。 “明天你就告诉我这一切。”去听吧！”然后，当她的目光随着路易莎回到迷人的角落时，她想，如果弗雷德希望她再次邀请玛丽，她不会反对，孩子们对她很满意。

But presently the corner became still more animated, for Mr. Farebrother came in, and seating himself behind Louisa, took her on his lap; whereupon the girls all insisted that he must hear Rumpelstiltskin, and Mary must tell it over again. He insisted too, and Mary, without fuss, began again in her neat fashion, with precisely the same words as before. Fred, who had also seated himself near, would have felt unmixed triumph in Mary’s effectiveness if Mr. Farebrother had not been looking at her with evident admiration, while he dramatized an intense interest in the tale to please the children.
但不久，角落里变得更加热闹了，因为费勒布拉泽先生走了进来，坐在路易莎身后，把她抱在腿上。于是，女孩们都坚持要他听小矮人的声音，而玛丽必须再讲一遍。他也坚持说，玛丽没有大惊小怪，又以她干净利落的方式开始，用的词与之前一模一样。弗雷德也坐在附近，如果费勒布拉泽先生没有用明显的钦佩的目光看着玛丽，而他则表现出对这个故事的浓厚兴趣，以取悦孩子们，他一定会对玛丽的效率感到无比的胜利。

‘You will never care any more about my one-eyed giant, Loo,’ said Fred at the end.
“你永远不会再关心我的独眼巨人卢，”弗雷德最后说道。

‘Yes, I shall. Tell about him now,’ said Louisa.
是的，我会的。现在谈谈他吧，”路易莎说。

‘Oh, I dare say; I am quite cut out. Ask Mr. Farebrother.’
‘哦，我敢说；我实在是太无聊了。问问费雷布拉泽先生吧。

‘Yes,’ added Mary; ‘ask Mr. Farebrother to tell you about the ants whose beautiful house was knocked down by a giant named Tom, and he thought they didn’t mind because he couldn’t hear them cry, or see them use their pocket-handkerchiefs.’
“是的，”玛丽补充道。 “请费雷布拉泽先生告诉你关于蚂蚁的故事，他们美丽的房子被一个名叫汤姆的巨人推倒了，他认为它们并不介意，因为他听不到它们哭泣，也看不到它们使用口袋手帕。”

‘Please,’ said Louisa, looking up at the Vicar.
“拜托，”路易莎抬头看着牧师。

‘No, no, I am a grave old parson. If I try to draw a story out of my bag a sermon comes instead. Shall I preach you a sermon?’ said he, putting on his short-sighted glasses, and pursing up his lips.
“不，不，我是一位严肃的老牧师。如果我试图从包里拿出一个故事，就会出现布道。我要给你讲道吗？”他戴上近视眼镜，撅起嘴唇说道。

‘Yes,’ said Louisa, falteringly.
“是的，”路易莎结结巴巴地说。

‘Let me see, then. Against cakes: how cakes are bad things, especially if they are sweet and have plums in them.’
‘那么让我看看。反对蛋糕：蛋糕是多么糟糕的东西，尤其是如果它们是甜的并且里面有李子的话。

Louisa took the affair rather seriously, and got down from the Vicar’s knee to go to Fred.
路易莎相当认真地对待这件事，从牧师的膝上下来，走向弗雷德。

‘Ah, I see it will not do to preach on New Year’s Day,’ said Mr. Farebrother, rising and walking—away. He had discovered of late that Fred had become jealous of him, and also that he himself was not losing his preference for Mary above all other women.
“啊，我看在元旦讲道是行不通的，”法尔布拉泽先生说着，站起身来走开。最近他发现弗雷德开始嫉妒他，而且他自己也没有失去对玛丽的偏爱。

‘A delightful young person is Miss Garth,’ said Mrs. Farebrother, who had been watching her son’s movements.
“加思小姐是一位令人愉快的年轻人，”一直注视着儿子一举一动的法尔布拉泽夫人说道。

‘Yes,’ said Mrs. Vincy, obliged to reply, as the old lady turned to her expectantly. ‘It is a pity she is not better-looking.’
“是的，”文西夫人不得不回答，老太太满怀期待地转向她。 “可惜她长得并不好看。”

‘I cannot say that,’ said Mrs. Farebrother, decisively. ‘I like her countenance. We must not always ask for beauty, when a good God has seen fit to make an excellent young woman without it. I put good manners first, and Miss Garth will know how to conduct herself in any station.’
“我不能这么说，”法尔布拉泽夫人果断地说。 ‘我喜欢她的面容。当良善的上帝认为没有美貌的优秀年轻女子是合适的时候，我们不能总是要求美貌。我把礼貌放在第一位，加斯小姐会知道如何在任何车站表现自己。

The old lady was a little sharp in her tone, having a prospective reference to Mary’s becoming her daughter-in-law; for there was this inconvenience in Mary’s position with regard to Fred, that it was not suitable to be made public, and hence the three ladies at Lowick Parsonage were still hoping that Camden would choose Miss Garth.
老太太的语气有些尖刻，有预谋地提到玛丽要成为她的儿媳妇。因为玛丽对于弗雷德的立场有这样的不便，不适合公开，因此洛威克牧师公馆的三位女士仍然希望卡姆登选择加斯小姐。

New visitors entered, and the drawing-room was given up to music and games, while whist-tables were prepared in the quiet room on the other side of the hall. Mr. Farebrother played a rubber to satisfy his mother, who regarded her occasional whist as a protest against scandal and novelty of opinion, in which light even a revoke had its dignity. But at the end he got Mr. Chichely to take his place, and left the room. As he crossed the hall, Lydgate had just come in and was taking off his great-coat.
新的访客进来了，客厅里充满了音乐和游戏，而大厅另一边安静的房间里则准备好了牌桌。费雷布拉泽先生玩橡皮牌是为了满足他母亲的要求，他母亲认为她偶尔打惠斯特是对丑闻和新奇观点的抗议，从这一点来看，即使是撤销也有其尊严。但最后他让奇切利先生代替他，然后离开了房间。当他穿过大厅时，利德盖特刚刚进来，正在脱大衣。

‘You are the man I was going to look for,’ said the Vicar; and instead of entering the drawing-room, they walked along the hall and stood against the fireplace, where the frosty air helped to make a glowing bank. ‘You see, I can leave the whist-table easily enough,’ he went on, smiling at Lydgate, ‘now I don’t play for money. I owe that to you, Mrs. Casaubon says.’
“你就是我要找的人，”牧师说。他们没有进入客厅，而是沿着大厅走，站在壁炉旁，那里寒冷的空气帮助形成了一个发光的堤岸。 “你看，我可以很容易地离开惠斯特牌桌，”他继续说道，微笑着利德盖特，“现在我不再为了钱而打牌了。卡苏邦夫人说，这是我欠你的。

‘How?’ said Lydgate, coldly.
“怎么办？”利德盖特冷冷地说。

‘Ah, you didn’t mean me to know it; I call that ungenerous reticence. You should let a man have the pleasure of feeling that you have done him a good turn. I don’t enter into some people’s dislike of being under an obligation: upon my word, I prefer being under an obligation to everybody for behaving well to me.’
“啊，你不是故意让我知道的；我称之为不慷慨的沉默。你应该让男人感到高兴，觉得你帮了他的忙。我不同意有些人不喜欢承担义务：说实话，我更喜欢对每个人都负有义务，因为他们对我表现得很好。

‘I can’t tell what you mean,’ said Lydgate, ‘unless it is that I once spoke of you to Mrs. Casaubon. But I did not think that she would break her promise not to mention that I had done so,’ said Lydgate, leaning his back against the corner of the mantel-piece, and showing no radiance in his face.
“我听不懂你的意思，”利德盖特说，“除非我曾经向卡苏朋夫人谈到过你。”但我不认为她会违背诺言，更不用说我已经这样做了。”利德盖特说着，背靠在壁炉架的一角上，脸上没有任何光彩。

‘It was Brooke who let it out, only the other day. He paid me the compliment of saying that he was very glad I had the living though you had come across his tactics, and had praised me up as a lien and a Tillotson, and that sort of thing, till Mrs. Casaubon would hear of no one else.’
“就在前几天，是布鲁克把这件事说出来的。他恭维我说，他很高兴我能活下去，尽管你已经发现了他的策略，并称赞我是留置权和蒂洛森之类的，直到卡苏邦夫人听到没有还有一个。”

‘Oh, Brooke is such a leaky-minded fool,’ said Lydgate, contemptuously.
“哦，布鲁克真是个心胸狭窄的傻瓜，”利德盖特轻蔑地说。

‘Well, I was glad of the leakiness then. I don’t see why you shouldn’t like me to know that you wished to do me a service, my dear fellow. And you certainly have done me one. It’s rather a strong check to one’s self-complacency to find how much of one’s right doing depends on not being in want of money. A man will not be tempted to say the Lord’s Prayer backward to please the devil, if he doesn’t want the devil’s services. I have no need to hang on the smiles of chance now.’
“嗯，当时我很高兴看到泄漏。我不明白为什么你不应该让我知道你想为我服务，我亲爱的朋友。你当然也为我做了一个。发现一个人的正确行为在多大程度上取决于不缺钱，这对一个人的自满是一种强有力的检查。如果一个人不想要魔鬼的服务，他就不会为了取悦魔鬼而倒着念主祷文。我现在不需要再抱着机遇的微笑了。”

‘I don’t see that there’s any money-getting without chance,’ said Lydgate; ‘if a man gets it in a profession, it’s pretty sure to come by chance.’
“我不认为没有机会就能赚钱，”利德盖特说。 “如果一个人在某个职业中获得了成功，那么这肯定是偶然的。”

Mr. Farebrother thought he could account for this speech, in striking contrast with Lydgate’s former way of talking, as the perversity which will often spring from the moodiness of a man ill at ease in his affairs. He answered in a tone of good-humored admission—
费勒布拉泽先生认为，他可以将这次演讲解释为与利德盖特以前的谈话方式形成鲜明对比的一种反常行为，这种反常往往是由于一个对自己的事务感到不自在的人的喜怒无常而产生的。他用一种幽默承认的语气回答道——

‘Ah, there’s enormous patience wanted with the way of the world. But it is the easier for a man to wait patiently when he has friends who love him, and ask for nothing better than to help him through, so far as it lies in their power.’
“啊，这个世界需要极大的耐心。但是，当一个人有爱他的朋友时，一个人更容易耐心等待，除了在他们力所能及的范围内帮助他渡过难关之外，别无他求。

‘Oh yes,’ said Lydgate, in a careless tone, changing his attitude and looking at his watch. ‘People make much more of their difficulties than they need to do.’
“哦，是的，”利德盖特改变态度，看了看手表，语气漫不经心地说。 “人们制造的困难比他们需要做的要多得多。”

He knew as distinctly as possible that this was an offer of help to himself from Mr. Farebrother, and he could not bear it. So strangely determined are we mortals, that, after having been long gratified with the sense that he had privately done the Vicar a service, the suggestion that the Vicar discerned his need of a service in return made him shrink into unconquerable reticence. Besides, behind all making of such offers what else must come?—that he should ‘mention his case,’ imply that he wanted specific things. At that moment, suicide seemed easier.
他清楚地知道，这是费雷布拉泽先生向自己提出的帮助，他无法忍受。我们凡人的决心是如此奇怪，以至于在对他私下为牧师提供了服务而感到很满意之后，当牧师意识到他需要服务作为回报的建议使他退缩到无法克服的沉默中。此外，在所有提出这样的提议的背后还必须有什么？——他应该“提及他的情况”，暗示他想要具体的东西。那一刻，自杀似乎更容易了。

Mr. Farebrother was too keen a man not to know the meaning of that reply, and there was a certain massiveness in Lydgate’s manner and tone, corresponding with his physique, which if he repelled your advances in the first instance seemed to put persuasive devices out of question.
法尔布拉泽先生太敏锐了，他不会不知道这个回答的意思，而且利德盖特的举止和语气有一定的厚重感，与他的体格相对应，如果他一开始就拒绝你的主动，似乎就会失去说服力。的问题。

‘What time are you?’ said the Vicar, devouring his wounded feeling.
“你现在几点了？”牧师强忍着受伤的心情问道。

‘After eleven,’ said Lydgate. And they went into the drawing-room.
“十一点以后，”利德盖特说。他们走进客厅。

CHAPTER LXIV
第十四章

1st Gent. Where lies the power, there let the blame lie too.
第一绅士。权力在哪里，责任就在哪里。

2d Gent. Nay, power is relative; you cannot fright
2d 绅士。不，权力是相对的；权力是相对的。你不能害怕

The coming pest with border fortresses,
边境要塞即将来临的害虫，

Or catch your carp with subtle argument.
或者用微妙的争论来钓鲤鱼。

All force is twain in one: cause is not cause
所有力量都合而为一：原因不是原因

Unless effect be there; and action’s self
除非有效果；和行动的自我

Must needs contain a passive. So command
必须需要包含被动语态。所以命令

Exists but with obedience.’
存在但要服从。

Even if Lydgate had been inclined to be quite open about his affairs, he knew that it would have hardly been in Mr. Farebrother’s power to give him the help he immediately wanted. With the year’s bills coming in from his tradesmen, with Dover’s threatening hold on his furniture, and with nothing to depend on but slow dribbling payments from patients who must not be offended—for the handsome fees he had had from Freshitt Hall and Lowick Manor had been easily absorbed—nothing less than a thousand pounds would have freed him from actual embarrassment, and left a residue which, according to the favorite phrase of hopefulness in such circumstances, would have given him ‘time to look about him.’
即使利德盖特倾向于对他的事务相当公开，他也知道费勒布拉泽先生几乎没有能力为他提供他立即想要的帮助。随着今年的账单从他的商人那里传来，多佛威胁要扣押他的家具，除了从病人那里缓慢流淌的付款之外别无他法，这些病人决不能被冒犯——因为他从弗雷西特庄园和洛威克庄园那里得到了可观的费用。很容易被吸收——至少一千英镑就能让他摆脱真正的尴尬，并留下一些残留物，根据这种情况下最喜欢的充满希望的短语，这些残留物会让他“有时间环顾四周”。

Naturally, the merry Christmas bringing the happy New Year, when fellow-citizens expect to be paid for the trouble and goods they have smilingly bestowed on their neighbors, had so tightened the pressure of sordid cares on Lydgate’s mind that it was hardly possible for him to think unbrokenly of any other subject, even the most habitual and soliciting. He was not an ill-tempered man; his intellectual activity, the ardent kindness of his heart, as well as his strong frame, would always, under tolerably easy conditions, have kept him above the petty uncontrolled susceptibilities which make bad temper. But he was now a prey to that worst irritation which arises not simply from annoyances, but from the second consciousness underlying those annoyances, of wasted energy and a degrading preoccupation, which was the reverse of all his former purposes. ‘THIS is what I am thinking of; and THAT is what I might have been thinking of,’ was the bitter incessant murmur within him, making every difficulty a double goad to impatience.
自然而然，圣诞快乐带来新年快乐，同胞们希望为他们微笑地给予邻居的麻烦和物品得到补偿，这让利德盖特的心里承受着肮脏的忧虑的压力，这对他来说几乎是不可能的。不间断地思考任何其他主题，即使是最习惯和最吸引人的主题。他并不是一个脾气暴躁的人；他的智力活动，他内心的热忱和善良，以及他坚强的体格，在还算轻松的条件下，总是使他不会因琐碎的、不受控制的易感性而发脾气。但他现在成了最严重的恼怒的牺牲品，这种恼怒不仅源于烦恼，还源于这些烦恼背后的第二个意识，即浪费的精力和可耻的专注，这与他以前的所有目的背道而驰。 ‘这就是我的想法； “这就是我可能想到的，”他内心不断地痛苦地低语，使每一个困难都成为不耐烦的双重刺激。

Some gentlemen have made an amazing figure in literature by general discontent with the universe as a trap of dulness into which their great souls have fallen by mistake; but the sense of a stupendous self and an insignificant world may have its consolations. Lydgate’s discontent was much harder to bear: it was the sense that there was a grand existence in thought and effective action lying around him, while his self was being narrowed into the miserable isolation of egoistic fears, and vulgar anxieties for events that might allay such fears. His troubles will perhaps appear miserably sordid, and beneath the attention of lofty persons who can know nothing of debt except on a magnificent scale. Doubtless they were sordid; and for the majority, who are not lofty, there is no escape from sordidness but by being free from money-craving, with all its base hopes and temptations, its watching for death, its hinted requests. its horse-dealer’s desire to make bad work pass for good, its seeking for function which ought to be another’s, its compulsion often to long for Luck in the shape of a wide calamity.
有些绅士对宇宙普遍不满，认为宇宙是一个愚蠢的陷阱，他们伟大的灵魂错误地掉进了这个陷阱，从而在文学上取得了惊人的成就。但自我的伟大和世界的微不足道的感觉可能有其安慰。利德盖特的不满情绪更难以忍受：他感觉到自己周围的思想和有效的行动都存在着宏伟的存在，而他的自我却被缩小为自私恐惧的悲惨孤立，以及对可能减轻这种恐惧的事件的粗俗焦虑。恐惧。他的麻烦也许会显得极其肮脏，并受到那些高人一等的关注，他们对债务一无所知，除非规模宏大。毫无疑问，他们是肮脏的；对于大多数并不崇高的人来说，除了摆脱对金钱的贪婪及其所有卑鄙的希望和诱惑、对死亡的警惕和暗示的要求之外，就无法摆脱肮脏。它的马贩子希望把坏事变成好事，它寻求本应属于别人的功能，它常常渴望以大灾难的形式获得好运。

It was because Lydgate writhed under the idea of getting his neck beneath this vile yoke that he had fallen into a bitter moody state which was continually widening Rosamond’s alienation from him. After the first disclosure about the bill of sale, he had made many efforts to draw her into sympathy with him about possible measures for narrowing their expenses, and with the threatening approach of Christmas his propositions grew more and more definite. ‘We two can do with only one servant, and live on very little,’ he said, ‘and I shall manage with one horse.’ For Lydgate, as we have seen, had begun to reason, with a more distinct vision, about the expenses of living, and any share of pride he had given to appearances of that sort was meagre compared with the pride which made him revolt from exposure as a debtor, or from asking men to help him with their money.
正是因为利德盖特一想到要把自己的脖子置于这个卑鄙的枷锁之下，他就陷入了痛苦的喜怒无常的状态，这不断扩大了罗莎蒙德与他的疏远。在第一次披露销售单后，他做了很多努力来吸引她同情他可能采取的措施来缩小他们的开支，随着圣诞节的临近，他的主张变得越来越明确。 “我们两个人只能靠一个仆人，生活费很少，”他说，“而我可以用一匹马来应付。”正如我们所见，利德盖特已经开始以更清晰的眼光推理，关于生活费用，以及他对这种外表的任何自豪感，与使他反抗作为债务人或要求人们帮助他用钱的自豪感相比，都是微不足道的。

‘Of course you can dismiss the other two servants, if you like,’ said Rosamond; ‘but I should have thought it would be very injurious to your position for us to live in a poor way. You must expect your practice to be lowered.’
“当然，如果你愿意的话，你可以解雇另外两个仆人，”罗莎蒙德说。 “但我应该想到，如果我们过着贫穷的生活，会对你的地位造成很大损害。”你必须预料到你的练习会被降低。

‘My dear Rosamond, it is not a question of choice. We have begun too expensively. Peacock, you know, lived in a much smaller house than this. It is my fault: I ought to have known better, and I deserve a thrashing—if there were anybody who had a right to give it me—for bringing you into the necessity of living in a poorer way than you have been used to. But we married because we loved each other, I suppose. And that may help us to pull along till things get better. Come, dear, put down that work and come to me.’
“我亲爱的罗莎蒙德，这不是一个选择的问题。我们的起步成本太高了。你知道，孔雀住在比这小得多的房子里。这是我的错：我应该更了解，而且我应该受到鞭打——如果有人有权给我的话——因为我让你不得不以比你过去习惯的更贫穷的方式生活。但我想，我们结婚是因为我们彼此相爱。这可能会帮助我们继续前进，直到事情变得更好。来吧，亲爱的，放下手头上的工作来找我吧。

He was really in chill gloom about her at that moment, but he dreaded a future without affection, and was determined to resist the oncoming of division between them. Rosamond obeyed him, and he took her on his knee, but in her secret soul she was utterly aloof from him. The poor thing saw only that the world was not ordered to her liking, and Lydgate was part of that world. But he held her waist with one hand and laid the other gently on both of hers; for this rather abrupt man had much tenderness in his manners towards women, seeming to have always present in his imagination the weakness of their frames and the delicate poise of their health both in body and mind. And he began again to speak persuasively.
那一刻他确实对她感到阴森森的，但他又害怕没有感情的未来，并决心抵制他们之间即将到来的分裂。罗莎蒙德服从了他，他把她抱在膝上，但在她秘密的灵魂里，她完全疏远他。这个可怜的东西只看到这​​个世界并不按照她的喜好排列，而利德盖特就是这个世界的一部分。但他却一手揽住了她的腰，另一只手轻轻的放在了她的双腰上。因为这个相当唐突的男人对女人的举止非常温柔，似乎总是在他的想象中呈现出她们身体虚弱的体格和她们身心健康的微妙平衡。他又开始有说服力地讲话。

‘I find, now I look into things a little, Rosy, that it is wonderful what an amount of money slips away in our housekeeping. I suppose the servants are careless, and we have had a great many people coming. But there must be many in our rank who manage with much less: they must do with commoner things, I suppose, and look after the scraps. It seems, money goes but a little way in these matters, for Wrench has everything as plain as possible, and he has a very large practice.’
“我发现，罗西，现在我稍微调查一下，我们的家务上浪费了这么多钱，这真是太棒了。”我想仆人们太粗心了，而且我们来了很多人。但我们队伍中肯定有很多人处理的事情要少得多：我想，他们必须处理普通的事情，并照顾残渣。看来，钱在这些事情上只起到了一点作用，因为扳手把一切都尽可能简单化了，而且他有一个非常大的诊所。

‘Oh, if you think of living as the Wrenches do!’ said Rosamond, with a little turn of her neck. ‘But I have heard you express your disgust at that way of living.’
“哦，如果你想像扳手那样生活的话！”罗莎蒙德说，脖子轻轻一转。 “但我听到你表达了对这种生活方式的厌恶。”

‘Yes, they have bad taste in everything—they make economy look ugly. We needn’t do that. I only meant that they avoid expenses, although Wrench has a capital practice.’
“是的，他们对一切事物的品味都很差——他们让经济看起来很丑陋。我们不需要那样做。我只是说他们避免了开支，尽管扳手有资本实践。

‘Why should not you have a good practice, Tertius? Mr. Peacock had. You should be more careful not to offend people, and you should send out medicines as the others do. I am sure you began well, and you got several good houses. It cannot answer to be eccentric; you should think what will be generally liked,’ said Rosamond, in a decided little tone of admonition.
‘为什么你不应该好好练习一下呢，特蒂乌斯？孔雀先生做到了。你要小心一点，不要得罪人，也应该像其他人一样去送药。我相信你一开始就很好，并且得到了几栋好房子。它不能回答为古怪；它不能回答为古怪。 “你应该想想什么会受到普遍的欢迎。”罗莎蒙德以一种坚决的警告语气说道。

Lydgate’s anger rose: he was prepared to be indulgent towards feminine weakness, but not towards feminine dictation. The shallowness of a waternixie’s soul may have a charm until she becomes didactic. But he controlled himself, and only said, with a touch of despotic firmness—
利德盖特的怒火升腾起来：他准备纵容女性的弱点，但不会纵容女性的指令。水精灵灵魂的浅薄可能具有魅力，直到她变得说教为止。但他控制住了自己，只是带着一丝霸道的坚定说道——

‘What I am to do in my practice, Rosy, it is for me to judge. That is not the question between us. It is enough for you to know that our income is likely to be a very narrow one— hardly four hundred, perhaps less, for a long time to come, and we must try to re-arrange our lives in accordance with that fact.’
‘罗西，我在练习中要做什么，由我来判断。这不是我们之间的问题。你只要知道，在未来很长一段时间内，我们的收入很可能会非常微薄——不到四百，甚至可能更少，我们必须根据这一事实尝试重新安排我们的生活。

Rosamond was silent for a moment or two, looking before her, and then said, ‘My uncle Bulstrode ought to allow you a salary for the time you give to the Hospital: it is not right that you should work for nothing.’
罗莎蒙德沉默了一两分钟，看着她的前方，然后说道：“布尔斯特罗德叔叔应该给你一份工资，相当于你为医院付出的时间：你不劳而获是不对的。”

‘It was understood from the beginning that my services would be gratuitous. That, again, need not enter into our discussion. I have pointed out what is the only probability,’ said Lydgate, impatiently. Then checking himself, he went on more quietly—
“从一开始大家就明白我的服务是免费的。同样，这不需要进入我们的讨论。我已经指出了唯一的可能性是什么。”利德盖特不耐烦地说。然后他检查了一下自己，然后更加平静地继续说道——

‘I think I see one resource which would free us from a good deal of the present difficulty. I hear that young Ned Plymdale is going to be married to Miss Sophy Toller. They are rich, and it is not often that a good house is vacant in Middlemarch. I feel sure that they would be glad to take this house from us with most of our furniture, and they would be willing to pay handsomely for the lease. I can employ Trumbull to speak to Plymdale about it.’
“我想我看到了一种资源，可以让我们摆脱目前的许多困难。我听说年轻的内德·普林代尔即将与苏菲·托勒小姐结婚。他们很富有，在米德尔马契，好房子空着的情况并不常见。我确信他们会很高兴从我们这里拿走这所房子和我们的大部分家具，并且他们愿意支付丰厚的租金。我可以聘请特朗布尔去和普林代尔谈谈这件事。

Rosamond left her husband’s knee and walked slowly to the other end of the room; when she turned round and walked towards him it was evident that the tears had come, and that she was biting her under-lip and clasping her hands to keep herself from crying. Lydgate was wretched—shaken with anger and yet feeling that it would be unmanly to vent the anger just now.
罗莎蒙德离开丈夫的膝盖，慢慢地走到房间的另一端。当她转身走向他时，很明显泪水已经涌出，她咬着下唇，紧握双手不让自己哭出来。利德盖特很可怜——气得浑身发抖，却又觉得现在发泄愤怒是没有男子气概的。

‘I am very sorry, Rosamond; I know this is painful.’
“我很抱歉，罗莎蒙德；我知道这很痛苦。

‘I thought, at least, when I had borne to send the plate back and have that man taking an inventory of the furniture—I should have thought THAT would suffice.’
“我想，至少，当我不得不把盘子寄回去并让那个人清点家具时——我应该认为这就足够了。”

‘I explained it to you at the time, dear. That was only a security and behind that Security there is a debt. And that debt must be paid within the next few months, else we shall have our furniture sold. If young Plymdale will take our house and most of our furniture, we shall be able to pay that debt, and some others too, and we shall be quit of a place too expensive for us. We might take a smaller house: Trumbull, I know, has a very decent one to let at thirty pounds a-year, and this is ninety.’ Lydgate uttered this speech in the curt hammering way with which we usually try to nail down a vague mind to imperative facts. Tears rolled silently down Rosamond’s cheeks; she just pressed her handkerchief against them, and stood looking al; the large vase on the mantel-piece. It was a moment of more intense bitterness than she had ever felt before. At last she said, without hurry and with careful emphasis—
“我当时就向你解释过，亲爱的。那只是一种证券，而在该证券的背后有一笔债务。这笔债务必须在接下来的几个月内偿还，否则我们的家具就会被卖掉。如果年轻的普利姆代尔将夺走我们的房子和大部分家具，我们将能够偿还这笔债务以及其他一些债务，我们将离开一个对我们来说太昂贵的地方。我们可能会买一栋小一点的房子：我知道，特朗布尔有一套非常不错的房子，每年出租三十英镑，而这是九十英镑。模糊的头脑对迫切的事实。泪水无声地从罗莎蒙德的脸颊上滚落。她只是把手帕按在他们身上，站在那里看着大家。壁炉架上的大花瓶。这是她从未感受过的更强烈的痛苦时刻。最后她不慌不忙地强调——

‘I never could have believed that you would like to act in that way.’
“我从来没想过你会这么做。”

‘Like it?’ burst out Lydgate, rising from his chair, thrusting his hands in his pockets and stalking away from the hearth; ‘it’s not a question of liking. Of course, I don’t like it; it’s the only thing I can do.’ He wheeled round there, and turned towards her.
“喜欢吗？”利德盖特突然从椅子上站起来，双手插进口袋，大步离开壁炉。 ‘这不是喜不喜欢的问题。当然，我不喜欢这样；这是我唯一能做的事。”他转过身来，转向她。

‘I should have thought there were many other means than that,’ said Rosamond. ‘Let us have a sale and leave Middlemarch altogether.’
“我本以为还有很多其他的办法，”罗莎蒙德说。 “让我们进行一次出售，然后彻底离开米德尔马奇。”

‘To do what? What is the use of my leaving my work in Middlemarch to go where I have none? We should be just as penniless elsewhere as we are here,’ said Lydgate still more angrily.
'做什么？我离开米德尔马奇的工作去我没有工作的地方有什么用呢？我们在其他地方也应该像在这里一样身无分文。”利德盖特更加愤怒地说。

‘If we are to be in that position it will be entirely your own doing, Tertius,’ said Rosamond, turning round to speak with the fullest conviction. ‘You will not behave as you ought to do to your own family. You offended Captain Lydgate. Sir Godwin was very kind to me when we were at Quallingham, and I am sure if you showed proper regard to him and told him your affairs, he would do anything for you. But rather than that, you like giving up our house and furniture to Mr. Ned Plymdale.’
“如果我们陷入那样的境地，那完全是你自己造成的，特提乌斯。”罗莎蒙德转过身来，满怀信心地说道。 ‘你不会对自己的家人做出应有的行为。你冒犯了利德盖特船长。当我们在夸林汉姆时，戈德温爵士对我非常友善，我相信如果你对他表现出适当的尊重并向他讲述你的事情，他会为你做任何事情。但除此之外，你还喜欢把我们的房子和家具让给内德·普林代尔先生。”

There was something like fierceness in Lydgate’s eyes, as he answered with new violence, ‘Well, then, if you will have it so, I do like it. I admit that I like it better than making a fool of myself by going to beg where it’s of no use. Understand then, that it is what I LIKE TO DO.’
利德盖特的眼睛里有一种凶狠的感觉，他用新的暴力回答道：“好吧，那么，如果你愿意的话，我确实喜欢它。”我承认我更喜欢这样，而不是在无用的地方乞讨而出丑。那么请理解，这就是我喜欢做的事情。

There was a tone in the last sentence which was equivalent to the clutch of his strong hand on Rosamond’s delicate arm. But for all that, his will was not a whit stronger than hers. She immediately walked out of the room in silence, but with an intense determination to hinder what Lydgate liked to do.
最后一句话的语气相当于他强有力的手抓住了罗莎蒙德纤弱的手臂。但尽管如此，他的意志并不比她强大半分。她立即​​默默地走出房间，但坚决要阻止利德盖特喜欢做的事情。

He went out of the house, but as his blood cooled he felt that the chief result of the discussion was a deposit of dread within him at the idea of opening with his wife in future subjects which might again urge him to violent speech. It was as if a fracture in delicate crystal had begun, and he was afraid of any movement that might mate it fatal. His marriage would be a mere piece of bitter irony if they could not go on loving each other. He had long ago made up his mind to what he thought was her negative character—her want of sensibility, which showed itself in disregard both of his specific wishes and of his general aims. The first great disappointment had been borne: the tender devotedness and docile adoration of the ideal wife must be renounced, and life must be taken up on a lower stage of expectation, as it is by men who have lost their limbs. But the real wife had not only her claims, she had still a hold on his heart, and it was his intense desire that the hold should remain strong. In marriage, the certainty, ‘She will never love me much,’ is easier to bear than the fear, ‘I shall love her no more.’ Hence, after that outburst, his inward effort was entirely to excuse her, and to blame the hard circumstances which were partly his fault. He tried that evening, by petting her, to heal the wound he had made in the morning, and it was not in Rosamond’s nature to be repellent or sulky; indeed, she welcomed the signs that her husband loved her and was under control. But this was something quite distinct from loving HIM. Lydgate would not have chosen soon to recur to the plan of parting with the house; he was resolved to carry it out, and say as little more about it as possible. But Rosamond herself touched on it at breakfast by saying, mildly—
他走出了家门，但当他的血液冷却下来时，他感到讨论的主要结果是他内心深处积聚了一种恐惧，因为他担心与妻子讨论未来的话题，这可能会再次促使他发表暴力言论。就好像精致的水晶开始破裂一样，他害怕任何可能致命的动作。如果他们不能继续彼此相爱，他的婚姻将只是一个苦涩的讽刺。他很早就认定了她的消极性格——她缺乏感性，这表现在无视他的具体愿望和总体目标。第一次巨大的失望已经来临：理想妻子的温柔忠诚和温顺崇拜必须被放弃，生活必须在较低的期望水平上开始，就像失去四肢的男人一样。但真正的妻子不仅拥有她的主张，她仍然牢牢地控制着他的心，而他强烈希望这种控制力能够保持牢固。在婚姻中，“她永远不会多爱我”的确定性比“我将不再爱她”的恐惧更容易忍受。因此，在那次爆发之后，他内心的努力完全是原谅她，责备她。艰苦的环境部分是他的错。那天晚上，他试图通过抚摸她来治愈早上造成的伤口，而罗莎蒙德的天性并不排斥或闷闷不乐。事实上，她很高兴看到丈夫爱她并且一切都在掌控之中。但这与爱他截然不同。利德盖特不会很快选择再次实施与房子分开的计划；他决心执行这件事，并且尽可能少说。但罗莎蒙德本人在早餐时谈到了这一点，温和地说——

‘Have you spoken to Trumbull yet?’
“你和特朗布尔谈过了吗？”

‘No,’ said Lydgate, ‘but I shall call on him as I go by this morning. No time must be lost.’ He took Rosamond’s question as a sign that she withdrew her inward opposition, and kissed her head caressingly when he got up to go away.
“不，”利德盖特说，“但我今天早上路过时会去拜访他。不能浪费时间。”他把罗莎蒙德的问题视为她撤回内心反对的信号，并在他起身离开时爱抚地吻了吻她的头。

As soon as it was late enough to make a call, Rosamond went to Mrs. Plymdale, Mr. Ned’s mother, and entered with pretty congratulations into the of the coming marriage. Mrs. Plymdale’s maternal view was, that Rosamond might possibly now have retrospective glimpses of her own folly; and feeling the advantages to be at present all on the side of her son, was too kind a woman not to behave graciously.
天色已晚，无法打电话时，罗莎蒙德就去找内德先生的母亲普林代尔夫人，对即将到来的婚姻表示热烈的祝贺。普利姆代尔夫人的母亲观点是，罗莎蒙德现在可能会回顾自己的愚蠢行为。她觉得目前站在儿子一边是有利的，她太善良了，不能表现得不客气。

‘Yes, Ned is most happy, I must say. And Sophy Toller is all I could desire in a daughter-in-law. Of course her father is able to do something handsome for her—that is only what would be expected with a brewery like his. And the connection is everything we should desire. But that is not what I look at. She is such a very nice girl—no airs, no pretensions, though on a level with the first. I don’t mean with the titled aristocracy. I see very little good in people aiming out of their own sphere. I mean that Sophy is equal to the best in the town, and she is contented with that.’
“是的，我必须说，内德非常高兴。苏菲·托勒就是我所希望的儿媳妇。当然，她的父亲能够为她做一些漂亮的事情——这只是对像他这样的啤酒厂的期望。这种联系就是我们所渴望的一切。但这不是我所看到的。她是一个非常好的女孩——没有架子，没有架子，尽管与第一个女孩处于同一水平。我指的不是那些有头衔的贵族。我认为人们的目标超出自己的范围没有什么好处。我的意思是，苏菲与镇上最优秀的人不相上下，她对此很满意。”

‘I have always thought her very agreeable,’ said Rosamond.
“我一直认为她非常和蔼可亲，”罗莎蒙德说。

‘I look upon it as a reward for Ned, who never held his head too high, that he should have got into the very best connection,’ continued Mrs. Plymdale, her native sharpness softened by a fervid sense that she was taking a correct view. ‘And such particular people as the Tollers are, they might have objected because some of our friends are not theirs. It is well known that your aunt Bulstrode and I have been intimate from our youth, and Mr. Plymdale has been always on Mr. Bulstrode’s side. And I myself prefer serious opinions. But the Tollers have welcomed Ned all the same.’
“我认为这是对内德的奖励，他从来没有把头抬得太高，他应该进入最好的联系，”普林代尔夫人继续说道，她天生的敏锐被一种强烈的感觉软化了，因为她正在采取正确的态度。看法。 “像托勒家族这样特殊的人，他们可能会反对，因为我们的一些朋友不是他们的。众所周知，我和布尔斯特罗德姨妈从小就很亲密，普利姆代尔先生也一直站在布尔斯特罗德先生一边。而我自己更喜欢严肃的意见。但托勒一家仍然欢迎内德。

‘I am sure he is a very deserving, well-principled young man,’ said Rosamond, with a neat air of patronage in return for Mrs. Plymdale’s wholesome corrections.
“我相信他是一个非常值得、有原则的年轻人，”罗莎蒙德说，带着一种干脆的恩惠态度，以回应普林代尔夫人有益的纠正。

‘Oh, he has not the style of a captain in the army, or that sort of carriage as if everybody was beneath him, or that showy kind of talking, and singing, and intellectual talent. But I am thankful he has not. It is a poor preparation both for here and Hereafter.’
“噢，他没有陆军上尉的风范，也没有那种仿佛人人都在他之下的举止，也没有那种炫耀的谈吐、歌唱和才智。但我很庆幸他没有。对于今生和来世来说，这都是一个糟糕的准备。

‘Oh dear, yes; appearances have very little to do with happiness,’ said Rosamond. ‘I think there is every prospect of their being a happy couple. What house will they take?’
“噢，亲爱的，是的；”外表与幸福没有多大关系，”罗莎蒙德说。 “我认为他们完全有可能成为幸福的一对。他们会选择什么房子？

‘Oh, as for that, they must put up with what they can get. They have been looking at the house in St. Peter’s Place, next to Mr. Hackbutt’s; it belongs to him, and he is putting it nicely in repair. I suppose they are not likely to hear of a better. Indeed, I think Ned will decide the matter to-day.’
‘哦，至于这一点，他们必须忍受他们所能得到的。他们一直在看圣彼得广场的房子，紧挨着哈克布特先生的房子；它是他的，他正在把它修理得很好。我想他们不太可能听到更好的。事实上，我认为内德今天会决定此事。

‘I should think it is a nice house; I like St. Peter’s Place.’
“我认为这是一座不错的房子；我喜欢圣彼得广场。

‘Well, it is near the Church, and a genteel situation. But the windows are narrow, and it is all ups and downs. You don’t happen to know of any other that would be at liberty?’ said Mrs. Plymdale, fixing her round black eyes on Rosamond with the animation of a sudden thought in them.
“嗯，这里离教堂很近，而且环境优雅。但窗户狭窄，而且都是高低起伏。 “你碰巧不知道还有其他人可以自由自在吗？”普林代尔太太说，她圆圆的黑眼睛盯着罗莎蒙德，眼神里突然闪现出一个想法。

‘Oh no; I hear so little of those things.’
'不好了;我很少听到这些事情。

Rosamond had not foreseen that question and answer in setting out to pay her visit; she had simply meant to gather any information which would help her to avert the parting with her own house under circumstances thoroughly disagreeable to her. As to the untruth in her reply, she no more reflected on it than she did on the untruth there was in her saying that appearances had very little to do with happiness. Her object, she was convinced, was thoroughly justifiable: it was Lydgate whose intention was inexcusable; and there was a plan in her mind which, when she had carried it out fully, would prove how very false a step it would have been for him to have descended from his position.
罗莎蒙德在出发去拜访她时并没有预见到这个问题和答案。她只是想收集任何信息，以帮助她避免在她完全不同意的情况下与自己的房子分开。至于她的回答中的谎言，她并没有反思，就像她没有反思她所说的“外表与幸福无关”的谎言一样。她确信，她的目标是完全合理的：利德盖特的意图是不可原谅的；利德盖特的意图是不可原谅的；而利德盖特的意图是不可原谅的。她心里有一个计划，当她完全执行这个计划时，就会证明他从自己的位置上下来是多么错误的一步。

She returned home by Mr. Borthrop Trumbull’s office, meaning to call there. It was the first time in her life that Rosamond had thought of doing anything in the form of business, but she felt equal to the occasion. That she should be obliged to do what she intensely disliked, was an idea which turned her quiet tenacity into active invention. Here was a case in which it could not be enough simply to disobey and be serenely, placidly obstinate: she must act according to her judgment, and she said to herself that her judgment was right—‘indeed, if it had not been, she would not have wished to act on it.’
她回家时经过博思罗普·特朗布尔先生的办公室，打算给那里打电话。这是罗莎蒙德一生中第一次想到以商业形式做任何事情，但她觉得自己可以应对这个场合。她应该被迫做她非常不喜欢的事情，这一想法将她安静的坚韧变成了积极的发明。在这种情况下，仅仅不服从和平静地、平静地固执是不够的：她必须根据自己的判断行事，她对自己说，她的判断是正确的——“确实，如果不是这样，她不会希望对此采取行动。

Mr. Trumbull was in the back-room of his office, and received Rosamond with his finest manners, not only because he had much sensibility to her charms, but because the good-natured fibre in him was stirred by his certainty that Lydgate was in difficulties, and that this uncommonly pretty woman—this young lady with the highest personal attractions—was likely to feel the pinch of trouble— to find herself involved in circumstances beyond her control. He begged her to do him the honor to take a seat, and stood before her trimming and comporting himself with an eager solicitude, which was chiefly benevolent. Rosamond’s first question was, whether her husband had called on Mr. Trumbull that morning, to speak about disposing of their house.
特朗布尔先生在他办公室的后屋里，以他最优雅的举止接待了罗莎蒙德，不仅因为他对她的魅力非常敏感，而且因为他确信利德盖特就在他身边，这激起了他内心的善良。困难，而这位异常漂亮的女人——这位具有最高个人吸引力的年轻女士——很可能会感到麻烦——发现自己陷入了无法控制的境地。他请求她给他一个荣幸的座位，然后站在她面前，打扮得漂漂亮亮，表现得热切关心，这主要是仁慈的。罗莎蒙德的第一个问题是，她的丈夫那天早上是否拜访过特朗布尔先生，谈论处置他们的房子的问题。

‘Yes, ma’am, yes, he did; he did so,’ said the good auctioneer, trying to throw something soothing into his iteration. ‘I was about to fulfil his order, if possible, this afternoon. He wished me not to procrastinate.’
“是的，女士，是的，他做到了；” “他这么做了。”这位优秀的拍卖师说道，试图在他的迭代中加入一些安慰的话。 “如果可能的话，我今天下午就要完成他的订单。他希望我不要拖延。

‘I called to tell you not to go any further, Mr. Trumbull; and I beg of you not to mention what has been said on the subject. Will you oblige me?’
“我打电话是要告诉你不要再走下去了，特朗布尔先生；”我恳求你不要提及有关这个问题的言论。你愿意答应我吗？

‘Certainly I will, Mrs. Lydgate, certainly. Confidence is sacred with me on business or any other topic. I am then to consider the commission withdrawn?’ said Mr. Trumbull, adjusting the long ends of his blue cravat with both hands, and looking at Rosamond deferentially.
“我当然会的，利德盖特夫人，当然。在商业或任何其他话题上，信心对我来说是神圣的。 “那么我就可以考虑撤回佣金吗？”特朗布尔先生一边说，一边用双手调整着蓝色领带的长端，恭敬地看着罗莎蒙德。

‘Yes, if you please. I find that Mr. Ned Plymdale has taken a house— the one in St. Peter’s Place next to Mr. Hackbutt’s. Mr. Lydgate would be annoyed that his orders should be fulfilled uselessly. And besides that, there are other circumstances which render the proposal unnecessary.’
是的，如果你愿意的话。我发现内德·普林代尔先生租了一栋房子——位于哈克布特先生旁边的圣彼得广场的那栋房子。利德盖特先生会因为他的命令毫无用处地执行而感到恼火。除此之外，还有其他情况使得该提案没有必要。”

‘Very good, Mrs. Lydgate, very good. I am at your commands, whenever you require any service of me,’ said Mr. Trumbull, who felt pleasure in conjecturing that some new resources had been opened. ‘Rely on me, I beg. The affair shall go no further.’
“很好，利德盖特夫人，很好。每当您需要我提供任何服务时，我都听从您的指挥。”特朗布尔先生说道，他很高兴推测一些新资源已经被开放。 ‘相信我，我恳求你。事情不会再进一步​​了。

That evening Lydgate was a little comforted by observing that Rosamond was more lively than she had usually been of late, and even seemed interested in doing what would please him without being asked. He thought, ‘If she will be happy and I can rub through, what does it all signify? It is only a narrow swamp that we have to pass in a long journey. If I can get my mind clear again, I shall do.’
那天晚上，利德盖特看到罗莎蒙德比平时更活泼，甚至似乎有兴趣在没有被要求的情况下做一些让他高兴的事情，这让利德盖特感到有点安慰。他想，‘如果她能幸福，而我能坚持下去，这一切意味着什么？这只是我们长途跋涉必须经过的一片狭窄的沼泽。如果我能再次理清思路，我就会这么做。

He was so much cheered that he began to search for an account of experiments which he had long ago meant to look up, and had neglected out of that creeping self-despair which comes in the train of petty anxieties. He felt again some of the old delightful absorption in a far-reaching inquiry, while Rosamond played the quiet music which was as helpful to his meditation as the plash of an oar on the evening lake. It was rather late; he had pushed away all the books, and was looking at the fire with his hands clasped behind his head in forgetfulness of everything except the construction of a new controlling experiment, when Rosamond, who had left the piano and was leaning back in her chair watching him, said—
他非常高兴，开始寻找一些他早就想查找的实验记录，但由于随着琐碎的焦虑而来的逐渐蔓延的自我绝望，他忽略了这些实验。当罗莎蒙德演奏着安静的音乐时，他再次感受到了过去那种令人愉快的专注于深远的探究的感觉，这对他的冥想有帮助，就像傍晚湖面上桨的拍打声一样。时间已经很晚了。他推开了所有的书，双手抱在脑后看着火，除了构建一个新的控制实验之外，什么都忘记了，这时罗莎蒙德离开了钢琴，靠在椅子上看着。他说——

‘Mr. Ned Plymdale has taken a house already.’
'先生。内德·普林代尔已经买了一所房子。

Lydgate, startled and jarred, looked up in silence for a moment, like a man who has been disturbed in his sleep. Then flushing with an unpleasant consciousness, he asked—
利德盖特感到震惊和震惊，沉默地抬起头看了一会儿，就像一个在睡梦中被打扰的人。然后他满脸通红，带着一种不愉快的意识问道——

‘How do you know?’
'你怎么知道？'

‘I called at Mrs. Plymdale’s this morning, and she told me that he had taken the house in St. Peter’s Place, next to Mr. Hackbutt’s.’
“今天早上我去了普利姆代尔夫人家，她告诉我，他已经租下了哈克布特先生家旁边的圣彼得广场的房子。”

Lydgate was silent. He drew his hands from behind his head and pressed them against the hair which was hanging, as it was apt to do, in a mass on his forehead, while he rested his elbows on his knees. He was feeling bitter disappointment, as if he had opened a door out of a suffocating place and had found it walled up; but he also felt sure that Rosamond was pleased with the cause of his disappointment. He preferred not looking at her and not speaking, until he had got over the first spasm of vexation. After all, he said in his bitterness, what can a woman care about so much as house and furniture? a husband without them is an absurdity. When he looked up and pushed his hair aside, his dark eyes had a miserable blank non-expectance of sympathy in them, but he only said, coolly—
利德盖特沉默了。他把手从脑后抽出来，按在前额上垂下来的头发上，而他的手肘则放在膝盖上。他感到一阵苦涩的失望，就好像他从一个令人窒息的地方打开了一扇门，却发现它被墙堵住了；但他也确信罗莎蒙德对他失望的原因感到满意。他宁愿不看她也不说话，直到他克服了第一次的烦恼。毕竟，他苦涩地说，一个女人，还有什么比房子和家具更在乎的呢？没有她们的丈夫是荒谬的。当他抬起头，将头发拨到一边时，漆黑的眸子里闪着悲惨的茫然，不期待同情，但他只是冷冷地说——

‘Perhaps some one else may turn up. I told Trumbull to be on the look-out if he failed with Plymdale.’
‘也许其他人可能会出现。我告诉特朗布尔，如果他在普利姆代尔失败了，要小心。

Rosamond made no remark. She trusted to the chance that nothing more would pass between her husband and the auctioneer until some issue should have justified her interference; at any rate, she had hindered the event which she immediately dreaded. After a pause, she said—
罗莎蒙德没有发表任何评论。她相信，在某些问题证明她的干涉是合理的之前，她的丈夫和拍卖师之间不会再有任何事情发生。无论如何，她阻碍了她立即害怕的事​​情。停顿了一下，她说道——

‘How much money is it that those disagreeable people want?’
“那些讨厌的人想要多少钱？”

‘What disagreeable people?’
“什么令人讨厌的人？”

‘Those who took the list—and the others. I mean, how much money would satisfy them so that you need not be troubled any more?’
“那些拿到名单的人——以及其他人。我的意思是，多少钱才能让他们满意，这样你就不用再受困扰了？

Lydgate surveyed her for a moment, as if he were looking for symptoms, and then said, ‘Oh, if I could have got six hundred from Plymdale for furniture and as premium, I might have managed. I could have paid off Dover, and given enough on account to the others to make them wait patiently, if we contracted our expenses.’
利德盖特打量了她一会儿，仿佛在寻找症状，然后说道：“哦，如果我能从普利姆代尔买六百块家具和保费，我也许就能办到。”如果我们缩减开支的话，我本可以还清多佛的钱，并给其他人足够的货款，让他们耐心等待。

‘But I mean how much should you want if we stayed in this house?’
“但我的意思是，如果我们住在这所房子里，你想要多少钱？”

‘More than I am likely to get anywhere,’ said Lydgate, with rather a grating sarcasm in his tone. It angered him to perceive that Rosamond’s mind was wandering over impracticable wishes instead of facing possible efforts.
“比我可能得到的还要多，”利德盖特说道，语气中带着刺耳的讽刺。当他发现罗莎蒙德的心思在不切实际的愿望上徘徊，而不是面对可能的努力时，他感到愤怒。

‘Why should you not mention the sum?’ said Rosamond, with a mild indication that she did not like his manners.
“你为什么不提这笔钱呢？”罗莎蒙德说道，语气温和地表明她不喜欢他的举止。

‘Well,’ said Lydgate in a guessing tone, ‘it would take at least a thousand to set me at ease. But,’ he added, incisively, ‘I have to consider what I shall do without it, not with it.’
“好吧，”利德盖特用猜测的语气说道，“至少需要一千次才能让我放心。但是，”他尖锐地补充道，“我必须考虑没有它我该怎么办，而不是有了它。”

Rosamond said no more.
罗莎蒙德不再说话。

But the next day she carried out her plan of writing to Sir Godwin Lydgate. Since the Captain’s visit, she had received a letter from him, and also one from Mrs. Mengan, his married sister, condoling with her on the loss of her baby, and expressing vaguely the hope that they should see her again at Quallingham. Lydgate had told her that this politeness meant nothing; but she was secretly convinced that any backwardness in Lydgate’s family towards him was due to his cold and contemptuous behavior, and she had answered the letters in her most charming manner, feeling some confidence that a specific invitation would follow. But there had been total silence. The Captain evidently was not a great penman, and Rosamond reflected that the sisters might have been abroad. However, the season was come for thinking of friends at home, and at any rate Sir Godwin, who had chucked her under the chin, and pronounced her to be like the celebrated beauty, Mrs. Croly, who had made a conquest of him in 1790, would be touched by any appeal from her, and would find it pleasant for her sake to behave as he ought to do towards his nephew. Rosamond was naively convinced of what an old gentleman ought to do to prevent her from suffering annoyance. And she wrote what she considered the most judicious letter possible— one which would strike Sir Godwin as a proof of her excellent sense— pointing out how desirable it was that Tertius should quit such a place as Middlemarch for one more fitted to his talents, how the unpleasant character of the inhabitants had hindered his professional success, and how in consequence he was in money difficulties, from which it would require a thousand pounds thoroughly to extricate him. She did not say that Tertius was unaware of her intention to write; for she had the idea that his supposed sanction of her letter would be in accordance with what she did say of his great regard for his uncle Godwin as the relative who had always been his best friend. Such was the force of Poor Rosamond’s tactics now she applied them to affairs.
但第二天她就执行了给戈德温·利德盖特爵士写信的计划。自从上尉来访后，她收到了他的一封信，还有他已婚的妹妹门甘夫人的一封信，信中对她失去孩子表示哀悼，并含糊地表示希望他们能在夸林厄姆再次见到她。利德盖特告诉她，这种礼貌毫无意义。但她暗自确信，利德盖特家族对他的任何落后都是由于他的冷漠和轻蔑行为，她以最迷人的方式回了信，对随之而来的特定邀请感到有些信心。但周围一片寂静。船长显然不是一个伟大的作家，罗莎蒙德认为姐妹俩可能去了国外。然而，想到家里的朋友的季节到了，无论如何，戈德温爵士把她扔到了下巴下面，并宣称她就像著名的美女克罗利夫人一样，克罗利夫人在一年中征服了他。 1790年，他会被她的任何呼吁所感动，并且会发现为了她而对他的侄子采取他应该做的事情是令人愉快的。罗莎蒙德天真地相信，一位老绅士应该采取什么措施来避免她遭受烦恼。她写了一封她认为可能是最明智的信——一封令戈德温爵士印象深刻的信，证明了她卓越的判断力——指出特提乌斯离开米德尔马契这样的地方去寻找一个更适合他才能的地方是多么可取，居民们令人不愉快的性格阻碍了他职业上的成功，结果他陷入了经济困难，需要一千英镑才能彻底摆脱困境。 她并没有说特蒂乌斯不知道她写作的意图；而是说，特蒂乌斯不知道她写作的意图。因为她认为他对她的信的所谓批准将与她所说的他对他叔叔戈德温的高度尊重相一致，戈德温是他的亲戚，也是他最好的朋友。这就是可怜的罗莎蒙德的策略的力量，现在她把它们应用到事务上。

This had happened before the party on New Year’s Day, and no answer had yet come from Sir Godwin. But on the morning of that day Lydgate had to learn that Rosamond had revoked his order to Borthrop Trumbull. Feeling it necessary that she should be gradually accustomed to the idea of their quitting the house in Lowick Gate, he overcame his reluctance to speak to her again on the subject, and when they were breakfasting said—
这件事发生在元旦聚会之前，戈德温爵士还没有给出任何答复。但就在那天早上，利德盖特得知罗莎蒙德已经撤销了对博思罗普·特朗布尔的命令。他觉得她有必要逐渐习惯他们离开洛威克门的房子的想法，他克服了不愿再次与她谈论这个话题的心情，在他们吃早餐的时候说道——

‘I shall try to see Trumbull this morning, and tell him to. advertise the house in the ‘Pioneer’ and the ‘Trumpet.’ If the thing were advertised, some one might be inclined to take it who would not otherwise have thought of a change. In these country places many people go on in their old houses when their families are too large for them, for want of knowing where they can find another. And Trumbull seems to have got no bite at all.’
“今天早上我会试着去见特朗布尔，并告诉他。在《先锋报》和《小号报》上为这所房子做广告。如果这件事被登出广告，一些人可能会倾向于接受它，否则他们不会想到改变。在这些乡村地区，当家庭人口过多时，许多人仍继续住在自己的老房子里，因为他们不知道在哪里可以找到另一个家庭。特朗布尔似乎根本没有被咬到。

Rosamond knew that the inevitable moment was come. ‘I ordered Trumbull not to inquire further,’ she said, with a careful calmness which was evidently defensive.
罗莎蒙德知道不可避免的时刻已经到来。 “我命令特朗布尔不要进一步询问，”她说，语气小心谨慎，显然是出于防御。

Lydgate stared at her in mute amazement. Only half an hour before he had been fastening up her plaits for her, and talking the ‘little language’ of affection, which Rosamond, though not returning it, accepted as if she had been a serene and lovely image, now and then miraculously dimpling towards her votary. With such fibres still astir in him, the shock he received could not at once be distinctly anger; it was confused pain. He laid down the knife and fork with which he was carving, and throwing himself back in his chair, said at last, with a cool irony in his tone—
利德盖特无声地惊讶地看着她。就在半小时前，他还为她扎紧辫子，说着爱意的“小语言”，罗莎蒙德虽然没有回应，但还是接受了，仿佛她是一个宁静而可爱的形象，时不时奇迹般地露出酒窝。走向她的选民。由于这些纤维仍在他体内搅动，他所受到的震惊不可能立刻就明显是愤怒；而是愤怒。这是混乱的痛苦。他放下正在切肉的刀叉，往椅背上一靠，最后说道，语气中带着冷酷的讽刺——

‘May I ask when and why you did so?’
“请问您何时以及为何这样做？”
