‘When I knew that the Plymdales had taken a house, I called to tell him not to mention ours to them; and at the same time I told him not to let the affair go on any further. I knew that it would be very injurious to you if it were known that you wished to part with your house and furniture, and I had a very strong objection to it. I think that was reason enough.’
“当我知道普林代尔夫妇已经买了一套房子时，我打电话告诉他不要向他们提起我们的房子；同时我也告诉他不要再让这件事继续下去了。我知道，如果让别人知道你想放弃你的房子和家具，对你来说是非常伤害的，我对此非常反对。我认为这已经是足够的理由了。

‘It was of no consequence then that I had told you imperative reasons of another kind; of no consequence that I had come to a different conclusion, and given an order accordingly?’ said Lydgate, bitingly, the thunder and lightning gathering about his brow and eyes.
“那么，我告诉你另一种迫在眉睫的原因并不重要。 “我得出了不同的结论，并相应地下达了命令，这没什么影响吗？”利德盖特尖刻地说，雷电在他的额头和眼睛周围聚集。

The effect of any one’s anger on Rosamond had always been to make her shrink in cold dislike, and to become all the more calmly correct, in the conviction that she was not the person to misbehave whatever others might do. She replied—
任何人的愤怒对罗莎蒙德的影响总是让她因冷酷的厌恶而畏缩，并变得更加冷静正确，因为她坚信她不是一个无论别人做什么都会做出不法行为的人。她回应-

‘I think I had a perfect right to speak on a subject which concerns me at least as much as you.’
“我认为我完全有权利就一个至少和你一样关心的话题发表看法。”

‘Clearly—you had a right to speak, but only to me. You had no right to contradict my orders secretly, and treat me as if I were a fool,’ said Lydgate, in the same tone as before. Then with some added scorn, ‘Is it possible to make you understand what the consequences will be? Is it of any use for me to tell you again why we must try to part with the house?’
“显然——你有权说话，但仅限于我。你没有权利暗中违背我的命令，把我当傻瓜一样。”利德盖特语气和之前一样说道。然后又带着几分轻蔑，‘能不能让你明白后果是什么？我再告诉你为什么我们必须尝试放弃房子有什么用吗？

‘It is not necessary for you to tell me again,’ said Rosamond, in a voice that fell and trickled like cold water-drops. ‘I remembered what you said. You spoke just as violently as you do now. But that does not alter my opinion that you ought to try every other means rather than take a step which is so painful to me. And as to advertising the house, I think it would be perfectly degrading to you.’
“你没有必要再告诉我一次，”罗莎蒙德说道，声音像冰冷的水滴一样低沉而滴落。 ‘我记住了你说的话。你说话的语气和现在一样粗暴。但这并没有改变我的观点，即你应该尝试所有其他方法，而不是采取对我来说如此痛苦的一步。至于为房子做广告，我认为这对你来说是完全有辱人格的。”

‘And suppose I disregard your opinion as you disregard mine?’
“假设我无视你的意见，就像你无视我的意见一样？”

‘You can do so, of course. But I think you ought to have told me before we were married that you would place me in the worst position, rather than give up your own will.’
‘当然，你可以这样做。但我认为你应该在我们结婚之前告诉我，你会把我置于最糟糕的境地，而不是放弃你自己的意愿。”

Lydgate did not speak, but tossed his head on one side, and twitched the corners of his mouth in despair. Rosamond, seeing that he was not looking at her, rose and set his cup of coffee before him; but he took no notice of it, and went on with an inward drama and argument, occasionally moving in his seat, resting one arm on the table, and rubbing his hand against his hair. There was a conflux of emotions and thoughts in him that would not let him either give thorough way to his anger or persevere with simple rigidity of resolve. Rosamond took advantage of his silence.
利德盖特没有说话，只是把头偏向一侧，绝望地抽动着嘴角。罗莎蒙德发现他没有看她，便站起身来，将一杯咖啡放在他面前。但他没有注意到这一点，继续进行内心的戏剧和争论，偶尔在座位上移动，将一只手臂放在桌子上，用手摩擦头发。他内心的情绪和思想混杂在一起，既无法彻底发泄愤怒，也无法坚持简单的坚定决心。罗莎蒙德利用了他的沉默。

‘When we were married everyone felt that your position was very high. I could not have imagined then that you would want to sell our furniture, and take a house in Bride Street, where the rooms are like cages. If we are to live in that way let us at least leave Middlemarch.’
“我们结婚的时候，大家都觉得你的地位很高。我当时无法想象你会想卖掉我们的家具，在新娘街买一套房子，那里的房间就像笼子一样。如果我们要那样生活，我们至少要离开米德尔马契。”

‘These would be very strong considerations,’ said Lydgate, half ironically—still there was a withered paleness about his lips as he looked at his coffee, and did not drink—‘these would be very strong considerations if I did not happen to be in debt.’
“这些将是非常强烈的考虑，”利德盖特半讽刺地说——当他看着咖啡时，他的嘴唇仍然呈现枯萎的苍白，并没有喝——“如果我不碰巧是的话，这些将是非常强烈的考虑负债累累。

‘Many persons must have been in debt in the same way, but if they are respectable, people trust them. I am sure I have heard papa say that the Torbits were in debt, and they went on very well It cannot be good to act rashly,’ said Rosamond, with serene wisdom.
“很多人肯定都以同样的方式负债累累，但如果他们受人尊敬，人们就会信任他们。我确信我听爸爸说过，托比特家族负债累累，而且他们过得很好。鲁莽行事可不好。”罗莎蒙德平静而睿智地说。

Lydgate sat paralyzed by opposing impulses: since no reasoning he could apply to Rosamond seemed likely to conquer her assent, he wanted to smash and grind some object on which he could at least produce an impression, or else to tell her brutally that he was master, and she must obey. But he not only dreaded the effect of such extremities on their mutual life—he had a growing dread of Rosamond’s quiet elusive obstinacy, which would not allow any assertion of power to be final; and again, she had touched him in a spot of keenest feeling by implying that she had been deluded with a false vision of happiness in marrying him. As to saying that he was master, it was not the fact. The very resolution to which he had wrought himself by dint of logic and honorable pride was beginning to relax under her torpedo contact. He swallowed half his cup of coffee, and then rose to go.
利德盖特因相反的冲动而瘫痪了：因为他无法向罗莎蒙德提出任何推理，似乎都不可能赢得她的同意，所以他想粉碎和研磨一些他至少可以产生印象的物体，或者残酷地告诉她他是主人，她必须服从。但他不仅担心这种极端行为会对他们共同的生活产生影响——他越来越害怕罗莎蒙德安静而难以捉摸的固执，这不允许任何权力的主张成为最终的；她再次触动了他最强烈的感情，暗示她被嫁给他的幸福幻想所欺骗。至于说他是师父，那不是事实。他凭借逻辑和光荣的自豪感下定的决心在她的鱼雷接触下开始放松。他吞下半杯咖啡，然后起身要走。

‘I may at least request that you will not go to Trumbull at present— until it has been seen that there are no other means,’ said Rosamond. Although she was not subject to much fear, she felt it safer not to betray that she had written to Sir Godwin. ‘Promise me that you will not go to him for a few weeks, or without telling me.’
“我至少可以请求你目前不要去特朗布尔——直到发现没有其他办法为止，”罗莎蒙德说。虽然她并没有感到太多的恐惧，但她觉得还是不要泄露她给戈德温爵士写过信的事实更安全。 “答应我，几周内你不会去找他，或者不告诉我。”

Lydgate gave a short laugh. ‘I think it is I who should exact a promise that you will do nothing without telling me,’ he said, turning his eyes sharply upon her, and then moving to the door.
利德盖特短促地笑了一声。 “我想我应该向她保证，你不会在没有告诉我的情况下做任何事情，”他说，目光锐利地转向她，然后向门口走去。

‘You remember that we are going to dine at papa’s,’ said Rosamond, wishing that he should turn and make a more thorough concession to her. But he only said ‘Oh yes,’ impatiently, and went away. She held it to be very odious in him that he did not think the painful propositions he had had to make to her were enough, without showing so unpleasant a temper. And when she put the moderate request that he would defer going to Trumbull again, it was cruel in him not to assure her of what he meant to do. She was convinced of her having acted in every way for the best; and each grating or angry speech of Lydgate’s served only as an addition to the register of offences in her mind. Poor Rosamond for months had begun to associate her husband with feelings of disappointment, and the terribly inflexible relation of marriage had lost its charm of encouraging delightful dreams. It had freed her from the disagreeables of her father’s house, but it had not given her everything that she had wished and hoped. The Lydgate with whom she had been in love had been a group of airy conditions for her, most of which had disappeared, while their place had been taken by every-day details which must be lived through slowly from hour to hour, not floated through with a rapid selection of favorable aspects. The habits of Lydgate’s profession, his home preoccupation with scientific subjects, which seemed to her almost like a morbid vampire’s taste, his peculiar views of things which had never entered into the dialogue of courtship— all these continually alienating influences, even without the fact of his having placed himself at a disadvantage in the town, and without that first shock of revelation about Dover’s debt, would have made his presence dull to her. There was another presence which ever since the early days of her marriage, until four months ago, had been an agreeable excitement, but that was gone: Rosamond would not confess to herself how much the consequent blank had to do with her utter ennui; and it seemed to her (perhaps she was right) that an invitation to Quallingham, and an opening for Lydgate to settle elsewhere than in Middlemarch—in London, or somewhere likely to be free from unpleasantness—would satisfy her quite well, and make her indifferent to the absence of Will Ladislaw, towards whom she felt some resentment for his exaltation of Mrs. Casaubon.
“你记得我们要在爸爸家吃饭，”罗莎蒙德说道，希望他能转身对她做出更彻底的让步。但他只是不耐烦地说了句“哦，是的”，然后就走了。她认为他非常可恶，因为他认为自己必须向她提出的痛苦建议还不够，还没有表现出如此令人不快的脾气。当她温和地请求他推迟再次去特朗布尔时，他没有向她保证他打算做什么，这对他来说是残酷的。她确信自己所做的一切都是为了最好的结果。利德盖特的每一次刺耳或愤怒的言论都只是在她的脑海中增加了一些冒犯行为。几个月来，可怜的罗莎蒙德开始将她的丈夫与失望的感觉联系在一起，极其僵化的婚姻关系也失去了鼓励美好梦想的魅力。它使她摆脱了父亲家里的不愉快，但并没有给她带来她所希望和希望的一切。她所爱的利德盖特对她来说是一群虚无缥缈的环境，其中大部分已经消失，取而代之的是日常细节，这些细节必须一个小时一个小时地慢慢经历，而不是飘过。快速选择有利的方面。利德盖特的职业习惯，他在家对科学科目的痴迷，在她看来几乎就像病态吸血鬼的品味，他对从未进入求爱对话的事物的独特看法——所有这些不断疏远的影响，即使没有事实他让自己在镇上处于不利地位，如果不是第一次得知多佛欠债的消息，她就会觉得他的存在索然无味。 还有另一种存在，从她结婚之初，直到四个月前，一直是令人愉快的兴奋，但那已经消失了：罗莎蒙德不会向自己承认，随之而来的空白与她彻底的厌倦有多大关系；在她看来（也许她是对的），邀请奎林厄姆，并为利德盖特提供一个在米德尔马契以外的地方定居的机会——在伦敦，或者可能没有不愉快的地方——会让她非常满意，并使她她对威尔·拉迪斯瓦夫的缺席漠不关心，她对他对卡苏邦夫人的高举感到有些怨恨。

That was the state of things with Lydgate and Rosamond on the New Year’s Day when they dined at her father’s, she looking mildly neutral towards him in remembrance of his ill-tempered behavior at breakfast, and he carrying a much deeper effect from the inward conflict in which that morning scene was only one of many epochs. His flushed effort while talking to Mr. Farebrother—his effort after the cynical pretence that all ways of getting money are essentially the same, and that chance has an empire which reduces choice to a fool’s illusion—was but the symptom of a wavering resolve, a benumbed response to the old stimuli of enthusiasm.
这就是元旦那天利德盖特和罗莎蒙德在她父亲家里吃饭时的情况，她对他表现出温和的中立态度，因为她记得他在早餐时的脾气暴躁，而他的内心冲突给他带来了更深层次的影响。那个早晨的场景只是众多时代之一。他在与费雷布拉泽先生交谈时脸红的努力——他的努力是在愤世嫉俗地假装所有赚钱的方式本质上都是一样的，而机会有一个帝国，将选择减少到傻瓜的幻想——只不过是决心动摇的症状。对旧的热情刺激的麻木反应。

What was he to do? He saw even more keenly than Rosamond did the dreariness of taking her into the small house in Bride Street, where she would have scanty furniture around her and discontent within: a life of privation and life with Rosamond were two images which had become more and more irreconcilable ever since the threat of privation had disclosed itself. But even if his resolves had forced the two images into combination, the useful preliminaries to that hard change were not visibly within reach. And though he had not given the promise which his wife had asked for, he did not go again to Trumbull. He even began to think of taking a rapid journey to the North and seeing Sir Godwin. He had once believed that nothing would urge him into making an application for money to his uncle, but he had not then known the full pressure of alternatives yet more disagreeable. He could not depend on the effect of a letter; it was only in an interview, however disagreeable this might be to himself, that he could give a thorough explanation and could test the effectiveness of kinship. No sooner had Lydgate begun to represent this step to himself as the easiest than there was a reaction of anger that he—he who had long ago determined to live aloof from such abject calculations, such self-interested anxiety about the inclinations and the pockets of men with whom he had been proud to have no aims in common—should have fallen not simply to their level, but to the level of soliciting them.
他该怎么办？他比罗莎蒙德更敏锐地看到了带她走进布莱德街那间小房子的沉闷，在那里她周围的家具很少，内心不满：贫困的生活和与罗莎蒙德的生活是两个越来越强烈的形象。自从贫困的威胁暴露出来以来，这种矛盾就一直是不可调和的。但即使他的决心迫使这两个图像结合在一起，但这一艰难改变的有用的准备工作显然还遥不可及。尽管他没有做出妻子所要求的承诺，但他没有再去特朗布尔。他甚至开始考虑快速前往北方，去见见戈德温爵士。他曾经相信没有什么会促使他向叔叔申请金钱，但他当时并不知道其他选择的全部压力，而且更令人不快。他不能依赖一封信的效果；只有在接受采访时，无论这对他自己来说有多么不愉快，他才能给出彻底的解释，才能检验亲属关系的有效性。利德盖特一开始对自己说这一步是最简单的，他就感到愤怒，因为他——他很久以前就决定远离这种卑鄙的算计，这种对个人倾向和口袋的自私焦虑。他曾经为自己没有共同目标而自豪的那些人，不应该仅仅落入他们的水平，而应该落入招揽他们的水平。

CHAPTER LXV
第六十五章

‘One of us two must bowen douteless,
“我们两个人中的一个必须毫无疑问地鲍恩，

And, sith a man is more reasonable
而且，男人更通情达理

Than woman is, ye [men] moste be suffrable.
与女人相比，你们[男人]最容易忍受。

—CHAUCER: Canterbury Tales.
——乔叟：《坎特伯雷故事集》。

The bias of human nature to be slow in correspondence triumphs even over the present quickening in the general pace of things: what wonder then that in 1832 old Sir Godwin Lydgate was slow to write a letter which was of consequence to others rather than to himself? Nearly three weeks of the new year were gone, and Rosamond, awaiting an answer to her winning appeal, was every day disappointed. Lydgate, in total ignorance of her expectations, was seeing the bills come in, and feeling that Dover’s use of his advantage over other creditors was imminent. He had never mentioned to Rosamond his brooding purpose of going to Quallingham: he did not want to admit what would appear to her a concession to her wishes after indignant refusal, until the last moment; but he was really expecting to set off soon. A slice of the railway would enable him to manage the whole journey and back in four days.
人性中迟缓的通信倾向甚至战胜了当今事物普遍节奏的加快：那么，1832 年，老戈德温·利德盖特爵士写一封对别人而不是对他自己来说重要的信时，有什么奇怪的呢？新年已经过去了近三个星期，罗莎蒙德在等待她获胜上诉的答复时，每天都感到失望。利德盖特完全不知道她的期望，看到账单进来，并感到多佛即将利用他相对于其他债权人的优势。他从来没有向罗莎蒙德提起他去奎林厄姆的深思熟虑的目的：直到最后一刻，他都不想承认在她愤怒的拒绝之后，他认为这似乎是对她愿望的让步；但他不想承认这一点。但他真的很期待很快就出发。铁路的一段可以让他在四天内完成整个旅程并返回。

But one morning after Lydgate had gone out, a letter came addressed to him, which Rosamond saw clearly to be from Sir Godwin. She was full of hope. Perhaps there might be a particular note to her enclosed; but Lydgate was naturally addressed on the question of money or other aid, and the fact that he was written to, nay, the very delay in writing at all, seemed to certify that the answer was thoroughly compliant. She was too much excited by these thoughts to do anything but light stitching in a warm corner of the dining-room, with the outside of this momentous letter lying on the table before her. About twelve she heard her husband’s step in the passage, and tripping to open the door, she said in her lightest tones, ‘Tertius, come in here— here is a letter for you.’
但利德盖特出去后的一天早上，一封写给他的信收到了，罗莎蒙德清楚地看出这封信是戈德温爵士寄来的。她充满了希望。或许附上一张给她的特别便条；但利德盖特很自然地谈到了金钱或其他援助的问题，事实上，他是写信给他的，不，甚至是迟迟没有写信，似乎证明了他的答复是完全顺从的。这些想法让她太兴奋了，除了在餐厅温暖的角落里轻轻缝合之外，她什么也做不了，这封重要信件的外面就放在她面前的桌子上。十二点左右，她听到丈夫在过道里的脚步声，她绊倒去开门，用最轻松的声音说：“特蒂乌斯，进来吧——这是给你的一封信。”

‘Ah?’ he said, not taking off his hat, but just turning her round within his arm to walk towards the spot where the letter lay. ‘My uncle Godwin!’ he exclaimed, while Rosamond reseated herself, and watched him as he opened the letter. She had expected him to be surprised.
“啊？”他没有摘下帽子，只是将她搂在怀里，朝放信的地方走去。 “我的戈德温叔叔！”他喊道，罗莎蒙德重新坐下，看着他打开信。她本来以为他会感到惊讶。

While Lydgate’s eyes glanced rapidly over the brief letter, she saw his face, usually of a pale brown, taking on a dry whiteness; with nostrils and lips quivering he tossed down the letter before her, and said violently—
当利德盖特的眼睛快速扫过那封简短的信时，她看到他通常是浅棕色的脸变成了干燥的白色；他鼻孔和嘴唇都在颤抖，把信扔到她面前，粗暴地说——

‘It will be impossible to endure life with you, if you will always be acting secretly—acting in opposition to me and hiding your actions.’
“如果你总是秘密行事——与我对立并隐藏你的行为，那么你就不可能忍受和你一起生活。”

He checked his speech and turned his back on her—then wheeled round and walked about, sat down, and got up again restlessly, grasping hard the objects deep down in his pockets. He was afraid of saying something irremediably cruel.
他核对了一下自己的措辞，转身背对着她——然后转身走来走去，坐了下来，又不安地站起来，用力地抓着口袋深处的东西。他害怕说出一些无法挽回的残酷的话。

Rosamond too had changed color as she read. The letter ran in this way:—
罗莎蒙德读着读着，脸色也变了。这封信是这样写的：——

‘DEAR TERTIUS,—Don’t set your wife to write to me when you have anything to ask. It is a roundabout wheedling sort of thing which I should not have credited you with. I never choose to write to a woman on matters of business. As to my supplying you with a thousand pounds, or only half that sum, I can do nothing of the sort. My own family drains me to the last penny. With two younger sons and three daughters, I am not likely to have cash to spare. You seem to have got through your own money pretty quickly, and to have made a mess where you are; the sooner you go somewhere else the better. But I have nothing to do with men of your profession, and can’t help you there. I did the best I could for you as guardian, and let you have your own way in taking to medicine. You might have gone into the army or the Church. Your money would have held out for that, and there would have been a surer ladder before you. Your uncle Charles has had a grudge against you for not going into his profession, but not I. I have always wished you well, but you must consider yourself on your own legs entirely now.
“亲爱的特蒂斯，——当你有什么要问的时候，不要让你的妻子写信给我。这是一种迂回的哄骗行为，我不应该把这归功于你。我从不选择写信给女人谈生意。至于我给你一千英镑，或者只给你一半，我无能为力。我自己的家人耗尽了我的最后一分钱。我有两个小儿子和三个女儿，不太可能有多余的现金。你似乎很快就花光了自己的钱，却把自己的处境搞得一团糟；你越早去别的地方越好。但我和你这个职业没有任何关系，也帮不了你。我以监护人的身份为你尽了最大的努力，让你有自己的吃药方式。你可能已经参军或去教堂了。你的钱会坚持下去，而且在你面前会有一个更可靠的阶梯。你的查尔斯叔叔因为你没有从事他的职业而对你怀恨在心，但我却没有。我一直祝愿你一切顺利，但你现在必须考虑自己完全靠自己的力量了。

Your affectionate uncle,
你慈爱的叔叔，

GODWIN LYDGATE.’
戈德温·利德盖特。”

When Rosamond had finished reading the letter she sat quite still, with her hands folded before her, restraining any show of her keen disappointment, and intrenching herself in quiet passivity under her husband’s wrath Lydgate paused in his movements, looked at her again, and said, with biting severity—
罗莎蒙德读完信后，她一动不动地坐着，双手交叉在身前，克制住自己强烈失望的表现，在丈夫的愤怒之下，保持着安静的被动。 利德盖特停下了动作，再次看着她，说道： ，具有咬人的严重性——

‘Will this be enough to convince you of the harm you may do by secret meddling? Have you sense enough to recognize now your incompetence to judge and act for me—to interfere with your ignorance in affairs which it belongs to me to decide on?’
‘这足以让你相信秘密干预可能造成的危害吗？你现在是否有足够的意识认识到你没有能力为我判断和行动——在本应由我决定的事情上干涉你的无知？

The words were hard; but this was not the first time that Lydgate had been frustrated by her. She did not look at him, and made no reply.
这句话很难听；但这并不是利德盖特第一次对她感到沮丧。她没有看他，也没有回答。

‘I had nearly resolved on going to Quallingham. It would have cost me pain enough to do it, yet it might have been of some use. But it has been of no use for me to think of anything. You have always been counteracting me secretly. You delude me with a false assent, and then I am at the mercy of your devices. If you mean to resist every wish I express, say so and defy me. I shall at least know what I am doing then.’
“我差点就决定去夸林汉姆了。这样做会让我付出足够的痛苦，但它可能会有一些用处。但我想什么都没有用。你一直在暗中对抗我。你用虚假的同意来欺骗我，然后我就任由你的诡计摆布。如果你想抵制我表达的每一个愿望，那就直说并反抗我。那时我至少会知道我在做什么。

It is a terrible moment in young lives when the closeness of love’s bond has turned to this power of galling. In spite of Rosamond’s self-control a tear fell silently and rolled over her lips. She still said nothing; but under that quietude was hidden an intense effect: she was in such entire disgust with her husband that she wished she had never seen him. Sir Godwin’s rudeness towards her and utter want of feeling ranged him with Dover and all other creditors— disagreeable people who only thought of themselves, and did not mind how annoying they were to her. Even her father was unkind, and might have done more for them. In fact there was but one person in Rosamond’s world whom she did not regard as blameworthy, and that was the graceful creature with blond plaits and with little hands crossed before her, who had never expressed herself unbecomingly, and had always acted for the best—the best naturally being what she best liked.
当爱情的亲密纽带变成这种令人难堪的力量时，这是年轻生命中一个可怕的时刻。尽管罗莎蒙德极力克制，一滴眼泪却无声地滑落，从她的唇边滑落。她仍然什么也没说；但在这种平静之下，隐藏着一种强烈的影响：她对她的丈夫感到非常厌恶，以至于她希望自己从未见过他。戈德温爵士对她的粗鲁和完全缺乏感情，使他与多佛和所有其他债权人站在一起——这些讨厌的人只考虑自己，不介意他们对她来说有多么烦人。就连她的父亲也不友善，本来可以为他们做更多的事情。事实上，在罗莎蒙德的世界里，只有一个人是她不认为应该受到责备的，那就是那个有着金色辫子、双手交叉在她面前的优雅生物，她从来没有表现出不恰当的态度，而且总是表现得最好——最好的自然是她最喜欢的。

Lydgate pausing and looking at her began to feel that half-maddening sense of helplessness which comes over passionate people when their passion is met by an innocent-looking silence whose meek victimized air seems to put them in the wrong, and at last infects even the justest indignation with a doubt of its justice. He needed to recover the full sense that he was in the right by moderating his words.
利德盖特停下来，看着她，开始感到一种近乎疯狂的无助感，当热情的人的热情遭到看似无辜的沉默的满足时，这种无助的温顺的受害态度似乎让他们陷入了错误，最后甚至感染了他们。对其公正性的怀疑是最公正的愤慨。他需要通过缓和自己的言辞来完全恢复自己的正确感。

‘Can you not see, Rosamond,’ he began again, trying to be simply grave and not bitter, ‘that nothing can be so fatal as a want of openness and confidence between us? It has happened again and again that I have expressed a decided wish, and you have seemed to assent, yet after that you have secretly disobeyed my wish. In that way I can never know what I have to trust to. There would be some hope for us if you would admit this. Am I such an unreasonable, furious brute? Why should you not be open with me?’ Still silence.
“你难道没有看到吗，罗莎蒙德，”他又开始说道，尽量表现得严肃而不是痛苦，“没有什么比我们之间缺乏开放和信任更致命的了？”一次又一次，我表达了明确的愿望，你表面上同意了，但后来却又背地里违背了我的愿望。这样我就永远不知道我必须相信什么。如果你承认这一点，我们就会有一些希望。难道我就是这么不可理喻、狂怒的畜生吗？你为什么不应该对我敞开心扉？” 仍然是沉默。

‘Will you only say that you have been mistaken, and that I may depend on your not acting secretly in future?’ said Lydgate, urgently, but with something of request in his tone which Rosamond was quick to perceive. She spoke with coolness.
“你只能说你错了，我以后可能会相信你不会秘密行事吗？”利德盖特急切地说，但语气中带着一些请求，罗莎蒙德很快就察觉到了。她说话的语气很冷淡。

‘I cannot possibly make admissions or promises in answer to such words as you have used towards me. I have not been accustomed to language of that kind. You have spoken of my ‘secret meddling,’ and my ‘interfering ignorance,’ and my ‘false assent.’ I have never expressed myself in that way to you, and I think that you ought to apologize. You spoke of its being impossible to live with me. Certainly you have not made my life pleasant to me of late. I think it was to be expected that I should try to avert some of the hardships which our marriage has brought on me.’ Another tear fell as Rosamond ceased speaking, and she pressed it away as quietly as the first.
“我不可能承认或做出承诺来回应你对我所说的这些话。我不习惯这种语言。你谈到了我的“暗中干涉”，我的“干涉无知”，以及我的“假同意”。我从来没有以这种方式向你表达过自己的意思，我认为你应该道歉。你说不可能和我一起生活。当然，你最近并没有让我的生活变得愉快。我认为我应该尽力避免我们的婚姻给我带来的一些困难。”罗莎蒙德不再说话时，另一滴泪水落下，她像第一滴眼泪一样安静地把它擦掉。

Lydgate flung himself into a chair, feeling checkmated. What place was there in her mind for a remonstrance to lodge in? He laid down his hat, flung an arm over the back of his chair, and looked down for some moments without speaking. Rosamond had the double purchase over him of insensibility to the point of justice in his reproach, and of sensibility to the undeniable hardships now present in her married life. Although her duplicity in the affair of the house had exceeded what he knew, and had really hindered the Plymdales from knowing of it, she had no consciousness that her action could rightly be called false. We are not obliged to identify our own acts according to a strict classification, any more than the materials of our grocery and clothes. Rosamond felt that she was aggrieved, and that this was what Lydgate had to recognize.
利德盖特猛地坐到椅子上，感觉自己被将死了。她心里有什么地方可以提出抗议？他放下帽子，用一只手臂搭在椅背上，低头看了一会儿，没有说话。罗莎蒙德对他有双重的购买力，一是他对他的责备冷漠到了正义的地步，二是对她婚姻生活中目前存在的不可否认的困难很敏感。尽管她在房子的事情上的口是心非超出了他的认知，并且确实阻碍了普林代尔家族的了解，但她没有意识到她的行为可以被正确地称为虚假。我们没有义务按照严格的分类来识别我们自己的行为，就像我们的杂货和衣服的材料一样。罗莎蒙德觉得自己很委屈，这也是利德盖特必须承认的。

As for him, the need of accommodating himself to her nature, which was inflexible in proportion to its negations, held him as with pincers. He had begun to have an alarmed foresight of her irrevocable loss of love for him, and the consequent dreariness of their life. The ready fulness of his emotions made this dread alternate quickly with the first violent movements of his anger. It would assuredly have been a vain boast in him to say that he was her master.
至于他，需要让自己适应她的本性，而她的本性与它的否定成比例地不灵活，这让他像被钳子一样束缚着。他开始惊恐地预见到她将不可挽回地失去对他的爱，以及随之而来的他们生活的凄凉。他的情绪已经快要饱和了，这种恐惧很快就与他最初爆发的愤怒交替出现。如果说他是她的主人，那肯定是虚夸的。

‘You have not made my life pleasant to me of late’—‘the hardships which our marriage has brought on me’—these words were stinging his imagination as a pain makes an exaggerated dream. If he were not only to sink from his highest resolve, but to sink into the hideous fettering of domestic hate?
“你最近没有让我的生活变得愉快”——“我们的婚姻给我带来了艰辛”——这些话刺痛了他的想象力，就像痛苦造就了夸张的梦想。如果他不仅失去了最高的决心，而且陷入了家庭仇恨的可怕束缚呢？

‘Rosamond,’ he said, turning his eyes on her with a melancholy look, ‘you should allow for a man’s words when he is disappointed and provoked. You and I cannot have opposite interests. I cannot part my happiness from yours. If I am angry with you, it is that you seem not to see how any concealment divides us. How could I wish to make anything hard to you either by my words or conduct? When I hurt you, I hurt part of my own life. I should never be angry with you if you would be quite open with me.’
“罗莎蒙德，”他说道，目光忧郁地转向她，“你应该考虑到一个男人在失望和被激怒时所说的话。你和我不能有相反的利益。我无法将我的幸福与你的幸福分开。如果说我对你生气的话，那就是你似乎没有看到任何隐瞒都会如何分裂我们。我怎么可能希望通过我的言语或行为让你为难呢？当我伤害你时，我也伤害了自己生命的一部分。如果你能对我开诚布公的话，我永远不会生你的气。

‘I have only wished to prevent you from hurrying us into wretchedness without any necessity,’ said Rosamond, the tears coming again from a softened feeling now that her husband had softened. ‘It is so very hard to be disgraced here among all the people we know, and to live in such a miserable way. I wish I had died with the baby.’
“我只是想阻止你毫无必要地让我们陷入困境。”罗莎蒙德说，她的丈夫已经软化了，她的感情又软化了，眼泪又流了下来。 “在这里，在我们认识的所有人面前丢脸，过着如此悲惨的生活，真是太难受了。我希望我和孩子一起死。”

She spoke and wept with that gentleness which makes such words and tears omnipotent over a loving-hearted man. Lydgate drew his chair near to hers and pressed her delicate head against his cheek with his powerful tender hand. He only caressed her; he did not say anything; for what was there to say? He could not promise to shield her from the dreaded wretchedness, for he could see no sure means of doing so. When he left her to go out again, he told himself that it was ten times harder for her than for him: he had a life away from home, and constant appeals to his activity on behalf of others. He wished to excuse everything in her if he could— but it was inevitable that in that excusing mood he should think of her as if she were an animal of another and feebler species. Nevertheless she had mastered him.
她说话和哭泣时都带着温柔，这使得这样的言语和眼泪对于一个充满爱心的男人来说是无所不能的。利德盖特把他的椅子拉到她的身边，用他有力而温柔的手将她娇嫩的头按在他的脸颊上。他只是爱抚她；他什么也没说；有什么好说的呢？他无法保证保护她免受可怕的不幸，因为他看不出有什么可靠的方法可以做到这一点。当他离开她再次出去时，他告诉自己，这对她来说比他困难十倍：他过着远离家乡的生活，并且不断地为他人呼吁他的活动。如果可以的话，他希望原谅她身上的一切——但在那种原谅的心情下，他不可避免地会把她视为另一个更弱种的动物。尽管如此，她还是征服了他。

CHAPTER LXVI
第六十六章

‘Tis one thing to be tempted, Escalus,
“受到诱惑是一回事，埃斯卡勒斯，

Another thing to fall.’
又一件事要落下。

—Measure for Measure.
——一报还一报。

Lydgate certainly had good reason to reflect on the service his practice did him in counteracting his personal cares. He had no longer free energy enough for spontaneous research and speculative thinking, but by the bedside of patients, the direct external calls on his judgment and sympathies brought the added impulse needed to draw him out of himself. It was not simply that beneficent harness of routine which enables silly men to live respectably and unhappy men to live calmly—it was a perpetual claim on the immediate fresh application of thought, and on the consideration of another’s need and trial. Many of us looking back through life would say that the kindest man we have ever known has been a medical man, or perhaps that surgeon whose fine tact, directed by deeply informed perception, has come to us in our need with a more sublime beneficence than that of miracle-workers. Some of that twice-blessed mercy was always with Lydgate in his work at the Hospital or in private houses, serving better than any opiate to quiet and sustain him under his anxieties and his sense of mental degeneracy.
利德盖特当然有充分的理由反思他的做法为他消除个人忧虑所提供的服务。他不再有足够的自由能量来进行自发的研究和推测性思考，但在病人的床边，外部对他的判断力和同情心的直接召唤给他带来了额外的冲动，使他摆脱了自我。这不仅仅是一种仁慈的日常安排，它使愚蠢的人能够体面地生活，让不幸的人平静地生活——它是对立即新的思想应用、对他人的需要和考验的考虑的永久要求。我们中的许多人回顾一生都会说，我们所认识的最仁慈的人是一位医生，或者也许是一位外科医生，他的机智在深刻的洞察力指导下，在我们需要帮助时以比医生更崇高的仁慈来帮助我们。创造奇迹的人。利德盖特在医院或私人住宅的工作中总是有一些双重祝福的怜悯，比任何鸦片都更能帮助他平静和维持他的焦虑和精神堕落感。

Mr. Farebrother’s suspicion as to the opiate was true, however. Under the first galling pressure of foreseen difficulties, and the first perception that his marriage, if it were not to be a yoked loneliness, must be a state of effort to go on loving without too much care about being loved, he had once or twice tried a dose of opium. But he had no hereditary constitutional craving after such transient escapes from the hauntings of misery. He was strong, could drink a great deal of wine, but did not care about it; and when the men round him were drinking spirits, he took sugar and water, having a contemptuous pity even for the earliest stages of excitement from drink. It was the same with gambling. He had looked on at a great deal of gambling in Paris, watching it as if it had been a disease. He was no more tempted by such winning than he was by drink. He had said to himself that the only winning he cared for must be attained by a conscious process of high, difficult combination tending towards a beneficent result. The power he longed for could not be represented by agitated fingers clutching a heap of coin, or by the half-barbarous, half-idiotic triumph in the eyes of a man who sweeps within his arms the ventures of twenty chapfallen companions.
然而，费雷布拉泽先生对阿片类药物的怀疑是正确的。在预见到的困难所带来的第一个令人恼火的压力下，在第一次意识到他的婚姻如果不是一种束缚的孤独，就必须是一种努力继续爱而不太在意被爱的状态时，他有一两次尝试了一剂鸦片。但在短暂摆脱痛苦之后，他并没有继承宪法的渴望。他身体强壮，能喝很多酒，但并不在意；当他周围的人喝烈酒时，他就拿糖和水，甚至对饮酒带来的最初兴奋阶段也抱有轻蔑的怜悯。赌博也是如此。他目睹了巴黎的大量赌博活动，仿佛这是一种疾病。他对这种胜利的诱惑并不比对酒精的诱惑更大。他对自己说，他所关心的唯一胜利必须通过有意识的过程来实现，将高难度的组合趋向于有益的结果。他所渴望的力量无法用紧握一堆硬币的激动的手指来代表，也不能用一个将二十个失败同伴的冒险抱在怀里的人眼中半野蛮半愚蠢的胜利来代表。

But just as he had tried opium, so his thought now began to turn upon gambling—not with appetite for its excitement, but with a sort of wistful inward gaze after that easy way of getting money, which implied no asking and brought no responsibility. If he had been in London or Paris at that time, it is probable that such thoughts, seconded by opportunity, would have taken him into a gambling-house, no longer to watch the gamblers, but to watch with them in kindred eagerness. Repugnance would have been surmounted by the immense need to win, if chance would be kind enough to let him. An incident which happened not very long after that airy notion of getting aid from his uncle had been excluded, was a strong sign of the effect that might have followed any extant opportunity of gambling.
但就像他尝试过鸦片一样，他的思想现在开始转向赌博——不是为了刺激的欲望，而是一种渴望的内心凝视，因为这种简单的赚钱方式意味着不要求任何要求，也不带来任何责任。如果他当时在伦敦或巴黎，很可能这种想法加上机会，就会带他走进赌场，不再是观看赌徒，而是怀着同样的热切与他们一起观看。如果机会足够好的话，对胜利的巨大渴望就会克服反感。在他排除了从叔叔那里获得援助的空想之后不久发生的一件事，是一个强烈的迹象，表明任何现有的赌博机会都可能产生影响。

The billiard-room at the Green Dragon was the constant resort of a certain set, most of whom, like our acquaintance Mr. Bambridge, were regarded as men of pleasure. It was here that poor Fred Vincy had made part of his memorable debt, having lost money in betting, and been obliged to borrow of that gay companion. It was generally known in Middlemarch that a good deal of money was lost and won in this way; and the consequent repute of the Green Dragon as a place of dissipation naturally heightened in some quarters the temptation to go there. Probably its regular visitants, like the initiates of freemasonry, wished that there were something a little more tremendous to keep to themselves concerning it; but they were not a closed community, and many decent seniors as well as juniors occasionally turned into the billiard-room to see what was going on. Lydgate, who had the muscular aptitude for billiards, and was fond of the game, had once or twice in the early days after his arrival in Middlemarch taken his turn with the cue at the Green Dragon; but afterwards he had no leisure for the game, and no inclination for the socialities there. One evening, however, he had occasion to seek Mr. Bambridge at that resort. The horsedealer had engaged to get him a customer for his remaining good horse, for which Lydgate had determined to substitute a cheap hack, hoping by this reduction of style to get perhaps twenty pounds; and he cared now for every small sum, as a help towards feeding the patience of his tradesmen. To run up to the billiard-room, as he was passing, would save time.
绿龙酒店的台球室是某些人常去的地方，他们中的大多数人，就像我们的熟人班布里奇先生一样，被认为是享乐之人。正是在这里，可怜的弗雷德·文西（Fred Vincy）在赌博中输了钱，欠下了他难忘的债务，不得不向那个同性恋同伴借钱。在米德尔马契，众所周知，通过这种方式输掉了很多钱，也赢得了很多钱。随之而来的“绿龙”作为放荡之地的名声自然增强了某些人前往那里的诱惑。也许它的常客，就像共济会的发起人一样，希望有一些更重大的事情可以保密；但他们并不是一个封闭的社区，许多体面的老年人和年轻人偶尔会跑到台球室看看发生了什么。利德盖特有着强健的台球天赋，并且热爱这项运动，在抵达米德尔马奇后的最初几天，他曾在绿龙球场用球杆打过一两次球。但后来他就没有闲暇去玩游戏，也没有兴趣参加那里的社交活动了。然而，有一天晚上，他有机会到那个度假胜地去找班布里奇先生。马商已经答应为他剩下的好马找一个顾客，利德盖特决定用一匹廉价的马匹来代替，希望通过这种风格的减少，可以赚到大约二十英镑；但是，他的马匹却被卖掉了。他现在关心每一笔小钱，以帮助增强商人的耐心。当他经过时跑到台球室会节省时间。

Mr. Bambridge was not yet come, bat would be sure to arrive by-and-by, said his friend Mr. Horrock; and Lydgate stayed, playing a game for the sake of passing the time. That evening he had the peculiar light in the eyes and the unusual vivacity which had been once noticed in him by Mr. Farebrother. The exceptional fact of his presence was much noticed in the room, where there was a good deal of Middlemarch company; and several lookers-on, as well as some of the players, were betting with animation. Lydgate was playing well, and felt confident; the bets were dropping round him, and with a swift glancing thought of the probable gain which might double the sum he was saving from his horse, he began to bet on his own play, and won again and again. Mr. Bambridge had come in, but Lydgate did not notice him. He was not only excited with his play, but visions were gleaming on him of going the next day to Brassing, where there was gambling on a grander scale to be had, and where, by one powerful snatch at the devil’s bait, he might carry it off without the hook, and buy his rescue from his daily solicitings.
班布里奇先生还没有来，蝙蝠很快就会到达，他的朋友霍罗克先生说；利德盖特留下来，玩游戏来打发时间。那天晚上，他的眼睛里闪烁着奇特的光芒，表现出一种不同寻常的活力，费雷布拉泽先生曾在他身上注意到过这一点。他的出现在房间里引起了很多人的注意，那里有很多米德尔马契的人。几名围观的人，以及一些玩家，都在用动画的方式下注。利德盖特打得很好，而且很有信心。他周围的赌注都在下注，他迅速瞥见了可能的收益，这可能会使他从马身上省下来的钱翻倍，他开始赌自己的赌注，并一次又一次地获胜。班布里奇先生进来了，但利德盖特没有注意到他。他不仅对自己的比赛感到兴奋，而且还梦想着第二天就去布拉辛，那里有更大规模的赌博，在那里，只要抓住魔鬼的诱饵，他就可以赢得胜利。不劳而获，并从他的日常拉拢中收买他的救援。

He was still winning when two new visitors entered. One of them was a young Hawley, just come from his law studies in town, and the other was Fred Vincy, who had spent several evenings of late at this old haunt of his. Young Hawley, an accomplished billiard-player, brought a cool fresh hand to the cue. But Fred Vincy, startled at seeing Lydgate, and astonished to see him betting with an excited air, stood aside, and kept out of the circle round the table.
当两名新访客进来时，他仍在获胜。其中一个是年轻的霍利，刚刚从镇上学习法律，另一个是弗雷德·文西，他最近几个晚上都在他的老地方呆过。年轻的霍利是一位多才多艺的台球运动员，他为球杆带来了冷静而新鲜的手感。但弗莱德·文西看到利德盖特大吃一惊，又惊讶地发现他下注时神情激动，他站在一旁，避开了桌子周围的圈子。

Fred had been rewarding resolution by a little laxity of late. He had been working heartily for six months at all outdoor occupations under Mr. Garth, and by dint of severe practice had nearly mastered the defects of his handwriting, this practice being, perhaps, a little the less severe that it was often carried on in the evening at Mr. Garth’s under the eyes of Mary. But the last fortnight Mary had been staying at Lowick Parsonage with the ladies there, during Mr. Farebrother’s residence in Middlemarch, where he was carrying out some parochial plans; and Fred, not seeing anything more agreeable to do, had turned into the Green Dragon, partly to play at billiards, partly to taste the old flavor of discourse about horses, sport, and things in general, considered from a point of view which was not strenuously correct. He had not been out hunting once this season, had had no horse of his own to ride, and had gone from place to place chiefly with Mr. Garth in his gig, or on the sober cob which Mr. Garth could lend him. It was a little too bad, Fred began to think, that he should be kept in the traces with more severity than if he had been a clergyman. ‘I will tell you what, Mistress Mary—it will be rather harder work to learn surveying and drawing plans than it would have been to write sermons,’ he had said, wishing her to appreciate what he went through for her sake; ‘and as to Hercules and Theseus, they were nothing to me. They had sport, and never learned to write a bookkeeping hand.’ And now, Mary being out of the way for a little while, Fred, like any other strong dog who cannot slip his collar, had pulled up the staple of his chain and made a small escape, not of course meaning to go fast or far. There could be no reason why he should not play at billiards, but he was determined not to bet. As to money just now, Fred had in his mind the heroic project of saving almost all of the eighty pounds that Mr. Garth offered him, and returning it, which he could easily do by giving up all futile money-spending, since he had a superfluous stock of clothes, and no expense in his board. In that way he could, in one year, go a good way towards repaying the ninety pounds of which he had deprived Mrs. Garth, unhappily at a time when she needed that sum more than she did now. Nevertheless, it must be acknowledged that on this evening, which was the fifth of his recent visits to the billiard-room, Fred had, not in his pocket, but in his mind, the ten pounds which he meant to reserve for himself from his half-year’s salary (having before him the pleasure of carrying thirty to Mrs. Garth when Mary was likely to be come home again)— he had those ten pounds in his mind as a fund from which he might risk something, if there were a chance of a good bet. Why? Well, when sovereigns were flying about, why shouldn’t he catch a few? He would never go far along that road again; but a man likes to assure himself, and men of pleasure generally, what he could do in the way of mischief if he chose, and that if he abstains from making himself ill, or beggaring himself, or talking with the utmost looseness which the narrow limits of human capacity will allow, it is not because he is a spooney. Fred did not enter into formal reasons, which are a very artificial, inexact way of representing the tingling returns of old habit, and the caprices of young blood: but there was lurking in him a prophetic sense that evening, that when he began to play he should also begin to bet—that he should enjoy some punch-drinking, and in general prepare himself for feeling ‘rather seedy’ in the morning. It is in such indefinable movements that action often begins.
弗雷德最近表现得有点松懈，但他的决心得到了回报。他在加思先生的指导下，在所有户外职业中热心工作了六个月，凭借严格的练习，几乎已经掌握了他的笔迹缺陷，这种练习也许比在加斯先生经常进行的练习稍微不那么严格。那天晚上，在玛丽的注视下，在加斯先生家里。但最近两周，费雷布拉泽先生在米德尔马奇的住所期间，玛丽一直和那里的女士们住在洛伊克牧师公馆，他在那里执行一些教区计划；弗雷德看不出有什么更愉快的事可做，就变成了绿龙，部分是为了打台球，部分是为了尝尝关于马、运动和一般事物的旧式话语，从一种观点来考虑。不太正确。这个季节他一次也没有出去打猎，也没有自己的马可以骑，主要是和加斯先生一起骑着马车，或者骑着加斯先生借给他的清醒的玉米棒从一个地方到另一个地方。弗雷德开始想，这有点太糟糕了，他应该比他是一名牧师更严厉地被留在痕迹中。 “我告诉你吧，玛丽小姐——学习测量和绘制平面图比写布道书要困难得多，”他说，希望她能欣赏他为她所经历的一切； ‘至于赫拉克勒斯和忒修斯，他们对我来说毫无意义。他们有运动，但从来没有学会写簿记手。”现在，玛丽离开了一会儿，弗雷德，就像其他无法脱掉项圈的强壮狗一样，拉起了他链子的订书钉，进行了一次小小的逃脱，当然并不是要走得快或走得远。 他没有理由不打台球，但他坚决不打赌。至于刚才的钱，弗雷德心里有一个英雄计划，把加斯先生给他的八十英镑几乎全部存起来，然后归还，他可以很容易地做到这一点，只要放弃所有无用的金钱支出，因为他已经多余的衣服，他的膳食也没有开支。这样，他就可以在一年之内，很好地偿还他剥夺了加斯夫人的九十英镑，不幸的是，当时她比现在更需要这笔钱。然而，必须承认的是，今天晚上，这是他最近第五次来到台球室，弗雷德并没有在口袋里，而是在他的脑海里，他打算从他的口袋里为自己保留十英镑。半年的工资（当玛丽可能再次回家时，他很乐意带三十英镑给加斯太太）——他把这十英镑当作一笔基金，如果有的话，他可以用它冒险。一个好的赌注的机会。为什么？好吧，既然金币飞来飞去，他为什么不抓一些呢？他再也不会沿着那条路走得太远了；但是，一个人和一般的享乐者一样，喜欢向自己保证，如果他选择的话，他可以以恶作剧的方式做些什么，并且如果他不让自己生病，或者乞讨自己，或者以狭隘的人所要求的最宽松的态度​​说话，那么他可以做些什么。人类能力的极限会允许，这并不是因为他是个痴迷者。 弗雷德没有进入正式的原因，这是一种非常人为的、不准确的方式，代表了旧习惯的刺痛回归和年轻血液的反复无常：但那天晚上他内心潜藏着一种预言感，当他开始演奏时他还应该开始打赌——他应该喝点潘趣酒，并为早上感觉“相当邋遢”做好准备。正是在这种难以定义的运动中，行动常常开始。

But the last thing likely to have entered Fred’s expectation was that he should see his brother-in-law Lydgate—of whom he had never quite dropped the old opinion that he was a prig, and tremendously conscious of his superiority—looking excited and betting, just as he himself might have done. Fred felt a shock greater than he could quite account for by the vague knowledge that Lydgate was in debt, and that his father had refused to help him; and his own inclination to enter into the play was suddenly checked. It was a strange reversal of attitudes: Fred’s blond face and blue eyes, usually bright and careless, ready to give attention to anything that held out a promise of amusement, looking involuntarily grave and almost embarrassed as if by the sight of something unfitting; while Lydgate, who had habitually an air of self-possessed strength, and a certain meditativeness that seemed to lie behind his most observant attention, was acting, watching, speaking with that excited narrow consciousness which reminds one of an animal with fierce eyes and retractile claws.
但弗雷德最不可能想到的事情是，他会看到他的姐夫利德盖特——他从未完全放弃他的旧观念，认为他是一个一本正经的人，并且非常意识到自己的优越性——看起来很兴奋，并且打赌，就像他自己可能做的那样。当弗雷德模糊地知道利德盖特负债累累，而且他的父亲拒绝帮助他时，他感到震惊得难以解释。他自己的入戏意愿突然受到抑制。这是一种奇怪的态度逆转：弗雷德的金发碧眼，通常明亮而粗心，随时准备关注任何有望带来娱乐的东西，看起来不由自主地严肃，几乎尴尬，好像看到了一些不合适的东西；而利德盖特则习惯性地表现出一种泰然自若的力量，并且在他最敏锐的注意力背后似乎隐藏着某种冥想，他在行动、观察、说话，带着一种兴奋的狭隘意识，这让人想起一种目光凶猛、缩回的动物。爪子。

Lydgate, by betting on his own strokes, had won sixteen pounds; but young Hawley’s arrival had changed the poise of things. He made first-rate strokes himself, and began to bet against Lydgate’s strokes, the strain of whose nerves was thus changed from simple confidence in his own movements to defying another person’s doubt in them. The defiance was more exciting than the confidence, but it was less sure. He continued to bet on his own play, but began often to fail. Still he went on, for his mind was as utterly narrowed into that precipitous crevice of play as if he had been the most ignorant lounger there. Fred observed that Lydgate was losing fast, and found himself in the new situation of puzzling his brains to think of some device by which, without being offensive, he could withdraw Lydgate’s attention, and perhaps suggest to him a reason for quitting the room. He saw that others were observing Lydgate’s strange unlikeness to himself, and it occurred to him that merely to touch his elbow and call him aside for a moment might rouse him from his absorption. He could think of nothing cleverer than the daring improbability of saying that he wanted to see Rosy, and wished to know if she were at home this evening; and he was going desperately to carry out this weak device, when a waiter came up to him with a message, saying that Mr. Farebrother was below, and begged to speak with him.
利德盖特赌自己的击球，赢得了十六英镑。但年轻的霍利的到来改变了一切。他自己打出了一流的击球，并开始与利德盖特的击球打赌，利德盖特的神经紧张因此从对自己动作的简单自信转变为无视别人对自己动作的怀疑。反抗比自信更令人兴奋，但不太确定。他继续对自己的玩法下注，但开始经常失败。他仍然继续说下去，因为他的思维完全被狭窄的游戏缝隙所束缚，就好像他是那里最无知的闲逛者一样。弗雷德观察到利德盖特正在快速失败，他发现自己陷入了新的境地，他的大脑困惑不已，他想出一些方法，通过这种方法，他可以在不冒犯他人的情况下转移利德盖特的注意力，也许还可以向他提出退出房间的理由。他看到其他人都在观察利德盖特与自己的奇怪的不同之处，他突然想到，只要碰一下他的肘部，把他叫到一边，就可能让他从专注中醒来。他想不出比大胆地说他想见罗西，并想知道她今晚是否在家更聪明的事了。他正拼命地去执行这个微弱的装置，这时一个侍者向他走来，告诉他费雷布拉泽先生在下面，并请求与他交谈。

Fred was surprised, not quite comfortably, but sending word that he would be down immediately, he went with a new impulse up to Lydgate, said, ‘Can I speak to you a moment?’ and drew him aside.
弗雷德很惊讶，不太舒服，但他传达了他将立即下来的消息，他带着一种新的冲动走向利德盖特，说：“我可以和你谈谈吗？”然后把他拉到一边。

‘Farebrother has just sent up a message to say that he wants to speak to me. He is below. I thought you might like to know he was there, if you had anything to say to him.’
‘费布雷兄弟刚刚发了一条消息说他想和我说话。他在下面。我想你可能想知道他在那儿，如果你有什么话要对他说的话。

Fred had simply snatched up this pretext for speaking, because he could not say, ‘You are losing confoundedly, and are making everybody stare at you; you had better come away.’ But inspiration could hardly have served him better. Lydgate had not before seen that Fred was present, and his sudden appearance with an announcement of Mr. Farebrother had the effect of a sharp concussion.
弗雷德只是抓住了这个借口说话，因为他不能说，‘你输得很惨，让所有人都盯着你看；’你最好走开。”但是灵感对他来说再好不过了。利德盖特之前并没有看到弗雷德在场，他突然出现并宣布费雷布拉泽先生的消息造成了剧烈的脑震荡。

‘No, no,’ said Lydgate; ‘I have nothing particular to say to him. But—the game is up—I must be going—I came in just to see Bambridge.’
“不，不，”利德盖特说。 “我没有什么特别要对他说的。但是——比赛结束了——我必须走了——我进来只是为了看看班布里奇。”

‘Bambridge is over there, but he is making a row—I don’t think he’s ready for business. Come down with me to Farebrother. I expect he is going to blow me up, and you will shield me,’ said Fred, with some adroitness.
“班布里奇在那边，但他正在大吵大闹——我认为他还没有准备好做生意。跟我一起去费雷兄弟吧。我预计他会炸死我，而你会保护我。”弗雷德熟练地说道。

Lydgate felt shame, but could not bear to act as if he felt it, by refusing to see Mr. Farebrother; and he went down. They merely shook hands, however, and spoke of the frost; and when all three had turned into the street, the Vicar seemed quite willing to say good-by to Lydgate. His present purpose was clearly to talk with Fred alone, and he said, kindly, ‘I disturbed you, young gentleman, because I have some pressing business with you. Walk with me to St. Botolph’s, will you?’
利德盖特感到羞耻，但又不忍心假装感觉到羞耻，拒绝见费勒布拉泽先生。他就倒下了。然而，他们只是握了握手，并谈到了霜冻。当三个人都转向街道时，牧师似乎很愿意向利德盖特告别。他现在的目的显然是要单独和弗雷德谈谈，他和蔼地说：“我打扰你了，年轻的先生，因为我有一些紧急的事情要找你。”跟我一起去圣博托夫教堂吧，好吗？

It was a fine night, the sky thick with stars, and Mr. Farebrother proposed that they should make a circuit to the old church by the London road. The next thing he said was—
那是一个晴朗的夜晚，天空繁星密布，费勒布拉泽先生提议他们应该沿着伦敦路绕一圈去老教堂。他接下来说的是——

‘I thought Lydgate never went to the Green Dragon?’
“我以为利德盖特从来没有去过绿龙号？”

‘So did I,’ said Fred. ‘But he said that he went to see Bambridge.’
“我也是，”弗雷德说。 “但他说他去看了班布里奇。”

‘He was not playing, then?’
“那么他没有在比赛吗？”

Fred had not meant to tell this, but he was obliged now to say, ‘Yes, he was. But I suppose it was an accidental thing. I have never seen him there before.’
弗雷德本来不想告诉这些，但他现在不得不说：“是的，他是。”但我想这是一件偶然的事情。我以前从未在那里见过他。

‘You have been going often yourself, then, lately?’
“那么，最近你自己经常去吗？”

‘Oh, about five or six times.’
“哦，大约五六次。”

‘I think you had some good reason for giving up the habit of going there?’
“我想你有充分的理由放弃去那里的习惯吗？”

‘Yes. You know all about it,’ said Fred, not liking to be catechised in this way. ‘I made a clean breast to you.’
'是的。你都知道了。”弗雷德说道，他不喜欢以这种方式接受教义问答。 “我向你坦白了。”

‘I suppose that gives me a warrant to speak about the matter now. It is understood between us, is it not?—that we are on a footing of open friendship: I have listened to you, and you will be willing to listen to me. I may take my turn in talking a little about myself?’
“我想这给了我现在谈论此事的理由。我们之间有一个共识，不是吗？——我们建立在开放的友谊基础上：我听了你的话，你也会愿意听我的。我可以轮流谈谈我自己吗？

‘I am under the deepest obligation to you, Mr. Farebrother,’ said Fred, in a state of uncomfortable surmise.
“费雷布拉泽先生，我对您负有最深的责任。”弗雷德带着一种不安的猜测说道。

‘I will not affect to deny that you are under some obligation to me. But I am going to confess to you, Fred, that I have been tempted to reverse all that by keeping silence with you just now. When somebody said to me, ‘Young Vincy has taken to being at the billiard-table every night again—he won’t bear the curb long;’ I was tempted to do the opposite of what I am doing—to hold my tongue and wait while you went down the ladder again, betting first and then—‘
“我不会否认你对我负有某种义务。但我要向你承认，弗雷德，我刚才很想通过对你保持沉默来扭转这一切。当有人对我说：“年轻的文西又开始每天晚上都坐在台球桌旁了——他受不了太久的限制了；”我很想做与我正在做的事情相反的事——闭嘴，不说话。等你再走下梯子，先下注，然后——”

‘I have not made any bets,’ said Fred, hastily.
“我没有打赌，”弗雷德急忙说道。

‘Glad to hear it. But I say, my prompting was to look on and see you take the wrong turning, wear out Garth’s patience, and lose the best opportunity of your life—the opportunity which you made some rather difficult effort to secure. You can guess the feeling which raised that temptation in me—I am sure you know it. I am sure you know that the satisfaction of your affections stands in the way of mine.’
'听到那个消息很开心。但我要说的是，我的动机是看着你走错了方向，耗尽了加思的耐心，失去了你一生中最好的机会——这个机会是你付出了相当大的努力才获得的。你可以猜到我内心产生这种诱惑的感觉——我相信你知道这一点。我相信你知道你的感情的满足会阻碍我的感情。

There was a pause. Mr. Farebrother seemed to wait for a recognition of the fact; and the emotion perceptible in the tones of his fine voice gave solemnity to his words. But no feeling could quell Fred’s alarm.
一阵停顿。费勒布拉泽先生似乎在等待人们承认这一事实。从他优美的声音中可以感觉到的情感使他的话语显得庄严。但没有任何感觉可以平息弗雷德的警报。

‘I could not be expected to give her up,’ he said, after a moment’s hesitation: it was not a case for any pretence of generosity.
“我不能指望放弃她，”他犹豫片刻后说道：这不是假装慷慨的理由。

‘Clearly not, when her affection met yours. But relations of this sort, even when they are of long standing, are always liable to change. I can easily conceive that you might act in a way to loosen the tie she feels towards you—it must be remembered that she is only conditionally bound to you—and that in that ease, another man, who may flatter himself that he has a hold on her regard, might succeed in winning that firm place in her love as well as respect which you had let slip. I can easily conceive such a result,’ repeated Mr. Farebrother, emphatically. ‘There is a companionship of ready sympathy, which might get the advantage even over the longest associations.’ It seemed to Fred that if Mr. Farebrother had had a beak and talons instead of his very capable tongue, his mode of attack could hardly be more cruel. He had a horrible conviction that behind all this hypothetic statement there was a knowledge of some actual change in Mary’s feeling.
“显然不是，当她的感情遇到你的时候。但这种关系，即使是长期存在的，也总是容易发生变化。我很容易想象，你可能会采取某种方式来放松她对你的感觉——必须记住，她对你的束缚只是有条件的——而在这种轻松的情况下，另一个男人可能会自以为他有一个保持她的尊重，可能会成功地在她的爱和尊重中赢得你所失去的牢固地位。我很容易想到这样的结果。”费雷布拉泽先生强调道。 “有一种随时准备好的同情心的陪伴，这甚至可能比最长的交往更有优势。”在弗雷德看来，如果法尔布拉泽先生有喙和爪子，而不是他非常能干的舌头，他的攻击方式就很难是更残酷。他有一种可怕的信念，在所有这些假设性陈述的背后，他知道玛丽的感情确实发生了一些变化。

‘Of course I know it might easily be all up with me,’ he said, in a troubled voice. ‘If she is beginning to compare—‘ He broke off, not liking to betray all he felt, and then said, by the help of a little bitterness, ‘But I thought you were friendly to me.’
“我当然知道这很容易就完蛋了，”他声音不安地说。 “如果她开始比较——”他停了下来，不想泄露自己的全部感受，然后带着一点苦涩说道，“但我以为你对我很友好。”

‘So I am; that is why we are here. But I have had a strong disposition to be otherwise. I have said to myself, ‘If there is a likelihood of that youngster doing himself harm, why should you interfere? Aren’t you worth as much as he is, and don’t your sixteen years over and above his, in which you have gone rather hungry, give you more right to satisfaction than he has? If there’s a chance of his going to the dogs, let him—perhaps you could nohow hinder it— and do you take the benefit.’’
'我也是;这就是我们在这里的原因。但我有一种强烈的倾向，不这样做。我对自己说，‘如果那个年轻人有可能伤害自己，你为什么要干涉呢？你难道不和他一样有价值吗？你比他多了十六年，你已经挨饿了，难道你不比他更有权利获得满足吗？如果他有机会发疯，那就让他去吧——也许你无论如何也阻止不了——然后你就从中受益。”

There was a pause, in which Fred was seized by a most uncomfortable chill. What was coming next? He dreaded to hear that something had been said to Mary—he felt as if he were listening to a threat rather than a warning. When the Vicar began again there was a change in his tone like the encouraging transition to a major key.
停顿了一下，弗雷德感到一阵极其不舒服的寒意。接下来会发生什么？他害怕听到别人对玛丽说了些什么——他觉得自己听到的是威胁而不是警告。当牧师再次开始时，他的语气发生了变化，就像鼓励性地转向大调一样。

‘But I had once meant better than that, and I am come back to my old intention. I thought that I could hardly SECURE MYSELF in it better, Fred, than by telling you just what had gone on in me. And now, do you understand me? want you to make the happiness of her life and your own, and if there is any chance that a word of warning from me may turn aside any risk to the contrary—well, I have uttered it.’
“但我的本意曾经比这更好，现在我又回到了原来的意图。弗雷德，我想，除了告诉你我内心发生的事情之外，我没有什么比这更能让我安全的了。现在，你明白我的意思了吗？想让你为她和你自己创造幸福的生活，如果我的一句警告可能会化解任何相反的风险——好吧，我已经说了。

There was a drop in the Vicar’s voice when he spoke the last words He paused—they were standing on a patch of green where the road diverged towards St. Botolph’s, and he put out his hand, as if to imply that the conversation was closed. Fred was moved quite newly. Some one highly susceptible to the contemplation of a fine act has said, that it produces a sort of regenerating shudder through the frame, and makes one feel ready to begin a new life. A good degree of that effect was just then present in Fred Vincy.
牧师说最后一句话时，声音低沉了。他停了下来——他们站在通往圣博托夫教堂的道路分叉处的一片绿地上，他伸出手，仿佛暗示谈话结束了。 。弗雷德是新搬家的。一些对美好行为的沉思非常敏感的人说，它会在整个框架中产生一种再生的颤抖，并使人感到准备好开始新的生活。弗雷德·文西当时就充分体现了这种效果。

‘I will try to be worthy,’ he said, breaking off before he could say ‘of you as well as of her.’ And meanwhile Mr. Farebrother had gathered the impulse to say something more.
“我会努力做到配得上，”他说，还没来得及说“你和她。”与此同时，费尔布拉泽先生又想再说点什么。

‘You must not imagine that I believe there is at present any decline in her preference of you, Fred. Set your heart at rest, that if you keep right, other things will keep right.’
“你千万别以为我相信目前她对你的好感度有任何下降，弗雷德。让你的心平静下来，如果你保持正确，其他事情就会保持正确。

‘I shall never forget what you have done,’ Fred answered. ‘I can’t say anything that seems worth saying—only I will try that your goodness shall not be thrown away.’
“我永远不会忘记你所做的一切，”弗雷德回答道。 “我不能说任何值得说的话——只是我会尽力不让你的善良被抛弃。”

‘That’s enough. Good-by, and God bless you.’
‘够了。再见，愿上帝保佑你。

In that way they parted. But both of them walked about a long while before they went out of the starlight. Much of Fred’s rumination might be summed up in the words, ‘It certainly would have been a fine thing for her to marry Farebrother—but if she loves me best and I am a good husband?’
就这样他们分手了。但两人又走了好一会儿，才走出了星光。弗雷德的大部分沉思可以用这句话来概括：“对她来说，嫁给费雷布拉泽当然是一件好事——但如果她最爱我并且我是一个好丈夫呢？”

Perhaps Mr. Farebrother’s might be concentrated into a single shrug and one little speech. ‘To think of the part one little woman can play in the life of a man, so that to renounce her may be a very good imitation of heroism, and to win her may be a discipline!’
也许费雷布拉泽先生的讲话会集中在一次耸肩和一次简短的讲话中。 “想想一个小女人在男人的生活中可以扮演的角色，因此放弃她可能是对英雄主义的很好模仿，而赢得她可能是一种纪律！”

CHAPTER LXVII
第十六章

Now is there civil war within the soul:
现在灵魂中有内战：

Resolve is thrust from off the sacred throne
决心被推离神圣宝座

By clamorous Needs, and Pride the grand-vizier
出于喧闹的需要，以及大维齐尔的骄傲

Makes humble compact, plays the supple part
打造简洁紧凑，发挥柔软作用

Of envoy and deft-tongued apologist
特使和巧舌如簧的辩护者

For hungry rebels.
对于饥饿的叛乱分子来说。

Happily Lydgate had ended by losing in the billiard-room, and brought away no encouragement to make a raid on luck. On the contrary, he felt unmixed disgust with himself the next day when he had to pay four or five pounds over and above his gains, and he carried about with him a most unpleasant vision of the figure he had made, not only rubbing elbows with the men at the Green Dragon but behaving just as they did. A philosopher fallen to betting is hardly distinguishable from a Philistine under the same circumstances: the difference will chiefly be found in his subsequent reflections, and Lydgate chewed a very disagreeable cud in that way. His reason told him how the affair might have been magnified into ruin by a slight change of scenery—if it had been a gambling-house that he had turned into, where chance could be clutched with both hands instead of being picked up with thumb and fore-finger. Nevertheless, though reason strangled the desire to gamble, there remained the feeling that, with an assurance of luck to the needful amount, he would have liked to gamble, rather than take the alternative which was beginning to urge itself as inevitable.
令人高兴的是，利德盖特最终在台球室输了，并没有给他带来任何去碰运气的鼓励。相反，第二天，当他不得不支付比他的收入多出四五英镑的钱时，他对自己感到无比的厌恶，他对自己所创造的形象抱有一种最不愉快的愿景，不仅与他人擦肩而过。绿龙酒店的人，但他们的行为却和他们一样。在同样的情况下，一个沉迷于赌博的哲学家与一个庸人几乎没有区别：区别主要在于他随后的反思，利德盖特以这种方式反刍了非常令人不快的反刍。他的理智告诉他，这件事可能会因为风景的轻微变化而被放大到毁灭——如果他把它变成了一个赌场，在那里机会可以用双手抓住，而不是用拇指和拇指捡起来。食指。然而，尽管理性扼杀了赌博的欲望，但仍然有一种感觉，即如果有必要的运气保证，他宁愿赌博，而不是采取开始敦促自己不可避免的替代方案。

That alternative was to apply to Mr. Bulstrode. Lydgate had so many times boasted both to himself and others that he was totally independent of Bulstrode, to whose plans he had lent himself solely because they enabled him to carry out his own ideas of professional work and public benefit—he had so constantly in their personal intercourse had his pride sustained by the sense that he was making a good social use of this predominating banker, whose opinions he thought contemptible and whose motives often seemed to him an absurd mixture of contradictory impressions— that he had been creating for himself strong ideal obstacles to the proffering of any considerable request to him on his own account.
另一种选择是向布尔斯特罗德先生提出申请。利德盖特多次向自己和他人吹嘘说，他完全独立于布尔斯特罗德，他之所以将自己借给布尔斯特罗德的计划，只是因为这些计划使他能够执行自己的专业工作和公共利益想法——他总是在他们的计划中工作。在个人交往中，他感到自己正在很好地利用这位占主导地位的银行家，他的自豪感得以维持，他认为银行家的观点是可鄙的，而他的动机在他看来往往是矛盾印象的荒谬混合体——他一直在为自己创造强烈的理想。为他自己的利益而向他提出任何重大要求的障碍。

Still, early in March his affairs were at that pass in which men begin to say that their oaths were delivered in ignorance, and to perceive that the act which they had called impossible to them is becoming manifestly possible. With Dover’s ugly security soon to be put in force, with the proceeds of his practice immediately absorbed in paying back debts, and with the chance, if the worst were known, of daily supplies being refused on credit, above all with the vision of Rosamond’s hopeless discontent continually haunting him, Lydgate had begun to see that he should inevitably bend himself to ask help from somebody or other. At first he had considered whether he should write to Mr. Vincy; but on questioning Rosamond he found that, as he had suspected, she had already applied twice to her father, the last time being since the disappointment from Sir Godwin; and papa had said that Lydgate must look out for himself. ‘Papa said he had come, with one bad year after another, to trade more and more on borrowed capital, and had had to give up many indulgences; he could not spare a single hundred from the charges of his family. He said, let Lydgate ask Bulstrode: they have always been hand and glove.’
尽管如此，三月初，他的事情已经到了这样的阶段，人们开始说他们的誓言是在无知的情况下做出的，并意识到他们认为不可能的行动显然变得可能了。多佛丑陋的担保很快就会生效，他的做法收益立即被用来偿还债务，而且，如果最坏的情况发生的话，日常供应有可能被拒绝赊购，尤其是罗莎蒙德的愿景绝望的不满不断地困扰着他，利德盖特开始意识到他应该不可避免地向某人或其他人寻求帮助。起初他考虑过是否应该给文西先生写信；但他没有考虑过。但在询问罗莎蒙德时，他发现，正如他所怀疑的那样，她已经向她父亲提出了两次申请，最后一次是在戈德温爵士失望之后。爸爸说过利德盖特必须照顾好自己。 “爸爸说，他来了，年复一年地不好，用借来的资本进行越来越多的交易，不得不放弃许多放纵；他不能免除他家人的一百块罪名。他说，让利德盖特问布尔斯特罗德：他们一直都是手和手套。

Indeed, Lydgate himself had come to the conclusion that if he must end by asking for a free loan, his relations with Bulstrode, more at least than with any other man, might take the shape of a claim which was not purely personal. Bulstrode had indirectly helped to cause the failure of his practice, and had also been highly gratified by getting a medical partner in his plans:— but who among us ever reduced himself to the sort of dependence in which Lydgate now stood, without trying to believe that he had claims which diminished the humiliation of asking? It was true that of late there had seemed to be a new languor of interest in Bulstrode about the Hospital; but his health had got worse, and showed signs of a deep-seated nervous affection. In other respects he did not appear to be changed: he had always been highly polite, but Lydgate had observed in him from the first a marked coldness about his marriage and other private circumstances, a coldness which he had hitherto preferred to any warmth of familiarity between them. He deferred the intention from day to day, his habit of acting on his conclusions being made infirm by his repugnance to every possible conclusion and its consequent act. He saw Mr. Bulstrode often, but he did not try to use any occasion for his private purpose. At one moment he thought, ‘I will write a letter: I prefer that to any circuitous talk;’ at another he thought, ‘No; if I were talking to him, I could make a retreat before any signs of disinclination.’
事实上，利德盖特本人已经得出这样的结论：如果他必须以要求无偿贷款作为结束，那么他与布尔斯特罗德的关系，至少比与任何其他人的关系，可能会采取一种不纯粹是个人的主张的形式。布尔斯特罗德间接地导致了他的实践失败，并且还因为在他的计划中找到了一个医疗合作伙伴而感到非常高兴：——但是我们当中谁曾将自己降低到利德盖特现在所面临的那种依赖，而不试图相信他的主张可以减轻询问的羞辱吗？确实，最近布尔斯特罗德似乎对医院产生了新的兴趣。但他的健康状况每况愈下，并表现出根深蒂固的紧张情绪。在其他方面，他似乎没有改变：他一直非常有礼貌，但利德盖特从一开始就在他身上观察到对他的婚姻和其他私人情况的明显冷漠，迄今为止他更喜欢这种冷漠，而不是任何熟悉的温暖它们之间。他日复一日地推迟着这个意图，他对每一个可能的结论及其随之而来的行动的反感使得他根据结论采取行动的习惯变得脆弱。他经常见到布尔斯特罗德先生，但他并没有试图利用任何场合来达到他的私人目的。一会儿他想，“我要写一封信：我更喜欢写一封信，而不是任何迂回的谈话；”一会儿他又想，“不；”如果我和他说话，我可以在出现任何不愿意的迹象之前撤退。

Still the days passed and no letter was written, no special interview sought. In his shrinking from the humiliation of a dependent attitude towards Bulstrode, he began to familiarize his imagination with another step even more unlike his remembered self. He began spontaneously to consider whether it would be possible to carry out that puerile notion of Rosamond’s which had often made him angry, namely, that they should quit Middlemarch without seeing anything beyond that preface. The question came—‘Would any man buy the practice of me even now, for as little as it is worth? Then the sale might happen as a necessary preparation for going away.’
然而日子一天天过去，我们仍然没有写信，也没有寻求特别采访。当他因对布尔斯特罗德的依赖态度而感到羞耻时，他开始熟悉自己的想象，迈出与记忆中的自己更加不同的一步。他开始自发地考虑是否有可能实现罗莎蒙德的那个经常让他生气的幼稚想法，即他们应该在没有看到序言之外的任何内容的情况下离开米德尔马契。问题来了——“即使是现在，还有人愿意花很少的钱购买我的实践吗？”那么出售可能会发生，作为离开的必要准备。

But against his taking this step, which he still felt to be a contemptible relinquishment of present work, a guilty turning aside from what was a real and might be a widening channel for worthy activity, to start again without any justified destination, there was this obstacle, that the purchaser, if procurable at all, might not be quickly forthcoming. And afterwards? Rosamond in a poor lodging, though in the largest city or most distant town, would not find the life that could save her from gloom, and save him from the reproach of having plunged her into it. For when a man is at the foot of the hill in his fortunes, he may stay a long while there in spite of professional accomplishment. In the British climate there is no incompatibility between scientific insight and furnished lodgings: the incompatibility is chiefly between scientific ambition and a wife who objects to that kind of residence.
但反对他迈出这一步，他仍然觉得这是对当前工作的可鄙的放弃，是对真正的、可能是有价值活动的拓宽渠道的内疚转向，在没有任何正当目的地的情况下重新开始，有这样的情况：障碍，即购买者即使可以采购，也可能不会很快出现。然后呢？罗莎蒙德住在一间简陋的住所里，尽管是在最大的城市或最遥远的城镇，但她找不到一种生活可以使她摆脱忧郁，也无法使他免受让她陷入困境的责备。因为当一个人的命运处于山脚下时，尽管他在职业上取得了成就，但他可能会在那里停留很长时间。在英国的气候下，科学洞察力和配备齐全的住宿之间并不存在不相容性：不相容的主要是科学抱负和反对这种住宿的妻子之间。

But in the midst of his hesitation, opportunity came to decide him. A note from Mr. Bulstrode requested Lydgate to call on him at the Bank. A hypochondriacal tendency had shown itself in the banker’s constitution of late; and a lack of sleep, which was really only a slight exaggeration of an habitual dyspeptic symptom, had been dwelt on by him as a sign of threatening insanity. He wanted to consult Lydgate without delay on that particular morning, although he had nothing to tell beyond what he had told before. He listened eagerly to what Lydgate had to say in dissipation of his fears, though this too was only repetition; and this moment in which Bulstrode was receiving a medical opinion with a sense of comfort, seemed to make the communication of a personal need to him easier than it had been in Lydgate’s contemplation beforehand. He had been insisting that it would be well for Mr. Bulstrode to relax his attention to business.
但就在他犹豫不决的时候，机会来了，决定了他。布尔斯特罗德先生写来一张便条，要求利德盖特去银行拜访他。最近，这位银行家的体质中出现了疑病症的倾向。睡眠不足实际上只是习惯性消化不良症状的轻微夸大，他一直认为这是精神错乱的一个迹象。他想在那个早晨立即咨询利德盖特，尽管除了之前所说的之外，他没有什么可说的。他热切地听着利德盖特为了驱散他的恐惧而说的话，尽管这也只是重复。布尔斯特罗德带着安慰的心情接受医疗意见的这一刻，似乎比利德盖特之前考虑的更容易向他传达个人需求。他一直坚持认为布尔斯特罗德先生最好放松对生意的关注。

‘One sees how any mental strain, however slight, may affect a delicate frame,’ said Lydgate at that stage of the consultation when the remarks tend to pass from the personal to the general, ‘by the deep stamp which anxiety will make for a time even on the young and vigorous. I am naturally very strong; yet I have been thoroughly shaken lately by an accumulation of trouble.’
“人们看到任何精神紧张，无论多么轻微，都可能影响脆弱的身体，”利德盖特在咨询的那个阶段说道，当时言论往往从个人转移到一般情况，“焦虑会给人留下深刻的印记。”时光更就年轻气盛。我天生就很坚强；但近来我却被不断积累的麻烦彻底动摇了。

‘I presume that a constitution in the susceptible state in which mine at present is, would be especially liable to fall a victim to cholera, if it visited our district. And since its appearance near London, we may well besiege the Mercy-seat for our protection,’ said Mr. Bulstrode, not intending to evade Lydgate’s allusion, but really preoccupied with alarms about himself.
“我认为，如果霍乱来到我们地区，我目前所在的易感国家的宪法将特别容易成为霍乱的受害者。布尔斯特罗德先生说，自从它出现在伦敦附近以来，我们很可能会围攻仁慈座以求保护。

‘You have at all events taken your share in using good practical precautions for the town, and that is the best mode of asking for protection,’ said Lydgate, with a strong distaste for the broken metaphor and bad logic of the banker’s religion, somewhat increased by the apparent deafness of his sympathy. But his mind had taken up its long-prepared movement towards getting help, and was not yet arrested. He added, ‘The town has done well in the way of cleansing, and finding appliances; and I think that if the cholera should come, even our enemies will admit that the arrangements in the Hospital are a public good.’
利德盖特说：“无论如何，你已经为这座城镇采取了良好的实际预防措施，这是寻求保护的最佳方式。”他的同情心明显充耳不闻，这让他的同情心更加强烈。但他的思绪已经开始了准备已久的寻求帮助的运动，并且还没有被逮捕。他补充说，“该镇在清洁和寻找器具方面做得很好；我认为，如果霍乱来了，即使是我们的敌人也会承认医院的安排是公共利益。

‘Truly,’ said Mr. Bulstrode, with some coldness. ‘With regard to what you say, Mr. Lydgate, about the relaxation of my mental labor, I have for some time been entertaining a purpose to that effect— a purpose of a very decided character. I contemplate at least a temporary withdrawal from the management of much business, whether benevolent or commercial. Also I think of changing my residence for a time: probably I shall close or let ‘The Shrubs,’ and take some place near the coast—under advice of course as to salubrity. That would be a measure which you would recommend?’
“确实如此，”布尔斯特罗德先生说道，语气有些冷淡。 “关于你所说的，利德盖特先生，关于放松我的脑力劳动，我有一段时间一直在考虑这样的目的——一个非常坚定的性格的目的。我考虑至少暂时退出许多企业的管理，无论是慈善的还是商业的。我还考虑暂时改变我的住所：也许我会关闭或出租“灌木丛”，并在靠近海岸的地方找个地方——当然要考虑到健康。这是您会推荐的措施吗？

‘Oh yes,’ said Lydgate, falling backward in his chair, with ill-repressed impatience under the banker’s pale earnest eyes and intense preoccupation with himself.
“哦，是的，”利德盖特说着，向后倒在椅子上，在银行家苍白而认真的眼神和对自己的全神贯注之下，他压抑着不耐烦。

‘I have for some time felt that I should open this subject with you in relation to our Hospital,’ continued Bulstrode. ‘Under the circumstances I have indicated, of course I must cease to have any personal share in the management, and it is contrary to my views of responsibility to continue a large application of means to an institution which I cannot watch over and to some extent regulate. I shall therefore, in case of my ultimate decision to leave Middlemarch, consider that I withdraw other support to the New Hospital than that which will subsist in the fact that I chiefly supplied the expenses of building it, and have contributed further large sums to its successful working.’
“一段时间以来，我一直觉得我应该向您提出这个与我们医院有关的话题，”布尔斯特罗德继续说道。 “在我所指出的情况下，我当然必须停止以个人身份参与管理，继续对一个我无法监督且在某种程度上无法监督的机构使用大量手段，这与我的责任观相悖”调节。因此，如果我最终决定离开米德尔马契，我将考虑撤回对新医院的其他支持，而不仅仅是我主要提供建设它的费用，并为其提供了更多的大笔资金。工作成功。”

Lydgate’s thought, when Bulstrode paused according to his wont, was, ‘He has perhaps been losing a good deal of money.’ This was the most plausible explanation of a speech which had caused rather a startling change in his expectations. He said in reply—
当布尔斯特罗德按照他的习惯停下来时，利德盖特的想法是，“他可能损失了很多钱。”这是对这场演讲最合理的解释，这场演讲使他的期望发生了惊人的变化。他回复说——

‘The loss to the Hospital can hardly be made up, I fear.’
“我担心医院的损失很难弥补。”

‘Hardly,’ returned Bulstrode, in the same deliberate, silvery tone; ‘except by some changes of plan. The only person who may be certainly counted on as willing to increase her contributions is Mrs. Casaubon. I have had an interview with her on the subject, and I have pointed out to her, as I am about to do to you, that it will be desirable to win a more general support to the New Hospital by a change of system.’ Another pause, but Lydgate did not speak.
“几乎没有，”布尔斯特罗德用同样从容的、银白色的语气回答道。 “除了计划的一些改变。唯一可以肯定愿意增加捐款的人是卡苏邦夫人。我就这个问题与她进行了采访，我已经向她指出，就像我即将对你做的那样，通过改变系统来为新医院赢得更广泛的支持是可取的。又停顿了一下，但利德盖特没有说话。

‘The change I mean is an amalgamation with the Infirmary, so that the New Hospital shall be regarded as a special addition to the elder institution, having the same directing board. It will be necessary, also, that the medical management of the two shall be combined. In this way any difficulty as to the adequate maintenance of our new establishment will be removed; the benevolent interests of the town will cease to be divided.’
“我指的改变是与医务室合并，这样新医院将被视为对老机构的特殊补充，拥有相同的董事会。两者的医疗管理也有必要结合起来。这样，我们新机构的充分维护方面的任何困难都将被消除；该镇的慈善利益将不再分裂。

Mr. Bulstrode had lowered his eyes from Lydgate’s face to the buttons of his coat as he again paused.
布尔斯特罗德先生再次停了下来，目光从利德盖特的脸上移到了他外套的纽扣上。

‘No doubt that is a good device as to ways and means,’ said Lydgate, with an edge of irony in his tone. ‘But I can’t be expected to rejoice in it at once, since one of the first results will be that the other medical men will upset or interrupt my methods, if it were only because they are mine.’
“毫无疑问，就方式和手段而言，这是一个很好的策略，”利德盖特说道，语气中带着一丝讽刺。 “但我不能指望立即为此感到高兴，因为第一个结果将是其他医务人员会扰乱或打断我的方法，如果这只是因为他们是我的。”

‘I myself, as you know, Mr. Lydgate, highly valued the opportunity of new and independent procedure which you have diligently employed: the original plan, I confess, was one which I had much at heart, under submission to the Divine Will. But since providential indications demand a renunciation from me, I renounce.’
“正如您所知，利德盖特先生，我本人高度重视您辛勤采用的新的独立程序的机会：我承认，最初的计划是我内心深处的计划，服从神圣意志。但既然天意要求我放弃，我就放弃。”

Bulstrode showed a rather exasperating ability in this conversation. The broken metaphor and bad logic of motive which had stirred his hearer’s contempt were quite consistent with a mode of putting the facts which made it difficult for Lydgate to vent his own indignation and disappointment. After some rapid reflection, he only asked—
布尔斯特罗德在这次谈话中表现出了相当令人恼火的能力。那些引起听者蔑视的不完整的隐喻和糟糕的动机逻辑，与使利德盖特难以发泄自己的愤慨和失望的事实陈述方式非常一致。快速思考后，他只是问道——

‘What did Mrs. Casaubon say?’
“卡苏朋夫人说什么？”

‘That was the further statement which I wished to make to you,’ said Bulstrode, who had thoroughly prepared his ministerial explanation. ‘She is, you are aware, a woman of most munificent disposition, and happily in possession—not I presume of great wealth, but of funds which she can well spare. She has informed me that though she has destined the chief part of those funds to another purpose, she is willing to consider whether she cannot fully take my place in relation to the Hospital. But she wishes for ample time to mature her thoughts on the subject, and I have told her that there is no need for haste—that, in fact, my own plans are not yet absolute.’
“这就是我想向你做的进一步声明，”布尔斯特罗德说，他已经充分准备了他的部长解释。 “你知道，她是一个性情最慷慨的女人，并且幸福地拥有——我认为不是拥有巨大的财富，而是她可以充分利用的资金。她告诉我，虽然她已将这些资金的主要部分用于其他用途，但她愿意考虑是否不能完全取代我与医院的关系。但她希望有足够的时间来成熟她对这个问题的想法，我已经告诉她没有必要着急——事实上，我自己的计划还不是绝对的。

Lydgate was ready to say, ‘If Mrs. Casaubon would take your place, there would be gain, instead of loss.’ But there was still a weight on his mind which arrested this cheerful candor. He replied, ‘I suppose, then, that I may enter into the subject with Mrs. Casaubon.’
利德盖特正准备说：“如果卡苏朋夫人接替你的位置，就会有收获，而不是有损失。”但他心中仍有重担，阻止了他这种愉快的坦诚。他回答说：“那么我想我可以和卡苏朋夫人谈谈这个话题。”

‘Precisely; that is what she expressly desires. Her decision, she says, will much depend on what you can tell her. But not at present: she is, I believe, just setting out on a journey. I have her letter here,’ said Mr. Bulstrode, drawing it out, and reading from it. ‘I am immediately otherwise engaged,’ she says. ‘I am going into Yorkshire with Sir James and Lady Chettam; and the conclusions I come to about some land which I am to see there may affect my power of contributing to the Hospital.’ Thus, Mr. Lydgate, there is no haste necessary in this matter; but I wished to apprise you beforehand of what may possibly occur.’
'恰恰;这就是她明确想要的。她说，她的决定很大程度上取决于你能告诉她什么。但目前还不是：我相信她刚刚踏上旅程。 “我这里有她的信。”布尔斯特罗德先生一边说，一边把信拿出来读了起来。 “我立刻就订婚了，”她说。 “我要和詹姆斯爵士和切塔姆夫人一起去约克郡；因此，利德盖特先生，在这件事上没有必要仓促行事；但我想提前告知您可能发生的情况。

Mr. Bulstrode returned the letter to his side-pocket, and changed his attitude as if his business were closed. Lydgate, whose renewed hope about the Hospital only made him more conscious of the facts which poisoned his hope, felt that his effort after help, if made at all, must be made now and vigorously.
布尔斯特罗德先生将信放回侧袋，然后改变了态度，就好像他的生意已经结束了一样。利德盖特对医院重新燃起了希望，这让他更加意识到那些毒害了他的希望的事实，他觉得他必须立即做出努力，而且要积极地寻求帮助。

‘I am much obliged to you for giving me full notice,’ he said, with a firm intention in his tone, yet with an interruptedness in his delivery which showed that he spoke unwillingly. ‘The highest object to me is my profession, and I had identified the Hospital with the best use I can at present make of my profession. But the best use is not always the same with monetary success. Everything which has made the Hospital unpopular has helped with other causes— I think they are all connected with my professional zeal—to make me unpopular as a practitioner. I get chiefly patients who can’t pay me. I should like them best, if I had nobody to pay on my own side.’ Lydgate waited a little, but Bulstrode only bowed, looking at him fixedly, and he went on with the same interrupted enunciation— as if he were biting an objectional leek.
“我非常感谢你对我的充分通知。”他说道，语气中带着坚定的意图，但语气中却时不时地打断，表明他不太情愿。 “我的最高目标是我的职业，我认为医院是我目前可以充分利用我的职业的地方。”但最佳用途并不总是与金钱上的成功相同。一切让医院不受欢迎的事情都与其他原因有关——我认为它们都与我的职业热情有关——使我作为一名从业者不受欢迎。我接待的病人主要是付不起钱的病人。利德盖特等了一会儿，但布尔斯特罗德只是鞠了一躬，定定地看着他，然后他继续用同样的断断续续的发音——好像他在咬一个反对者。韭葱。

‘I have slipped into money difficulties which I can see no way out of, unless some one who trusts me and my future will advance me a sum without other security. I had very little fortune left when I came here. I have no prospects of money from my own family. My expenses, in consequence of my marriage, have been very much greater than I had expected. The result at this moment is that it would take a thousand pounds to clear me. I mean, to free me from the risk of having all my goods sold in security of my largest debt— as well as to pay my other debts—and leave anything to keep us a little beforehand with our small income. I find that it is out of the question that my wife’s father should make such an advance. That is why I mention my position to—to the only other man who may be held to have some personal connection with my prosperity or ruin.’
“我陷入了资金困难，我看不到任何出路，除非有人信任我和我的未来，在没有其他担保的情况下预支一笔钱给我。”当我来到这里时，我所剩的财产已经所剩无几了。我没有希望从自己的家人那里得到钱。由于结婚，我的开支比我预期的要多得多。现在的结果是，需要一千英镑才能清理我。我的意思是，让我摆脱出售所有货物以偿还我最大的债务的风险——以及偿还我的其他债务——并留下任何东西来让我们提前用我们的微薄收入维持一点。我觉得我岳父不可能垫付这样的钱。这就是为什么我向唯一可能与我的繁荣或毁灭有某种个人联系的人提及我的立场。

Lydgate hated to hear himself. But he had spoken now, and had spoken with unmistakable directness. Mr. Bulstrode replied without haste, but also without hesitation.
利德盖特讨厌听自己说话。但他现在开口说话了，而且说话的语气毫无疑问是直接的。布尔斯特罗德先生不慌不忙地回答，但也毫不犹豫。

‘I am grieved, though, I confess, not surprised by this information, Mr. Lydgate. For my own part, I regretted your alliance with my brother-in-law’s family, which has always been of prodigal habits, and which has already been much indebted to me for sustainment in its present position. My advice to you, Mr. Lydgate, would be, that instead of involving yourself in further obligations, and continuing a doubtful struggle, you should simply become a bankrupt.’
“不过，我承认，我很伤心，对这个消息并不感到惊讶，利德盖特先生。就我个人而言，我对你与我姐夫家族的联盟感到遗憾，我姐夫家族一向有挥霍的习惯，而且维持现在的地位已经对我有很大的恩惠。利德盖特先生，我给你的建议是，你应该破产，而不是让自己承担更多的义务，继续进行可疑的斗争。

‘That would not improve my prospect,’ said Lydgate, rising and speaking bitterly, ‘even if it were a more agreeable thing in itself.’
“这不会改善我的前景，”利德盖特站起来，苦涩地说，“即使这本身是一件更令人愉快的事情。”

‘It is always a trial,’ said Mr. Bulstrode; ‘but trial, my dear sir, is our portion here, and is a needed corrective. I recommend you to weigh the advice I have given.’
“这始终是一场考验，”布尔斯特罗德先生说。 “但是，亲爱的先生，审判是我们的责任，也是必要的纠正。我建议你权衡一下我给出的建议。

‘Thank you,’ said Lydgate, not quite knowing what he said. ‘I have occupied you too long. Good-day.’
“谢谢你，”利德盖特说，不太明白自己说了什么。 ‘我已经占据你太久了。再会。'

CHAPTER LXVIII
第六十八章

‘What suit of grace hath Virtue to put on
‘美德要穿上什么样的恩典衣服？

If Vice shall wear as good, and do as well?
如果 Vice 穿起来也同样好，做的也同样好的话？

If Wrong, if Craft, if Indiscretion
如果错误，如果技巧，如果轻率

Act as fair parts with ends as laudable?
表现得公平，结果值得称赞？

Which all this mighty volume of events
这么多的事件

The world, the universal map of deeds,
世界，行为的普遍地图，

Strongly controls, and proves from all descents,
强有力的控制，并从所有血统中证明，

That the directest course still best succeeds.
最直接的做法仍然最成功。

For should not grave and learn’d Experience
不应该埋葬和学习经验

That looks with the eyes of all the world beside,
用旁边全世界的目光来看，

And with all ages holds intelligence,
并拥有所有年龄段的智慧，

Go safer than Deceit without a guide!
在没有向导的情况下，比欺骗更安全！

—DANIEL: Musophilus.
——丹尼尔：穆索菲勒斯。

That change of plan and shifting of interest which Bulstrode stated or betrayed in his conversation with Lydgate, had been determined in him by some severe experience which he had gone through since the epoch of Mr. Larcher’s sale, when Raffles had recognized Will Ladislaw, and when the banker had in vain attempted an act of restitution which might move Divine Providence to arrest painful consequences.
布尔斯特罗德在与利德盖特的谈话中所说或背叛的计划的改变和利益的转移，是由他自拉彻先生出售时代以来所经历的一些严峻的经历所决定的，当时莱佛士认识了威尔·拉迪斯洛，并且当银行家徒劳地尝试采取恢复原状的行为时，这可能会促使神圣的天意阻止痛苦的后果。

His certainty that Raffles, unless he were dead, would return to Middlemarch before long, had been justified. On Christmas Eve he had reappeared at The Shrubs. Bulstrode was at home to receive him, and hinder his communication with the rest of the family, but he could not altogether hinder the circumstances of the visit from compromising himself and alarming his wife. Raffles proved more unmanageable than he had shown himself to be in his former appearances, his chronic state of mental restlessness, the growing effect of habitual intemperance, quickly shaking off every impression from what was said to him. He insisted on staying in the house, and Bulstrode, weighing two sets of evils, felt that this was at least not a worse alternative than his going into the town. He kept him in his own room for the evening and saw him to bed, Raffles all the while amusing himself with the annoyance he was causing this decent and highly prosperous fellow-sinner, an amusement which he facetiously expressed as sympathy with his friend’s pleasure in entertaining a man who had been serviceable to him, and who had not had all his earnings. There was a cunning calculation under this noisy joking—a cool resolve to extract something the handsomer from Bulstrode as payment for release from this new application of torture. But his cunning had a little overcast its mark.
他确信莱佛士除非死了，否则不久就会回到米德尔马奇，这是有道理的。圣诞节前夕，他再次出现在灌木丛酒店。布尔斯特罗德在家接待他，并阻碍了他与家人其他成员的沟通，但他无法完全阻止访问的情况对他自己造成损害并惊动他的妻子。事实证明，莱佛士比他以前的表现更加难以控制，他长期处于精神不安的状态，习惯性不节制的影响日益严重，很快就摆脱了对他所说的话的每一个印象。他坚持留在房子里，而布尔斯特罗德权衡了两方面的弊端，觉得这至少不比进城更糟糕。晚上，他把他留在自己的房间里，送他上床睡觉，莱佛士一直在自娱自乐地自娱自乐，他给这个正派、非常富裕的罪人带来了烦恼，他开玩笑地将这种乐趣表达为对他朋友的快乐的同情。款待一个曾经为他服务过但并没有得到他全部收入的人。在这个吵闹的玩笑背后隐藏着一个狡猾的算计——一个冷静的决定，要从布尔斯特罗德那里索取更漂亮的东西，作为从这种新的酷刑中释放的报酬。但他的狡猾有点掩盖了它的印记。

Bulstrode was indeed more tortured than the coarse fibre of Raffles could enable him to imagine. He had told his wife that he was simply taking care of this wretched creature, the victim of vice, who might otherwise injure himself; he implied, without the direct form of falsehood, that there was a family tie which bound him to this care, and that there were signs of mental alienation in Raffles which urged caution. He would himself drive the unfortunate being away the next morning. In these hints he felt that he was supplying Mrs. Bulstrode with precautionary information for his daughters and servants, and accounting for his allowing no one but himself to enter the room even with food and drink. But he sat in an agony of fear lest Raffles should be overheard in his loud and plain references to past facts— lest Mrs. Bulstrode should be even tempted to listen at the door. How could he hinder her, how betray his terror by opening the door to detect her? She was a woman of honest direct habits, and little likely to take so low a course in order to arrive at painful knowledge; but fear was stronger than the calculation of probabilities.
