There are natures in which, if they love us, we are conscious of having a sort of baptism and consecration: they bind us over to rectitude and purity by their pure belief about us; and our sins become that worst kind of sacrilege which tears down the invisible altar of trust. ‘If you are not good, none is good’— those little words may give a terrific meaning to responsibility, may hold a vitriolic intensity for remorse.
在某些天性中，如果他们爱我们，我们就会意识到自己接受了某种洗礼和奉献：他们通过对我们的纯粹信仰将我们束缚在正直和纯洁上；我们的罪孽成为最严重的亵渎行为，摧毁了无形的信任祭坛。 “如果你不好，那么没有人会好”——这句小话可能赋予责任重大的意义，可能会带来强烈的悔恨。

Dorothea’s nature was of that kind: her own passionate faults lay along the easily counted open channels of her ardent character; and while she was full of pity for the, visible mistakes of others, she had not yet any material within her experience for subtle constructions and suspicions of hidden wrong. But that simplicity of hers, holding up an ideal for others in her believing conception of them, was one of the great powers of her womanhood. And it had from the first acted strongly on Will Ladislaw. He felt, when he parted from her, that the brief words by which he had tried to convey to her his feeling about herself and the division which her fortune made between them, would only profit by their brevity when Dorothea had to interpret them: he felt that in her mind he had found his highest estimate.
多萝西娅的性格就是这样：她自己热情的缺点在她热情的性格中很容易数出。虽然她对别人明显的错误充满怜悯，但她的经验中还没有任何材料来证明微妙的结构和对隐藏错误的怀疑。但她的单纯，在她对他人的信念中为他人树立了理想，这是她女性气质的伟大力量之一。从一开始，它就对威尔·拉迪斯瓦夫产生了强烈的影响。他觉得，当他与她分别时，他试图用简短的话语向她表达他对自己的感觉以及她的命运在他们之间造成的分歧，只有当多萝西娅必须解释它们时，它们的简短才会受益：他感觉在她心里他已经找到了自己的最高估计。

And he was right there. In the months since their parting Dorothea had felt a delicious though sad repose in their relation to each other, as one which was inwardly whole and without blemish. She had an active force of antagonism within her, when the antagonism turned on the defence either of plans or persons that she believed in; and the wrongs which she felt that Will had received from her husband, and the external conditions which to others were grounds for slighting him, only gave the more tenacity to her affection and admiring judgment. And now with the disclosures about Bulstrode had come another fact affecting Will’s social position, which roused afresh Dorothea’s inward resistance to what was said about him in that part of her world which lay within park palings.
他就在那里。分手后的几个月里，多萝西娅在他们彼此的关系中感受到了一种甜蜜而又悲伤的安息，因为他们的内心是完整的、没有瑕疵的。她内心有一股积极的对抗力量，当这种对抗转向捍卫她所相信的计划或人时；她觉得威尔从她丈夫那里受到的委屈，以及在别人眼里成为轻视他的理由的外在条件，只会让她的感情和钦佩的判断力更加坚韧。现在，随着布尔斯特罗德的曝光，另一个影响威尔社会地位的事实又出现了，这再次激起了多萝西娅内心的抵制，因为在她的世界里，公园的栅栏内，关于他的言论再次激起了多萝西娅的抵触。

‘Young Ladislaw the grandson of a thieving Jew pawnbroker’ was a phrase which had entered emphatically into the dialogues about the Bulstrode business, at Lowick, Tipton, and Freshitt, and was a worse kind of placard on poor Will’s back than the ‘Italian with white mice.’ Upright Sir James Chettam was convinced that his own satisfaction was righteous when he thought with some complacency that here was an added league to that mountainous distance between Ladislaw and Dorothea, which enabled him to dismiss any anxiety in that direction as too absurd. And perhaps there had been some pleasure in pointing Mr. Brooke’s attention to this ugly bit of Ladislaw’s genealogy, as a fresh candle for him to see his own folly by. Dorothea had observed the animus with which Will’s part in the painful story had been recalled more than once; but she had uttered no word, being checked now, as she had not been formerly in speaking of Will, by the consciousness of a deeper relation between them which must always remain in consecrated secrecy. But her silence shrouded her resistant emotion into a more thorough glow; and this misfortune in Will’s lot which, it seemed, others were wishing to fling at his back as an opprobrium, only gave something more of enthusiasm to her clinging thought.
“年轻的拉迪斯瓦夫是一个偷窃的犹太当铺老板的孙子”，这句话在洛威克、蒂普顿和弗雷希特关于布尔斯特罗德生意的对话中被强调，而且是挂在可怜的威尔背上的标语牌，比挂在“意大利人”更糟糕。正直的詹姆斯·切塔姆爵士确信自己的满足感是正当的，因为他有些自满地认为，拉迪斯瓦夫和多萝西娅之间的山地距离又增加了一个联盟，这使他能够消除任何在这个方向上的焦虑，因为这太荒谬了。也许让布鲁克先生注意到拉迪斯瓦家谱中这一丑陋的部分是有某种乐趣的，就像一根新的蜡烛让他看到自己的愚蠢行为。多萝西娅注意到威尔在这个痛苦的故事中所扮演的角色不止一次地被回忆起时的敌意。但她一言不发，因为她意识到他们之间有更深层的关系，而这种关系必须始终保持神圣的秘密，所以现在她没有说话，因为她以前没有谈论过威尔。但她的沉默却将她的抗拒情绪笼罩在更彻底的光芒之中。威尔的不幸遭遇，其他人似乎都想以此作为对他的责难，但这却给她执着的想法增添了更多的热情。

She entertained no visions of their ever coming into nearer union, and yet she had taken no posture of renunciation. She had accepted her whole relation to Will very simply as part of her marriage sorrows, and would have thought it very sinful in her to keep up an inward wail because she was not completely happy, being rather disposed to dwell on the superfluities of her lot. She could bear that the chief pleasures of her tenderness should lie in memory, and the idea of marriage came to her solely as a repulsive proposition from some suitor of whom she at present knew nothing, but whose merits, as seen by her friends, would be a source of torment to her:— ‘somebody who will manage your property for you, my dear,’ was Mr. Brooke’s attractive suggestion of suitable characteristics. ‘I should like to manage it myself, if I knew what to do with it,’ said Dorothea. No—she adhered to her declaration that she would never be married again, and in the long valley of her life which looked so flat and empty of waymarks, guidance would come as she walked along the road, and saw her fellow-passengers by the way.
她没有想到他们会更加紧密地结合在一起，但她也没有采取放弃的姿态。她很简单地接受了她与威尔的整个关系，将其视为婚姻悲伤的一部分，并认为她内心的哀号是非常有罪的，因为她并不完全幸福，更倾向于沉迷于自己命运的多余。 。她可以忍受，她温柔的主要快乐应该存在于记忆中，而婚姻的想法只是作为一个令人厌恶的提议而产生的，她目前对这个追求者一无所知，但正如她的朋友们所看到的，他的优点将是值得的。成为她痛苦的根源：“亲爱的，有人会为你管理你的财产，”布鲁克先生对合适的特征提出了有吸引力的建议。 “如果我知道如何处理它，我想自己管理它，”多萝西娅说。不——她坚持自己的誓言，不再结婚，在她人生的漫长低谷中，看似平坦、空无一物的路标，当她走在路上，看到路边的同行者时，指引就会出现。方式。

This habitual state of feeling about Will Ladislaw had been strong. in all her waking hours since she had proposed to pay a visit to Mrs. Lydgate, making a sort of background against which she saw Rosamond’s figure presented to her without hindrances to her interest and compassion. There was evidently some mental separation, some barrier to complete confidence which had arisen between this wife and the husband who had yet made her happiness a law to him. That was a trouble which no third person must directly touch. But Dorothea thought with deep pity of the loneliness which must have come upon Rosamond from the suspicions cast on her husband; and there would surely be help in the manifestation of respect for Lydgate and sympathy with her.
这种对威尔·拉迪斯瓦夫的习惯性感情一直很强烈。自从她提议去拜访利德盖特夫人以来，在她醒着的所有时间里，她都在营造一种背景，在这种背景下，她看到罗莎蒙德的身影呈现在她面前，而没有妨碍她的兴趣和同情心。显然，这位妻子和丈夫之间存在某种精神上的隔阂，某种完全信任的障碍，而丈夫却还把她的幸福视为他的法则。那是第三者不能直接触及的麻烦。但多萝西娅怀着深深的怜悯想到，罗莎蒙德一定会因为对她丈夫的怀疑而感到孤独。表达对利德盖特的尊重和同情肯定会有所帮助。

‘I shall talk to her about her husband,’ thought Dorothea, as she was being driven towards the town. The clear spring morning, the scent of the moist earth, the fresh leaves just showing their creased-up wealth of greenery from out their half-opened sheaths, seemed part of the cheerfulness she was feeling from a long conversation with Mr. Farebrother, who had joyfully accepted the justifying explanation of Lydgate’s conduct. ‘I shall take Mrs. Lydgate good news, and perhaps she will like to talk to me and make a friend of me.’
“我要跟她谈谈她的丈夫，”多萝西娅一边想，一边被车开往镇上。晴朗的春天早晨，潮湿的泥土的香味，新鲜的叶子刚刚从半开的叶鞘中露出褶皱的绿色植物，这似乎是她从与费雷布拉泽先生长时间交谈中感受到的快乐的一部分。高兴地接受了对利德盖特行为的合理解释。 “我会给利德盖特夫人带来好消息，也许她会愿意和我说话并成为我的朋友。”

Dorothea had another errand in Lowick Gate: it was about a new fine-toned bell for the school-house, and as she had to get out of her carriage very near to Lydgate’s, she walked thither across the street, having told the coachman to wait for some packages. The street door was open, and the servant was taking the opportunity of looking out at the carriage which was pausing within sight when it became apparent to her that the lady who ‘belonged to it’ was coming towards her.
多萝西娅在洛威克门还有另一件事：是为校舍安装一个新的精美铃声，因为她必须在离利德盖特很近的地方下马车，所以她步行穿过街道，告诉车夫等待一些包裹。临街的门开着，仆人正趁机向外张望停在视线范围内的马车，这时她发现那位“属于这辆马车”的女士正在向她走来。

‘Is Mrs. Lydgate at home?’ said Dorothea.
“利德盖特太太在家吗？”多萝西娅问。

‘I’m not sure, my lady; I’ll see, if you’ll please to walk in,’ said Martha, a little confused on the score of her kitchen apron, but collected enough to be sure that ‘mum’ was not the right title for this queenly young widow with a carriage and pair. ‘Will you please to walk in, and I’ll go and see.’
“我不确定，夫人； “我会看看，如果你愿意走进去的话，”玛莎说，她对厨房围裙的分数感到有点困惑，但她已经足够镇定了，可以确定“妈妈”并不是这个年轻女王寡妇的正确称呼。一辆马车和一对。 “请你走进去，我去看看。”

‘Say that I am Mrs. Casaubon,’ said Dorothea, as Martha moved forward intending to show her into the drawing-room and then to go up-stairs to see if Rosamond had returned from her walk.
“就说我是卡苏朋夫人吧。”多萝西娅说道，玛莎向前走去，打算带她进客厅，然后上楼去看看罗莎蒙德是否散步回来了。

They crossed the broader part of the entrance-hall, and turned up the passage which led to the garden. The drawing-room door was unlatched, and Martha, pushing it without looking into the room, waited for Mrs. Casaubon to enter and then turned away, the door having swung open and swung back again without noise.
他们穿过门厅较宽的部分，拐进通向花园的通道。客厅的门没锁，玛莎推门而入，没有朝房间里看，等卡苏邦太太进来，然后转过身去，门无声无息地打开了又转了回去。

Dorothea had less of outward vision than usual this morning, being filled with images of things as they had been and were going to be. She found herself on the other side of the door without seeing anything remarkable, but immediately she heard a voice speaking in low tones which startled her as with a sense of dreaming in daylight, and advancing unconsciously a step or two beyond the projecting slab of a bookcase, she saw, in the terrible illumination of a certainty which filled up all outlines, something which made her pause, motionless, without self-possession enough to speak.
今天早上，多萝西娅的外在视野比平时要少，她的脑海里充满了事物过去和未来的景象。她发现自己到了门的另一边，并没有看到任何值得注意的东西，但立即她听到一个低声说话的声音，这让她吃了一惊，有一种白天做梦的感觉，不知不觉地向前迈出了一两步，超出了突出的石板。她看到了书架，在充满了所有轮廓的确定性的可怕照明中，有什么东西让她停了下来，一动不动，没有足够的冷静来说话。

Seated with his back towards her on a sofa which stood against the wall on a line with the door by which she had entered, she saw Will Ladislaw: close by him and turned towards him with a flushed tearfulness which gave a new brilliancy to her face sat Rosamond, her bonnet hanging back, while Will leaning towards her clasped both her upraised hands in his and spoke with low-toned fervor.
她背对着她坐在一张沙发上，沙发靠墙与她进来的门在一条线上，她看到了威尔·拉迪斯瓦夫：靠近他，转身面向他，满脸通红，泪流满面，这给她的脸增添了新的光彩罗莎蒙德坐着，帽子向后垂着，而威尔则靠向她，握住她举起的双手，低声热情地说道。

Rosamond in her agitated absorption had not noticed the silently advancing figure; but when Dorothea, after the first immeasurable instant of this vision, moved confusedly backward and found herself impeded by some piece of furniture, Rosamond was suddenly aware of her presence, and with a spasmodic movement snatched away her hands and rose, looking at Dorothea who was necessarily arrested. Will Ladislaw, starting up, looked round also, and meeting Dorothea’s eyes with a new lightning in them, seemed changing to marble: But she immediately turned them away from him to Rosamond and said in a firm voice—
罗莎蒙德全神贯注地焦躁不安，没有注意到那个默默走来的身影。但是当多萝西娅在看到这个景象的第一个不可估量的瞬间后，困惑地向后退去，发现自己被一件家具挡住了，罗莎蒙德突然意识到她的存在，并以痉挛的动作抽回双手，站起来，看着多萝西娅。必然被逮捕。威尔·拉迪斯瓦夫站了起来，也环顾四周，与多萝西娅的双眸相遇，双眸中闪烁着新的光芒，似乎变成了大理石：但她立即将目光从他身上转向罗莎蒙德，并用坚定的声音说道——

‘Excuse me, Mrs. Lydgate, the servant did not know that you were here. I called to deliver an important letter for Mr. Lydgate, which I wished to put into your own hands.’
“对不起，利德盖特夫人，仆人不知道您在这里。我打电话是为了给利德盖特先生转递一封重要的信，我希望将这封信交到您手中。

She laid down the letter on the small table which had checked her retreat, and then including Rosamond and Will in one distant glance and bow, she went quickly out of the room, meeting in the passage the surprised Martha, who said she was sorry the mistress was not at home, and then showed the strange lady out with an inward reflection that grand people were probably more impatient than others.
她把信放在那张检查了她撤退的小桌子上，然后远远地看了一眼罗莎蒙德和威尔，鞠了一躬，她快步走出了房间，在过道里遇到了惊讶的玛莎，她说她很抱歉女主人不在家，便把这位陌生的女士领了出去，心里暗想，大人物恐怕比其他人更不耐烦。

Dorothea walked across the street with her most elastic step and was quickly in her carriage again.
多萝西娅用她最有弹性的步伐穿过街道，很快又坐上了马车。

‘Drive on to Freshitt Hall,’ she said to the coachman, and any one looking at her might have thought that though she was paler than usual she was never animated by a more self-possessed energy. And that was really her experience. It was as if she had drunk a great draught of scorn that stimulated her beyond the susceptibility to other feelings. She had seen something so far below her belief, that her emotions rushed back from it and made an excited throng without an object. She needed something active to turn her excitement out upon. She felt power to walk and work for a day, without meat or drink. And she would carry out the purpose with which she had started in the morning, of going to Freshitt and Tipton to tell Sir James and her uncle all that she wished them to know about Lydgate, whose married loneliness under his trial now presented itself to her with new significance, and made her more ardent in readiness to be his champion. She had never felt anything like this triumphant power of indignation in the struggle of her married life, in which there had always been a quickly subduing pang; and she took it as a sign of new strength.
“开车去弗雷希特庄园，”她对车夫说，任何看着她的人都可能会认为，尽管她比平常更苍白，但她从来没有被一种更加沉着的能量所激励。这确实是她的经历。就好像她喝了一大口轻蔑的酒，刺激着她，超越了对其他感情的敏感度。她看到了一些远远低于她的信念的东西，她的情绪从那里涌了回来，形成了一个没有目标的兴奋人群。她需要一些积极的东西来发泄她的兴奋。她感到自己有力量步行和工作一天，不吃不喝。她将实现她早上开始的目的，去弗雷希特和蒂普顿那里，告诉詹姆斯爵士和她叔叔她希望他们知道的关于利德盖特的一切，现在她在他的审判下，已婚的孤独感浮现了出来。具有新的意义，并使她更加热衷于成为他的冠军。在她婚姻生活的挣扎中，她从来没有感受到过如此胜利的愤怒力量，在婚姻生活中，她总是有一种很快就被压制住的痛苦。她认为这是新力量的标志。

‘Dodo, how very bright your eyes are!’ said Celia, when Sir James was gone out of the room. ‘And you don’t see anything you look at, Arthur or anything. You are going to do something uncomfortable, I know. Is it all about Mr. Lydgate, or has something else happened?’ Celia had been used to watch her sister with expectation.
“多多，你的眼睛多么明亮啊！”当詹姆斯爵士走出房间时，西莉亚说道。 “你看不到任何东西，亚瑟或者任何东西。我知道你会做一些不舒服的事情。 “是利德盖特先生的事，还是发生了其他事情？”西莉亚已经习惯用期待的目光看着她的妹妹。

‘Yes, dear, a great many things have happened,’ said Dodo, in her full tones.
“是的，亲爱的，发生了很多事情，”多多用她的声音说道。

‘I wonder what,’ said Celia, folding her arms cozily and leaning forward upon them.
“我想知道是什么，”西莉亚说道，舒适地交叉着双臂，身体前倾。

‘Oh, all the troubles of all people on the face of the earth,’ said Dorothea, lifting her arms to the back of her head.
“哦，地球上所有人的所有烦恼，”多萝西娅说，将双臂举到脑后。

‘Dear me, Dodo, are you going to have a scheme for them?’ said Celia, a little uneasy at this Hamlet-like raving.
“天哪，多多，你要为他们制定一个计划吗？”西莉亚说，对这种哈姆雷特式的胡言乱语感到有点不安。

But Sir James came in again, ready to accompany Dorothea to the Grange, and she finished her expedition well, not swerving in her resolution until she descended at her own door.
但詹姆斯爵士又进来了，准备陪多萝西娅去田庄，她很好地完成了她的探险，直到她来到自家门口才改变了她的决心。

CHAPTER LXXVIII
第 六十八章

Would it were yesterday and I i’ the grave,
如果是昨天，我会在坟墓里吗？

With her sweet faith above for monument ‘
以她甜蜜的信念为纪念碑”

Rosamond and Will stood motionless—they did not know how long— he looking towards the spot where Dorothea had stood, and she looking towards him with doubt. It seemed an endless time to Rosamond, in whose inmost soul there was hardly so much annoyance as gratification from what had just happened. Shallow natures dream of an easy sway over the emotions of others, trusting implicitly in their own petty magic to turn the deepest streams, and confident, by pretty gestures and remarks, of making the thing that is not as though it were. She knew that Will had received a severe blow, but she had been little used to imagining other people’s states of mind except as a material cut into shape by her own wishes; and she believed in her own power to soothe or subdue. Even Tertius, that most perverse of men, was always subdued in the long-run: events had been obstinate, but still Rosamond would have said now, as she did before her marriage, that she never gave up what she had set her mind on.
罗莎蒙德和威尔一动不动地站着——他们不知道多久——他看着多萝西娅站着的地方，而她则疑惑地看着他。对罗莎蒙德来说，这似乎是一段无尽的时光，刚刚发生的事情在她内心深处几乎没有多少烦恼，而是更多的满足。肤浅的本性梦想着能够轻松地左右他人的情绪，暗中相信自己的小魔法能够扭转最深的溪流，并自信地通过漂亮的手势和言论使事物变得不那么像。她知道威尔受到了沉重的打击，但她很少习惯去想象别人的心态，除非她把自己想象成一块根据自己意愿塑造的材料；她相信自己有能力安抚或征服。即使是特提乌斯，那个最任性的男人，从长远来看也总是被制服的：事情一直是顽固的，但罗莎蒙德现在仍然会说，就像她在结婚前所做的那样，她从未放弃过她所下定的决心。

She put out her arm and laid the tips of her fingers on Will’s coat-sleeve.
她伸出手臂，将指尖放在威尔的衣袖上。

‘Don’t touch me!’ he said, with an utterance like the cut of a lash, darting from her, and changing from pink to white and back again, as if his whole frame were tingling with the pain of the sting. He wheeled round to the other side of the room and stood opposite to her, with the tips of his fingers in his pockets and his head thrown back, looking fiercely not at Rosamond but at a point a few inches away from her.
“别碰我！”他说，声音就像鞭子割过一样，从她身边飞奔而出，从粉红色变成白色，然后又变回来，仿佛他的整个身体都因刺痛而刺痛。他转身到房间的另一边，站在她对面，手指插在口袋里，头向后仰着，目光凶狠地看着，不是罗莎蒙德，而是离她几英寸远的地方。

She was keenly offended, but the Signs she made of this were such as only Lydgate was used to interpret. She became suddenly quiet and seated herself, untying her hanging bonnet and laying it down with her shawl. Her little hands which she folded before her were very cold.
她非常生气，但她对此做出的迹象只有利德盖特才能解释。她突然安静下来，坐下来，解开挂在身上的帽子，把它和披肩一起放下。她叠在身前的小手非常冰凉。

It would have been safer for Will in the first instance to have taken up his hat and gone away; but he had felt no impulse to do this; on the contrary, he had a horrible inclination to stay and shatter Rosamond with his anger. It seemed as impossible to bear the fatality she had drawn down on him without venting his fury as it would be to a panther to bear the javelin-wound without springing and biting. And yet—how could he tell a woman that he was ready to curse her? He was fuming under a repressive law which he was forced to acknowledge: he was dangerously poised, and Rosamond’s voice now brought the decisive vibration. In flute-like tones of sarcasm she said—
对于威尔来说，首先拿起帽子走开会更安全。但他并没有这样做的冲动；相反，他有一种可怕的倾向，想留下来，用自己的愤怒击垮罗莎蒙德。承受她给他带来的死亡而不发泄他的愤怒似乎是不可能的，就像一头黑豹承受标枪的伤口而不跳起来和咬人一样。然而——他怎么能告诉一个女人他准备诅咒她呢？他对他被迫承认的压制性法律感到愤怒：他保持着危险的泰然自若，而罗莎蒙德的声音现在带来了决定性的振动。她用笛子般的讽刺语气说道——

‘You can easily go after Mrs. Casaubon and explain your preference.’
“你可以轻松地找到卡苏邦夫人并解释你的偏好。”

‘Go after her!’ he burst out, with a sharp edge in his voice. ‘Do you think she would turn to look at me, or value any word I ever uttered to her again at more than a dirty feather?—Explain! How can a man explain at the expense of a woman?’
“追她！”他大声喊道，声音尖锐。 “你认为她会转身看着我，或者认为我对她说过的任何一句话都比一根肮脏的羽毛更重要吗？——解释一下！男人怎么能以牺牲女人为代价来解释呢？

‘You can tell her what you please,’ said Rosamond with more tremor.
“你想告诉她什么就告诉她，”罗莎蒙德更加颤抖地说。

‘Do you suppose she would like me better for sacrificing you? She is not a woman to be flattered because I made myself despicable— to believe that I must be true to her because I was a dastard to you.’
‘你认为她会因为我牺牲你而更喜欢我吗？她不是一个因为我让自己变得卑鄙而被奉承的女人——相信我必须对她忠诚，因为我对你来说是一个卑鄙的人。

He began to move about with the restlessness of a wild animal that sees prey but cannot reach it. Presently he burst out again—
他开始四处走动，就像一只看到猎物却无法够到的野生动物一样焦躁不安。不一会儿，他又爆发了——

‘I had no hope before—not much—of anything better to come. But I had one certainty—that she believed in me. Whatever people had said or done about me, she believed in me.—That’s gone! She’ll never again think me anything but a paltry pretence— too nice to take heaven except upon flattering conditions, and yet selling myself for any devil’s change by the sly. She’ll think of me as an incarnate insult to her, from the first moment we—‘
“我之前对未来的事情不抱任何希望——也不抱太大希望。但我有一个确信——她相信我。无论人们对我说什么或做了什么，她都相信我。——那已经过去了！她再也不会认为我只是一个微不足道的假装——太善良了，除非有讨人喜欢的条件，否则无法进入天堂，却又偷偷地为了任何魔鬼的改变而出卖自己。她会认为我是对她的侮辱，​​从我们第一刻起——”

Will stopped as if he had found himself grasping something that must not be thrown and shattered. He found another vent for his rage by snatching up Rosamond’s words again, as if they were reptiles to be throttled and flung off.
威尔停了下来，仿佛他发现自己抓住了一些不能扔掉或打碎的东西。他再次抓住罗莎蒙德的话，找到了另一个发泄愤怒的方式，就好像它们是被掐死并被扔掉的爬行动物一样。

‘Explain! Tell a man to explain how he dropped into hell! Explain my preference! I never had a PREFERENCE for her, any more than I have a preference for breathing. No other woman exists by the side of her. I would rather touch her hand if it were dead, than I would touch any other woman’s living.’
'解释！请一个人解释一下他是如何坠入地狱的！解释一下我的偏好！我对她从来没有偏爱，就像我对呼吸没有偏爱一样。她身边没有其他女人。如果她的手已经死了，我宁愿碰她的手，也不愿碰其他女人的活人。”

Rosamond, while these poisoned weapons were being hurled at her, was almost losing the sense of her identity, and seemed to be waking into some new terrible existence. She had no sense of chill resolute repulsion, of reticent self-justification such as she had known under Lydgate’s most stormy displeasure: all her sensibility was turned into a bewildering novelty of pain; she felt a new terrified recoil under a lash never experienced before. What another nature felt in opposition to her own was being burnt and bitten into her consciousness. When Will had ceased to speak she had become an image of sickened misery: her lips were pale, and her eyes had a tearless dismay in them. If it had been Tertius who stood opposite to her, that look of misery would have been a pang to him, and he would have sunk by her side to comfort her, with that strong-armed comfort which, she had often held very cheap.
当这些有毒武器向她投掷时，罗莎蒙德几乎失去了自己的身份感，似乎正在苏醒到某种新的可怕的存在中。她没有那种冷酷、坚决的排斥感，也没有那种沉默寡言的自我辩解的感觉，就像她在利德盖特最暴风雨般的不满之下所知道的那样：她所有的敏感都变成了一种令人困惑的新奇的痛苦；她在从未经历过的鞭打下感到了新的恐惧反冲。与她的本性相对立的另一种本性正在被烧毁并侵蚀她的意识。当威尔不再说话时，她就变成了一副令人作呕的痛苦形象：她的嘴唇苍白，眼睛里流露出无泪的沮丧。如果站在她对面的是泰尔提乌斯，那痛苦的表情会让他感到痛苦，他会趴在她身边安慰她，用她常常认为很廉价的那种强有力的安慰。

Let it be forgiven to Will that he had no such movement of pity. He had felt no bond beforehand to this woman who had spoiled the ideal treasure of his life, and he held himself blameless. He knew that he was cruel, but he had no relenting in him yet.
请原谅威尔没有这样的怜悯之心。他之前对这个毁掉了他一生理想财富的女人没有任何感情，他认为自己无可指责。他知道自己很残忍，但他还没有心软。

After he had done speaking, he still moved about, half in absence of mind, and Rosamond sat perfectly still. At length Will, seeming to bethink himself, took up his hat, yet stood some moments irresolute. He had spoken to her in a way that made a phrase of common politeness difficult to utter; and yet, now that he had come to the point of going away from her without further speech, he shrank from it as a brutality; he felt checked and stultified in his anger. He walked towards the mantel-piece and leaned his arm on it, and waited in silence for—he hardly knew what. The vindictive fire was still burning in him, and he could utter no word of retractation; but it was nevertheless in his mind that having come back to this hearth where he had enjoyed a caressing friendship he had found. calamity seated there—he had had suddenly revealed to him a trouble that lay outside the home as well as within it. And what seemed a foreboding was pressing upon him as with slow pincers:—that his life might come to be enslaved by this helpless woman who had thrown herself upon him in the dreary sadness of her heart. But he was in gloomy rebellion against the fact that his quick apprehensiveness foreshadowed to him, and when his eyes fell on Rosamond’s blighted face it seemed to him that he was the more pitiable of the two; for pain must enter into its glorified life of memory before it can turn into compassion.
说完之后，他仍然走来走去，半心不在焉的样子，而罗莎蒙德则一动不动地坐着。最后，威尔似乎回过神来，拿起帽子，但又站了一会儿，犹豫不决。他对她说话的方式让一般的礼貌用语都很难说出口。然而，既然他已经到了不再说话就离开她的地步，他就将这种行为视为一种粗暴而退缩了。他感到自己被愤怒压制住了。他走向壁炉架，把手臂靠在上面，默默地等待着——他几乎不知道会发生什么。他体内的斗气仍在燃烧，他说不出任何反悔的话。但无论如何，在他看来，回到这个他曾享受过的温暖的壁炉后，他找到了一种充满爱抚的友谊。灾难就在那里——他突然向他揭示了家庭内外的麻烦。似乎有一种不祥的预感像缓慢的钳子一样压在他身上：他的生命可能会被这个无助的女人所奴役，这个女人在内心的沉闷悲伤中将自己投向了他。但他对自己的快速忧虑预示着这一事实感到阴郁的反抗，当他的目光落在罗莎蒙德那张枯萎的脸上时，他觉得自己是两人中更可怜的一个。因为痛苦必须进入其光荣的记忆生活，然后才能转化为同情心。

And so they remained for many minutes, opposite each other, far apart, in silence; Will’s face still possessed by a mute rage, and Rosamond’s by a mute misery. The poor thing had no force to fling out any passion in return; the terrible collapse of the illusion towards which all her hope had been strained was a stroke which had too thoroughly shaken her: her little world was in ruins, and she felt herself tottering in the midst as a lonely bewildered consciousness.
就这样，他们保持了很多分钟，彼此相对，相距甚远，一言不发。威尔的脸上仍然充满了无声的愤怒，罗莎蒙德的脸上仍然充满了无声的痛苦。这个可怜的家伙没有力量以任何热情作为回报。她所有的希望都寄托在幻想上，但可怕的崩溃却彻底震撼了她：她的小世界变成了废墟，她感到自己在其中摇摇欲坠，就像一个孤独而困惑的意识。

Will wished that she would speak and bring some mitigating shadow across his own cruel speech, which seemed to stand staring at them both in mockery of any attempt at revived fellowship. But she said nothing, and at last with a desperate effort over himself, he asked, ‘Shall I come in and see Lydgate this evening?’
威尔希望她能开口说话，给他自己残酷的言论带来一些缓和的阴影，他的言论似乎正盯着他们俩，嘲笑任何恢复友谊的尝试。但她什么也没说，最后他拼命地问：“今晚我可以进来看看利德盖特吗？”

‘If you like,’ Rosamond answered, just audibly.
“如果你愿意的话，”罗莎蒙德回答道，声音很小。

And then Will went out of the house, Martha never knowing that he had been in.
然后威尔走出了房子，玛莎根本不知道他进来过。

After he was gone, Rosamond tried to get up from her seat, but fell back fainting. When she came to herself again, she felt too ill to make the exertion of rising to ring the bell, and she remained helpless until the girl, surprised at her long absence, thought for the first time of looking for her in all the down-stairs rooms. Rosamond said that she had felt suddenly sick and faint, and wanted to be helped up-stairs. When there she threw herself on the bed with her clothes on, and lay in apparent torpor, as she had done once before on a memorable day of grief.
他走后，罗莎蒙德试图从座位上站起来，但又晕倒了。当她再次清醒过来时，她觉得病得很重，无力起身去按门铃，她一直处于无助的状态，直到女孩对她这么久不见感到惊讶，第一次想到要在所有的沮丧中寻找她——楼梯间。罗莎蒙德说，她突然感到恶心和晕倒，需要有人搀扶上楼。当她到达那里时，她穿着衣服倒在床上，显然是麻木地躺着，就像她在一个难忘的悲伤日子里曾经做过的那样。

Lydgate came home earlier than he had expected, about half-past five, and found her there. The perception that she was ill threw every other thought into the background. When he felt her pulse, her eyes rested on him with more persistence than they had done for a long while, as if she felt some content that he was there. He perceived the difference in a moment, and seating himself by her put his arm gently under her, and bending over her said, ‘My poor Rosamond! has something agitated you?’ Clinging to him she fell into hysterical sobbings and cries, and for the next hour he did nothing but soothe and tend her. He imagined that Dorothea had been to see her, and that all this effect on her nervous system, which evidently involved some new turning towards himself, was due to the excitement of the new impressions which that visit had raised.
利德盖特比他预计的要早回家，大约五点半，并在那里找到了她。她病了的感觉把其他所有的想法都抛到了脑后。当他给她把脉时，她的目光比以往更持久地落在他身上，似乎对他的存在感到有些满足。他立刻察觉到了差异，坐在她旁边，轻轻地将手臂放在她身下，弯下腰对她说：“我可怜的罗莎蒙德！”有什么事让你心烦意乱吗？”她紧贴着他，歇斯底里地抽泣着，在​​接下来的一个小时里，他什么也没做，只是安抚和照顾她。他想象多萝西娅是来见她的，而她的神经系统受到的所有这些影响，显然涉及到对自己的一些新的转变，都是由于那次拜访所带来的新印象的兴奋所致。

CHAPTER LXXIX
第六十九章

‘Now, I saw in my dream, that just as they had ended their talk, they drew nigh to a very miry slough, that was in the midst of the plain; and they, being heedless, did both fall suddenly into the bog. The name of the slough was Despond.’—BUNYAN.
现在，我在梦中看到，他们刚结束谈话，就接近了平原中央的一片泥泞的沼泽。他们一不留神，一下子就双双掉进了沼泽里。沼泽的名字叫绝望。”——班扬。

When Rosamond was quiet, and Lydgate had left her, hoping that she might soon sleep under the effect of an anodyne, he went into the drawing-room to fetch a book which he had left there, meaning to spend the evening in his work-room, and he saw on the table Dorothea’s letter addressed to him. He had not ventured to ask Rosamond if Mrs. Casaubon had called, but the reading of this letter assured him of the fact, for Dorothea mentioned that it was to be carried by herself.
当罗莎蒙德安静下来时，利德盖特离开了她，希望她能在止痛药的作用下很快入睡，他走进客厅去取一本他留在那儿的书，打算在工作中度过一个晚上——房间里，他看到桌子上有多萝西娅写给他的信。他没有冒险问罗莎蒙德卡苏朋夫人是否来过电话，但是读了这封信后，他确信了这一点，因为多萝西娅提到这封信要由她自己携带。

When Will Ladislaw came in a little later Lydgate met him with a surprise which made it clear that he had not been told of the earlier visit, and Will could not say, ‘Did not Mrs. Lydgate tell you that I came this morning?’
稍后，当威尔·拉迪斯瓦夫进来时，利德盖特见到了他，他感到很惊讶，这显然表明他没有被告知早些时候的来访，威尔无法说：“利德盖特夫人没有告诉过你我今天早上来过吗？”

‘Poor Rosamond is ill,’ Lydgate added immediately on his greeting.
“可怜的罗莎蒙德病了，”利德盖特在问候后立即补充道。

‘Not seriously, I hope,’ said Will.
“我希望不是认真的，”威尔说。

‘No—only a slight nervous shock—the effect of some agitation. She has been overwrought lately. The truth is, Ladislaw, I am an unlucky devil. We have gone through several rounds of purgatory since you left, and I have lately got on to a worse ledge of it than ever. I suppose you are only just come down—you look rather battered— you have not been long enough in the town to hear anything?’
“不——只是轻微的神经休克——某种激动的影响。她最近太劳累了。事实是，拉迪斯瓦夫，我是一个不幸的恶魔。自从你离开后，我们已经经历了几轮炼狱，而我最近陷入了比以往任何时候都更糟糕的境地。我想你才刚刚下来——你看起来很疲惫——你在城里呆的时间还不够长，听不到任何声音吗？

‘I travelled all night and got to the White Hart at eight o’clock this morning. I have been shutting myself up and resting,’ said Will, feeling himself a sneak, but seeing no alternative to this evasion.
“我整夜赶路，今天早上八点到达白鹿球场。我一直把自己关起来休息。”威尔说，他感觉自己在偷偷摸摸，但除了逃避之外别无选择。

And then he heard Lydgate’s account of the troubles which Rosamond had already depicted to him in her way. She had not mentioned the fact of Will’s name being connected with the public story— this detail not immediately affecting her—and he now heard it for the first time.
然后他听到利德盖特讲述了罗莎蒙德已经用她的方式向他描述过的麻烦。她没有提到威尔的名字与公众故事有关的事实——这个细节并没有立即影响到她——而他现在第一次听到这个消息。

‘I thought it better to tell you that your name is mixed up with the disclosures,’ said Lydgate, who could understand better than most men how Ladislaw might be stung by the revelation. ‘You will be sure to hear it as soon as you turn out into the town. I suppose it is true that Raffles spoke to you.’
“我认为最好告诉你，你的名字与披露的内容混在一起，”利德盖特说，他比大多数人更了解拉迪斯瓦夫可能会因这一披露而受到怎样的刺痛。 ‘你一进城就一定会听到它。我想莱佛士确实和你说过话。”

‘Yes,’ said Will, sardonically. ‘I shall be fortunate if gossip does not make me the most disreputable person in the whole affair. I should think the latest version must be, that I plotted with Raffles to murder Bulstrode, and ran away from Middlemarch for the purpose.’
“是的，”威尔讽刺地说。 “如果流言蜚语没有让我成为整个事件中最声名狼藉的人，那我就很幸运了。我想最新的版本一定是，我和莱佛士密谋谋杀布尔斯特罗德，并为此目的逃离了米德尔马奇。

He was thinking ‘Here is a new ring in the sound of my name to recommend it in her hearing; however—what does it signify now?’
他在想：“这是我名字的新发音，可以在她的听力中推荐它；”然而——现在这意味着什么？

But he said nothing of Bulstrode’s offer to him. Will was very open and careless about his personal affairs, but it was among the more exquisite touches in nature’s modelling of him that he had a delicate generosity which warned him into reticence here. He shrank from saying that he had rejected Bulstrode’s money, in the moment when he was learning that it was Lydgate’s misfortune to have accepted it.
但他对布尔斯特罗德向他提出的提议只字未提。威尔对自己的个人事务非常开放和粗心，但在大自然对他的塑造中，他有一种微妙的慷慨，这也是他在这件事上要保持沉默的微妙之处之一。当他得知利德盖特接受这笔钱是不幸的时候，他不敢说自己拒绝了布尔斯特罗德的钱。

Lydgate too was reticent in the midst of his confidence. He made no allusion to Rosamond’s feeling under their trouble, and of Dorothea he only said, ‘Mrs. Casaubon has been the one person to come forward and say that she had no belief in any of the suspicions against me.’ Observing a change in Will’s face, he avoided any further mention of her, feeling himself too ignorant of their relation to each other not to fear that his words might have some hidden painful bearing on it. And it occurred to him that Dorothea was the real cause of the present visit to Middlemarch.
利德盖特在自信中也保持沉默。他没有提及罗莎蒙德在他们的麻烦下的感受，而谈到多萝西娅，他只说：“夫人。”卡索邦是唯一一个站出来说她不相信针对我的任何怀疑的人。”观察到威尔脸上的变化，他避免进一步提及她，觉得自己对他们之间的关系太无知了。不要担心他的话可能会带来一些隐藏的痛苦影响。他突然想到，多萝西娅才是这次访问米德尔马奇的真正原因。

The two men were pitying each other, but it was only Will who guessed the extent of his companion’s trouble. When Lydgate spoke with desperate resignation of going to settle in London, and said with a faint smile, ‘We shall have you again, old fellow.’ Will felt inexpressibly mournful, and said nothing. Rosamond had that morning entreated him to urge this step on Lydgate; and it seemed to him as if he were beholding in a magic panorama a future where he himself was sliding into that pleasureless yielding to the small solicitations of circumstance, which is a commoner history of perdition than any single momentous bargain.
两个人互相怜悯，但只有威尔猜到了他同伴的麻烦有多大。当利德盖特绝望地放弃去伦敦定居的想法时，他微笑着说：“我们会再次见到你的，老伙计。”威尔感到难以言表的悲伤，但什么也没说。那天早上，罗莎蒙德恳求他敦促对利德盖特采取这一措施；但他拒绝了。在他看来，他仿佛在一幅神奇的全景中看到了一个未来，他自己正在滑入那种无趣的屈服于环境的小诱惑的情况，这是一个比任何重大交易更常见的灭亡历史。

We are on a perilous margin when we begin to look passively at our future selves, and see our own figures led with dull consent into insipid misdoing and shabby achievement. Poor Lydgate was inwardly groaning on that margin, and Will was arriving at it. It seemed to him this evening as if the cruelty of his outburst to Rosamond had made an obligation for him, and he dreaded the obligation: he dreaded Lydgate’s unsuspecting good-will: he dreaded his own distaste for his spoiled life, which would leave him in motiveless levity.
当我们开始被动地审视未来的自己，看到自己的形象在愚钝的同意下犯下乏味的错误行为和卑鄙的成就时，我们就处于危险的边缘。可怜的利德盖特正在内心呻吟，而威尔也快到了。今晚在他看来，他对罗莎蒙德的暴怒似乎对他产生了一种义务，而他害怕这种义务：他害怕利德盖特毫无戒心的善意：他害怕自己对自己被破坏的生活的厌恶，这会让他离开毫无动机的轻浮。

CHAPTER LXXX
第LXXX章

‘Stern lawgiver! yet thou dost wear
‘严厉的立法者！但你却穿着

The Godhead’s most benignant grace;
神性最仁慈的恩典；

Nor know we anything so fair
也不知道我们有什么如此公平

As is the smile upon thy face;
正如你脸上的微笑；

Flowers laugh before thee on their beds,
花儿在你面前在床上笑，

And fragrance in thy footing treads;
你的脚步充满芬芳；

Thou dost preserve the Stars from wrong;
你保护群星免遭错误；

And the most ancient Heavens, through thee, are fresh and strong.
最古老的天堂，通过你，变得新鲜而强大。

—WORDSWORTH: Ode to Duty.
——华兹沃斯：《责任颂》。

When Dorothea had seen Mr. Farebrother in the morning, she had promised to go and dine at the parsonage on her return from Freshitt. There was a frequent interchange of visits between her and the Farebrother family, which enabled her to say that she was not at all lonely at the Manor, and to resist for the present the severe prescription of a lady companion. When she reached home and remembered her engagement, she was glad of it; and finding that she had still an hour before she could dress for dinner, she walked straight to the schoolhouse and entered into a conversation with the master and mistress about the new bell, giving eager attention to their small details and repetitions, and getting up a dramatic sense that her life was very busy. She paused on her way back to talk to old Master Bunney who was putting in some garden-seeds, and discoursed wisely with that rural sage about the crops that would make the most return on a perch of ground, and the result of sixty years’ experience as to soils—namely, that if your soil was pretty mellow it would do, but if there came wet, wet, wet to make it all of a mummy, why then—
当多萝西娅早上见到费雷布拉泽先生时，她答应从弗雷希特回来后去牧师住宅吃饭。她和费雷布拉泽一家经常来往，这使她能够说她在庄园里一点也不孤独，并且暂时抵制了一位女士同伴的严厉规定。当她回到家并想起自己订婚时，她很高兴。发现距离穿好衣服去吃晚饭还有一个小时，她径直走到校舍，与主人和女主人谈论新的钟声，热切地关注他们的小细节和重复，然后起床。戏剧性地感觉她的生活非常忙碌。她在回来的路上停下来，与正在撒一些花园种子的老邦尼大师交谈，并明智地与那位乡村圣人讨论了在栖息地上可以获得最大回报的农作物，以及六十年的结果。关于土壤的经验——也就是说，如果你的土壤相当软，那就可以了，但如果潮湿、潮湿、潮湿，让它变成木乃伊，那为什么——

Finding that the social spirit had beguiled her into being rather late, she dressed hastily and went over to the parsonage rather earlier than was necessary. That house was never dull, Mr. Farebrother, like another White of Selborne, having continually something new to tell of his inarticulate guests and proteges, whom he was teaching the boys not to torment; and he had just set up a pair of beautiful goats to be pets of the village in general, and to walk at large as sacred animals. The evening went by cheerfully till after tea, Dorothea talking more than usual and dilating with Mr. Farebrother on the possible histories of creatures that converse compendiously with their antennae, and for aught we know may hold reformed parliaments; when suddenly some inarticulate little sounds were heard which called everybody’s attention.
她发现社交精神使她迟到了，于是她匆忙穿好衣服，比必要的时间早到了牧师住宅。那所房子从来不乏味，费勒布拉泽先生，就像另一个塞尔伯恩白人一样，不断地有新的事情要告诉他不善言辞的客人和门生，他教导孩子们不要折磨他们；他刚刚养了一对漂亮的山羊作为全村的宠物，并作为神圣的动物自由行走。整个晚上都在愉快地度过，直到喝完茶后，多萝西娅比平时谈得更多，并与费勒布拉泽先生详细讨论了用触角简明地交谈的生物的可能历史，并且我们知道可能会举行改革后的议会；突然，一些含糊不清的小声音响起，引起了所有人的注意。

‘Henrietta Noble,’ said Mrs. Farebrother, seeing her small sister moving about the furniture-legs distressfully, ‘what is the matter?’
“亨利埃塔·诺布尔，”法尔布拉泽太太看到她的小妹妹在家具腿上痛苦地走来走去，说道，“出了什么事？”

‘I have lost my tortoise-shell lozenge-box. I fear the kitten has rolled it away,’ said the tiny old lady, involuntarily coutinuing her beaver-like notes.
“我丢了我的龟甲菱形盒子。我担心小猫把它滚走了。”小老太太说道，不由自主地继续她海狸般的笔记。

‘Is it a great treasure, aunt?’ said Mr. Farebrother, putting up his glasses and looking at the carpet.
“这是一个伟大的宝藏吗，姑妈？”费雷布拉泽先生一边说，一边戴上眼镜，看着地毯。

‘Mr. Ladislaw gave it me,’ said Miss Noble. ‘A German box— very pretty, but if it falls it always spins away as far as it can.’
'先生。拉迪斯瓦夫给了我，”诺布尔小姐说。 “一个德国盒子——非常漂亮，但如果它掉下来，它总是会旋转得尽可能远。”

‘Oh, if it is Ladislaw’s present,’ said Mr. Farebrother, in a deep tone of comprehension, getting up and hunting. The box was found at last under a chiffonier, and Miss Noble grasped it with delight, saying, ‘it was under a fender the last time.’
“哦，如果这是拉迪斯瓦夫的礼物就好了。”费雷布拉泽先生用深沉的理解语气说道，然后站了起来，开始寻找。盒子终于在抽屉柜下被发现了，诺布尔小姐高兴地抓住了它，说道：“上次是在挡泥板下的。”

‘That is an affair of the heart with my aunt,’ said Mr. Farebrother, smiling at Dorothea, as he reseated himself.
“这是我姨妈的心事，”费雷布拉泽先生一边说，一边重新坐下，对多萝西娅微笑着。

‘If Henrietta Noble forms an attachment to any one, Mrs. Casaubon,’ said his mother, emphatically,—‘she is like a dog—she would take their shoes for a pillow and sleep the better.’
“如果亨利埃塔·诺布尔对任何人产生了依恋，卡苏朋夫人，”他的母亲强调道，“她就像一只狗，她会把他们的鞋子当作枕头，这样睡得更好。”

‘Mr. Ladislaw’s shoes, I would,’ said Henrietta Noble.
'先生。拉迪斯拉夫的鞋子，我愿意，”亨利埃塔·诺布尔说。

Dorothea made an attempt at smiling in return. She was surprised and annoyed to find that her heart was palpitating violently, and that it was quite useless to try after a recovery of her former animation. Alarmed at herself—fearing some further betrayal of a change so marked in its occasion, she rose and said in a low voice with undisguised anxiety, ‘I must go; I have overtired myself.’
多萝西娅试图微笑回应。她又惊讶又恼火地发现自己的心脏剧烈地跳动着，恢复了之前的活力之后再尝试也毫无用处。她对自己感到震惊——担心如此显着的变化会遭到进一步的背叛，她站起来，低声说道，毫不掩饰焦虑，“我必须走了；我必须走了。”我自己太累了。

Mr. Farebrother, quick in perception, rose and said, ‘It is true; you must have half-exhausted yourself in talking about Lydgate. That sort of work tells upon one after the excitement is over.’
法尔布拉泽先生反应敏捷，站起来说道：“确实如此；你一定已经在谈论利德盖特时感到疲惫不堪了。这种工作会在兴奋结束后对人产生影响。

He gave her his arm back to the Manor, but Dorothea did not attempt to speak, even when he said good-night.
他把手臂放回庄园，但多萝西娅没有说话，即使他说了晚安。

The limit of resistance was reached, and she had sunk back helpless within the clutch of inescapable anguish. Dismissing Tantripp with a few faint words, she locked her door, and turning away from it towards the vacant room she pressed her hands hard on the top of her head, and moaned out—
抵抗已经到了极限，她无助地陷入了无法逃避的痛苦之中。她淡淡说了几句就打发走了坦特里普，锁上门，转身朝空荡荡的房间走去，双手用力按在头顶上，呻吟出声——

‘Oh, I did love him!’
“哦，我确实爱他！”

Then came the hour in which the waves of suffering shook her too thoroughly to leave any power of thought. She could only cry in loud whispers, between her sobs, after her lost belief which she had planted and kept alive from a very little seed since the days in Rome—after her lost joy of clinging with silent love and faith to one who, misprized by others, was worthy in her thought— after her lost woman’s pride of reigning in his memory—after her sweet dim perspective of hope, that along some pathway they should meet with unchanged recognition and take up the backward years as a yesterday.
接下来的时刻到来了，痛苦的浪潮彻底震撼了她，让她失去了任何思考的能力。她只能在啜泣中低声哭泣，因为她失去了从罗马时代起就用一粒小小的种子种下并保持活力的信仰——因为她失去了以沉默的爱和信仰依附于一个被错失的人的快乐。在她失去的女人在他的记忆中占据统治地位的骄傲之后，在她甜蜜而模糊的希望视角之后，在她看来，在某些道路上，他们应该得到不变的认可，并把过去的岁月当作昨天。

In that hour she repeated what the merciful eyes of solitude have looked on for ages in the spiritual struggles of man— she besought hardness and coldness and aching weariness to bring her relief from the mysterious incorporeal might of her anguish: she lay on the bare floor and let the night grow cold around her; while her grand woman’s frame was shaken by sobs as if she had been a despairing child.
在那一刻，她重复了多年来孤独的仁慈之眼在人类精神斗争中所注视的一切——她祈求坚强、寒冷和痛苦的疲倦，以使她从痛苦的神秘无形力量中解脱出来：她躺在光秃秃的地板上让夜色在她周围变得寒冷；而她的大女人的身躯因抽泣而摇晃，仿佛她是一个绝望的孩子。

There were two images—two living forms that tore her heart in two, as if it had been the heart of a mother who seems to see her child divided by the sword, and presses one bleeding half to her breast while her gaze goes forth in agony towards the half which is carried away by the lying woman that has never known the mother’s pang.
有两个画面——两个活生生的形体，将她的心撕成两半，仿佛母亲的心，似乎看到自己的孩子被剑劈开，将流血的一半压在胸前，目光投向前方。一半的痛苦被那个撒谎的女人带走，而她从来不知道母亲的痛苦。

Here, with the nearness of an answering smile, here within the vibrating bond of mutual speech, was the bright creature whom she had trusted—who had come to her like the spirit of morning visiting the dim vault where she sat as the bride of a worn-out life; and now, with a full consciousness which had never awakened before, she stretched out her arms towards him and cried with bitter cries that their nearness was a parting vision: she discovered her passion to herself in the unshrinking utterance of despair.
在这里，带着回应的微笑，在这里，在相互言语的振动纽带中，是她所信任的聪明的生物——她来到她身边，就像早晨的精灵来到昏暗的拱顶，她坐在那里，作为一个新娘的新娘。疲惫不堪的生活；现在，她带着前所未有的清醒意识，向他伸出双臂，痛苦地哭喊着，他们的靠近是离别的幻象：她在绝望的不屈不挠的话语中发现了她对自己的热情。

And there, aloof, yet persistently with her, moving wherever she moved, was the Will Ladislaw’ who was a changed belief exhausted of hope, a detected illusion—no, a living man towards whom there could not yet struggle any wail of regretful pity, from the midst of scorn and indignation and jealous offended pride. The fire of Dorothea’s anger was not easily spent, and it flamed out in fitful returns of spurning reproach. Why had he come obtruding his life into hers, hers that might have been whole enough without him? Why had he brought his cheap regard and his lip-born words to her who had nothing paltry to give in exchange? He knew that he was deluding her—wished, in the very moment of farewell, to make her believe that he gave her the whole price of her heart, and knew that he had spent it half before. Why had he not stayed among the crowd of whom she asked nothing— but only prayed that they might be less contemptible?
在那里，威尔·拉迪斯拉夫（Will Ladislaw）冷漠而坚定地与她同在，无论她走到哪里，他都是一个改变了的信仰，耗尽了希望，一个被发现的幻觉——不，一个活生生的人，对他还无法挣扎出任何遗憾的怜悯的哀号。 ，来自蔑视、愤慨和嫉妒，冒犯了骄傲。多萝西娅的怒火不容易熄灭，它在断断续续的蔑视责备中熄灭。为什么他要强行闯入她的生活，即使没有他，她的生活也可能很完整？他为什么要对她毫无微不足道的回报，带着廉价的问候和口头上的话语呢？他知道自己在欺骗她——希望在告别的那一刻，让她相信他为她付出了全部的心，并且知道他已经花掉了一半。为什么他不留在人群中，她什么也没要求，只是祈祷他们不要那么可鄙？

But she lost energy at last even for her loud-whispered cries and moans: she subsided into helpless sobs, and on the cold floor she sobbed herself to sleep.
但她最终还是失去了力气，即使她大声呼喊和呻吟：她陷入无助的抽泣中，在冰冷的地板上抽泣着睡着了。

In the chill hours of the morning twilight, when all was dim around her, she awoke—not with any amazed wondering where she was or what had happened, but with the clearest consciousness that she was looking into the eyes of sorrow. She rose, and wrapped warm things around her, and seated
在晨曦中寒冷的时刻，当周围一切都昏暗时，她醒来了——并没有惊讶地想知道自己在哪里或发生了什么事，而是清楚地意识到她正在看着悲伤的眼睛。她站起来，用温暖的东西裹住自己，然后坐下

herself in a great chair where she had often watched before. She was vigorous enough to have borne that hard night without feeling ill in body, beyond some aching and fatigue; but she had waked to a new condition: she felt as if her soul had been liberated from its terrible conflict; she was no longer wrestling with her grief, but could sit down with it as a lasting companion and make it a sharer in her thoughts. For now the thoughts came thickly. It was not in Dorothea’s nature, for longer than the duration of a paroxysm, to sit in the narrow cell of her calamity, in the besotted misery of a consciousness that only sees another’s lot as an accident of its own.
她自己坐在一把大椅子上，她以前经常在那里观看。她精力充沛，熬过了那个艰难的夜晚，身体没有感到任何不适，除了一些疼痛和疲劳之外。但她醒来时发现了一种新的状况：她感觉自己的灵魂似乎已经从可怕的冲突中解放出来了；她不再与悲伤作斗争，而是可以坐下来与它作为永久的伴侣，分享她的思绪。现在思绪纷繁。多萝西娅的天性不会让她在灾难的狭小牢房里待太久，她的意识只把别人的命运看作是自己的偶然事件，陷入了沉迷的痛苦之中。

She began now to live through that yesterday morning deliberately again, forcing herself to dwell on every detail and its possible meaning. Was she alone in that scene? Was it her event only? She forced herself to think of it as bound up with another woman’s life—a woman towards whom she had set out with a longing to carry some clearness and comfort into her beclouded youth. In her first outleap of jealous indignation and disgust, when quitting the hateful room, she had flung away all the mercy with which she had undertaken that visit. She had enveloped both Will and Rosamond in her burning scorn, and it seemed to her as if Rosamond were burned out of her sight forever. But that base prompting which makes a women more cruel to a rival than to a faithless lover, could have no strength of recurrence in Dorothea when the dominant spirit of justice within her had once overcome the tumult and had once shown her the truer measure of things. All the active thought with which she had before been representing to herself the trials of Lydgate’s lot, and this young marriage union which, like her own, seemed to have its hidden as well as evident troubles— all this vivid sympathetic experience returned to her now as a power: it asserted itself as acquired knowledge asserts itself and will not let us see as we saw in the day of our ignorance. She said to her own irremediable grief, that it should make her more helpful, instead of driving her back from effort.
她现在又开始刻意地回忆昨天早上的事情，强迫自己仔细思考每一个细节及其可能的含义。那个场景只有她一个人吗？这是她一个人的活动吗？她强迫自己认为这与另一个女人的生活息息相关——她怀着渴望为她迷茫的青春带来一些清晰和安慰的愿望走向这个女人。当她离开这个可恶的房间时，她第一次爆发出嫉妒、愤慨和厌恶，她抛弃了她这次拜访时所表现出的所有怜悯。她把威尔和罗莎蒙德都笼罩在她炽热的蔑视之中，在她看来，罗莎蒙德似乎永远从她的视线中消失了。但是，当多萝西娅内心占主导地位的正义精神一旦克服了骚乱，并一度向她展示了事物的更真实衡量标准时，那种使女人对情敌比对不忠的情人更残酷的卑鄙冲动就不再有力量在多萝西娅身上重现。 。她以前用所有积极的思想向自己描述利德盖特命运的考验，以及这个年轻的婚姻关系，就像她自己的婚姻一样，似乎有其隐藏的和明显的麻烦——所有这些生动的同情体验现在又回到了她的身上。作为一种力量：它像获得的知识一样主张自己，并且不会让我们看到我们在无知的日子所看到的那样。她对自己无法挽回的悲伤说，这应该让她更有帮助，而不是让她放弃努力。

And what sort of crisis might not this be in three lives whose contact with hers laid an obligation on her as if they had been suppliants bearing the sacred branch? The objects of her rescue were not to be sought out by her fancy: they were chosen for her. She yearned towards the perfect Right, that it might make a throne within her, and rule her errant will. ‘What should I do— how should I act now, this very day, if I could clutch my own pain, and compel it to silence, and think of those three?’
对于三个与她的生命接触的人来说，这不是一场什么样的危机，这三个生命都对她产生了义务，就好像他们是拿着神圣树枝的恳求者一样？拯救她的对象不是凭她的想象来寻找的：它们是为她选择的。她向往完美的右派，希望它能在她内心占据王座，统治她错误的意志。 “如果我能抓住自己的痛苦，强迫它安静下来，并想到那三个人，我现在该怎么办？就在今天，我该怎么办？”

It had taken long for her to come to that question, and there was light piercing into the room. She opened her curtains, and looked out towards the bit of road that lay in view, with fields beyond outside the entrance-gates. On the road there was a man with a bundle on his back and a woman carrying her baby; in the field she could see figures moving—perhaps the shepherd with his dog. Far off in the bending sky was the pearly light; and she felt the largeness of the world and the manifold wakings of men to labor and endurance. She was a part of that involuntary, palpitating life, and could neither look out on it from her luxurious shelter as a mere spectator, nor hide her eyes in selfish complaining.
她花了很长时间才想到这个问题，房间里透进了光。她拉开窗帘，望向眼前的那条路，大门外就是田野。路上有一个背着包袱的男人和一个背着孩子的女人；在田野里，她可以看到有人在移动——也许是牧羊人和他的狗。远处弯曲的天空中闪烁着珍珠般的光芒；她感受到了世界的广阔以及人们对劳动和忍耐力的多方面觉醒。她是那不由自主的、令人心悸的生活的一部分，她既不能在豪华的住所里作为一个旁观者观看它，也不能掩饰自己的眼睛自私的抱怨。

What she would resolve to do that day did not yet seem quite clear, but something that she could achieve stirred her as with an approaching murmur which would soon gather distinctness. She took off the clothes which seemed to have some of the weariness of a hard watching in them, and began to make her toilet. Presently she rang for Tantripp, who came in her dressing-gown.
那天她决定做什么似乎还不太清楚，但她能实现的某件事让她兴奋不已，就像一种即将到来的低语一样，很快就会变得清晰。她脱下身上似乎有些看守的疲倦的衣服，开始洗漱。不久，她按铃叫坦特里普，他穿着晨衣进来了。

‘Why, madam, you’ve never been in bed this blessed night,’ burst out Tantripp, looking first at the bed and then at Dorothea’s face, which in spite of bathing had the pale cheeks and pink eyelids of a mater dolorosa. ‘You’ll kill yourself, you WILL. Anybody might think now you had a right to give yourself a little comfort.’
“为什么，夫人，在这个幸福的夜晚，你从来没有上过床。”坦特里普突然说道，他先看看床，然后看看多萝西娅的脸，尽管洗过澡，她的脸颊还是苍白的，眼睑是粉红色的，就像一位痛苦的母亲。 ‘你会自杀，你会的。任何人都可能认为你现在有权给自己一点安慰。

‘Don’t be alarmed, Tantripp,’ said Dorothea, smiling. ‘I have slept; I am not ill. I shall be glad of a cup of coffee as soon as possible. And I want you to bring me my new dress; and most likely I shall want my new bonnet to-day.’
“别惊慌，坦特里普，”多萝西娅微笑着说。 ‘我已经睡了；我没有病。我会很高兴尽快喝杯咖啡。我要你给我带来我的新衣服；很可能我今天就会想要我的新帽子。

‘They’ve lain there a month and more ready for you, madam, and most thankful I shall be to see you with a couple o’ pounds’ worth less of crape,’ said Tantripp, stooping to light the fire. ‘There’s a reason in mourning, as I’ve always said; and three folds at the bottom of your skirt and a plain quilling in your bonnet— and if ever anybody looked like an angel, it’s you in a net quilling— is what’s consistent for a second year. At least, that’s MY thinking,’ ended Tantripp, looking anxiously at the fire; ‘and if anybody was to marry me flattering himself I should wear those hijeous weepers two years for him, he’d be deceived by his own vanity, that’s all.’
“夫人，它们已经在那里放了一个月多了，为您准备好了，最让我感激的是，我会很感激地看到您拿着价值几英镑的黑纱，”坦特里普说，弯腰生火。 “正如我常说的，哀悼是有原因的；裙子底部有三层褶皱，帽子上有朴素的羽绒服——如果有人看起来像天使，那就是戴着网状羽绒服的你——这是第二年的一贯风格。至少，我是这么想的。”坦特里普焦急地看着火，最后说道。 “如果有人要娶我来奉承自己，我应该为他穿那些可恶的哭泣者两年，他会被自己的虚荣心所欺骗，仅此而已。”

‘The fire will do, my good Tan,’ said Dorothea, speaking as she used to do in the old Lausanne days, only with a very low voice; ‘get me the coffee.’
“生火就可以了，我的好谭，”多萝西娅说道，就像过去洛桑的日子一样，只是声音很低。 “给我拿杯咖啡。”

She folded herself in the large chair, and leaned her head against it in fatigued quiescence, while Tantripp went away wondering at this strange contrariness in her young mistress—that just the morning when she had more of a widow’s face than ever, she should have asked for her lighter mourning which she had waived before. Tantripp would never have found the clew to this mystery. Dorothea wished to acknowledge that she had not the less an active life before her because she had buried a private joy; and the tradition that fresh garments belonged to all initiation, haunting her mind, made her grasp after even that slight outward help towards calm resolve. For the resolve was not easy.
她把自己折叠在大椅子上，疲倦地把头靠在上面，一言不发，而坦特里普走开时，对她年轻女主人身上这种奇怪的矛盾感到惊讶——就在那天早上，当她的脸比以往任何时候都更像寡妇时，她应该要求减轻她之前放弃的哀悼。坦特里普永远不会找到这个谜团的线索。多萝西娅希望承认，她面前的生活依然充满活力，因为她埋葬了私人的快乐。干净的衣服属于所有入会仪式的传统，萦绕在她的脑海中，使她在即使是轻微的外在帮助之后也能平静地下定决心。因为这个决心并不容易。

Nevertheless at eleven o’clock she was walking towards Middlemarch, having made up her mind that she would make as quietly and unnoticeably as possible her second attempt to see and save Rosamond.
尽管如此，十一点钟她还是朝米德尔马奇走去，并决定尽可能安静地、不引人注意地第二次尝试去见并拯救罗莎蒙德。

CHAPTER LXXXI
第LXXXI章

‘Du Erde warst auch diese Nacht bestandig,
“Du Erde warst auch diese Nacht bestandig，

Und athmest neu erquickt zu meinen Fussen,
和 athmest neu erquickt zu meinen Fussen,

Beginnest schon mit Lust mich zu umgeben,
Zum regst und ruhrst ein kraftiges Reschliessen
规则和规则

Zum hochsten Dasein immerfort zu streben.
Zum hochsten Dasein immerfort zu streben。

—Faust: 2r Theil.
——浮士德：2r泰尔。

When Dorothea was again at Lydgate’s door speaking to Martha, he was in the room close by with the door ajar, preparing to go out. He heard her voice, and immediately came to her.
当多萝西娅再次来到利德盖特门口与玛莎说话时，他正在附近的房间里，门半开着，准备出去。他听到她的声音，立刻来到她身边。

‘Do you think that Mrs. Lydgate can receive me this morning?’ she said, having reflected that it would be better to leave out all allusion to her previous visit.
“你认为利德盖特夫人今天早上可以接待我吗？”她说，考虑到最好不要提到她上次来访的情况。

‘I have no doubt she will,’ said Lydgate, suppressing his thought about Dorothea’s looks, which were as much changed as Rosamond’s, ‘if you will be kind enough to come in and let me tell her that you are here. She has not been very well since you were here yesterday, but she is better this morning, and I think it is very likely that she will be cheered by seeing you again.’
“我毫不怀疑她会的，”利德盖特说，抑制住自己对多萝西娅外表的想法，她的外表和罗莎蒙德的变化一样大，“如果你能好心进来，让我告诉她你在这里。”自从你昨天来这里以来，她的身体一直不太好，但今天早上她好多了，我想她很可能会因为再次见到你而感到高兴。”

It was plain that Lydgate, as Dorothea had expected, knew nothing about the circumstances of her yesterday’s visit; nay, he appeared to imagine that she had carried it out according to her intention. She had prepared a little note asking Rosamond to see her, which she would have given to the servant if he had not been in the way, but now she was in much anxiety as to the result of his announcement.
显然，正如多萝西娅所料，利德盖特对她昨天来访的情况一无所知。不仅如此，他似乎还以为她是按照自己的意图去做的。她准备了一张小纸条，请罗莎蒙德见她，如果仆人不妨碍的话，她会把这张纸条交给仆人，但现在她对他宣布的结果感到非常焦虑。

After leading her into the drawing-room, he paused to take a letter from his pocket and put it into her hands, saying, ‘I wrote this last night, and was going to carry it to Lowick in my ride. When one is grateful for something too good for common thanks, writing is less unsatisfactory than speech one does not at least HEAR how inadequate the words are.’
领着她走进客厅后，他停下来，从口袋里掏出一封信，塞到她手里，说道：“这是我昨晚写的，准备乘车去洛威克。”当一个人对某件事的感激之情超出了普通人的感谢时，写作比演讲更令人满意，人们至少不会听到言语有多么不足。

Dorothea’s face brightened. ‘It is I who have most to thank for, since you have let me take that place. You HAVE consented?’ she said, suddenly doubting.
多萝西娅的脸变得明亮起来。 ‘最要感谢的是我，因为你让我占据了那个位置。你同意了吗？”她突然疑惑地说。

‘Yes, the check is going to Bulstrode to-day.’
“是的，支票今天将寄往布尔斯特罗德。”

He said no more, but went up-stairs to Rosamond, who had but lately finished dressing herself, and sat languidly wondering what she should do next, her habitual industry in small things, even in the days of her sadness, prompting her to begin some kind of occupation, which she dragged through slowly or paused in from lack of interest. She looked ill, but had recovered her usual quietude of manner, and Lydgate had feared to disturb her by any questions. He had told her of Dorothea’s letter containing the check, and afterwards he had said, ‘Ladislaw is come, Rosy; he sat with me last night; I dare say he will be here again to-day. I thought he looked rather battered and depressed.’ And Rosamond had made no reply.
他不再说话，而是上楼去找罗莎蒙德，罗莎蒙德最近才穿好衣服，懒洋洋地坐着，想知道她下一步应该做什么，她习惯于做小事，即使在她悲伤的日子里，也促使她开始做事。某种职业，她拖得很慢，或者因为缺乏兴趣而暂停。她看起来病了，但已经恢复了平常的安静态度，利德盖特害怕任何问题打扰她。他告诉她多萝西娅的信里有支票，后来他说：“拉迪斯瓦来了，罗西；昨晚他和我坐在一起；我敢说他今天会再次来到这里。我觉得他看起来很疲惫，很沮丧。”罗莎蒙德没有做出任何回应。

Now, when he came up, he said to her very gently, ‘Rosy, dear, Mrs. Casaubon is come to see you again; you would like to see her, would you not?’ That she colored and gave rather a startled movement did not surprise him after the agitation produced by the interview yesterday—a beneficent agitation, he thought, since it seemed to have made her turn to him again.
现在，当他走过来时，他非常温柔地对她说：“罗西，亲爱的，卡苏邦夫人又来看你了；你要知道吗？”你想见见她，不是吗？”在昨天的采访引起的骚动之后，她的脸色变得苍白，做出了一个相当惊讶的动作，这并没有让他感到惊讶——他想，这是一种善意的激动，因为这似乎让她转向了又是他。

Rosamond dared not say no. She dared not with a tone of her voice touch the facts of yesterday. Why had Mrs. Casaubon come again? The answer was a blank which Rosamond could only fill up with dread, for Will Ladislaw’s lacerating words had made every thought of Dorothea a fresh smart to her. Nevertheless, in her new humiliating uncertainty she dared do nothing but comply. She did not say yes, but she rose and let Lydgate put a light shawl over her shoulders, while he said, ‘I am going out immediately.’ Then something crossed her mind which prompted her to say, ‘Pray tell Martha not to bring any one else into the drawing-room.’ And Lydgate assented, thinking that he fully understood this wish. He led her down to the drawing-room door, and then turned away, observing to himself that he was rather a blundering husband to be dependent for his wife’s trust in him on the influence of another woman.
罗莎蒙德不敢拒绝。她的语气不敢触及昨天的事实。卡苏朋夫人为什么又来了？答案是一片空白，罗莎蒙德只能用恐惧来填补，因为威尔·拉迪斯洛的撕心裂肺的话语让她对多萝西娅的每一个想法都变得新鲜。然而，在她新的令人羞辱的不确定性中，她除了服从之外什么也不敢做。她没有答应，但她站了起来，让利德盖特在她肩上披了一条轻薄的披肩，而他则说：“我马上出去。”然后她的脑海里闪过一件事，促使她说：“请告诉玛莎不要带上。”利德盖特同意了，他认为自己完全理解这个愿望。他领着她走到客厅门口，然后转身走开，心想自己是一个相当笨拙的丈夫，妻子对他的信任依赖于另一个女人的影响。

Rosamond, wrapping her soft shawl around her as she walked towards Dorothea, was inwardly wrapping her soul in cold reserve. Had Mrs. Casaubon come to say anything to her about Will? If so, it was a liberty that Rosamond resented; and she prepared herself to meet every word with polite impassibility. Will had bruised her pride too sorely for her to feel any compunction towards him and Dorothea: her own injury seemed much the greater. Dorothea was not only the ‘preferred’ woman, but had also a formidable advantage in being Lydgate’s benefactor; and to poor Rosamond’s pained confused vision it seemed that this Mrs. Casaubon— this woman who predominated in all things concerning her—must have come now with the sense of having the advantage, and with animosity prompting her to use it. Indeed, not Rosamond only, but any one else, knowing the outer facts of the case, and not the simple inspiration on which Dorothea acted, might well have wondered why she came.
罗莎蒙德裹着柔软的围巾，向多萝西娅走去，内心却将她的灵魂包裹在冰冷的保留之中。卡苏朋夫人来找她是想跟她说一些关于威尔的事情吗？如果是这样，罗莎蒙德就讨厌这种自由。她准备好以礼貌、冷漠的态度对待每一个字。威尔深深地伤害了她的自尊心，以至于她对他和多萝西娅没有任何愧疚：她自己受到的伤害似乎更大。多萝西娅不仅是“首选”的女人，而且作为利德盖特的恩人也拥有巨大的优势。在可怜的罗莎蒙德痛苦而混乱的视野中，这位卡苏邦夫人——这个在与她有关的所有事情上都占主导地位的女人——现在一定是带着一种拥有优势的感觉而来，并且带着敌意促使她利用它。事实上，不仅是罗莎蒙德，任何其他人，如果了解案件的外部事实，而不是多萝西娅采取行动的简单灵感，很可能会想知道她为什么来。

Looking like the lovely ghost of herself, her graceful slimness wrapped in her soft white shawl, the rounded infantine mouth and cheek inevitably suggesting mildness and innocence, Rosamond paused at three yards’ distance from her visitor and bowed. But Dorothea, who had taken off her gloves, from an impulse which she could never resist when she wanted a sense of freedom, came forward, and with her face full of a sad yet sweet openness, put out her hand. Rosamond could not avoid meeting her glance, could not avoid putting her small hand into Dorothea’s, which clasped it with gentle motherliness; and immediately a doubt of her own prepossessions began to stir within her. Rosamond’s eye was quick for faces; she saw that Mrs. Casaubon’s face looked pale and changed since yesterday, yet gentle, and like the firm softness of her hand. But Dorothea had counted a little too much on her own strength: the clearness and intensity of her mental action this morning were the continuance of a nervous exaltation which made her frame as dangerously responsive as a bit of finest Venetian crystal; and in looking at Rosamond, she suddenly found her heart swelling, and was unable to speak—all her effort was required to keep back tears. She succeeded in that, and the emotion only passed over her face like the spirit of a sob; but it added to Rosamond’s impression that Mrs. Casaubon’s state of mind must be something quite different from what she had imagined.
罗莎蒙德看起来就像是她自己可爱的鬼魂，柔软的白色披肩包裹着她优雅的苗条，婴儿般的圆润的嘴唇和脸颊不可避免地暗示着温和和天真，罗莎蒙德在距离她的访客三码远的地方停了下来，鞠了一躬。但多萝西娅脱下了手套，出于想要自由感时无法抗拒的冲动，她走上前来，脸上充满悲伤而甜蜜的开放，伸出了手。罗莎蒙德无法避免与她的目光对视，无法避免将她的小手放入多萝西娅的手中，多萝西娅以温柔的母性紧握着她的手。她的内心立刻开始对自己的先入之见产生了怀疑。罗莎蒙德的眼睛很快就能辨认出面孔。她看到卡苏朋夫人的脸色从昨天起就变得苍白、变了，但依然温柔，就像她的手一样坚定而柔软。但多萝西娅对自己的力量有些过于依赖了：今天早上她精神活动的清晰和强烈是一种神经兴奋的持续，这使她的身体像一块最好的威尼斯水晶一样危险地反应;看着罗莎蒙德，她突然发现自己的心在膨胀，说不出话来——她用尽全力才忍住泪水。她成功了，但情绪却像抽泣一样从她脸上掠过。但这更让罗莎蒙德觉得卡苏朋夫人的心境一定与她想象的完全不同。

So they sat down without a word of preface on the two chairs that happened to be nearest, and happened also to be close together; though Rosamond’s notion when she first bowed was that she should stay a long way off from Mrs. Casaubon. But she ceased thinking how anything would turn out—merely wondering what would come. And Dorothea began to speak quite simply, gathering firmness as she went on.
于是，他们二话不说，就坐在了最近的、也靠得很近的两张椅子上。尽管罗莎蒙德第一次鞠躬时的想法是她应该远离卡苏邦夫人。但她不再思考事情会如何发展——只是想知道会发生什么。多萝西娅开始说得很简单，越说越坚定。

‘I had an errand yesterday which I did not finish; that is why I am here again so soon. You will not think me too troublesome when I tell you that I came to talk to you about the injustice that has been shown towards Mr. Lydgate. It will cheer you—will it not?— to know a great deal about him, that he may not like to speak about himself just because it is in his own vindication and to his own honor. You will like to know that your husband has warm friends, who have not left off believing in his high character? You will let me speak of this without thinking that I take a liberty?’
“我昨天有件事没有完成；这就是为什么我这么快又来到这里。当我告诉你我来找你谈论利德盖特先生遭受的不公正待遇时，你不会认为我太麻烦了。如果你对他有很多了解，你会很高兴——不是吗？——他可能不喜欢仅仅因为这是为了他自己的辩护和他自己的荣誉而谈论自己。您想知道您的丈夫有热情的朋友，他们一直相信他的高尚品格吗？你会让我谈论这件事而不认为我冒昧吗？

The cordial, pleading tones which seemed to flow with generous heedlessness above all the facts which had filled Rosamond’s mind as grounds of obstruction and hatred between her and this woman, came as soothingly as a warm stream over her shrinking fears. Of course Mrs. Casaubon had the facts in her mind, but she was not going to speak of anything connected with them. That relief was too great for Rosamond to feel much else at the moment. She answered prettily, in the new ease of her soul—
亲切、恳求的语气似乎流淌着慷慨的疏忽，超越了罗莎蒙德脑海中充满的所有事实，这些事实是她和这个女人之间的阻碍和仇恨的理由，就像一股温暖的溪流抚平了她不断缩小的恐惧。卡苏朋夫人当然心里有数，但她不会谈论与这些事实有关的任何事情。这种解脱让罗莎蒙德此刻没有太多其他感觉。她带着新的轻松心情，漂亮地回答道——

‘I know you have been very good. I shall like to hear anything you will say to me about Tertius.’
‘我知道你一直很好。我很想听听你对我说的关于特蒂乌斯的任何事情。

‘The day before yesterday,’ said Dorothea, ‘when I had asked him to come to Lowick to give me his opinion on the affairs of the Hospital, he told me everything about his conduct and feelings in this sad event which has made ignorant people cast suspicions on him. The reason he told me was because I was very bold and asked him. I believed that he had never acted dishonorably, and I begged him to tell me the history. He confessed to me that he had never told it before, not even to you, because he had a great dislike to say, ‘I was not wrong,’ as if that were proof, when there are guilty people who will say so. The truth is, he knew nothing of this man Raffles, or that there were any bad secrets about him; and he thought that Mr. Bulstrode offered him the money because he repented, out of kindness, of having refused it before. All his anxiety about his patient was to treat him rightly, and he was a little uncomfortable that the case did not end as he had expected; but he thought then and still thinks that there may have been no wrong in it on any one’s part. And I have told Mr. Farebrother, and Mr. Brooke, and Sir James Chettam: they all believe in your husband. That will cheer you, will it not? That will give you courage?’
“前天，”多萝西娅说，“当我请他来洛威克就医院事务发表意见时，他告诉了我他在这起让无知的人们感到悲伤的事件中的一切行为和感受。对他产生怀疑。他之所以告诉我，是因为我很大胆地问了他。我相信他从未有过不光彩的行为，我恳求他告诉我这段历史。他向我承认，他以前从未告诉过这件事，甚至没有告诉过你，因为他非常不喜欢说“我没有错”，仿佛这就是证据，而有罪的人会这么说。事实上，他对莱佛士这个人一无所知，也不知道他有什么不好的秘密。他认为布尔斯特罗德先生之所以愿意给他这笔钱，是因为他出于善意而后悔之前拒绝了这笔钱。他对病人的所有焦虑都是为了正确地对待他，而案子并没有按照他预想的那样结束，他有点不舒服；但他当时想，现在仍然认为，这件事可能没有任何人有错。我已经告诉法尔布拉泽先生、布鲁克先生和詹姆斯·切塔姆爵士：他们都相信你的丈夫。这会让你高兴，不是吗？这会给你勇气吗？

Dorothea’s face had become animated, and as it beamed on Rosamond very close to her, she felt something like bashful timidity before a superior, in the presence of this self-forgetful ardor. She said, with blushing embarrassment, ‘Thank you: you are very kind.’
多萝西娅的脸变得生动起来，当它微笑着照在离她很近的罗莎蒙德身上时，在这种忘我的热情面前，她感到一种在上级面前害羞的胆怯。她尴尬地红着脸说道：“谢谢你，你真是太好了。”

‘And he felt that he had been so wrong not to pour out everything about this to you. But you will forgive him. It was because he feels so much more about your happiness than anything else— he feels his life bound into one with yours, and it hurts him more than anything, that his misfortunes must hurt you. He could speak to me because I am an indifferent person. And then I asked him if I might come to see you; because I felt so much for his trouble and yours. That is why I came yesterday, and why I am come to-day. Trouble is so hard to bear, is it not?— How can we live and think that any one has trouble—piercing trouble— and we could help them, and never try?’
“他觉得自己没有向你倾诉所有关于这件事的事情是非常错误的。”但你会原谅他的。这是因为他对你的幸福的感受比其他任何事情都多——他觉得他的生活与你的生活紧密相连，而他的不幸也必然会伤害你，这对他来说比任何事都更痛苦。他可以和我说话，因为我是一个冷漠的人。然后我问他我是否可以来看你；因为我对他和你的麻烦感到非常难过。这就是我昨天来的原因，也是我今天来的原因。麻烦是如此难以忍受，不是吗？——我们怎么能生活并认为任何人遇到麻烦——刺痛的麻烦——我们可以帮助他们，却从不尝试呢？

Dorothea, completely swayed by the feeling that she was uttering, forgot everything but that she was speaking from out the heart of her own trial to Rosamond’s. The emotion had wrought itself more and more into her utterance, till the tones might have gone to one’s very marrow, like a low cry from some suffering creature in the darkness. And she had unconsciously laid her hand again on the little hand that she had pressed before.
多萝西娅完全被自己所说的感觉所左右，忘记了一切，只记得她是出于自己对罗莎蒙德的考验而说的。她的言语中的情绪越来越强烈，直到语调深入骨髓，就像黑暗中某个受苦生物的低声哭泣。而她的手，又不自觉的放到了之前压着的小手上。

Rosamond, with an overmastering pang, as if a wound within her had been probed, burst into hysterical crying as she had done the day before when she clung to her husband. Poor Dorothea was feeling a great wave of her own sorrow returning over her— her thought being drawn to the possible share that Will Ladislaw might have in Rosamond’s mental tumult. She was beginning to fear that she should not be able to suppress herself enough to the end of this meeting, and while her hand was still resting on Rosamond’s lap, though the hand underneath it was withdrawn, she was struggling against her own rising sobs. She tried to master herself with the thought that this might be a turning-point in three lives— not in her own; no, there the irrevocable had happened, but— in those three lives which were touching hers with the solemn neighborhood of danger and distress. The fragile creature who was crying close to her—there might still be time to rescue her from the misery of false incompatible bonds; and this moment was unlike any other: she and Rosamond could never be together again with the same thrilling consciousness of yesterday within them both. She felt the relation between them to be peculiar enough to give her a peculiar influence, though she had no conception that the way in which her own feelings were involved was fully known to Mrs. Lydgate.
罗莎蒙德感到一阵难以忍受的剧痛，仿佛内心的伤口已被探查出来，突然歇斯底里地哭了起来，就像前一天她紧紧抓住丈夫时那样。可怜的多萝西娅感到自己的悲伤再次涌上心头——她的思绪被威尔·拉迪斯拉夫可能在罗莎蒙德的精神混乱中所扮演的角色所吸引。她开始担心自己无法压抑自己到会议结束，虽然她的手仍然放在罗莎蒙德的腿上，但下面的手已经缩回了，但她却在挣扎着抑制自己不断上升的抽泣。她试图控制自己，认为这可能是她三个人生的转折点——不是她自己的转折点；而是她自己的转折点。不，不可挽回的事情已经发生了，但是——在这三个生命中，她的生命充满了危险和痛苦的庄严邻里。这个在她身边哭泣的脆弱生物——也许还有时间把她从虚假的不相容关系的痛苦中拯救出来；这一刻与众不同：她和罗莎蒙德再也不能在一起了，两人内心都怀着昨天同样令人兴奋的意识。她觉得他们之间的关系很奇怪，足以给她带来一种特殊的影响，尽管她不知道利德盖特夫人完全了解她自己的感受。

It was a newer crisis in Rosamond’s experience than even Dorothea could imagine: she was under the first great shock that had shattered her dream-world in which she had been easily confident of herself and critical of others; and this strange unexpected manifestation of feeling in a woman whom she had approached with a shrinking aversion and dread, as one who must necessarily have a jealous hatred towards her, made her soul totter all the more with a sense that she had been walking in an unknown world which had just broken in upon her.
罗莎蒙德的经历中，这是一场比多萝西娅想象的更新的危机：她第一次受到巨大的冲击，这粉碎了她的梦想世界，在这个世界里，她很容易对自己充满信心，对别人也很挑剔；她的梦想世界被打破了。她带着一种逐渐减弱的厌恶和恐惧接近一个女人，因为她必然对她怀有嫉妒的仇恨，这种奇怪的、出乎意料的感情表现，让她的灵魂更加颤抖，感觉自己一直在走着一条不归路。未知的世界刚刚闯入她的内心。

When Rosamond’s convulsed throat was subsiding into calm, and she withdrew the handkerchief with which she had been hiding her face, her eyes met Dorothea’s as helplessly as if they had been blue flowers. What was the use of thinking about behavior after this crying? And Dorothea looked almost as childish, with the neglected trace of a silent tear. Pride was broken down between these two.
当罗莎蒙德抽搐的喉咙渐渐平静下来，抽出遮住脸的手帕时，她的眼睛像蓝色的花朵一样无助地与多萝西娅的眼睛相遇。哭完之后再思考行为有什么用呢？多萝西娅看起来几乎同样孩子气，脸上隐隐约约流着一滴无声的泪水。两人之间的骄傲被打破了。

‘We were talking about your husband,’ Dorothea said, with some timidity. ‘I thought his looks were sadly changed with suffering the other day. I had not seen him for many weeks before. He said he had been feeling very lonely in his trial; but I think he would have borne it all better if he had been able to be quite open with you.’
“我们正在谈论你的丈夫，”多萝西娅有些胆怯地说。 “我认为他的容貌因前几天的痛苦而发生了悲伤的变化。我已经好几个星期没见过他了。他说他在审判中感到非常孤独；但我认为，如果他能够对你开诚布公的话，他会更好地忍受这一切。

‘Tertius is so angry and impatient if I say anything,’ said Rosamond, imagining that he had been complaining of her to Dorothea. ‘He ought not to wonder that I object to speak to him on painful subjects.’
“如果我说什么，特蒂斯就会非常生气和不耐烦，”罗莎蒙德说道，想象着他一直在向多萝西娅抱怨她。 “他不应该奇怪我反对与他谈论痛苦的话题。”

‘It was himself he blamed for not speaking,’ said Dorothea. ‘What he said of you was, that he could not be happy in doing anything which made you unhappy—that his marriage was of course a bond which must affect his choice about everything; and for that reason he refused my proposal that he should keep his position at the Hospital, because that would bind him to stay in Middlemarch, and he would not undertake to do anything which would be painful to you. He could say that to me, because he knows that I had much trial in my marriage, from my husband’s illness, which hindered his plans and saddened him; and he knows that I have felt how hard it is to walk always in fear of hurting another who is tied to us.’
“他责怪自己没有说话，”多萝西娅说。 “他对你的评价是，他不会因为做任何让你不高兴的事情而感到高兴——他的婚姻当然是一种纽带，必然会影响他对一切的选择；出于这个原因，他拒绝了我的建议，即他应该保留在医院的职位，因为这将使他必须留在米德尔马奇，而且他不会承诺做任何会让你痛苦的事情。他可以对我这么说，因为他知道我的婚姻经历了很多考验，因为我丈夫的病，阻碍了他的计划，让他感到悲伤；他知道我已经感受到走路是多么困难，总是害怕伤害与我们联系在一起的另一个人。

Dorothea waited a little; she had discerned a faint pleasure stealing over Rosamond’s face. But there was no answer, and she went on, with a gathering tremor, ‘Marriage is so unlike everything else. There is something even awful in the nearness it brings. Even if we loved some one else better than—than those we were married to, it would be no use’—poor Dorothea, in her palpitating anxiety, could only seize her language brokenly—‘I mean, marriage drinks up all our power of giving or getting any blessedness in that sort of love. I know it may be very dear—but it murders our marriage— and then the marriage stays with us like a murder—and everything else is gone. And then our husband—if he loved and trusted us, and we have not helped him, but made a curse in his life—‘
多萝西娅等了一会儿。她察觉到罗莎蒙德的脸上掠过一丝淡淡的快乐。但没有得到回答，她继续说道，浑身颤抖不已，“婚姻与其他一切都不同。”它带来的亲近感甚至有些可怕。即使我们比——比那些我们结婚的人更爱别人，那也是没有用的”——可怜的多萝西娅，在她心悸的焦虑中，只能破碎地抓住她的语言——“我的意思是，婚姻耗尽了我们所有的力量。在这种爱中给予或获得任何祝福。我知道它可能非常昂贵——但它谋杀了我们的婚姻——然后婚姻就像一场谋杀一样留在我们身边——而其他一切都消失了。然后我们的丈夫——如果他爱我们、信任我们，而我们没有帮助他，反而诅咒了他——”

Her voice had sunk very low: there was a dread upon her of presuming too far, and of speaking as if she herself were perfection addressing error. She was too much preoccupied with her own anxiety, to be aware that Rosamond was trembling too; and filled with the need to express pitying fellowship rather than rebuke, she put her hands on Rosamond’s, and said with more agitated rapidity,—‘I know, I know that the feeling may be very dear—it has taken hold of us unawares—it is so hard, it may seem like death to part with it—and we are weak—I am weak—‘
她的声音很低：她害怕假设太过分，害怕说得好像她自己在解决错误时是完美的一样。她太专注于自己的焦虑，没有意识到罗莎蒙德也在发抖。她充满了表达怜悯的友谊而不是责备的需要，她把手放在罗莎蒙德的手上，并以更加激动的速度说道，“我知道，我知道这种感觉可能非常珍贵——它已经在不知不觉中抓住了我们——它太难了，与它分开似乎就像死亡——而我们很弱——我很弱——”

The waves of her own sorrow, from out of which she was struggling to save another, rushed over Dorothea with conquering force. She stopped in speechless agitation. not crying, but feeling as if she were being inwardly grappled. Her face had become of a deathlier paleness, her lips trembled, and she pressed her hands helplessly on the hands that lay under them.
她自己的悲伤的波浪，她正努力从悲伤中拯救另一个人，以征服的力量冲向多萝西娅。她激动得说不出话来。没有哭，只是感觉内心好像被揪住了一样。她的脸色变得更加苍白，嘴唇颤抖着，双手无助地按在了身下的双手上。

Rosamond, taken hold of by an emotion stronger than her own— hurried along in a new movement which gave all things some new, awful, undefined aspect—could find no words, but involuntarily she put her lips to Dorothea’s forehead which was very near her, and then for a minute the two women clasped each other as if they had been in a shipwreck.
罗莎蒙德被一种比她自己更强烈的情感所控制——以一种新的动作匆忙前行，这给一切带来了新的、可怕的、不确定的面貌——找不到言语，但她不由自主地把嘴唇贴在离她很近的多萝西娅的额头上。 ，然后有那么一分钟，两个女人紧紧地抱在一起，就像是在海难中一样。

‘You are thinking what is not true,’ said Rosamond, in an eager half-whisper, while she was still feeling Dorothea’s arms round her— urged by a mysterious necessity to free herself from something that oppressed her as if it were blood guiltiness.
“你在想什么不是真的，”罗莎蒙德急切地低声说道，同时她仍然感觉到多萝西娅的手臂搂着她——一种神秘的必要性催促着她摆脱那些压迫她的东西，就好像它是血统的罪孽一样。

They moved apart, looking at each other.
他们分开，互相看着对方。

‘When you came in yesterday—it was not as you thought,’ said Rosamond in the same tone.
“昨天你进来的时候——事情并不像你想象的那样，”罗莎蒙德用同样的语气说道。

There was a movement of surprised attention in Dorothea She expected a vindication of Rosamond herself.
多萝西娅露出了惊讶的神情，她期待着罗莎蒙德本人的平反。

‘He was telling me how he loved another woman, that I might know he could never love me,’ said Rosamond, getting more and more hurried as she went on. ‘And now I think he hates me because— because you mistook him yesterday. He says it is through me that you will think ill of him—think that he is a false person. But it shall not be through me. He has never had any love for me— I know he has not—he has always thought slightly of me. He said yesterday that no other woman existed for him beside you. The blame of what happened is entirely mine. He said he could never explain to you—because of me. He said you could never think well of him again. But now I have told you, and he cannot reproach me any more.’
“他告诉我他如何爱另一个女人，这样我就知道他永远不会爱我，”罗莎蒙德说，她说得越来越急。 “现在我认为他恨我是因为——因为你昨天误会了他。他说通过我你就会对他产生不好的看法——认为他是一个虚伪的人。但这不会通过我。他从来没有爱过我——我知道他没有——他总是轻视我。他昨天说除了你之外他不存在其他女人。发生的事情的责任完全是我的。他说他永远无法向你解释——因为我。他说你再也不能看好他了。但现在我已经告诉你了，他不能再责备我了。”

Rosamond had delivered her soul under impulses which she had not known before. She had begun her confession under the subduing influence of Dorothea’s emotion; and as she went on she had gathered the sense that she was repelling Will’s reproaches, which were still like a knife-wound within her.
罗莎蒙德在她以前不知道的冲动下释放了她的灵魂。她是在多萝西娅的情绪的压抑下开始忏悔的。当她继续说下去时，她感觉到自己正在排斥威尔的责备，这些责备仍然像刀伤一样留在她心里。

The revulsion of feeling in Dorothea was too strong to be called joy. It was a tumult in which the terrible strain of the night and morning made a resistant pain:—she could only perceive that this would be joy when she had recovered her power of feeling it. Her immediate consciousness was one of immense sympathy without cheek; she cared for Rosamond without struggle now, and responded earnestly to her last words—
多萝西娅内心的厌恶感太强烈了，不能称之为喜悦。这是一场骚乱，夜晚和早晨的可怕压力造成了一种难以忍受的疼痛：——只有当她恢复了感觉的能力时，她才能意识到这将是一种快乐。她的第一反应是一种毫不厚脸皮的巨大同情。她现在毫无挣扎地照顾着罗莎蒙德，并认真地回应着她的遗言——

‘No, he cannot reproach you any more.’
“不，他不能再责备你了。”

With her usual tendency to over-estimate the good in others, she felt a great outgoing of her heart towards Rosamond, for the generous effort which had redeemed her from suffering, not counting that the effort was a reflex of her own energy. After they had been silent a little, she said—
由于她通常倾向于高估别人的优点，她对罗莎蒙德感到一种强烈的感情，因为她慷慨的努力将她从痛苦中解救出来，更不用说这种努力是她自己能量的反射。两人沉默了一会儿后，她说道——

‘You are not sorry that I came this morning?’
“你对我今天早上来不感到遗憾吗？”

‘No, you have been very good to me,’ said Rosamond. ‘I did not think that you would be so good. I was very unhappy. I am not happy now. Everything is so sad.’
“不，你对我很好，”罗莎蒙德说。 ‘我没想到你会这么优秀。我很不高兴。我现在不高兴。一切都是如此悲伤。

‘But better days will come. Your husband will be rightly valued. And he depends on you for comfort. He loves you best. The worst loss would be to lose that—and you have not lost it,’ said Dorothea.
‘但更好的日子将会到来。你的丈夫会受到正确的重视。他依赖你来寻求安慰。他最爱你。最糟糕的损失就是失去它——而你并没有失去它，”多萝西娅说。

She tried to thrust away the too overpowering thought of her own relief, lest she should fail to win some sign that Rosamond’s affection was yearning back towards her husband.
她试图抛开过于强烈的自我解脱的想法，以免她无法赢得一些迹象，表明罗莎蒙德对她丈夫的感情正在渴望回归。

‘Tertius did not find fault with me, then?’ said Rosamond, understanding now that Lydgate might have said anything to Mrs. Casaubon, and that she certainly was different from other women. Perhaps there was a faint taste of jealousy in the question. A smile began to play over Dorothea’s face as she said—
“那么，特蒂乌斯没有对我挑剔吗？”罗莎蒙德说道，她现在明白了利德盖特可能对卡苏朋夫人说了些什么，而且她肯定与其他女人不同。也许这个问题里带着一丝嫉妒的味道。多萝西娅的脸上开始露出微笑，她说道：

‘No, indeed! How could you imagine it?’ But here the door opened, and Lydgate entered.
‘不，确实如此！你怎么能想象呢？”但是门开了，利德盖特走了进来。

‘I am come back in my quality of doctor,’ he said. ‘After I went away, I was haunted by two pale faces: Mrs. Casaubon looked as much in need of care as you, Rosy. And I thought that I had not done my duty in leaving you together; so when I had been to Coleman’s I came home again. I noticed that you were walking, Mrs. Casaubon, and the sky has changed—I think we may have rain. May I send some one to order your carriage to come for you?’
“我又恢复了医生的品质，”他说。 “我走后，两张苍白的脸一直困扰着我：卡苏邦夫人看起来和你一样需要照顾，罗西。我认为我没有尽到让你们在一起的义务；所以当我去过科尔曼家后，我又回到了家。我注意到你在走路，卡苏朋夫人，天空变了——我想我们可能会下雨。我可以派人叫马车来接你吗？

‘Oh, no! I am strong: I need the walk,’ said Dorothea, rising with animation in her face. ‘Mrs. Lydgate and I have chatted a great deal, and it is time for me to go. I have always been accused of being immoderate and saying too much.’
'不好了！我很坚强：我需要散步。”多萝西娅站起来，脸上充满活力。 '太太。利德盖特和我聊了很多，我该走了。我一直被指责为不节制、说得太多。”

She put out her hand to Rosamond, and they said an earnest, quiet good-by without kiss or other show of effusion: there had been between them too much serious emotion for them to use the signs of it superficially.
她向罗莎蒙德伸出手，他们真诚、安静地道别，没有亲吻或其他流露的表情：他们之间有太多严肃的情感，不能肤浅地使用它的迹象。

As Lydgate took her to the door she said nothing of Rosamond, but told him of Mr. Farebrother and the other friends who had listened with belief to his story.
当利德盖特带她到门口时，她没有提及罗莎蒙德，只是告诉他费雷布拉泽先生和其他朋友，他们都相信他的故事。

When he came back to Rosamond, she had already thrown herself on the sofa, in resigned fatigue.
当他回到罗莎蒙德身边时，她已经一屁股坐在沙发上，疲惫不堪。

‘Well, Rosy,’ he said, standing over her, and touching her hair, ‘what do you think of Mrs. Casaubon now you have seen so much of her?’
“好吧，罗西，”他站在她身旁，抚摸着她的头发，“既然你已经经常见到卡苏朋夫人了，你觉得她怎么样？”

‘I think she must be better than any one,’ said Rosamond, ‘and she is very beautiful. If you go to talk to her so often, you will be more discontented with me than ever!’
“我想她一定比任何人都优秀，”罗莎蒙德说，“而且她非常漂亮。”你要是经常去找她说话，你会对我更加不满！

Lydgate laughed at the ‘so often.’ ‘But has she made you any less discontented with me?’
利德盖特嘲笑“经常”。“但是她让你对我的不满减轻了吗？”

‘I think she has,’ said Rosamond, looking up in his face. ‘How heavy your eyes are, Tertius—and do push your hair back.’ He lifted up his large white hand to obey her, and felt thankful for this little mark of interest in him. Poor Rosamond’s vagrant fancy had come back terribly scourged—meek enough to nestle under the old despised shelter. And the shelter was still there: Lydgate had accepted his narrowed lot with sad resignation. He had chosen this fragile creature, and had taken the burthen of her life upon his arms. He must walk as he could, carrying that burthen pitifully.
“我想她做到了，”罗莎蒙德抬头看着他的脸说道。 “你的眼睛好重啊，特提乌斯——把你的头发向后梳。”他举起白皙的大手服从她，并为自己对他的这一点兴趣而感到感激。可怜的罗莎蒙德的流浪幻想回来后受到了严重的打击——温顺地依偎在旧的被鄙视的庇护所下。避难所仍然在那里：利德盖特悲伤地接受了他狭窄的命运。他选择了这个脆弱的生物，并用双臂承担了她的生命重担。他必须尽其所能地行走，可怜地背负着这个重担。

CHAPTER LXXXII
第LXXXII章

‘My grief lies onward and my joy behind.’
“我的悲伤在前方，我的欢乐在后方。”

—SHAKESPEARE: Sonnets.
——莎士比亚：十四行诗。

Exiles notoriously feed much on hopes, and are unlikely to stay in banishment unless they are obliged. When Will Ladislaw exiled himself from Middlemarch he had placed no stronger obstacle to his return than his own resolve, which was by no means an iron barrier, but simply a state of mind liable to melt into a minuet with other states of mind, and to find itself bowing, smiling, and giving place with polite facility.
